The Sages discussed what occurred that caused her husband to become so angry with her that she left him, and <b>Rabbi Evyatar says: He found her</b> responsible for <b>a fly</b> in the food that she prepared for him, while <b>Rabbi Yonatan says: He found her</b> responsible for <b>a hair [<i>nima</i>].</b>
<b>And Rabbi Evyatar found Elijah</b> the prophet and <b>said to him: What is the Holy One, Blessed be He, doing</b> now? Elijah <b>said to him: He is</b> currently <b>engaged in</b> studying the episode of <b>the concubine in Gibeah.</b> Rabbi Evyatar asked him: <b>And what is He saying</b> about it? Elijah <b>said to him</b> that God is saying the following: <b>Evyatar, My son, says this</b> and <b>Yonatan, My son, says that.</b> It is seen here that God saw fit to cite the statement of Rabbi Evyatar.
Rabbi Evyatar <b>said to him: God forbid, is there uncertainty before Heaven?</b> Doesn’t God know what happened? Why does He mention both opinions? Elijah <b>said to him:</b> Both <b>these and those are the words of the living God,</b> i.e., both incidents happened. The incident occurred in the following manner: <b>He found a fly</b> in his food <b>and did not take umbrage,</b> and later <b>he found a hair and took umbrage.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> a different explanation: The man found <b>a fly in the dish</b> that she cooked for him, <b>and</b> he found <b>a hair in that place,</b> i.e., in her genital area. When he found <b>a fly</b> it produced a reaction of <b>disgust,</b> and he did not grow angry with her, <b>but</b> the <b>hair</b> was a matter of <b>danger,</b> as he might be hurt by it, and therefore he became angry with her. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say: This and that</b> were found <b>in a dish.</b> The difference is that the <b>fly</b> was a result of <b>circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control,</b> as it fell into the dish on its own, <b>but the hair</b> was found in the dish due to her <b>negligence.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda says: A person should never impose excessive fear upon</b> the members of <b>his household, as the husband of the concubine of Gibeah imposed excessive fear upon her and</b> this ultimately <b>caused the downfall of many tens of thousands of Jews</b> in the resulting war (see Judges 19–20).
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: Anyone who imposes excessive fear upon</b> the members of <b>his household</b> will <b>ultimately come to</b> commit <b>three sins: Engaging in forbidden sexual intercourse,</b> as the wife will be so fearful of her husband that she will sometimes tell him that she has immersed in a ritual bath after her menstruation has ended when she has not done so; <b>and</b> he will also end up committing <b>bloodshed,</b> as she is likely to run away from him and expose herself to dangers; <b>and desecration of Shabbat,</b> as she will cook for him on Shabbat because she is scared that he will be angry with her for neglecting to do so beforehand.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> a <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> statement <b>that the Sages said:</b> There are <b>three matters a person must say in his home on Shabbat eve at nightfall.</b> He should ask the members of his household: <b>Have you tithed</b> the produce that required tithing? <b>Have you placed the <i>eiruv</i></b> for joining the courtyards? If you have already done so, <b>light the lamp</b> in honor of Shabbat. Rabba bar bar Ḥana said that one <b>must</b>

Daf 7a

<b>say them with calmness so that they will accept</b> instruction <b>from him. Rav Ashi said: I did not hear this</b> statement <b>of Rabba bar bar Ḥana, and</b> yet <b>I fulfilled it through</b> my own <b>reasoning.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu says: A person should never impose excessive fear upon</b> the members of <b>his household, as a great man imposed excessive fear upon his household and they fed him something</b> that carried <b>a great</b> prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>And who was</b> this individual? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Would it enter your mind</b> to say that <b>they</b> actually <b>fed him</b> forbidden food? <b>Now</b> consider that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not cause an error</b> to be performed <b>through the animals of the righteous.</b> With regard to <b>the righteous themselves</b> is it <b>not all the more so?</b> How can you say that Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel ate forbidden food?
<b>Rather,</b> it means that <b>they sought to feed him something</b> that carried <b>a great</b> prohibition. <b>And what was this? A limb from a living</b> animal. One day the animal they brought him was missing a limb, and as the members of his household were very fearful they severed a limb from a living animal to make his meal appear whole, and he almost ate it.
§ After mentioning letters sent from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia and the issue of scoring parchment, the Gemara relates: <b>Mar Ukva,</b> the Exilarch in Babylonia, <b>sent</b> a letter <b>to Rabbi Elazar,</b> who was in Eretz Yisrael, in which the following was written: With regard to <b>people who stand over</b> and torment <b>me, and I have the power to deliver them into</b> the hands of <b>the government, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May I hand them over to the authorities or not?
Rabbi Elazar <b>scored</b> parchment <b>and wrote to him</b> the following verse: <b>“I said: I will take heed to my ways, that I do not sin with my tongue; I will keep a curb upon my mouth, while the wicked is before me”</b> (Psalms 39:2). Rabbi Elazar quoted this verse to allude to the following response: <b>Even though “the wicked is before me,” “I will keep a curb upon my mouth.”</b>
Mar Ukva <b>sent</b> word to <b>him</b> again: <b>They are tormenting me a great deal and I cannot stand them.</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>sent to him</b> in response: <b>“Resign yourself to the Lord, and wait patiently [<i>hitḥolel</i>] for Him;</b> do not fret yourself because of he who prospers in his way, because of the man who brings wicked devices to pass” (Psalms 37:7). This verse indicates: <b>“Resign yourself to the Lord,”</b> i.e., do not do anything, <b>and He will strike them down as many corpses [<i>ḥalalim</i>]. Rise before and stay later than them</b> in your visits <b>to the study hall, and they will disappear on their own.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>The matter emerged from the mouth of Rabbi Elazar, and Geneiva,</b> Mar Ukva’s tormentor, <b>was placed in a neck iron [<i>kolar</i>],</b> as one sentenced by the government.
The Gemara further relates: <b>They sent</b> the following question <b>to Mar Ukva: From where do we</b> derive that <b>song is forbidden</b> in the present, following the destruction of the Temple? <b>He scored</b> parchment <b>and wrote to them: “Rejoice not, O Israel, to exultation, like the peoples”</b> (Hosea 9:1).
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him send them</b> a response <b>from here: “They do not drink wine with a song; strong drink is bitter to them who drink it”</b> (Isaiah 24:9), indicating that song is no longer allowed. The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> he had answered <b>by</b> citing <b>that</b> verse, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this matter</b> applies only to <b>instrumental music,</b> in accordance with the previous verse: “The mirth of tabrets ceases, the noise of them who rejoice ends, the joy of the harp ceases” (Isaiah 24:8); <b>however, vocal</b> song is <b>permitted.</b> Therefore, Mar Ukva <b>teaches us</b> that all types of song are forbidden.
In connection to the incident in which Mar Ukva was instructed not to take revenge against his tormentors, the Gemara relates similar discussions. <b>Rav Huna bar Natan said to Rav Ashi: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Kina, and Dimonah, and Adadah”</b> (Joshua 15:22)? <b>He said to him:</b> The verse <b>is listing the cities of Eretz Yisrael.</b>
Rav Huna <b>said to him: Is that to say</b> that you think <b>I don’t know that</b> the verse <b>is listing the cities of Eretz Yisrael?</b> This is certainly the straightforward meaning of the verse. <b>Rather, Rav Geviha from Argiza said an explanation of</b> this verse, suggesting that it is an allusion to the following idea: <b>Anyone who harbors jealousy [<i>kina</i>] toward another, and</b> yet remains <b>silent [<i>domem</i>], He who dwells for all eternity [<i>adei ad</i>] performs judgment on his behalf.</b>
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: If that is so,</b> you should <b>also</b> expound the verse: <b>“Ziklag, and Madmannah, and Sansannah”</b> (Joshua 15:31), in a similar manner. Rav Huna <b>said to him: If Rav Geviha from Bei Argiza was here, he would say an explanation for it.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Aḥa from Bei Ḥoza’a said this about that</b> verse: <b>Anyone who has a complaint against another over a sip [<i>tza’akat legima</i>],</b> i.e., he has a claim that someone did not give him food, <b>and</b> remains <b>silent [<i>domem</i>], the One who dwells in the</b> burning <b>bush [<i>seneh</i>] performs judgment on his behalf.</b>
<b>The Exilarch said to Rav Huna: From where do we</b> derive that it is <b>prohibited</b> to place <b>a garland</b> on a groom’s head? Rav Huna <b>said to him:</b> It is prohibited <b>by rabbinic law, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Sota</i> 49a): <b>In the war [<i>pulmus</i>] of Vespasian they decreed upon the garlands of bridegrooms,</b> meaning that bridegrooms may no longer wear garlands, <b>and</b> they decreed <b>upon the drum [<i>irus</i>],</b> meaning they also banned the playing of drums.
<b>In the meantime Rav Huna stood to relieve himself,</b> and after he left, <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> who had not spoken up to that point out of reverence for his teacher, Rav Huna, <b>said to</b> the Exilarch: <b>A verse is written</b> with regard to this matter: <b>“Thus says the Lord God: The mitre shall be removed, and the garland taken off; this shall no more be the same; that which is low shall be exalted, and that which is high abased”</b> (Ezekiel 21:31).
<b>But in what way is a mitre connected to a garland?</b> These two are not placed on the head of the same type of person. <b>Rather,</b> this verse serves <b>to say to you: When the mitre is</b> found <b>on the head of the High Priest,</b> i.e., when the Temple is standing, then <b>a garland</b> may be found <b>on the head of every man</b> at his wedding. However, once <b>the mitre is removed from the head of the High Priest, the garland is removed from the head of every man.</b>
<b>In the meantime, Rav Huna came</b> back and <b>he found them sitting</b> and discussing this matter. <b>He said to</b> Rav Ḥisda in the form of an oath: <b>By God!</b> This prohibition applies <b>by rabbinic law. However, your name is Ḥisda and your words find favor [<i>ḥisda’in</i>],</b> as you have discovered a fine source for this <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara relates: <b>Ravina found Mar bar Rav Ashi braiding a garland for his daughter</b> upon her marriage. <b>He said to him: Doesn’t the Master hold</b> in accordance with the aforementioned <i>halakha</i> derived from the verse: <b>“The mitre shall be removed and the garland taken off”? He said to him:</b> This prohibition was stated in reference to one who is <b>similar to a High Priest,</b> and is only applicable <b>with regard to men. However, with regard to women,</b> the Sages did <b>not</b> issue this decree.
With regard to the above verse, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the expression: <b>“This shall no more be the same”? Rabbi Avira interpreted</b> this verse <b>homiletically. Sometimes he would say it in the name of Rav Ami, and sometimes he would say it in the name of Rav Asi: When the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the Jewish people</b> at the time of the destruction of the Temple: <b>“Remove the mitre and take off the garland,” the ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe,</b> is <b>this</b> the appropriate treatment <b>for the Jewish people, who,</b> at the giving of the Torah <b>at Sinai, preceded</b> the statement of: <b>“We will do” to</b> the statement: <b>“We will hear”</b> (Exodus 22:7)?
God <b>said to them:</b> Is <b>this not</b> appropriate <b>for the Jewish people, who lowered the exalted and who exalted the lowly,</b> i.e., they did not serve God, <b>and</b> instead worshiped idols when <b>they established an idol in the Sanctuary?</b> This response is alluded to in the verse: “This shall no more be the same.”
The Gemara cites another statement by the same Sages. <b>Rav Avira interpreted</b> a verse <b>homiletically. Sometimes he would say it in the name of Rav Ami, and sometimes he would say it in the name of Rav Asi: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Thus says the Lord: Though they be in full strength [<i>shelemim</i>], and likewise many, even so shall they be cut down, and he shall pass away;</b> and though I have afflicted you, I will afflict you no more” (Nahum 1:12). This means: <b>If a person sees that his sustenance is limited he should use it for charity, and all the more so when it is plentiful.</b> In other words, if his livelihood has finished [<i>nishlam</i>] he should perform charity, and he should certainly act in this manner if his means are plentiful.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>“Even so shall they be cut down [<i>nagozzu</i>], and he shall pass away”?</b> A Sage from <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Anyone who shears off [<i>gozez</i>]</b> some <b>of his property and performs charity with it will be saved from the judgment of Gehenna.</b> The Gemara offers <b>a parable</b> that compares this case <b>to two sheep that were passing through the water. One</b> of them was <b>shorn and</b> the other <b>one</b> was <b>unshorn.</b> The <b>shorn</b> sheep <b>crossed</b> to the other side, <b>but the unshorn</b> sheep <b>did not cross,</b> as its wool absorbed the water and it drowned. Similarly, one who shears off his property and gives it as charity will not descend to Gehenna.

Daf 7b

The Gemara addresses the continuation of the verse: <b>“And though I have afflicted you [<i>ve’innitikh</i>]”</b> (Nahum 1:12). <b>Mar Zutra says:</b> This means that <b>even a poor person [<i>ani</i>] who is sustained from charity</b> must also <b>perform charity.</b> With regard to the expression: <b>“And I will afflict you [<i>a’anekh</i>] no more,” Rav Yosef teaches:</b> This means that if he gives charity to others, God <b>will no longer show him signs of poverty [<i>aniyyut</i>].</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: From Rekem and eastward</b> is considered to be a country overseas, from Akko and northward is also outside of Eretz Yisrael, and Akko itself is like north of Eretz Yisrael. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that Akko is located to</b> the <b>north of Eretz Yisrael? And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Oholot</i> 18:14) that indicates that Akko is not on the northern border of Eretz Yisrael: If one <b>was traveling from Akko to Keziv,</b> the area <b>on his right, to the east of the road,</b> is <b>impure due to</b> the impurity of <b>the land of the nations, and</b> that area <b>is exempt from the</b> obligation to separate <b>tithe</b> from its produce <b>and from</b> the mitzvot of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year, as it is assumed to be outside of Eretz Yisrael, <b>until</b> he arrives at a place <b>where it is known to you that it is obligated.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Conversely, the territory <b>on his left, to the west of the road,</b> is <b>pure with regard to</b> the impurity of <b>the land of the nations,</b> as it is assumed to be within Eretz Yisrael, <b>and obligated in the</b> mitzva to separate <b>tithe</b> from its produce <b>and in</b> the mitzvot of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>until</b> he arrives at a place <b>where it is known to you that it is exempt. Until where</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply? <b>Until Keziv. Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said in the name of his father: Until</b> the place known as <b>Lavlevu.</b> In any case, this indicates that Akko is not considered the northern border of Eretz Yisrael, as the description in the <i>baraita</i> indicates that Keziv is further north than Akko.
<b>Abaye said: A strip extends</b> northward from Akko, which is still considered part of Eretz Yisrael, but the general border is at the latitude of Akko. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> would the <b><i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>provide a sign</b> in <b>this</b> manner for an area of a strip of land? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> and <b>a verse also provides a sign</b> in this manner, <b>as it is written: “And they said: Behold, there is the feast of the Lord from year to year in Shiloh, which is on the north of Bethel, on the east side of the highway that goes up from Bethel to Shechem, and on the south of Lebonah”</b> (Judges 21:19). <b>And Rav Pappa said:</b> The expression: “On the east side,” should be understood as meaning <b>to the east of the highway.</b> This verse demonstrates that an area as narrow as a road can be used as a sign.
§ The Gemara presents a contradiction between two <i>baraitot</i>. <b>It was taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who brings a bill of divorce</b> that was written <b>on a boat</b> in Eretz Yisrael is considered to be <b>like one who brings</b> it <b>in Eretz Yisrael,</b> and therefore he is not required to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence. <b>And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 1:1) that one who brings a bill of divorce written on a boat in Eretz Yisrael is <b>like one who brings</b> a bill of divorce <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as one can say that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥalla</i> 2:2): With regard to <b>soil from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>that is brought on a boat to Eretz</b> Yisrael, anything that grew in that soil <b>is obligated in tithe and in</b> the mitzvot of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year. According to this opinion, soil is considered part of Eretz Yisrael once it arrives there, which means that the plants growing in it are considered to be in Eretz Yisrael.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> did the Sages say this ruling? <b>When the boat is skimming [<i>gosheshet</i>]</b> the sea floor, as it is weighed down in the water. <b>However,</b> when <b>the boat is not skimming</b> the sea floor, the soil is <b>exempt.</b> The Sage who maintains that the boat is considered to be like Eretz Yisrael with regard to a bill of divorce holds in accordance with the Rabbis of this mishna, and the one who maintains that the boat is not like Eretz Yisrael for the purposes of a bill of divorce holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>Abaye said:</b> It is possible to say that both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> it is <b>not difficult: Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> where the soil is considered outside of Eretz Yisrael, deals with a situation <b>when the boat is not skimming</b> the sea floor; and <b>there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that states that the soil is considered to be like Eretz Yisrael, it is referring to a case <b>when the boat is skimming</b> the sea floor.
<b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> In the case of <b>a perforated pot that is resting on pegs,</b> if something grew in it, <b>we have arrived at the dispute</b> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis</b> concerning the soil on the boat. Just as the Rabbis maintain that the soil is considered attached to Eretz Yisrael even if the boat does not actually touch the sea floor, the same applies to a perforated flowerpot on pegs, whereas Rabbi Yehuda holds that in both cases the soil must actually be in contact with the earth for it to be considered part of Eretz Yisrael.
<b>Rava said,</b> in rejection of this claim: <b>Perhaps</b> that <b>is not so,</b> as <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> his opinion <b>only there, with regard to a boat,</b>

Daf 8a

<b>which is made to move,</b> i.e., it is not set in one place. Consequently, one can argue that the soil in the boat is not considered attached to the ground. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a flowerpot, which is not made to move,</b> as ordinarily a flowerpot remains in one place, <b>no,</b> one cannot reasonably claim that the fixed soil in it is not part of the ground, even when the pot itself is not touching the ground.
<b>Alternatively,</b> one can say the opposite: Perhaps <b>the Rabbis state</b> their opinion, that the soil in the boat is considered to be like the land itself, <b>only there, in</b> the case of <b>a boat, where there is no barrier of airspace</b> between the soil in the boat and the land below, <b>as water is considered to be like solid earth.</b> Therefore, the soil in the boat is viewed as connected to the earth, and has the status of Eretz Yisrael. <b>But</b> in the case of a perforated <b>pot, where there is a barrier of airspace, no,</b> the soil is not connected to the ground.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: With regard to</b> the <b>rivers that are in Eretz Yisrael</b> on which a boat is sailing, <b>everyone agrees</b> that a bill of divorce written on that boat is considered to be written in Eretz Yisrael. <b>However, when they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to the Great Sea,</b> i.e., the Mediterranean Sea. In other words, is a boat located in the Mediterranean Sea considered to be in Eretz Yisrael or not?
<b>As it is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Terumot</i> 2:12): <b>What is Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and what is outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael? <b>Any</b> slope <b>that descends at an angle from Turei Amnon</b> in Syria <b>and inward</b> toward Eretz Yisrael is part of <b>Eretz Yisrael. From Turei Amnon and outward,</b> northward, is considered <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. With regard to <b>the islands [<i>nissin</i>] that are in the sea, one views them as though a string were pulled taut over them from Turei Amnon</b> in the north <b>to the River of Egypt,</b> Wadi el-Arish, in the south. <b>From the string and inward,</b> i.e., east, is <b>Eretz Yisrael; from the string and outward,</b> west, is considered <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. This is the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Any</b> place <b>that</b> is directly <b>across from Eretz Yisrael,</b> including the sea itself, <b>is considered</b> part <b>of Eretz Yisrael, as it is stated: “And for the western border, you shall have the Great Sea for a border, this shall be your west border”</b> (Numbers 34:6). According to this opinion, the entire territory directly across from Eretz Yisrael is considered part of Eretz Yisrael.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>the islands that are on the sides,</b> which do not exactly line up on the north or the south, <b>one views them as though a string were pulled taut over them</b> in the north <b>from Kefalorya,</b> west of Turei Amnon, <b>to the Atlantic Ocean, and</b> in the south <b>from the River of Egypt</b> westward <b>until the Atlantic Ocean.</b> Those islands that lie <b>from the string and inward</b> are part of <b>Eretz Yisrael,</b> whereas those <b>from the string and outward</b> are <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis, what do they do with this</b> verse: <b>“And for the border”?</b> Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion that the border of Eretz Yisrael extends into the sea is apparently supported by this verse. The Gemara answers: <b>They require it to</b> teach that the <b>islands</b> themselves are considered to be within Eretz Yisrael. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> would respond that an additional <b>verse is not required</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i> concerning the <b>islands,</b> as it is clear that they are part of Eretz Yisrael.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Meir says: Akko is like Eretz Yisrael</b> with regard to bills of divorce. The Sages <b>raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: One who sells his slave to</b> a master in <b>Syria,</b> is <b>he considered like one who sells</b> his slave <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, in which case the seller is penalized by the emancipation of his slave, <b>or not?</b>
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <b>said to them: You learned</b> a resolution for this dilemma from the mishna: <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that <b>Akko</b> is <b>like Eretz Yisrael with regard to bills of divorce,</b> from which it may be inferred: <b>With regard to bills of divorce, yes,</b> but <b>with regard to slaves, no,</b> it is not considered part of Eretz Yisrael, <b>and all the more so Syria, which is far more distant</b> than Akko from the main areas of Eretz Yisrael. Therefore, this owner has sold his slave outside of Eretz Yisrael.
Having mentioned the status of Syria, the Gemara cites a related <i>halakha</i>. <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Kelim</i> 1:5): <b>In three ways Syria is equal to Eretz Yisrael, and in three</b> ways it is similar <b>to outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. The Gemara inserts <b>a mnemonic</b> device for the ways in which Syria is different than Eretz Yisrael and is similar to Eretz Yisrael: <b><i>Ayin beit</i>, <i>beit reish</i>, <i>reish kuf</i>.</b> Syria has the status of land that is outside of Eretz Yisrael in the following respects: First, <b>its soil is ritually impure like</b> that of land <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. <b>And</b> the second is that <b>one who sells his slave to</b> a master in <b>Syria is like one who sells</b> him to a master <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, and the second master is obligated to emancipate the slave. <b>And</b> third, <b>one who brings a bill of divorce from Syria is like one who brings</b> it <b>from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, in that he must say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence.
<b>And in three</b> ways Syria is similar <b>to Eretz Yisrael:</b> Its produce is <b>obligated in tithe and in</b> the mitzvot of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>like Eretz Yisrael. And one who wishes to enter it</b> while remaining <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity may</b> so <b>enter,</b> as though it were part of Eretz Yisrael. <b>And one who acquires a field in Syria</b>

Daf 8b

<b>is like one who purchases</b> a field <b>in the outskirts [<i>parvarei</i>] of Jerusalem.</b> The Gemara clarifies: The <i>tanna</i> who says Syria is <b>obligated in tithe and</b> the mitzvot of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>like Eretz Yisrael holds</b> that the <b>conquest of an individual is called a conquest.</b> Once Syria was conquered by King David, who is considered an individual in this regard, the sanctity of Eretz Yisrael applied to it and its residents became obligated in the mitzvot of Eretz Yisrael.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>And one who wishes to enter it</b> and remain <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual purity may</b> so <b>enter.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say</b> that <b>its soil is ritually impure?</b> How then is it possible for one to enter it in a state of ritual purity? The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> means that one enters it <b>in a chest, a box, or a cabinet.</b> In this case he remains pure, as he did not come into contact with the ground itself.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who enters the land of the nations,</b> i.e., any territory outside of Eretz Yisrael, <b>in a chest, a box, or a cabinet, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> him ritually <b>impure,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, deems</b> him <b>pure. And even Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> one who did not touch the ground itself <b>impure only in the land of the nations,</b> concerning <b>which they decreed</b> impurity <b>upon</b> both <b>its clumps</b> of soil <b>and upon its air. However,</b> with regard to <b>Syria,</b> everyone agrees that <b>they decreed</b> impurity <b>upon its clumps</b> of soil, but <b>they did not decree</b> impurity <b>upon its air.</b> Therefore, it is possible to enter Syria and remain in a state of ritual purity if one does not touch the ground itself.
The <i>baraita</i> further teaches: <b>And one who purchases a field in Syria is like one who purchases</b> a field <b>in the outskirts of Jerusalem.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard <b>to which <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? What practical ruling is taught by this statement? <b>Rav Sheshet says:</b> This serves <b>to say that one writes a bill of sale [<i>ono</i>] for this</b> purchase, <b>and</b> one may write a bill of sale <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara asks: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that one may write this bill of sale <b>on Shabbat?</b> Writing on Shabbat is a prohibited labor for which one is liable to receive court-imposed capital punishment. The Gemara explains: This is <b>as Rava says</b> with regard to a similar issue, that <b>one tells a gentile</b> that he should do it, <b>and he does</b> so. <b>Here too,</b> it is referring to a situation where <b>one tells a gentile</b> that he should write a bill of sale, <b>and he does</b> so. <b>And even though</b> the <i>halakha</i> generally is <b>that telling a gentile</b> to perform an action that is prohibited for a Jew on Shabbat violates <b>a rabbinic decree,</b> since the Sages prohibited instructing a gentile to perform prohibited labor on behalf of a Jew on Shabbat, here <b>the Sages did not</b> impose this <b>decree, due to</b> the mitzva of <b>settling Eretz Yisrael.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>a slave who brought his bill</b> of manumission to a court, <b>and it is written in it: You and my property are transferred to you, he acquires himself</b> via this document, and he is emancipated. However, <b>he does not acquire</b> the <b>property</b> unless the document is confirmed in court through its witnesses, like other documents.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If the bill of manumission stated: <b>All of my property is transferred to you, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Abaye said: Since he acquired himself</b> as a freeman, as he is included in the property mentioned in the document, <b>he acquires</b> the rest of the <b>property</b> as well.
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: <b>Granted, he should acquire himself, just as it is in</b> the case of <b>a bill of divorce</b> of <b>a woman,</b> who is divorced when she brings the document herself. <b>However, he should not acquire</b> the <b>property, just as it is in</b> the case of the <b>ratification of typical</b> legal <b>documents.</b> If someone brings a typical document that deals with monetary matters that has not been ratified, the court will not rely on that document. So too here, as the bill of manumission, which includes a transfer of property, has not been ratified, he should not acquire the property.
After hearing Rava’s objection, <b>Abaye then said</b> the opposite: <b>Since he did not acquire the property, he does not acquire himself</b> either. <b>Rava said to him: Granted, he does not acquire the property, just as it is in</b> the case of the <b>ratification of typical</b> legal <b>documents; however, he should acquire himself, just as it is in</b> the case of <b>a bill of divorce</b> of <b>a woman,</b> who can bring her own bill of divorce and testify about it.
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>both this and that,</b> both in the case when the bill of manumission states: You and my property, and when it says: All of my property, <b>he acquires himself</b> but <b>he does not acquire</b> the <b>property. Rav Adda bar Mattana said to Rava: In accordance with whose</b> opinion do you say this? <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that <b>we divide the statement.</b> In other words, even if there is only one document or a single testimony, containing one general statement, it can be divided so that the court accepts it in part and rejects the rest.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 3:8): <b>One who writes,</b> i.e., gives via a document, <b>all of his property to his slave,</b> the slave <b>has been emancipated,</b> but if he <b>reserved</b> for himself even <b>any amount of land,</b> then he <b>has not been emancipated,</b> as perhaps he reserved the slave for himself as well. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b>

Daf 9a

<b>He always</b> becomes <b>a freeman</b> regardless of the wording of the document, even if the owner reserved land for himself, <b>unless it says</b> in the document: <b>All of my property is given to so-and-so my slave, except for one ten-thousandth of it,</b> as in that case it is possible that the master meant to include the slave in the portion that he is not giving. Consequently, the slave is not emancipated. In any case, according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, when the document states: All my property, a distinction is drawn between the emancipated slave and the property, as claimed by Rava.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Yosef bar Minyumi say</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: Even though Rabbi Yosei praised</b> the ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> with regard to this issue, <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> the first <i>tanna</i> in that mishna. The Gemara elaborates how Rabbi Yosei bestowed praise. <b>As it is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Pe’a</i> 1:13): <b>When</b> these <b>matters were said</b> by the Sages <b>before Rabbi Yosei, he recited this verse about him: “He kisses the lips that give the right answer”</b> (Proverbs 24:26). Despite this praise, the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
With regard to Rav Adda bar Mattana’s proof, the Gemara asks: <b>And did Rav Naḥman</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that we do not divide the statement? <b>But didn’t Rav Yosef bar Minyumi say</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> With regard to a person <b>on his deathbed who wrote all</b> of <b>his property to his slave,</b> and afterward he recuperated <b>and arose</b> from his illness, <b>he can retract</b> his transfer of property <b>with regard to</b> the gift of <b>the property</b> to the slave, <b>but he cannot retract</b> his transfer <b>with regard to</b> the emancipation of <b>the slave.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>He can retract</b> the transfer of <b>the property,</b> as <b>it is the gift</b> of a person <b>on his deathbed.</b> By rabbinic decree, no formal act of acquisition is required for a gift of this kind, as it was given based on the assumption that the owner is about to die. If he does survive, the gift is canceled. <b>But he cannot retract</b> the transfer <b>with regard to</b> the emancipation of <b>the slave, as it has been publicized about</b> the slave that he has the <b>status</b> of <b>a freeman.</b> This shows that Rav Naḥman accepts the principle that we divide the statement, as one portion of this document is accepted while the other part is rejected.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: There,</b> where Rav Naḥman ruled in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, he did not do so because he holds that we do not divide the statement, as this is not the issue in dispute. Instead, <b>this is the reason: Because it is not a document that</b> fully <b>severs</b> the ownership of the slave. A bill of manumission must fully sever the bond between slave and master. Since the master left over some property, which may include the slave, for himself, the bill of manumission does not fully sever their relationship. However, with regard to the basic issue of whether or not we divide a single statement, Rav Naḥman agrees with Rava that we do divide a statement.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>if there are those who contest</b> a bill of divorce that was brought within Eretz Yisrael, where it is not necessary to state the declaration: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, <b>it should be ratified through its signatories.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How many</b> people raise this <b>contestation? If we say</b> that this <b>contestation</b> is by <b>one</b> person, who claims that the bill of divorce is a forgery, <b>but didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Everyone agrees</b> that <b>a contestation</b> to a document may be brought by <b>no fewer than two</b> people?
<b>But</b> rather, you will say that the <b>contestation</b> involves <b>two</b> people claiming that the bill of divorce is a forgery, who are subsequently countered by two others who ratify it. If so, <b>they are two and two. What did you see that you relied on these</b> witnesses? <b>Rely</b> instead <b>on these.</b> Why does the court accept the testimony of the witnesses who ratify the bill of divorce rather than those who contest its validity? The Gemara therefore concludes that this is referring to a case in which one person contests, <b>however,</b> the <b>contestation</b> is raised <b>by</b> the <b>husband</b> himself, who claims that the bill of divorce is a forgery.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who brings a bill of divorce from a country overseas and is unable to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, if</b> the bill of divorce <b>has witnesses</b> signed <b>on it, it should be ratified through its signatories.</b> The witnesses themselves or someone who recognizes their signatures should ratify it, in the manner of typical documents.
<b>Both bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission are the same with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>delivering</b> the document from Eretz Yisrael to a country overseas <b>and with regard to bringing</b> it from a country overseas to Eretz Yisrael, i.e., the agents for both types of documents must declare that it was written and signed in their presence, and their statement is accepted. <b>And this is one of the ways in which</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>bills of divorce are equal to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of bills <b>of manumission.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the statement: <b>He is unable to say? If we say</b> that this is referring to <b>a deaf-mute, is a deaf-mute fit to bring a bill of divorce? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (23a): <b>Anyone is fit</b> to serve as an agent <b>to bring a bill of divorce</b> to a woman <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> all of whom may not be appointed as agents at all, as they are not intellectually competent according to <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Rav Yosef said: With what are we dealing here?</b> This is a case <b>where</b> the agent <b>gave</b> the bill of divorce <b>to her when he was</b> halakhically <b>competent, but he did not manage to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, before he became a deaf-mute.</b> In other words, although at the time he was appointed he was fit to be appointed as an agent, he is currently unable to say anything.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>both bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission</b> are the same in that the agent who brings them is required to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence. <b>The Sages taught: In three ways</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>bills of divorce are equal to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of bills of <b>manumission: They are equal with regard to one who delivers and one who brings,</b> i.e., if one takes a bill of divorce or a bill of manumission to a country overseas from Eretz Yisrael, or if he brings it from there, he is required to testify that it was written and signed in his presence. <b>And any document that has a Samaritan witness</b> signed <b>on it is invalid, except for bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission,</b> as Samaritan witnesses are permitted to serve as witnesses for these documents. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all documents</b>

Daf 9b

<b>that are produced in gentile courts [<i>arkaot</i>], even though their signatories</b> are <b>gentiles,</b> they are <b>valid, except for bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission.</b> These documents are not valid when prepared by gentiles. <b>And according to the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> bills of divorce and manumission are equal <b>in four</b> ways, the three aforementioned <i>halakhot</i> and also with regard to a man <b>who says: Give this bill of divorce to my wife, or:</b> Give <b>this bill of manumission to my slave.</b> They are equal in that if he <b>desires to retract</b> his instruction <b>with regard to both of these</b> documents, before they have reached the woman or slave, <b>he can retract.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> they state <b>the number</b> three <b>to exclude this</b> opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir,</b> by emphasizing that there are only three ways, not four. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, what</b> does <b>the number</b> four serve <b>to exclude?</b> Wouldn’t it have been enough to say that Rabbi Meir adds another case?
The Gemara answers: The Sages mention this number <b>to exclude that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>witnesses who do not know</b> how <b>to sign,</b> i.e., they do not know how to write their names, <b>one tears blank paper for them,</b> meaning that a stencil of their names is fashioned from blank paper and placed on the bill of divorce. <b>And</b> the witnesses <b>fill in the gaps</b> with <b>ink</b> so that their names appear on the document.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to bills of divorce. However,</b> with regard to bills of <b>manumission and all other documents, if</b> the witnesses <b>know</b> how <b>to read and sign, they sign, and if not, they do not sign.</b> Rabbi Meir agrees with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel that bills of divorce and bills of manumission are different with regard to this issue, and he mentioned the number to exclude the possibility that the <i>halakha</i> stated by the first <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> applies to both types of documents.
With regard to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s statement, the Gemara asks: <b>Reading, who mentioned anything about it?</b> Why does Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel mention a need for the witnesses to be able to read when the discussion is about a witness who does not know how to sign? The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete, and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> If <b>witnesses do not know</b> how <b>to read,</b> then <b>one reads in their presence and they sign. And</b> if <b>they do not know</b> how <b>to sign,</b> then one <b>tears</b> paper <b>for them</b> and they sign. Once the <i>baraita</i> is emended, it is clear that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel was responding to the statement of the previous <i>tanna</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there nothing else</b> that can be added to the list of ways in which bills of divorce and bills of manumission are equal? <b>But isn’t there</b> a case taught in the mishna (13a): If a person on his deathbed <b>says: Give this bill of divorce to my wife, or this bill of manumission to my slave, and he dies, they</b> should <b>not give</b> the bill <b>after</b> his <b>death.</b> However, if he said: <b>Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and he dies, they</b> should <b>give</b> it <b>after</b> his <b>death.</b> Apparently, this is another <i>halakha</i> in which bills of divorce and bills of manumission share equal status.
The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> the ways in which bills of divorce and bills of manumission are equal, it is referring only to <b>a matter that</b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to</b> typical <b>documents</b> and <b>it does not teach</b> any <b>matter that is</b> equally applicable <b>to</b> typical <b>documents.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>As Ravin sent</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>in the name of Rabbi Abbahu: You should know that Rabbi Elazar sent</b> this teaching <b>to the Diaspora,</b> i.e., Babylonia, <b>in the name of our teacher,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: With regard to the case of a person <b>on his deathbed who says: Write</b> a deed of transfer <b>and give</b> with it <b>one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and</b> then <b>dies</b> before they had the opportunity to write the document, <b>one does not write and give</b> the document. Why not?
The Gemara explains: <b>Perhaps he resolved to transfer</b> these one hundred dinars to him <b>only with a deed</b> of transfer, <b>and a deed</b> of transfer of property <b>is not</b> written <b>after the death</b> of the owner. This shows that other documents are also not written after one’s death, which means that this <i>halakha</i> is not specific to bills of divorce and bills of manumission. Therefore, it is not listed among the ways in which these two documents are similar.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But isn’t there</b> the <i>halakha</i> that both bills of divorce and bills of manumission must be written <b>for her sake,</b> i.e., for the sake of the particular woman or slave to whom they are given? Why isn’t this <i>halakha</i> included in the list?
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted,</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabba, this is</b> included in the statement: The two documents are similar with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>delivering and bringing,</b> as he maintains that this requirement to write the document for the sake of the recipient is the primary reason why the agents must state that it was written and signed in their presence. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> who holds that the reason for this statement is to ratify the bill of divorce, this is <b>difficult.</b>
<b>And furthermore, both according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba and according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, there is</b> the case of bills which were written and signed while they were <b>attached</b> to the ground, e.g., on a leaf attached to a tree, which invalidates both bills of divorce and bills of manumission. The Gemara explains: <b>When</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> its list it is referring solely to issues that cause the documents to be rendered <b>invalid by rabbinic law.</b> It <b>does not teach</b> cases involving invalidation <b>by Torah law.</b> Since these two cases, i.e., documents not written for the recipient’s sake or when they are attached to the ground, are not valid by Torah law, the <i>baraita</i> did not mention these cases.
The Gemara challenges this response: <b>But</b> there is the example of documents written in <b>gentile courts, which is an invalidation</b> of documents that applies <b>by Torah law, and</b> yet the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara answers: This is referring <b>to</b> a bill of divorce that was given with valid <b>witnesses who observe the transmission of a legal document, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says</b> in a mishna (10b): <b>Witnesses of the transmission</b> of a bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce. In his opinion, the effectiveness of the document depends on the witnesses who observe its transmission, not those who sign the bill of divorce. Consequently, a bill of divorce that was signed in a gentile court is rendered invalid by rabbinic law.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches in the latter clause</b> of that mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even these,</b> bills of divorce and bills of manumission, <b>are valid, and Rabbi Zeira said: Rabbi Shimon accepted the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, who said</b> that <b>witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, one can learn <b>by inference that the first <i>tanna</i></b> does <b>not hold</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar. Instead, he holds that the witnesses who sign effect a divorce. Yet even so, this <i>tanna</i> listed the cases where bills of divorce from gentile courts are invalidated, despite the fact that they are invalid by Torah law.

Daf 10a

The Gemara explains: It is possible that even the first <i>tanna</i> holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar that the witnesses who observe its transmission effect the divorce, and he does not dispute Rabbi Shimon on this point. Instead, <b>the</b> difference <b>between</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Shimon concerns a case where the signatures on the bill of divorce are <b>unambiguous [<i>muvhakin</i>]</b> gentile <b>names.</b> The first <i>tanna</i> holds that although a bill of divorce is valid if it was transmitted in the presence of valid witnesses, there is always a concern that it might have been transmitted in the presence of the same gentile witnesses who signed it. Therefore, it is rendered invalid by rabbinic law. Conversely, Rabbi Shimon holds that if it contained names that clearly belonged to gentiles it can be assumed that the bill of divorce was transmitted in the presence of two valid witnesses, and therefore it is valid.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>retraction</b> applies <b>by Torah law,</b> as according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir the husband can retract his instruction to give the bill of divorce and the master can retract his instruction to give the bill of manumission by Torah law, thereby canceling the agency. <b>And</b> yet the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> it among the ways in which bills of divorce are equal to bills of manumission. This indicates that the <i>tanna</i> does not distinguish between a case that applies by Torah law and one that applies by rabbinic law.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara retracts from the previous explanation in favor of the following: <b>When</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> the ways in which the two are equal it teaches only <b>a matter that does not</b> apply <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>betrothal;</b> however, <b>it does not teach a matter that does</b> apply <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of betrothal.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But retraction itself is</b> also applicable <b>with regard to betrothal,</b> as one who sent a betrothal document with an agent can retract it. The Gemara says: The <i>halakha</i> of agency in the case of betrothal is not the same as that of divorce, as there is a difference <b>with regard to agency</b> undertaken to enact a matter <b>against</b> the recipient’s <b>will.</b> If one appointed an agent for a matter that the recipient does not want, e.g., to betroth a woman against her will or to free a slave against his will, <b>as with regard to divorce, it is</b> a valid agency, as a bill of divorce need not be given with the woman’s consent, <b>but with regard to betrothal it is not</b> a valid agency, as a woman can be betrothed only with her consent.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any document that has a Samaritan witness</b> signed <b>on it is invalid, except for bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission. An incident</b> occurred in <b>which they brought a bill of divorce before Rabban Gamliel in the village of Otnai, and its witnesses were Samaritan witnesses, and he deemed it valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna?</b> It is <b>not</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>, nor</b> that of <b>Rabbi Elazar, nor</b> that of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> cited in the following <i>baraita</i>.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Pesaḥim</i> 1:15): The <b><i>matza</i> of a Samaritan is permitted</b> on Passover, as there is no concern that it might be leaven, <b>and a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on</b> the first night of <b>Passover with it. Rabbi Elazar prohibits</b> the consumption of the <i>matza</i> of a Samaritan <b>because</b> the Samaritans <b>are not well-versed in the details of mitzvot. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> On the contrary, with regard to <b>any mitzva that the Samaritans embraced</b> and accepted, <b>they are more exacting in its</b> observance <b>than</b> are <b>Jews.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in the mishna? <b>If</b> it is the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i></b> in the <i>baraita</i>, then <b>even other documents</b> should be valid when signed by Samaritan witnesses. By ruling that one can fulfill his obligation with Samaritan <i>matza</i>, this <i>tanna</i> apparently holds that the status of Samaritans is the same as that of Jews. If so, that should be their status with regard to their testimony on any document. <b>If</b> the opinion in the mishna is that of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who expresses the concern that Samaritans are not well versed in the details of mitzvot, they should <b>not</b> be fit to sign <b>even a bill of divorce.</b>
<b>And if</b> the opinion in the mishna is that of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should depend on the following consideration: <b>If they embrace</b> and accept the mitzva associated with the subject of the document, <b>even</b> with regard to <b>other documents</b> their testimony should be valid; <b>if they do not embrace</b> and accept the mitzva associated with the subject of the document, they should <b>not</b> be rendered fit to sign <b>even a bill of divorce.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that the opinion in the mishna <b>is</b> that of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and</b> the Samaritans <b>embrace this</b> mitzva of bills of divorce, <b>but</b> they <b>do not embrace this</b> mitzva associated with the subject of other documents, <b>if so, why</b> is a bill of divorce valid <b>specifically</b> in a case where only <b>one</b> Samaritan witness signed it? The same would hold true <b>even</b> if <b>two</b> Samaritan witnesses signed the bill of divorce <b>as well. Why,</b> then, <b>does Rabbi Elazar say:</b> The Sages <b>deemed it valid only</b> when there is <b>just one Samaritan witness</b> signed on the bill of divorce?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the opinion expressed in the mishna is that of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> and as a rule, one may not rely on the testimony of a Samaritan on a document. <b>And</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where a Jew signed</b> the document <b>last,</b>

Daf 10b

<b>as, if not</b> for the fact <b>that the Samaritan was one devoted to the meticulous observance of mitzvot [<i>ḥaver</i>],</b> the Jew would <b>not</b> have allowed <b>him</b> to <b>sign</b> the document <b>before him.</b> Therefore, one may rely on this Samaritan in this particular case. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that the mishna is referring to that case, then <b>even other documents</b> should be valid <b>as well,</b> if a Jew signed after the Samaritan.
<b>Rather,</b> this is not the case with regard to other documents, as <b>we say</b> that the fact that the Jew signed last does not prove that this Samaritan was a <i>ḥaver</i>, as perhaps in signing last <b>he was leaving space</b> above his signature <b>for one who was older than he is</b> in deference to the elder, and instead, a Samaritan came and signed the document. The Gemara asks: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a bill of divorce, perhaps he <b>was leaving space</b> above his signature <b>for one who was his elder.</b> Why, then, are bills of divorce and bills of manumission valid while other documents are not?
<b>Rav Pappa says: That is to say,</b> in explanation of the difference between bills of divorce and manumission and other documents, that <b>the witnesses of a bill of divorce</b> and a bill of manumission <b>may not sign one without the other;</b> rather, each witness signs in the presence of the other. A Jew would be aware that a Samaritan was signing with him, and he would not sign unless he knew that the Samaritan was a valid witness. However, with regard to other documents, witnesses are not required to sign such documents in each other’s presence. Therefore, the signature of the Jew indicates nothing about the fitness of the Samaritan witness.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the witnesses must sign a bill of divorce and a bill of manumission together? <b>Rav Ashi says:</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> issued <b>due to</b> a case where the husband says: <b>All of you</b> are witnesses on this bill of divorce. In that case, if any one of them fails to sign the bill of divorce, it is invalid. Therefore, the Sages decreed that the witnesses must sign a bill of divorce together in all cases.
§ Since the Gemara mentioned the <i>halakha</i> stated by Rabbi Elazar, it analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Elazar says: They deemed</b> a bill of divorce <b>valid only</b> when <b>just one witness</b> is <b>a Samaritan.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is he teaching us</b> by this statement? <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> in the mishna: <b>Any document that has a Samaritan witness on it is invalid</b> except for bills of divorce and bills of manumission. This indicates that those are valid only if they have the signature of one Samaritan witness, not two.
The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> it is learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone <b>I would have said</b> that <b>even two</b> Samaritan witnesses are <b>also</b> valid for a bill of divorce or a bill of manumission. <b>And</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches one</b> witness is <b>because</b> it wants to emphasize <b>that for</b> other <b>documents even one</b> Samaritan witness <b>is also not</b> valid. Therefore, Rabbi Eliezer <b>teaches us</b> that in the case of bills of divorce only one Samaritan witness is valid, but if both witnesses are Samaritans the bill of divorce is not valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> are <b>two</b> Samaritan witnesses <b>not</b> accepted on a bill of divorce? <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches: An incident</b> occurred in <b>which they brought a bill of divorce before Rabban Gamliel in the village of Otnai, and its witnesses were Samaritan witnesses, and he deemed it valid. Abaye said</b> that one should <b>teach</b> the mishna so that it does not read: Its witnesses, but rather: <b>Its witness,</b> i.e., Rabban Gamliel deemed valid a bill of divorce that had the signature of one Samaritan witness, as even he would invalidate a bill of divorce that included the signatures of two Samaritans.
<b>Rava said: Actually,</b> you do not need to say that the case was concerning one Samaritan witness, as it indeed is referring to <b>two</b> Samaritans witnesses, <b>and Rabban Gamliel disagrees</b> with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>. <b>And</b> the mishna <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching: And Rabban Gamliel deems valid</b> a bill of divorce <b>that</b> contains the signatures of <b>two</b> Samaritans, <b>and an incident</b> occurred in <b>which they brought a bill of divorce before Rabban Gamliel in the village of Otnai, and its witnesses were Samaritan witnesses, and he deemed it valid.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>all documents produced in gentile courts, even though their signatures</b> are those of <b>gentiles</b> they are all <b>valid, except for bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission. Rabbi Shimon says: Even these are valid,</b> as these two types of documents are <b>mentioned only when they are prepared by a common person,</b> not in court.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the ruling of the mishna that all documents written in gentile courts are valid, the Gemara comments: The <i>tanna</i> <b>categorically teaches</b> a general <i>halakha</i> in the mishna, and it <b>is no different</b> if it is a document concerning <b>a sale</b> and it <b>is no different</b> if it is a document concerning <b>a gift,</b> the document is valid in both cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> in the case of <b>a sale</b> this is reasonable, as <b>from when</b> the buyer <b>gave money</b> to the seller in the presence of the gentile judges <b>he has acquired</b> the property, since he has performed an act of acquisition. <b>And the document is merely a proof</b> for the acquisition. It must be that he already acquired the property in question, <b>as if he had not given money in their presence</b> the court <b>would not act to its own detriment and write a document for him,</b> as the document detailing the sale would not be accurate, and writing such a document would reflect poorly on them. Therefore, the document clearly serves as proof that the acquisition was performed in the correct manner.
<b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a gift, by what</b> means does the one who receives the gift <b>acquire</b> it from the giver? Is it <b>not via this document? And</b> yet <b>this document is merely a shard,</b> as a document written by gentiles is not considered a legal document according to <i>halakha</i>. <b>Shmuel said: The law of the kingdom is the law,</b> i.e., Jews must obey the laws of the state in which they live. Consequently, every form of property transfer accepted by local law is valid according to <i>halakha</i> as well.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that one should emend the text of the mishna, and <b>teach:</b> They are all valid <b>except for</b> documents that are <b>like bills of divorce.</b> In other words, the distinction is between different types of documents: Documents that are meant to serve only as proof are valid even if they were produced in gentile courts, whereas documents that effect a legal act, such as bills of divorce, are invalid if they were written in a gentile court.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even these</b> bills of divorce and bills of manumission <b>are valid</b> if they were written in a gentile court and were signed by gentiles. The Gemara asks: How can Rabbi Shimon rule in this manner? <b>But</b> gentiles are not fit for this role, as <b>they are not subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> concerning scrolls of <b>severance.</b> Since the <i>halakhot</i> of marriage and divorce in the Torah are stated exclusively with regard to Jews, gentiles cannot serve in any capacity in cases of this kind.
<b>Rabbi Zeira says: Rabbi Shimon follows the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, who says</b> that <b>the witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce. In other words, the signing of the bill of divorce is not essential to its effectiveness. Rather, the transfer of the bill of divorce completes the act of divorce, and therefore no attention is paid to who the signatories were.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Abba say</b> that although he considers a bill of divorce valid even without the signature of witnesses, <b>Rabbi Elazar concedes with regard to</b> a document <b>whose falsification is inherent in it that</b> it is <b>invalid</b> despite the fact that it was properly transferred. In other words, notwithstanding the <i>halakha</i> that the signatures on a bill of divorce are unnecessary, a document that includes invalid signatures is thereby invalidated. The reason is that there is a concern that people will rely upon these witnesses. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b>

Daf 11a

We are dealing <b>with unambiguous</b> gentile <b>names,</b> in which case there is no need to be concerned that people might rely on these individuals as witnesses for the transfer, as it is evident that they are gentiles.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>unambiguous</b> gentile <b>names? Rav Pappa said:</b> This is referring to names <b>such as Hurmiz, and Abbudina, bar Shibbetai, and bar Kidri, and Bati, and Nakim Una.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>However,</b> if the bill of divorce or manumission was signed by gentile witnesses with <b>ambiguous names, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is this <b>not</b> a valid document? <b>If so, instead of teaching</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: These two types of documents are <b>mentioned only when they are prepared by a common person,</b> not in court, <b>let him distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within</b> the case of gentile courts <b>itself,</b> as follows: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that gentile signatures are valid for a bill of divorce or manumission, <b>said? With regard to unambiguous names. However,</b> in a case of <b>ambiguous names, no,</b> gentile witnesses are not valid.
The Gemara answers: <b>That is also what he is saying,</b> i.e., Rabbi Shimon’s statement that these bills of divorce and bills of manumission are also valid should be understood in this very manner: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? With regard to unambiguous names. However, with regard to ambiguous names,</b> the document <b>becomes like one that was prepared by a common person, and</b> therefore such documents <b>are invalid.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different answer: In the <b>last clause</b> of the mishna, which states: These types of documents are mentioned only when they are prepared by a common person, we are no longer discussing bills of divorce; rather, <b>we arrive at</b> the case of <b>financial documents.</b> Furthermore, this clause of the mishna is not a continuation of Rabbi Shimon’s statement, as it returns to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>. <b>And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: Financial documents were mentioned as invalid only when they were prepared by a common person,</b> whereas if they were produced by a court they are valid.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 1:4): <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon said this to the Sages in</b> the city of <b>Tzaidan: Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis did not disagree with regard to all documents produced in gentile courts, that even though their signatories are gentiles,</b> these documents are <b>valid, even</b> in the case of <b>bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission. They disagreed only when they were prepared by a common person,</b> outside a court, <b>as Rabbi Akiva deems</b> a document of this kind <b>valid, and the Rabbis deem it invalid, except for bills of divorce and</b> bills <b>of manumission.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even these,</b> bills of divorce and manumission, <b>are valid in a place where Jews do not sign.</b> In other words, the <i>halakha</i> that a document with gentile signatories is valid applies only in a place where Jews are not allowed to sign, as everyone knows that gentile documents are not signed by Jews. <b>However, in a place where Jews sign, no,</b> these documents are not valid either, as people might mistakenly think that Jews signed this bill of divorce. Therefore there is a concern that one might deliver this bill of divorce in the presence of those witnesses, who are actually gentiles, which would render the bill of divorce invalid.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us also decree</b> in <b>a place where Jews do not sign due to a place where Jews do sign.</b> The Gemara answers: One might <b>confuse</b> one <b>name with</b> another <b>name.</b> It is possible that one might think that a certain name is that of a Jew when it is actually that of a gentile. However, one is <b>not</b> likely to <b>confuse</b> one <b>place with</b> another <b>place.</b> Since everyone knows that all of the signatures in certain places belong to gentiles, they are careful not to transfer a bill of divorce in the presence of the witnesses who signed it, unless they are certain that the witnesses are Jews.
§ The Gemara relates that <b>Ravina thought to deem valid</b> a document that was written <b>by a group of gentiles [<i>arma’ei</i>]. Rafram said to him</b> that <b>we learned:</b> Gentile <b>courts,</b> in the mishna, i.e., these documents are valid only if they were produced in an important court, not by every group of gentiles.
Similarly, <b>Rava said:</b> With regard to <b>this Persian document [<i>shetara parsa’a</i>]</b> written by the Persian authorities <b>that was transferred to</b> the recipient <b>in the presence of Jewish witnesses,</b> he <b>can collect with it non-liened</b> property, i.e., property that is unencumbered by a mortgage. Although this is not considered a proper document by means of which one can collect from any land sold by the debtor, nevertheless, the facts in the document are considered accurate, and therefore one may at least collect non-liened property with it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the witnesses for the transmission of this document <b>do not know</b> how <b>to read</b> Persian, as most Jews did not read that language. If so, how can they serve as witnesses? The Gemara answers: Rava is referring to a situation <b>where</b> the witnesses <b>know</b> how to read Persian.
The Gemara questions how the court can rely upon such a document: <b>But I require</b> that the document be <b>written</b> in a manner <b>that cannot be forged, and it is not</b> so in this document, as the Persians were not particular about preparing their documents in this manner when writing their legal documents. The Gemara explains: Rava’s statement applies <b>in</b> a case where the paper of the documents was processed <b>with gall.</b> Consequently, it is not possible to forge the writing (see 19b). <b>But I require that</b> a document <b>review the</b> essential <b>topic of the document in its last line, and it is not</b> so in the case of Persian documents. The Gemara answers: Rava’s statement applies <b>in</b> a case <b>where it returned</b> to review the essential topic of the document in the final line.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> he should be able to collect <b>from liened</b> property <b>as well,</b> as this document is equivalent to one written by a Jew. Why doesn’t Rava say that it can be used to collect from liened property as well? The Gemara answers: The reason is that this document does <b>not</b> generate <b>publicity,</b> i.e., a legal matter that is performed in a Persian court will not become publicized among Jews. Therefore, this case is similar to a loan by oral agreement, where the transaction is not publicized. In this case the lender can collect only from non-liened property, as purchasers from the debtor would not have been aware of his debt and consequently taken sufficient measures to ensure that the money would not be claimed from their purchase.
<b>Reish Lakish raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b>

Daf 11b

With regard to <b>witnesses who signed a bill of divorce and whose names are like the names of gentiles, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: There came before us</b> bills of divorce that were signed <b>only</b> with names such as <b>Lukos and Los, and we deemed</b> them <b>valid</b> by means of the witnesses of transmission.
The Gemara infers: <b>And</b> this applies <b>specifically</b> to names such as <b>Lukos and Los, as it is uncommon</b> to find <b>Jews who are called by these names. However,</b> with regard to <b>other</b> gentile <b>names,</b> concerning <b>which it is common</b> to find <b>Jews who are called by these names, no,</b> the documents are not valid, as people might mistakenly rely on the signatures of gentiles.
Reish Lakish <b>raised an objection to</b> this ruling from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 4:8): With regard to <b>bills of divorce that come from a country overseas, and witnesses are signed upon them, even though the names</b> of the witnesses <b>are like the names of gentiles, they are valid, because the names of most Jews outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>are like the names of gentiles.</b> This indicates that a bill of divorce is valid even when the names are not clearly those of gentiles.
The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> the <i>halakha</i> is different, <b>as it teaches the reason</b> explicitly: <b>Because the names of most Jews outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>are like the names of gentiles.</b> Consequently, it can be assumed that the court examined the matter at the time of the signing, and that the document was signed by Jews. However, in Eretz Yisrael it is more likely that ambiguous names are actually those of gentiles, and therefore a document of this kind is valid only when it is clear it was signed by gentiles, to avoid mistakes.
This was one version of the discussion. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Reish Lakish <b>asked</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan about the very <b>same</b> case as <b>in the <i>baraita</i>, and he resolved</b> the matter <b>for him from the <i>baraita</i>,</b> that even if the names signed on a bill of divorce brought from outside of Eretz Yisrael are like the names of gentiles, they are valid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who says</b> to another: <b>Give this bill of divorce to my wife, or:</b> Give <b>this bill of manumission to my slave, if</b> before the document reaches the woman or the slave the giver <b>wishes to retract</b> his decision, then <b>with regard to both of them, he can retract.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One can retract his decision <b>in</b> the case of <b>bills of divorce but not in</b> the case of bills <b>of manumission.</b> The Rabbis explain the reason for their ruling: This is <b>because one can act in a person’s interest in his absence,</b> and therefore the agent acquires the document on behalf of the slave from the moment the owner hands the bill of manumission to the agent. <b>But one can act to a person’s detriment only in his presence.</b> The receipt of a bill of divorce is considered to be to a woman’s detriment, and therefore an agent cannot receive it for her without her consent.
They explain further: The emancipation of a slave is in his interests, despite the fact that he receives sustenance from his master while a slave, <b>as, if</b> the master <b>wishes not to sustain his slave he is allowed</b> not to provide him with sustenance. This demonstrates that slavery is not in the interest of the slave, as he does not receive any guaranteed benefit. <b>But</b> if a husband wishes <b>not to sustain his wife, he is not allowed</b> to proceed in this manner. Consequently, marriage is in the interests of the woman.
Rabbi Meir <b>said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>But</b> even so, it is not in the interest of a slave to be emancipated, <b>as,</b> if his master is a priest, he <b>disqualifies his slave from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i></b> by emancipating him, <b>just as</b> a husband who is a priest <b>disqualifies his</b> Israelite <b>wife</b> from partaking of <i>teruma</i> by divorcing her. The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> It is permitted for a priest’s slave to partake of <i>teruma</i> not because he has a right to sustenance, but rather <b>because he is his</b> master’s <b>acquisition.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Huna and Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef were sitting before Rabbi Yirmeya, and Rabbi Yirmeya was sitting and dozing</b> while the other two Sages conversed. <b>And Rav Huna was sitting and saying:</b> With regard to the statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> that a master cannot retract a bill of manumission once he has given it to an agent, one can <b>conclude from</b> it <b>that</b> if a third party <b>seizes</b> a debtor’s property <b>on behalf of a creditor,</b> an act that is certainly in the interests of the creditor, he <b>acquires</b> this property on his behalf. This is similar to the case here, where the agent acquires the bill of manumission on behalf of the slave.
<b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef said to</b> Rav Huna: Do you state this <i>halakha</i> <b>even in a case when</b> the seizure of property <b>is to the detriment of others,</b> e.g., if there are other creditors who would lose the opportunity to seize the property? Rav Huna <b>said to him: Yes.</b>
<b>In the meantime Rabbi Yirmeya woke up, due to their</b> conversation, as he was not sleeping deeply. <b>He said to them: Children [<i>dardekei</i>], this is</b> what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One who seizes</b> property on behalf <b>of a creditor in a case where it is to the detriment of others does not acquire. And if you say</b> that <b>the mishna</b> apparently teaches the opposite, as the agent acquires the bill of manumission on behalf of the slave despite the fact that this causes a loss for the master, that case is different.
Rabbi Yirmeya elaborates: The reason for the ruling in the mishna is that <b>anyone who says: Give</b> to so-and-so, <b>is like one who says: Acquire</b> on behalf of so-and-so. Since the master said: Give this bill of manumission to my slave, the agent immediately acquires it on the slave’s behalf, despite the fact that the bill is to the detriment of the master. However, this <i>halakha</i> has no bearing on a case where a person independently seizes property on behalf of another, and by doing so acts to the disadvantage of others.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> With regard to this issue of <b>one who seizes</b> property <b>on behalf of a creditor in a case where it is to the detriment of others, we have arrived at the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis.</b> What is this dispute? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 4:9): With regard to <b>one who</b> is not poor but <b>collected produce in the corner of the field, which is given to the poor [<i>pe’a</i>], and said: This</b> produce that I have collected is <b>for so-and-so,</b> who is <b>a poor person, Rabbi Eliezer said: He has acquired</b> it <b>on his behalf, and the Rabbis say:</b> He has not acquired it on his behalf; rather, <b>he gives</b> the produce he gathered <b>to</b> whichever <b>poor person appears first</b> before him. Apparently, Rabbi Eliezer holds that one can gather <i>pe’a</i> on behalf of a poor person, despite the fact that he acts to the detriment of other paupers, while the Rabbis disagree.
<b>Ameimar said, and some say</b> that it was actually <b>Rav Pappa</b> who said:

Daf 12a

<b>Perhaps</b> that <b>is not so.</b> Perhaps this is not the point of dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis. There are two ways to explain why this might not be the case. First, it is possible that <b>Rabbi Eliezer states his opinion only there,</b> when the person took possession of the <i>pe’a</i> despite not being eligible to collect it for himself, <b>since if</b> the one who collected the produce <b>desired, he</b> could <b>declare his property ownerless and become a poor person, and</b> then the produce would have been <b>fit for him</b> to retain for himself. <b>And since</b> he could have <b>acquired</b> the <i>pe’a</i> <b>for himself,</b> he can likewise <b>acquire</b> it <b>for another</b> as well. <b>However, here,</b> where he seizes property on behalf of a creditor, he cannot seize this property for himself. Consequently, Rabbi Eliezer does <b>not</b> rule that he can do so when it is against the interests of another person.
