Second, one can argue from the opposite perspective: <b>The Rabbis state</b> their opinion <b>only there,</b> that one cannot acquire on behalf of the poor person, <b>as it is written:</b> “The corner of your field you shall not reap and the gleaning of your harvest <b>you shall not gather; for the poor</b> you shall leave them” (Leviticus 23:22), and the Sages expounded this verse by reading it as though there were no break in the middle: <b>You shall not gather for the poor,</b> i.e., the poor person must collect the produce for himself. <b>However, here,</b> where one seizes property on behalf of a creditor, this verse does not apply, and therefore the Rabbis did <b>not</b> rule that the action of the third party is ineffective. Consequently, it is possible that the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis is not with regard to the issue of whether one can seize property on behalf of a creditor in a case where it is to the detriment of others.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> with regard to <b>this</b> verse: <b>“You shall not gather,” what does he do with it?</b> How does he interpret this phrase, from which the Rabbis derived that one may not collect <i>pe’a</i> on behalf of a poor person? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it to warn a poor person with regard to his own</b> field, i.e., if a poor person had a field of his own he is not permitted to gather <i>pe’a</i> from it for himself, his poverty notwithstanding.
§ The mishna taught: <b>As, if</b> the master <b>wishes not to sustain</b> his slave he is allowed to act accordingly. The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude from</b> the mishna that <b>the master is</b> legally <b>able to say to</b> his <b>slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you.</b>
The Gemara rejects this claim: This is not a conclusive proof, as <b>with what are we dealing here,</b> in the mishna? We are dealing with a case <b>where he said to</b> the slave: <b>Spend your earnings to sustain yourself.</b> In other words, I will not provide for you; rather, you must work and earn money for your sustenance on your own. However, this does not mean that a master can force his slave to work for him without providing him with sustenance.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>in the corresponding</b> situation in the mishna <b>with regard to a wife,</b> will one explain <b>that he</b> could have <b>said to her: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself?</b> The mishna rules that one cannot exempt himself from his obligation to provide sustenance for his wife. In the case of <b>a wife, why</b> may he <b>not</b> do so? It is certainly permitted for a husband to stipulate with his wife that she will keep her earnings and not receive sustenance from him, yet it is clear in the mishna that there is a difference between a slave and a wife with regard to his ability to refuse to provide sustenance. The Gemara answers: The <b>wife</b> mentioned in the mishna is one whose earnings <b>are not sufficient</b> for her sustenance, and in that case the husband may not stipulate in this manner.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If so, the case of the <b>slave also</b> is referring to a situation where his earnings <b>are not sufficient</b> for his sustenance, and he is unable to sustain himself. Nevertheless, his master can refuse to sustain him. Therefore, one can conclude from the mishna that a master can say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you. The Gemara explains: <b>A slave who is not worth the bread that he consumes, for what is he needed by his master or his mistress?</b> If the value of his labor does not even pay for the cost of his sustenance why is he needed at all? The mishna certainly does not refer to a case of this kind. By contrast, with regard to a wife, the marriage does not depend on her ability to provide for herself by means of her earnings. Consequently, one cannot prove from the mishna that a master can say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Makkot</i> 2:8): With regard to <b>a slave who</b> unintentionally killed someone and <b>was exiled to</b> one of the <b>cities of refuge, his master is not required to sustain him. And not only that, but his earnings</b> in his city of refuge belong <b>to his master. Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that <b>a master can say to</b> his <b>slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you,</b> as in the case of a slave exiled to a city of refuge the master is entitled to his earnings despite not providing for him. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where</b> the master <b>said to him: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> if the master said this to the slave, then <b>why do his earnings</b> belong <b>to his master?</b> After all, his master stipulated that he should sustain himself. The Gemara answers: This <i>halakha</i> is referring <b>to</b> his <b>surplus</b> earnings, i.e., if the slave works and earns more than the cost of his sustenance, his surplus income belongs to the master.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it <b>obvious</b> that any <b>surplus</b> belongs to the master, as he owns the slave? The Gemara answers: This ruling is necessary, <b>lest you say that since, when he does not</b> work enough the master does <b>not give him</b> all he needs to eat, then <b>when he has</b> a surplus from his work the master <b>should also not take it.</b> Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that despite this consideration the surplus belongs to the master.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is different</b> with regard to a slave who was exiled <b>to</b> one of the <b>cities of refuge,</b> concerning whom the <i>baraita</i> was stated? According to this reasoning, the surplus should belong to the master no matter where the slave is located. The Gemara answers: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that as the verse states with regard to one who is exiled to a city of refuge: “And that fleeing to one of these cities <b>he might live”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:42), one should <b>act for him</b> so that he has <b>extra life,</b> i.e., in this specific case the slave should be allowed to retain any additional amount he earns. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that no special obligation of this kind applies even if the slave had been exiled to a city of refuge.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: However,</b> with regard to <b>a woman who was exiled to</b> one of the <b>cities of refuge, her husband is obligated in her sustenance, by inference</b> the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with a case <b>where he did not say to her:</b> Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, which is why he must sustain her. <b>As, if he said</b> this <b>to her, why is her husband obligated</b> to provide her with sustenance?
<b>And from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is speaking about a case <b>where he did not say</b> this <b>to her,</b> it may be inferred that the <b>first clause</b> is <b>also</b> dealing with a situation <b>where he did not say to</b> the slave: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself. The two clauses of the <i>baraita</i> must be referring to similar cases or they would not be taught together.
The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the master <b>said to</b> the slave: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, and the husband issued a similar statement to his wife. However, in the case of <b>a woman</b> it is referring to a situation <b>when</b> her earnings are <b>not sufficient</b> for her sustenance.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the last clause teaches: And if</b> the husband <b>said to her: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, he is permitted</b> to act accordingly, <b>it may be inferred that the first</b> half of the last <b>clause</b> is referring to a case <b>where he did not say</b> this <b>to her.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: And if</b> her earnings <b>suffice</b> to pay for her sustenance, <b>and he said to her: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, it is permitted</b> for him to say that.
The Gemara asks: If the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where her earnings <b>suffice, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who was exiled to a city of refuge? The same <i>halakha</i> applies to all wives. The Gemara answers: It is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that in light of the verse: <b>“All glorious is the king’s daughter within the palace”</b> (Psalms 45:14), from which it is derived that it is improper for a wife to spend too much time outside her home, this woman’s husband should be concerned that while his wife is in a city of refuge she should not work out of the home, but only in the home. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that there is no need to be concerned about this matter, and her husband may say to her: Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, even in a city of refuge.
With regard to the question of whether a master can decide to cease providing sustenance for his slave while the slave continues to serve him, the Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this matter is the <b>subject of</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A slave can say to his master in years of famine: Either sustain me</b> from your property <b>or emancipate me. And the Rabbis say: His master has permission to</b> retain his ownership over him without sustaining him.
<b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that <b>they disagree</b> about <b>this</b> issue, <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that a master <b>can</b> say to his slave that he should work for him and he will not sustain him. Consequently, he is not required to emancipate him even when he cannot provide for him. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds</b> that the master <b>cannot</b> say this, and therefore he is required to free him.
The Gemara responds: <b>And can you understand</b> the dispute that way? If so, <b>this</b> expression: <b>Either sustain me or emancipate me,</b> is inaccurate, as the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have</b> said: <b>Either sustain me or give me my earnings for my sustenance. And furthermore,</b> if the dispute concerns this general issue, <b>what is different about years of famine?</b> The same dispute should apply in all years.
<b>Rather, with what are we dealing here?</b> This <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where the master <b>said to</b> the slave: <b>Spend your earnings to sustain yourself, and</b> subsequently, <b>during years of famine,</b> the slave’s earnings do <b>not suffice</b> to provide himself with sustenance, as prices are higher than usual.
And <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds</b> that in this case the slave can say to his master: <b>Either sustain me or emancipate me, so that people will see me</b> in my helpless state, <b>and they will have mercy on me</b> and provide me with charity. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that this is not a justification for emancipating a slave, as <b>those who have mercy on freemen will also have mercy on a slave.</b> Consequently, it is not necessary for the slave to be emancipated for him to receive help from generous people. According to this interpretation, the <i>baraita</i> has no bearing on the question as to whether a master can say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you.
The Gemara offers another suggestion: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a statement <b>that Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>one who consecrates the hands of his slave,</b> so that all the work he does becomes Temple property, preventing the slave from working on his own behalf, then <b>that slave borrows and eats, and</b> afterward <b>performs</b> work <b>and repays</b> what he borrowed, as will be explained. <b>Conclude from</b> Rav’s statement that <b>the master is able to say to</b> his <b>slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you.</b> In this case the master has prevented his slave from working for himself, and yet he is not required to provide for him.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> the master <b>provides sustenance for him.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so, for what</b> reason

Daf 12b

<b>does he</b> find it necessary to <b>borrow and eat?</b> After all, his master provides for him. The Gemara answers: This is referring <b>to surplus</b> food, i.e., additional food that the slave wants to eat.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the <b>Temple</b> treasurer <b>say to him: Until now it was enough for you without a surplus; now too it should be enough for you without a surplus.</b> Why do you seek more now? Consequently, the consecration should apply to this surplus as well. The Gemara answers: <b>It is preferable to</b> the <b>Temple</b> treasury <b>itself</b> that he work and eat more, <b>so that</b> the value of <b>its slave will be enhanced</b> when he consumes this extra amount, as he will become stronger.
§ It was stated that the slave borrows and eats and afterward <b>performs</b> work <b>and repays</b> the loan. The Gemara asks: But his work <b>immediately becomes consecrated,</b> as his hands have been consecrated. How, then, can he repay this loan? The Gemara answers: The slave performs work <b>of less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>.</b> Anything worth less than one <i>peruta</i> does not become consecrated. Therefore he can collect these small sums and repay his debt little by little.
The Gemara comments: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> that Rav is referring to a case where the master provides sustenance for him. <b>As Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>one who consecrates the hands of his slave, that slave works and eats, as, if</b> the slave does <b>not work</b> for himself, <b>who will work</b> and provide <b>for him?</b> This ruling indicates that Rav maintains that consecration does not apply to the slave’s hands.
The Gemara explains: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>this</b> earlier <i>halakha</i> that Rav said, that the slave borrows and repays, refers to a situation <b>where</b> his master <b>provides sustenance for him, and</b> this is because in general <b>he cannot</b> say to him: Work for me but I will not sustain you, <b>and this</b> second <i>halakha</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> his master <b>does not provide</b> him with sustenance, and therefore he cannot consecrate the slave’s hands, it <b>is well,</b> as there is no contradiction between the two statements of Rav.
<b>However, if you say</b> that <b>this</b> first <i>halakha</i> is <b>also</b> speaking of a case <b>where</b> his master <b>does not provide</b> sustenance for him, and the consecration is effective because he <b>can</b> say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you, then what is the meaning of the statement: <b>As, if</b> the slave does <b>not work</b> for himself <b>who will work for him?</b> Let <b>whoever desires work for him,</b> i.e., the slave will be compelled to sustain himself from charity, but this is not the master’s concern.
<b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> here that Rav holds that a master <b>cannot</b> say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you? The Gemara comments: Indeed <b>conclude from</b> here that this is the case.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another source concerning the same dilemma, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One who severs the hand of another’s slave</b> must <b>give</b> compensation for <b>his</b> loss of <b>livelihood,</b> i.e., compensation for the slave’s inability to work as a result of his injury, <b>and</b> the slave’s <b>medical costs to his master. And that slave,</b> who can no longer work, is <b>sustained from charity. Conclude from</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement that <b>the master is able to say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you,</b> as otherwise the master would not receive compensation for his time in the form of payment for the slave’s earnings while the slave lives off of charity.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> his master <b>provides sustenance for him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, why is he sustained from charity?</b> He already has sustenance. The Gemara answers: This is referring <b>to surplus</b> food, i.e., additional food that the slave wants to eat.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> the phrase: <b>Sustained</b> from charity, is imprecise, as it indicates that he is provided only with enough for his basic needs. <b>It should have</b> said: He <b>earns a living</b> from charity. <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> his statement that Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that the master <b>can</b> to say to his slave: Work for me but I will not sustain you? The Gemara comments: Indeed <b>conclude from</b> his statement that this is the case.
The Gemara discusses the aforementioned <i>halakha</i>. <b>The Master says</b> earlier: <b>He</b> must <b>give</b> compensation for the slave’s loss of <b>livelihood and his medical costs to his master.</b> The Gemara comments: With regard to compensation for loss of <b>livelihood, it is obvious</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>, as the master incurs the loss when his slave does not work, and therefore <b>it was necessary for</b> the Sages to mention only that the compensation for <b>his medical costs</b> goes to his master.
The Gemara comments: Why is the payment for his medical costs given to his master? Shouldn’t the compensation for <b>his medical costs belong to him, as he needs to be healed with it?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where</b> doctors <b>estimated</b> that the blow or wound <b>would heal in five days and they made a strong medicine for him, and he was healed in three days</b> instead of five. <b>Lest you say:</b> Since <b>the pain</b> suffered by the slave by taking the strong medicine that caused a decrease in the costs of healing was his, the money should belong <b>to him,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case, as even this money belongs to the master, not the slave.
§ With regard to the discussion in the mishna between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis, <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 1:5) that <b>Rabbi Elazar said: We said to Meir: But isn’t it in the interest of a slave to leave his master to freedom? He said to us: It is to his detriment, as if he were the slave of a priest,</b> then by emancipating him the master thereby <b>disqualifies him from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>. We said to him: But what</b> would be <b>if</b> the master <b>wishes not to sustain him and not to provide him with a living?</b> He is <b>permitted</b> to do so. Therefore, the slave does not lose out when he is emancipated, as he was not guaranteed sustenance in any event.
Rabbi Meir <b>said to us:</b> Even if the master is not obligated to provide for him, it is still permitted for the slave to partake of <i>teruma</i>. The proof for this is the following case: <b>And what</b> would be <b>if</b> there were <b>the slave of a priest, who fled</b> from his master, <b>or</b> in the case of <b>the wife of a priest, who rebelled against her husband,</b> i.e., she refused to fulfill her obligations as a married woman? Are <b>they not</b> permitted to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> although not the <i>teruma</i> belonging to the master or husband? They are permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But this</b> slave who was emancipated <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> at all, even <i>teruma</i> that belongs to other priests. <b>But</b> in any event, in the case of <b>a woman,</b> a bill of divorce <b>is to her detriment, as it disqualifies her from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i> and causes her to lose</b> her <b>sustenance.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What did</b> the Rabbis <b>say to</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>and what</b> did he <b>respond to them?</b> In other words, the two sides do not appear to be discussing the same issue, as the Rabbis refer to sustenance while Rabbi Meir talks about <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara explains that <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Meir <b>is saying</b> to them: <b>You have answered me about sustenance,</b> that the master is not required to provide for his slave. However, <b>what will you answer me about <i>teruma</i>?</b>
<b>And if you were to say</b> that the acceptance of the document by the agent is not to the slave’s detriment, as in any event <b>if</b> the master <b>desires, he can throw the bill</b> of manumission within four cubits of the slave <b>and</b> thereby <b>disqualify him</b> from partaking of <i>teruma</i>; the slave can prevent this from occurring by <b>leaving</b> his master, <b>and escaping and going out to the world.</b> If he acts in this manner his master will be unable to emancipate him, and he can continue partaking of <i>teruma</i>.

Daf 13a

And Rabbi Meir further said to the Rabbis: <b>And what</b> would <b>be if</b> there was the <b>slave of a priest, who fled</b> from his master, <b>or</b> the <b>wife of a priest who rebelled against her husband,</b> are <b>they not</b> permitted to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> although not the <i>teruma</i> belonging to the master or husband? They are permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But this</b> slave who was emancipated <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> at all, even <i>teruma</i> that belongs to other priests. Evidently, emancipation is to his detriment.
The Gemara asks: If so, then Rabbi Meir <b>is saying</b> and responding <b>well</b> to the Rabbis. How do the Rabbis counter his claim? <b>Rava said: This is what</b> they <b>answered</b> and said <b>to him in the mishna:</b> The master can disqualify his slave from partaking of <i>teruma</i> in any event, <b>because he is his</b> master’s <b>acquisition.</b> The implication of this statement is the following: <b>As, if</b> the master <b>desires</b> to disqualify his slave from partaking of <i>teruma</i> after he has fled, he can <b>take four dinars from</b> any <b>Israelite</b> in exchange for the slave, <b>and he</b> thereby <b>disqualifies</b> him from partaking of <i>teruma</i> <b>anywhere that he is</b> located.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> his explanation <b>works out well</b> with regard to the <b>slave of a priest</b> whose emancipation causes him to be disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, and therefore it is possible to argue that his emancipation is to his detriment. However with regard to the <b>slave of an Israelite, what can be said? Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says:</b> Emancipation is even to the detriment of a slave of an Israelite, <b>because</b> by freeing him his master <b>causes him to lose</b> the option <b>of</b> engaging in sexual intercourse with <b>a Canaanite maidservant.</b> Until this point it was permitted for him to engage in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite maidservant, but once he is emancipated these women are forbidden to him.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>On the contrary,</b> by emancipating him the master renders it <b>permitted for him</b> to engage in sexual intercourse <b>with a free woman.</b> The Gemara answers: In the case of <b>a slave,</b> a life <b>of licentiousness is preferable for him.</b> Therefore, he would rather have the right to engage in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite maidservant, as <b>she is lowly to him, she is available for him, she is unrestricted for him.</b> None of these descriptions apply to a Jewish woman, and therefore he loses out on the benefit he could have received from being permitted to engage in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite maidservant. Consequently, Rabbi Meir maintains that his emancipation is to his detriment.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who says: Give this bill of divorce to my wife,</b> or: Give <b>this bill of manumission to my slave, and</b> then he <b>dies, one does not give it after</b> his <b>death.</b> The reason for this is that bills of divorce and manumission must be transferred by the husband or the master. Once he has died the document can no longer be given, and the agency he appointed for this purpose is likewise canceled. However, if he said: <b>Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and</b> then he <b>died, one does give</b> the recipient the money <b>after</b> his <b>death.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta says in the name of Rav: And this</b> ruling, that one gives the one hundred dinars after the death of the owner, is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when</b> those dinars <b>are piled up and placed in a corner</b> at the time of the command.
The Gemara asks: <b>With what are we dealing? If we say</b> that we are dealing <b>with a healthy person</b> who instructs others to give one hundred dinars, then <b>when they are piled, what of it?</b> After all, the recipient <b>did not pull</b> the money, and one must perform an act of acquisition to take possession of movable property. <b>Rather,</b> say that we are dealing <b>with</b> a person <b>on his deathbed,</b> in which case verbal instructions suffice. However, if that is so, <b>why</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply <b>specifically</b> when the money is <b>piled?</b> The same should be the case <b>when</b> the coins are <b>not piled as well, as we maintain</b> that <b>the statement of</b> a person <b>on his deathbed</b> who distributes his property <b>is considered as though it were written and delivered.</b> If so, no other act of acquisition should be necessary.
<b>Rav Zevid says: Actually,</b> the mishna is dealing <b>with a healthy person, and</b> this ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says. As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to one who says to another: <b>I</b> have <b>one hundred dinars in your possession; give it to so-and-so,</b> if this occurred <b>in the presence of</b> all <b>three</b> parties, that third person has <b>acquired</b> it. This type of acquisition applies only to money that is similar to a deposit, e.g., piled money.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Actually,</b> the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a person <b>on his deathbed, and it is in accordance with another</b> ruling <b>of Rav, as Rav says:</b> With regard to a person <b>on his deathbed who said: Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so from my property,</b> the <i>halakha</i> depends on his precise wording. If he said: Give him <b>this one hundred dinars,</b> where the money is in a particular place, <b>one gives</b> the money to him. However, if he merely said: <b>One hundred dinars, without specification, one does not give</b> it to him.
Why does one not give the one hundred dinars if he did not add further specification? <b>We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he spoke</b> about <b>a buried one hundred dinars.</b> In other words, he might have been referring to a specific one hundred dinars whose location is unknown, and he did not intend to give him any other money. For this reason, Rav explains that the mishna is referring to money piled up in a designated place, which the one who gives the instruction is referring to explicitly.
The Gemara comments: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>we are not concerned about a buried</b> sum of one hundred dinars, i.e., the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rav. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>Rav Pappa did not say</b> an explanation that is <b>in accordance with</b> that of <b>Rav Zevid</b> with regard to Rav’s statement?

Daf 13b

The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Pappa holds</b> that <b>when Rav said</b> that a transfer in the presence of all three parties is effective, it <b>is no different</b> if this is referring <b>to a loan</b> from the first party to the second party, where it is an abstract monetary obligation that is transferred, <b>and</b> it <b>is no different</b> if it is referring <b>to a deposit,</b> where specific money is transferred. Just as the transfer is effective in the case of a loan, in which there is an abstract monetary obligation, it would be effective even if the money were not piled. For this reason, Rav Pappa explained that the mishna is referring to piled money due to the concern about a collection of a buried one hundred dinars.
The Gemara asks the reverse question: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>Rav Zevid did not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Pappa?</b> The Gemara answers: He holds that it is <b>not</b> possible to <b>establish the mishna</b> as referring <b>to</b> a person <b>on his deathbed. From where</b> does he learn this? It is <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches:</b> In the case of <b>one who says: Give this bill of divorce to my wife, or:</b> Give <b>this bill of manumission to my slave, and</b> then he <b>dies, one should not give it after</b> his <b>death.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> for this ruling is <b>that</b> the man <b>died.</b> However, if it was <b>while</b> he was still <b>alive</b> then <b>one gives</b> the document. The Gemara continues: Even during his lifetime <b>the reason</b> for the ruling is specifically that <b>he said: Give, but</b> if <b>he did not say: Give,</b> and merely commanded: Write a bill of divorce, then <b>one does not give</b> it. <b>But</b> this is not the case with regard to a person <b>on his deathbed,</b> as, <b>although he did not say: Give,</b> but simply commanded: Write, nevertheless, <b>one gives</b> the document. Evidently, this <i>halakha</i> cannot be referring to a person on his deathbed.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (65b): <b>Initially</b> the Sages <b>would say:</b> With regard to <b>one who is taken out in a neck chain</b> to be executed <b>and said: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, these</b> people <b>should write and give</b> her the document. Although he did not explicitly say: Give, this is understood to have been his intention. <b>They then said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even to one who sets sail and one who departs in a caravan</b> to a far-off place. A bill of divorce is given to his wife under these circumstances even if her husband said just: Write.
<b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri says: Even</b> in the case of <b>one who is dangerously ill</b> who gives that instruction, they write the bill of divorce and give it to his wife. This shows that a dying person need not say: Give. Rather, it is sufficient for him to say: Write. By contrast, the mishna indicates that it is referring to one who says: Give, and therefore it is certainly not speaking about a dying person.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this</b> claim: <b>And who says to us that the mishna is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri? Perhaps it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who did not include a dangerously ill person in their list of those who are not required to say: Give. If so, it is possible that the mishna is referring to a person on his deathbed after all.
The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to one who says to another: <b>I</b> have <b>one hundred dinars in your possession; give it to so-and-so,</b> if this occurred <b>in the presence of</b> all <b>three</b> parties, that third person has <b>acquired</b> it. <b>Rava said: It stands to reason</b> that <b>Rav’s statement</b> is <b>with regard to a deposit,</b> when the owner of the deposit instructs its guardian to transfer specific money under his authority to someone else who is also present. <b>However,</b> in the case <b>of a loan, no,</b> one cannot dispense with an act of acquisition, as repayment of a loan does not involve specific money.
Rava himself adds, in the form of an oath: <b>But by God,</b> in truth, <b>Rav said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>even with regard to a loan.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Shmuel said in the name of Levi</b> that if someone says to another: <b>I have a loan in your possession,</b> i.e., you owe me payment for a loan, <b>give it to so-and-so,</b> and this occurred <b>in the presence of</b> all <b>three</b> parties, that named person has <b>acquired</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> for this? In what manner does he acquire it? <b>Ameimar said:</b> The case <b>becomes like</b> that of a borrower <b>who says to</b> a lender <b>at the time of the giving of the money,</b> when he receives a loan: <b>I am beholden to you and to anyone</b> who <b>comes</b> based <b>on your</b> authorization. In this case, the recipient is authorized by the lender to take the loan in the presence of all three parties.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: If that is so,</b> that the borrower’s obligation to the third party went into effect at the time of the loan, then if <b>he transferred</b> it in the presence of the three parties <b>to those who will be born,</b> i.e., people who <b>were not</b> yet born <b>when the money was</b> initially <b>given,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should <b>also</b> be <b>that</b> the recipients <b>do not acquire</b> it. The reason is that at the time the lender gave the money to the borrower, the person to whom it would eventually be transferred did not yet exist, and therefore the borrower could not have become obligated to him at that point in time.
Rav Ashi elaborates: <b>As, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who says</b> that <b>a person can transfer</b> ownership of <b>an entity that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world, this statement</b> applies only when he transfers it <b>to an entity,</b> i.e., a person, <b>that has come into the world. However,</b> even Rabbi Meir agrees with regard to the transfer of ownership of an article <b>to an entity that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world,</b> that this is <b>not</b> possible. Since Rav issued his statement in a general manner without any limitations, evidently the method of a transfer in the presence of all three parties applies in all cases, regardless of whether the third party was born at the time when the loan was given.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says</b> that this is the reason for the matter:

Daf 14a

<b>With that benefit</b> that the borrower receives when <b>his</b> debt <b>changes from an old debt to a new debt, he fully pledges himself</b> to the new lender. The borrower prefers to have a new lender from whom he can ask for an extension of the deadline for the repayment of his debt.
<b>Huna Mar, son of Rav Neḥemya, said to Rav Ashi: If that is so,</b> what about a case <b>where</b> the debt is transferred to <b>these</b> members <b>of the house of bar Elyashiv? As,</b> those implacable people <b>bind</b> debtors with handcuffs <b>and take</b> their money <b>immediately</b> when the time for repayment arrives. They certainly would not add to the time that the borrower has to repay the first loan, and he would not willingly pledge himself to them. <b>So too,</b> will you say <b>that they do not acquire</b> the money in the presence of all three parties, as the borrower would not agree to this arrangement?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>indeed</b> this method is not effective in a case of this kind, <b>if so you have rendered your statement subject to circumstances.</b> In other words, the application of the acquisition in the presence of all three parties is not absolute, and instead depends on whether in this particular case the borrower agrees to transfer his debt from one person to another.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara retracts the previous explanation in favor of that which <b>Mar Zutra said: These three matters were instituted by the Sages as a <i>halakha</i> without a reason,</b> i.e., they instituted these ordinances despite the fact that the logical mechanism by which they function is unclear: <b>One</b> is <b>this</b> case of an acquisition in the presence of all three parties. <b>And another</b> is <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: One who writes</b> over <b>all of his property to his wife</b> as a gift has <b>rendered her only a steward [<i>eppitrofeya</i>],</b> but she does not become the owner. <b>And another</b> is <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Ḥananya says:</b> With regard to <b>one who marries a woman to his eldest son,</b> and the wedding takes place <b>in</b> his <b>house,</b> the son has <b>acquired that</b> house.
With regard to acquisition in the presence of all three parties, the Gemara relates: <b>Rav said to Rav Aḥa Bardela: I have a <i>kav</i> of saffron [<i>morika</i>] with you</b> that you owe me; <b>give it to so-and-so.</b> Rav added: <b>I say</b> this <b>to you in his presence</b> so <b>that I will not retract</b> from this statement.
The Gemara asks: Can one learn <b>by inference that if he</b> had not stipulated in this manner and <b>wished to retract</b> his statement <b>he could</b> in fact <b>retract</b> it? This would mean that a standard acquisition in the presence of all three parties is not fully effective. The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> Rav <b>said:</b> I am saying this to you in his presence because <b>these</b> types of <b>statements</b> issued in the presence of all three parties <b>cannot be retracted,</b> i.e., Rav was not adding a condition but explaining the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why is this statement of Rav recorded at all? <b>Rav</b> already <b>said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>once. As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to one who says to another: <b>I</b> have <b>one hundred dinars in your possession, give it to so-and-so,</b> if this occurred <b>in the presence of</b> all <b>three</b> parties that third person has <b>acquired</b> it.
The Gemara explains: <b>If</b> the method of acquisition in the presence of all three parties was derived <b>from that</b> <i>halakha</i> alone, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this matter,</b> i.e., the need for the presence of the third party, applies only for the transfer of <b>a large gift. However,</b> in the case of <b>a small gift</b> one does <b>not need</b> to do this <b>in the presence</b> of the recipient. Instead, the giver can simply provide instructions and thereby transfer the gift to the other person, as there is no reason to think that he would retract. Therefore, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case, as in all cases the transfer takes effect only in the presence of all three parties.
The Gemara relates: There were <b>certain gardeners who made a calculation</b> of money owed <b>to each other,</b> and there <b>remained with one of them five <i>isterei zuzei</i></b> more than he should have received. The others <b>said to him: Give</b> the money <b>to the owner of the land,</b> and they said this <b>in the presence of the owner of the land, and</b> the owner of the land <b>acquired</b> the money <b>from him.</b> In other words, the owner of the land performed a proper act of acquisition obligating the gardener to pay that amount.
<b>Ultimately,</b> that gardener <b>went and performed a calculation on his own</b> and concluded that <b>nothing</b> extra <b>had been left</b> over <b>with him. He came before Rav Naḥman</b> to ask what to do. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: What can I do for you?</b> The <b>first</b> issue is <b>that Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that an acquisition in the presence of all three parties takes effect immediately, and therefore the owner of the land has already acquired the money. <b>And additionally, he</b> performed an actual act of acquisition and thereby <b>acquired</b> the money <b>from you.</b>
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Naḥman: <b>Is that to say</b> that the gardener <b>said: I will not give?</b> In other words, he did not refuse to give a sum in which he was obligated. <b>He</b> actually <b>said: Which is not in my possession,</b> as his colleagues told him to give five <i>isterei zuzei</i> that remained in his possession, and he now claims that this money actually belongs to him. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: If so, it is an acquisition</b> performed <b>in error, and any acquisition</b> performed <b>in error reverts</b> back to the previous owner.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the following dilemma: If someone instructs an agent: <b>Deliver one hundred dinars to so-and-so, as I owe him</b> that sum, <b>Rav says:</b> The person who sends him the money <b>bears</b> financial <b>responsibility for their</b> loss. If the one hundred dinars are lost by the agent, the sender must give another one hundred dinars to repay his debt. <b>But if</b> the sender <b>seeks to retract</b> this repayment after he has given it to the agent, <b>he cannot retract</b> it. <b>And Shmuel says: Since</b> the sender <b>bears</b> financial <b>responsibility for their</b> loss, this indicates that the one hundred dinars are considered to be in his domain, which means that <b>if he seeks to retract he can retract</b> it.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that they disagree about this</b> issue, <b>as</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that saying: <b>Deliver, is like</b> saying: <b>Acquire,</b> and therefore the agent immediately acquires the money on behalf of the recipient. For this reason the sender cannot retract. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds</b> that saying: <b>Deliver, is not like</b> saying: <b>Acquire,</b> and as the recipient has not yet acquired the money the sender can retract.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No; everyone agrees that</b> saying: <b>Deliver, is like</b> saying: <b>Acquire, and here,</b> in this case, <b>they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>since</b> the sender bears financial responsibility for the loss of the money he can retract. Therefore, he cannot retract. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do say</b> that <b>since</b> the sender bears financial responsibility for the loss of the money he can retract.
The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 1:6): If one said to another: <b>Deliver one hundred dinars to so-and-so, as I owe him</b> that sum, or if he said: <b>Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so, as I owe him</b> that sum, or if he said: <b>Deliver one hundred dinars to so-and-so,</b> as they are <b>a deposit he has in my possession,</b> or: <b>Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so,</b> as they are <b>a deposit he has in my possession,</b> in all these cases the sender <b>bears</b> financial <b>responsibility for their</b> loss, <b>but if he seeks to retract he cannot retract.</b>
The Gemara asks with regard to this <i>baraita</i>: In a case where the agent accepts upon himself to bring <b>a deposit</b> to its owners, <b>let</b> the sender, who is the bailee of the deposit, <b>say to</b> the agent: <b>It is not the will</b> of the owner of the deposit <b>that his deposit will be in the possession of another.</b> Since this transfer is not in the interests of the owner of the deposit, the money should remain fully in the possession of the sender, and therefore he should be able to retract. <b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> the sender, the bailee of the deposit, <b>is established</b> as <b>a denier</b> of financial obligations. For this reason, the owner of the deposit prefers the money to be transferred to someone else, and the sender cannot claim that it is not the will of the owner of the deposit that his deposit will be in the possession of another.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Sheshet had a credit [<i>asharta</i>] of cloaks [<i>sarbelei</i>] in</b> the city of <b>Meḥoza,</b> i.e., he had a set agreement with merchants that he would give them cloaks to sell in the city of Meḥoza and they would later reimburse him. Rav Sheshet <b>said to Rav Yosef bar Ḥama: When you come</b> here from Meḥoza, <b>bring me</b> the money. Rav Yosef <b>went</b> and <b>brought</b> the money <b>to him.</b> Those who gave him the money <b>said to him: Let us make an acquisition</b> for what you have received, so that if something happens to the money, you will be responsible. <b>He said to them: Yes.</b>
<b>Ultimately, he escaped them</b> and did not perform the act of acquisition. <b>When</b> Rav Yosef <b>came before</b> Rav Sheshet and told him what had occurred, Rav Sheshet <b>said to him: You did well, as you did not render yourself</b> the subject of the verse: <b>“The borrower is a slave to the lender”</b> (Proverbs 22:7), by obligating yourself for no reason. In <b>another version</b> of this incident Rav Sheshet said to Rav Yosef: <b>You did well,</b> as the verse states: <b>“The borrower is a slave to the lender,”</b> i.e., the merchants who borrowed from me must bear responsibility to ensure that the money will reach me.
The Gemara further relates: <b>Rabbi Aḥai, son of Rabbi Yoshiya, had a silver vessel [<i>ispeka</i>] in</b> the city of <b>Neharde’a.</b>

Daf 14b

Rabbi Aḥai <b>said to Rabbi Dostai bar Rabbi Yannai and to Rabbi Yosei bar Keifar: When you come</b> from Neharde’a <b>bring</b> the vessel <b>to me. They went</b> to Neharde’a and the people who were in possession of the vessel <b>gave it to them.</b> After handing over the vessel, those people <b>said to them: Let us perform</b> an act of <b>acquisition with you,</b> so that you will be responsible for the vessel until you reach Rabbi Aḥai. The agents <b>said to them: No;</b> we do not want to do this. <b>They said to them:</b> If so, <b>return</b> the vessel <b>to us,</b> as we do not wish to transfer it in such a manner that we retain responsibility.
<b>Rabbi Dostai, son of Rabbi Yannai, said to them: Yes,</b> I am willing to return it. However, <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Keifar said to them: No,</b> as you do not have the right to retract in this situation. <b>They tormented</b> Rabbi Yosei bar Keifar to force him to agree to return the vessel. Rabbi Yosei bar Keifar <b>said to</b> Rabbi Dostai: <b>See,</b> my <b>Master, what</b> they are <b>doing</b> to me. Rabbi Dostai <b>said to them:</b> You are acting <b>well; hit him.</b>
<b>When</b> these <b>two</b> agents <b>came before</b> Rabbi Aḥai, Rabbi Yosei bar Keifar <b>said to him: See,</b> my <b>Master, not only did</b> Rabbi Dostai <b>not support me; rather, he</b> even <b>said to them:</b> You are acting <b>well; hit him.</b> Rabbi Aḥai <b>said to</b> Rabbi Dostai: <b>Why did you do this?</b>
Rabbi Dostai <b>said to him: Those people</b> who were in possession of the vessel, <b>they are</b> the size of <b>a cubit, and their hats were a cubit, and they spoke from their midpoints, and their names were frightening: Arda and Arta and Pili Bereish.</b> If one were to <b>say to them: Restrain</b> this person, <b>they would restrain</b> him. If one were to <b>say</b> to them: <b>Kill</b> him, <b>they would kill. Had they killed Dostai,</b> i.e., me, <b>who would give Yannai,</b> my <b>father,</b> another <b>son like me?</b>
Rabbi Aḥai <b>said to him: Are these people close to the government?</b> Rabbi Dostai <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rabbi Aḥai asked him: <b>Do they have horses and mules that run after them,</b> i.e., do they have servants to perform their bidding? Rabbi Dostai <b>said to them: Yes.</b> Rabbi Aḥai <b>said to him: If so, you acted well,</b> as the situation was entirely out of your control.
§ The Gemara discusses the meaning of the expression: Deliver, in relation to a gift. With regard to one who said to his agent: <b>Deliver one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and</b> the agent <b>went and searched</b> for that person <b>but did not find him,</b> as he had died, it <b>is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: The money <b>should be returned to the sender. And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The money should be given <b>to the heirs of the one to whom it was sent.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that they disagree about this, as</b> one <b>Sage,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that in the case of a gift, saying: <b>Deliver, is like</b> saying: <b>Acquire,</b> and consequently the agent took possession of the money on behalf of the one to whom it was sent. Therefore, the heirs inherit this item. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that in the case of a gift, saying: <b>Deliver, is not like</b> saying: <b>Acquire,</b> and therefore the agent must return the money to the sender.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel said:</b> No; <b>everyone agrees</b> that in the case of a gift, saying: <b>Deliver, is not like</b> saying: <b>Acquire, and</b> the apparent contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i> is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which says that the agent must return the money to the sender, is dealing <b>with</b> a case where the giver was <b>a healthy person</b> when he issued the instructions. Such a gift is acquired by the recipient only once it reaches his possession, and this recipient died before the gift reached him. Conversely, <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which says that he should give it to the heirs of the one to whom it was sent, deals <b>with</b> the instructions of a person <b>on his deathbed.</b> Since the gift of a dying person is immediately acquired by the recipient, this recipient acquired it straightaway, and therefore it must be given to his heirs.
<b>Rav Zevid said:</b> It is possible to say that saying: Deliver, is not like saying: Acquire, and that both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are dealing <b>with</b> a case where the giver was a person <b>on his deathbed.</b> Instead, the difference between the two sources is that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that he should give it to the recipient’s heirs, is referring to a case <b>where the recipient was</b> alive <b>at the time of the giving of the money.</b> Consequently, when the sender gives the money to the agent the recipient immediately acquires it, and his heirs claim it in his stead. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which says that the agent must return the money to the sender, is referring to a case <b>where the recipient was not</b> alive <b>at the time of the giving of the money,</b> and consequently the agent could not acquire the money on his behalf.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> yet another explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are both dealing <b>with a healthy person</b> who subsequently died. The difference is that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which said that the agent must return the money to the sender, is dealing with a case <b>where the recipient died in the lifetime of the giver,</b> and as he did not acquire the money himself his heirs do not take possession of it either. By contrast, <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that the money should be given to the heirs of the recipient, is dealing with a case <b>where the giver died in the lifetime of the recipient.</b> Once he dies it is a mitzva to fulfill his wishes, and therefore the recipient, and his heirs after him, are entitled to the money.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Shall we say</b> that the issue of whether saying: <b>Deliver, is like</b> saying: <b>Acquire, is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>?</b> This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that if one person said to another: <b>Deliver one hundred dinars to so-and-so, and he went and searched for him but did not find him,</b> as he had died, the money <b>should be returned to the sender.</b> If <b>the sender died, Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Ya’akov said:</b> The money <b>should be returned to the heirs of the sender. And some say:</b> It should be given to <b>the heirs of the one to whom it was sent.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov, who said</b> this <b>in the name of Rabbi Meir: It is a mitzva to fulfill the statement of the dead.</b> Therefore the money should be given to the heirs of the one to whom it was sent. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Due to the uncertainty, <b>they should divide</b> it. <b>And here,</b> in Babylonia, <b>they said: Whatever the agent wishes to do he may do. Rabbi Shimon HaNasi said:</b> When <b>an incident</b> of this kind occurred <b>under my</b> jurisdiction I inquired into how to proceed, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>said</b> to me: The money <b>should be returned to the heirs of the sender.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that <b>they disagree about this</b> issue, <b>that the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that saying: <b>Deliver, is not like</b> saying: <b>Acquire,</b> and therefore the money should be returned to the sender? <b>And Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Ya’akov also</b> hold that saying: <b>Deliver, is not like</b> saying: <b>Acquire, but</b> they add that <b>even though</b> the sender <b>died, one does not say: It is a mitzva to fulfill the statement of the dead.</b> Consequently, the money is returned to the sender’s heirs. <b>And</b> the Sages in the clause beginning: <b>Some say,</b> claim that saying: <b>Deliver, is like</b> saying: <b>Acquire.</b> Therefore the recipient takes possession of the money immediately, and it is given to his heirs.
And <b>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi,</b> who <b>said in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov, who said</b> this <b>in the name of Rabbi Meir,</b> also holds that saying: <b>Deliver, is not like</b> saying: <b>Acquire. However,</b> in a case <b>where</b> the sender <b>died we say</b> that <b>it is a mitzva to fulfill the statement of the dead.</b> Therefore, the one hundred dinars should be given to the recipient or his heirs.
<b>And the Rabbis say: They should divide it,</b> because <b>they</b> are <b>uncertain</b> about the <i>halakha</i> in this situation. <b>And</b> the Sages in the clause beginning: <b>Here they said,</b> maintain that in this case <b>the discretion [<i>shuda</i>]</b> of the agent <b>is preferable</b> to an even division between the parties. <b>And Rabbi Shimon HaNasi</b> does not offer an opinion of his own; rather, <b>he came to teach us an incident</b> in which this case was decided in practice.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No;</b> it is possible that <b>in</b> a case where the giver was <b>a healthy person</b> when he appointed the agent <b>everyone agrees</b> that saying: Deliver, is not like saying: Acquire, <b>and with what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a person <b>on his deathbed</b> who sent these one hundred dinars, <b>and they disagree in the dispute between Rabbi Elazar and the Rabbis.</b>
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 156a): With regard to <b>one who divides his property orally, Rabbi Elazar says: Both</b> in the case of <b>a healthy person and</b> that of <b>a dangerously ill person, property that serves as a guarantee,</b> i.e., land, <b>is acquired by</b> means of <b>money, through a document, or by taking possession. And</b> property <b>that does not serve as a guarantee,</b> i.e., movable property, <b>can be acquired only through pulling. And the Rabbis say:</b> If the giver is on his deathbed, then both <b>this</b> property <b>and that</b> property <b>can be acquired through speech,</b> and there is no need for an additional act of acquisition.
<b>They said to</b> Rabbi Elazar: Didn’t <b>an incident</b> of this kind occur <b>with regard to the mother</b> of the family <b>of the sons of Rokhel, who was ill, and she said: Give</b>

Daf 15a

<b>my brooch [<i>kevinati</i>] to my daughter, and</b> the brooch is worth <b>twelve hundred dinars. And</b> this woman subsequently <b>died, and the Sages fulfilled her statement.</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>said to them</b> that <b>the sons of Rokhel should be buried by their mother,</b> i.e., he cursed them. Rabbi Elazar meant that it is not possible to bring a proof from this incident, as these sons were wicked people. Consequently, when dealing with them the Sages did not act in accordance with the <i>halakha</i>, but allowed their mother to give this valuable piece of jewelry to their sister, circumventing the <i>halakhot</i> of inheritance.
The Gemara states: <b>The first <i>tanna</i></b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who holds that there must be an actual act of acquisition or the money still belongs to the giver. <b>And Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Ya’akov also</b> hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b> However, they add that <b>even though</b> the giver <b>died one does not say: It is a mitzva to fulfill the statement of the dead. And</b> the Sages in the clause beginning: <b>Some say,</b> hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who say that the statement of a person on his deathbed effects acquisition through mere speech.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi,</b> who <b>said</b> his opinion <b>in the name of Rabbi Meir,</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar. However,</b> he maintains that <b>where</b> the giver <b>died we say: It is a mitzva to fulfill the statement of the dead. And the Rabbis say: They should divide</b> it, because <b>they</b> are <b>uncertain</b> about the <i>halakha</i> in this situation. <b>And</b> according to the Sages in the clause beginning: <b>Here they said, the discretion</b> of the agent <b>is preferable. And Rabbi Shimon HaNasi came to teach us</b> a relevant <b>incident</b> but does not express an additional opinion.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> those studying this issue: <b>Is</b> the <b>Rabbi Shimon HaNasi</b> mentioned here himself <b>a <i>Nasi</i>, or</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean <b>that he spoke in the name of the <i>Nasi</i>?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear that</b> which <b>Rav Yosef,</b> who was precise in his statements, <b>says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon HaNasi.</b> This indicates that he was an actual <i>Nasi</i>. <b>But</b> you can still <b>raise the dilemma: Is he a <i>Nasi</i>, or</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean <b>that he spoke in the name of the <i>Nasi</i>,</b> as Rav Yosef may merely be quoting the above <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara has no answer for this question, and states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Yosef says: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon HaNasi,</b> that the money should be returned to the heirs of the sender. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But don’t we maintain</b> that <b>the statement of</b> a person <b>on his deathbed is considered written and delivered?</b> If so, the agent should give the money to the heirs of the recipient.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yosef establishes</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a healthy person,</b> not someone on his deathbed. The Gemara asks: <b>But he said</b> that the money should be returned <b>to the heirs of the sender, and we maintain</b> that <b>it is a mitzva to fulfill the statement of the dead,</b> even if he issued these instructions when he was healthy. The Gemara answers: Emend Rabbi Shimon HaNasi’s statement and <b>teach: Return</b> the money <b>to the sender,</b> not to his heirs, as this is referring to a case where the sender had not died.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who brings a bill of divorce from a country overseas and says:</b> The bill of divorce <b>was written in my presence but it was not signed in my presence;</b> or if he said: <b>It was signed in my presence but it was not written in my presence;</b> or: <b>All of it was written in my presence and half of it was signed in my presence,</b> i.e., he observed the signing of only one witness; or: <b>Half of it was written in my presence and all of it was signed in my presence,</b> in all these cases the document is <b>invalid.</b>
If <b>one</b> agent bringing a bill of divorce <b>says: It was written in my presence, and one</b> other agent <b>says: It was signed in my presence,</b> it is <b>invalid.</b> If <b>two</b> agents <b>say: It was written in our presence, and one says: It was signed in my presence,</b> it is <b>invalid. And Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> the document <b>valid.</b> If <b>one</b> agent <b>says: It was written in my presence, and two</b> agents <b>say: It was signed in our presence,</b> it is <b>valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks with regard to the entire mishna: <b>Why do I</b> need all <b>these further</b> examples? <b>Didn’t it teach</b> these <i>halakhot</i> <b>once,</b> as the mishna states (2a): <b>One who brings a bill of divorce from a country overseas is required to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence?</b> This indicates that if one did not state this declaration, then the bill of divorce is invalid. The Gemara explains: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> were derived <b>from that</b> mishna alone, <b>I would say:</b> He is <b>required</b> to issue this statement <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but if he did not say</b> it the bill of divorce is nevertheless <b>valid</b> after the fact. Therefore, this mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the bill of divorce is invalid.
§ The mishna taught that if the agent said: <b>Half of it was written in my presence and all of it was signed in my presence,</b> the document is <b>invalid.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>which half</b> of the bill of divorce did he claim he saw written? <b>If we say</b> that he saw <b>its first half</b> written, <b>but didn’t Rabbi Elazar say: Even if</b> the husband or scribe <b>wrote only one line of it for her sake,</b> the agent <b>is no longer required</b> to check if the rest of the bill of divorce was written properly? <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> He testifies that he saw that <b>its latter half</b> was written, and he does not testify with regard to the first half, which is the primary section of the bill of divorce.
§ The mishna taught that if he said: <b>All of it was written in my presence and half of it was signed in my presence,</b> i.e., the agent observed the signing of only one of the witnesses, it is <b>invalid. Rav Ḥisda says: And even</b> if <b>two</b> people <b>testify to the signature</b> of the <b>second</b> witness, and the court ratifies this signature, nevertheless it is <b>invalid. What is the reason</b> for this ruling? After all, the court has the agent’s testimony with regard to one signature and the confirmation of two witnesses for the second signature.
The Gemara answers: The document must be authenticated <b>either entirely through</b> the process of <b>the ratification of a bill of divorce,</b> i.e., the bill of divorce must be ratified like any other legal document, by two people attesting to the validity of the signatures of both witnesses, <b>or it</b> must be <b>entirely</b> ratified <b>via</b> the <b>rabbinic decree</b> that the agent is deemed credible when he states: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence.
<b>Rava objects to this: Is there any</b> situation in <b>which if one</b> person <b>said</b> it, the document is <b>valid,</b> i.e., if the agent would have attested to the signature of the second witness the bill of divorce would be valid, and <b>now that there are two</b> witnesses who attest to the signatures it is <b>invalid? Rather, Rava says: Even</b> if

Daf 15b

<b>he,</b> i.e., the agent, <b>and another</b> person <b>testify with regard to the signature of the second</b> witness, the bill of divorce is <b>invalid. What is the reason</b> for this? Perhaps people <b>will come to confuse it with the typical</b> case of <b>ratification of</b> legal <b>documents,</b> and will rely on one witness who testifies about his own signature and that of the other signatory, while another witness joins with him to testify with regard to the other signature. <b>And</b> as a result of this, <b>the</b> full sum of <b>money, minus a quarter, will be extracted based upon</b> the testimony <b>of one witness.</b> In order to ratify legal documents in general, two witnesses must testify as to the validity of each of the signatures. If the Sages were to allow one witness to testify about his own signature and another witness to join him in testifying about the other signature in the case of a bill of divorce, it may lead to the same method being employed with regard to other legal documents.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this: Is there any</b> situation in <b>which if he</b> himself <b>would complete his entire statement</b> by saying: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, the document would be <b>valid,</b> and <b>now that there is</b> another <b>one</b> who testifies <b>with him,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>invalid?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says</b> that <b>even</b> if the agent <b>says: I am the second witness</b> who signed the bill of divorce, it is <b>invalid. What is the reason</b> for this? A bill of divorce cannot be validated by a combination of two types of credibility. <b>It</b> must be authenticated <b>either entirely through the ratification of the bill of divorce,</b> in the manner that other documents are ratified, <b>or it</b> must be <b>entirely</b> ratified <b>via</b> the <b>rabbinic decree,</b> in which case the testimony of the agent is considered equivalent to that of two people who ratify the signatures.
The Gemara cites a proof for this claim: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that if an agent for a bill of divorce said: <b>All of it was written in my presence</b> and <b>half of it was signed in my presence,</b> this bill of divorce is <b>invalid.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> with regard to <b>the other half of</b> the bill of divorce? <b>If we say that there is no</b> one <b>who testifies about it at all,</b> this is problematic: <b>Now</b> the mishna taught that if <b>one</b> agent <b>says: It was written in my presence, and one</b> agent <b>says: It was signed in my presence,</b> in <b>which</b> case <b>this</b> agent <b>testifies with regard to all</b> the <b>writing and that</b> agent <b>testifies with regard to all</b> the <b>signing,</b> it is <b>invalid.</b> When the agent testifies that only <b>half of it</b> was signed in his presence, <b>is it necessary</b> to say that the document is invalid?
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be teaching that the bill of divorce is invalid even if there is additional testimony with regard to the second signature. This novelty can be explained <b>either in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava,</b> who holds that the agent joins with another person to testify about the second signature, <b>or in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ashi,</b> who holds that he testifies about his own signature.
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> this is <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda,</b> who declares that the document is invalid even when there is a full ratification of the second signature. Because the mishna merely alludes to the novelty in this clause, without specifying it, one may infer only the lesser novelty. Since Rav Ḥisda’s novelty is greater than that of the other two Sages, had the mishna been taught for that purpose, it should have issued an explicit statement to that effect.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> could have <b>said to you: And according to your reasoning, why do I</b> need the ruling of the mishna which states that if the agent said: <b>It was written in my presence but it was not signed in my presence,</b> the bill of divorce is invalid? The mishna could simply have stated: If he said: All of it was written in my presence and half of it was signed in my presence, it is invalid. One would have inferred that it is invalid all the more so if one does not testify with regard to the signature at all. <b>Rather,</b> one must say that the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the mishna employing the style: <b>Not</b> only <b>this</b> but <b>also that,</b> i.e., each ensuing statement adds something novel.
If so, <b>here too</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the mishna employing the style: <b>Not</b> only <b>this</b> but <b>also that.</b> In other words, Rav Ḥisda would answer that the above inference, i.e., that the clause dealing with: It was written in my presence but it was not signed in my presence, must be teaching an additional novelty, is incorrect. This is because it is a stylistic feature of the Mishna to teach a less novel case followed by a more novel one, regardless of the fact that had it taught the more novel case first, there would have been no need to mention the less novel case at all. Therefore, there is no need to infer a special, unstated novelty from this clause at all, which means it cannot be cited as proof against Rav Ḥisda’s greater novelty.
§ Tangentially, the Gemara cites a discussion that involves a similar underlying principle. <b>Rav Ḥisda says,</b> with regard to Shabbat domains: <b>An embankment,</b> i.e., a height disparity between two surfaces, of <b>five</b> handbreadths <b>and</b> an additional <b>partition</b> of <b>five</b> handbreadths, <b>do not join</b> together to form a partition of ten handbreadths, which is the minimum height for a partition to enclose a private domain. A halakhic partition is regarded as being composed of ten handbreadths <b>only if it is</b> composed <b>entirely of a partition,</b> e.g., a fence, <b>or entirely of the embankment,</b> e.g., a pit or incline.
<b>Mareimar taught: An embankment</b> of <b>five</b> handbreadths <b>and a partition</b> of <b>five</b> handbreadths do <b>join</b> together to form a partition of ten handbreadths. The Gemara comments: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>they join</b> together. Rav Ḥisda’s opinion is analogous to the aforementioned case that a bill of divorce must be either entirely upheld by the agent or entirely upheld by the ratification of its signatures, although the <i>halakha</i> is ruled differently in the case of Shabbat domains.
The Gemara cites another case that is based on the same principle. <b>Ilfa raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to ritual washing, can one’s <b>hands</b> be <b>ritually pure in halves, or</b> can they <b>not</b> be <b>ritually pure in halves?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say that two</b> people <b>wash with</b> the requisite one <b>quarter-</b><i>log</i> of water, and therefore in actuality each one of them washes with only half of a quarter-<i>log</i>, <b>but didn’t we learn</b> explicitly in a mishna (<i>Yadayim</i> 1:1): <b>With</b> the amount of <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>one can wash the hands of one</b> person <b>and even of two?</b> A quarter-<i>log</i> of water suffices for one person to wash his hands before eating bread, and even two may wash their hands simultaneously with this amount, if they do so in the correct manner.
<b>But rather,</b> Ilfa is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>washed his</b> two <b>hands one by one,</b> not both hands at the same time. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Yadayim</i> 2:1): With regard to <b>one who</b> purifies <b>one hand by washing</b> with a vessel <b>and one</b> hand <b>by immersing</b> it in a river, <b>his hands are ritually pure?</b> This mishna indicates that there is no need for both hands to be washed simultaneously.
<b>But rather,</b> Ilfa’s dilemma refers to a case <b>where he washes his hand in two halves,</b> i.e., he first washes one half of his hand and next washes the second half of that same hand. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t</b> the Sages <b>from the school of Rabbi Yannai say: Hands cannot</b> be rendered <b>ritually pure in halves?</b> If so, one who washes half of his hand and pauses before washing the second half has not performed the act of washing the hands at all. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> Ilfa’s question is <b>necessary</b> only for a case <b>where there is liquid</b> that is still <b>moist</b> on his hand. When one washes the second half of his hand, some moisture remains on the portion of his hand that he already washed, and therefore one might think that this liquid joins with the water with which he washes the second half of his hand.
The Gemara asks: <b>And when there is liquid</b> that rendered one’s hand <b>moist, what of it?</b> Is this a relevant factor? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 8:9):

Daf 16a

<b>A stream</b> of water, <b>and</b> water descending <b>an incline [<i>katafres</i>], and liquid</b> that rendered an item <b>moist</b> do <b>not connect, neither for ritual impurity nor for purity.</b> These liquids do not connect for impurity, e.g., if impure water is in one place and becomes attached to another source of water pouring from above it, the water above is not considered attached to the impure water and is not rendered impure. They also do not connect for purity, e.g., if two collections of water are attached via the pouring of a stream, they do not join together to form the amount of water necessary to form a valid ritual bath, through which people and items can become ritually pure. If so, liquid that rendered a hand moist should not serve to attach the two halves of one’s hand when they are washed.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> this dilemma is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where there is</b> liquid that rendered an item <b>moist</b> enough <b>to render</b> another item <b>moist.</b> In other words, the half of the hand that was washed is not merely slightly moist, it is moist enough to render something else moist. The Gemara asks: <b>We</b> already <b>learned this as well:</b> With regard to liquid that rendered an item <b>moist</b> enough <b>to render</b> another item <b>moist,</b> it <b>connects</b> with other liquid. What, then, is Ilfa’s dilemma?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>halakha</i> that liquid rendered an item moist enough to render another item moist joins with other liquid is stated only <b>with regard to the issue of ritual baths, and</b> this <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 7:6): In the case of <b>a ritual bath that contains precisely forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water, <b>and two</b> people <b>descended and immersed</b> in it, if <b>both of them</b> immersed <b>at the same time they are ritually pure.</b>
If they immersed <b>sequentially,</b> then the <b>first</b> person is <b>ritually pure,</b> as he immersed in a ritual bath that contains the requisite amount of water, <b>but the second</b> person is <b>impure,</b> because some of the water must certainly have clung to the first individual as he left the ritual bath. Consequently, after the first person’s immersion the ritual bath contained slightly less than the requisite forty <i>se’a</i> of water.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If</b> the <b>first</b> person’s <b>feet were</b> still <b>touching the water</b> in the ritual bath when the second person immersed, then <b>the second</b> person is <b>also ritually pure.</b> According to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, the water left on the body of the person who has immersed connects with the water in the ritual bath to constitute the requisite amount of water. Clearly, in Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, liquid that rendered an item moist enough to render another item moist joins together with other liquid. However, this <i>halakha</i> was stated only with regard to a ritual bath. It remains unclear whether liquid that rendered an item moist enough to render another item moist joins with the water used to wash the second half of one’s hand. Perhaps this is the dilemma raised by Ilfa.
The Gemara cites another question with regard to this issue. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says: They said</b> in a mishna (<i>Zavim</i> 5:12): In the case of <b>one whose head and most of his</b> body <b>enter</b> into <b>drawn water</b> after he immersed himself in a ritual bath to purify himself, <b>and a ritually pure person</b> concerning <b>whom three <i>log</i></b> of <b>drawn water fell on his head and most of his</b> body, both of these people are <b>ritually impure.</b> With regard to this mishna, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>half of</b> a person became purified <b>by entering</b> into drawn water <b>and half of him</b> became purified <b>by</b> having water <b>fall</b> on him, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Do these acts join together to render him ritually impure or not? No answer is found, and therefore the Gemara says that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
Similarly, <b>Rav Pappa says: They said</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 3:4): In the case of <b>a sick</b> person <b>who experienced a seminal emission, who had nine <i>kav</i> of</b> drawn <b>water poured over him,</b> this is sufficient to render him <b>ritually pure.</b> He need not immerse himself in a ritual bath. <b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>half of him</b> is purified <b>by immersion and half of him through</b> this act of <b>pouring, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? No answer is found for this dilemma either, and the Gemara says that it <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna taught that if <b>one says: It was written in my presence, and one says:</b> It was signed in my presence, the bill of divorce is invalid. <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> that the document is invalid <b>only if the bill of divorce</b> was <b>not produced by both of them</b> in court. In other words, this <i>halakha</i> applies only if they were not both agents for bringing this bill of divorce. Rather, one of them alone fulfilled this role and he did not say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, in accordance with the rabbinic decree. <b>However,</b> if the <b>bill of divorce</b> was <b>produced by both of them,</b>

Daf 16b

it is <b>valid.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds</b> that <b>two</b> people <b>who brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas are not required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda: <b>If that is so,</b> if the mishna is referring specifically to a case where the document was not produced by both of them, consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches:</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>say: It was written in our presence, and one</b> person <b>says: It was signed in my presence,</b> it is <b>invalid, and Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> it <b>valid.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> this document is invalid is specifically due to the fact <b>that the bill of divorce was not produced by both of them,</b> but if the <b>bill of divorce was produced by both of them would the Rabbis deem</b> it <b>valid?</b> Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Yes,</b> the Rabbis would deem this bill of divorce valid.
