The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in a case <b>where the bill of divorce was not produced by both of them, with regard to what</b> underlying principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: One <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds:</b> The Sages <b>decree</b> that it is invalid <b>lest</b> people <b>will come to confuse</b> this case <b>with the typical</b> situation of <b>ratification of</b> legal <b>documents.</b> In other words, they will think it is possible to ratify other documents by the testimony <b>of one witness. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that the Sages <b>do not decree</b> that it is invalid for this reason.
<b>Some say another version</b> of this discussion: <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even a bill of divorce produced by both of them is invalid.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds</b> that if <b>two</b> people <b>brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas they are required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: If that is so,</b> consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches:</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>say: It was written in our presence, and one</b> person <b>says: It was signed in my presence,</b> then the document is <b>invalid. And Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> it <b>valid.</b> Is it true to say that <b>even</b> when <b>the bill of divorce was produced by both of them the Rabbis deem</b> it <b>invalid?</b> Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda <b>said to him: Yes.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: One <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that the reason for the declaration: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, is <b>because</b> the people who live overseas <b>are not experts</b> in writing a bill of divorce <b>for her sake.</b> Consequently, it is necessary for them to testify about both the writing and the signing for her sake, in accordance with the rabbinic decree, even when two people bring the bill of divorce. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that the reason for the declaration is <b>because there are no witnesses available to ratify it,</b> and when two people bring a bill of divorce there are people available to ratify it, and therefore the declaration is unnecessary.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>shall we say</b> that the disagreement <b>of Rabba and Rava</b> with regard to the two reasons for the declaration <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>?</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> as <b>Rava resolves</b> this issue and explains it <b>in accordance with the first version,</b> that the Rabbis agree that two people who bring a bill of divorce are not required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence. Consequently, it is possible that both opinions concur that an agent is required to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, so that witnesses will be available to ratify it.
<b>And Rabba</b> could have <b>said to you,</b> in accordance with the second formulation of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, i.e., two people who bring a bill of divorce are also required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence, <b>that everyone</b> agrees that <b>we require</b> them to issue the declaration because people are not experts in the <i>halakha</i> that it must be written <b>for her sake. And with what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with the period <b>after they learned</b> to write a bill of divorce for her sake even overseas.
<b>And they disagree with regard to</b> whether there is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that the bill of divorce is invalid <b>lest the matter return to its corrupt state,</b> i.e., the residents overseas will forget that a bill of divorce must be written for the woman’s sake. <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds:</b> The Sages <b>decree</b> that it is invalid for this reason, and therefore the declaration is still required even after they learned. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds:</b> The Sages <b>do not decree</b> that it is invalid lest they forget the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let Rabbi Yehuda disagree also with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna, concerning the case where one agent says: It was written in my presence, and the other agent says: It was signed in my presence. Why does he disagree only about a case where two say that the document was written in their presence? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda disagrees even with regard to the first clause, as <b>it was</b> already <b>stated with regard to</b> the mishna that <b>Ulla said: Rabbi Yehuda was in disagreement even with regard to the first clause.</b>
<b>Rav Oshaya raises an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla</b> from the following <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:2): <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> the bill of divorce <b>valid in this</b> case <b>but not in another</b> case. <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that this serves <b>to exclude</b> a case where <b>one says: It was written in my presence, and one says: It was signed in my presence?</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> this serves <b>to exclude</b> a case where only one witness testified: <b>It was signed in my presence but it was not written in my presence.</b> The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to exclude this case? It might <b>enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Yehuda did not issue</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that it is invalid <b>lest the matter return to its corrupt state, perhaps he also did not decree</b> that it is invalid lest people <b>will come to confuse</b> this case <b>with the typical</b> situation of <b>ratification of</b> legal <b>documents,</b> which cannot be performed <b>with one witness.</b> Consequently, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that although Rabbi Yehuda is not concerned about people forgetting the <i>halakha</i> and therefore holds that there is no longer any reason to be worried about the document not being written for her sake <i>ab initio</i>, nevertheless he is still concerned that a bill of divorce might be confused with other legal documents.
<b>It was also stated,</b> similar to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, but in the name of a different <i>amora</i>, that <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>two</b> people <b>who brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas, we have arrived at the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana was weak,</b> and <b>Rav Yehuda and Rabba entered to</b> visit <b>him</b> and <b>to inquire</b> about <b>his</b> well-being. While they were there, <b>they raised a dilemma before him:</b> With regard to <b>two</b> people <b>who brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas, are they required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence, or are they not required</b> to issue this declaration? <b>He said to them: They are not required</b> to say it, for the following reason: <b>What if they said: She was divorced in our presence, wouldn’t they be deemed credible?</b> Therefore, they do not have to state the declaration. <b>In the meantime,</b> while they were sitting there, <b>in came a certain</b>

Daf 17a

<b>Persian priest [<i>ḥabbara</i>]</b> and <b>took the lamp [<i>sheragga</i>] from before them.</b> It was a Persian holiday on which the Persians prohibited the public from maintaining light outside their temple. Rabba, who was from Eretz Yisrael, <b>said: Merciful One!</b> Let us live <b>either in Your shadow or in the shadow of the descendants of Esau,</b> the Romans.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that the Romans are preferable to the Persians? But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “God understands its way and He knows its place”</b> (Job 28:23)? This means that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, knows with regard to the Jewish people that they are unable to accept</b> and live under <b>Roman decrees,</b> and therefore <b>He arose and exiled them to Babylonia.</b> This indicates that living under Babylonian rule is preferable to living under Roman rule.
The Gemara explains: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> interpretation of Rabbi Ḥiyya refers to the period <b>before the Persians reached Babylonia,</b> when life there was very comfortable. <b>That</b> statement of Rabba was issued <b>after the Persians reached Babylonia,</b> when the situation changed and living there became more difficult.
§ The mishna taught that if <b>one</b> person <b>says: It was written in my presence, and two say: It was signed in our presence,</b> it is <b>valid. Rabbi Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> that the document is valid <b>only when the bill of divorce is produced by the witness</b> to the <b>writing,</b> i.e., the one who observed the writing is the agent of the bill of divorce, <b>as they become as two</b> witnesses <b>for this</b> act, the writing, <b>and two for that</b> act, the signing. The agent for the bill of divorce is considered like two witnesses when he testifies with regard to the writing. <b>However,</b> if the bill of divorce <b>was produced by</b> the <b>signatory witnesses</b> it is <b>invalid.</b> This is because only one witness, who is not an agent for the bill of divorce, testifies with regard to its writing.
The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds</b> that <b>two</b> people <b>who brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas are required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence,</b> and if they do not state this declaration the bill of divorce is invalid. <b>Rabbi Asi said to</b> Rabbi Ami: <b>If that is so,</b> how do you explain <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches:</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>say: It was written in our presence, and one says: It was signed in my presence,</b> then it is <b>invalid, and Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> it <b>valid? But</b> do <b>the Rabbis invalidate</b> the document <b>even</b> when the <b>bill of divorce is produced by both of them?</b> Rabbi Ami <b>said to him: Yes.</b>
The Gemara relates: Another <b>time</b> Rabbi Asi <b>found</b> Rabbi Ami <b>sitting and saying that even</b> if the <b>bill of divorce is produced by the signatory witnesses</b> it is <b>valid.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, in whose name Rabbi Ami stated this <i>halakha</i>, <b>holds</b> that in the case of <b>two</b> people <b>who brought a bill of divorce from a country overseas, they are not required to say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence.</b>
<b>Rabbi Asi said to him: However, if that is so,</b> how do you explain <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches:</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>say: It was written in our presence, and one says: It was signed in my presence,</b> it is <b>invalid, and Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> it <b>valid?</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>The reason</b> it is invalid is <b>that the bill of divorce is not produced by both of them,</b> from which it may be inferred that if the <b>bill of divorce is produced by both of them the Sages</b> would <b>deem</b> it <b>valid.</b>
Rabbi Ami <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rabbi Asi replied: <b>But</b> the other <b>time you did not say this to us.</b> You issued a ruling that indicated the opposite conclusion, and when I asked if that was the correct inference you affirmed that my reasoning was correct. Rabbi Ami <b>said to him:</b> What I am now telling you <b>is a spike that will not move;</b> you can rely on this ruling, and I retract my previous statement.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a bill of divorce <b>was written during the day and signed on</b> the same <b>day;</b> or if it was written <b>at night and signed on</b> that same <b>night;</b> or if it was written <b>at night and signed on</b> the following <b>day,</b> then it is <b>valid.</b> The new calendar day begins at night, so that in all of these cases the writing and the signing were performed on the same date. However, if it was written <b>during the day and signed on</b> that same <b>night,</b> it is <b>invalid,</b> as the writing and the signing were not on the same calendar day. <b>Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the bill of divorce <b>valid.</b>
The mishna explains the ruling of Rabbi Shimon: <b>As Rabbi Shimon would say: All documents that were written during the day and signed at night are invalid</b> because the date recorded in the document is a day prior to the day the document takes effect, <b>except for women’s bills of divorce.</b> Since a bill of divorce is not used to collect money, it is of no concern if the date that appears on it is before the time when it was signed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the following question: <b>For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>institute</b> the writing of <b>a date on bills of divorce?</b> Why must the date be written if this document is not intended to be used to collect money? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Due to the daughter of his sister.</b> The Sages were concerned that a man may claim that his divorce occurred earlier than it actually did. For example, if one was married to his niece, and she committed adultery, he may nevertheless desire to protect her judicial sanction and claim that they were already divorced at the time of her infidelity. In order to prevent this from happening, the Sages instituted an ordinance that bills of divorce must be dated.
<b>Reish Lakish says:</b> The ordinance was instituted <b>due to</b> the <b>produce</b> of her usufruct property. A husband owns the produce of the fields belonging to his wife up to the moment the divorce takes effect. The Sages instituted an ordinance that bills of divorce must be dated because she needs to be able to establish the time of the divorce in case the husband sold or consumed the produce of fields that belong to her after the divorce. If there is no date on the bill of divorce, he will be able to claim that the produce was sold or consumed before the divorce took place.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>Reish Lakish did not say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan?</b> The Gemara answers: Reish Lakish could have <b>said to you:</b>

Daf 17b

<b>Adultery is infrequent,</b> and the Sages would not institute the dating of a bill of divorce to avoid an infrequent problem.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan did not say in accordance with</b> the reason of <b>Reish Lakish?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>he holds the produce belongs to the husband until the time of</b> the <b>giving</b> of the bill of divorce, and only afterward does the woman have the rights to the produce of her property. If she attempts to collect the value of the produce sold after her divorce, she will be asked to prove when she received the bill of divorce. Therefore, in terms of assisting her to collect these monies, the dating of the bill of divorce does not serve any purpose.
The Gemara continues and asks: <b>Granted, according to Reish Lakish, due to that</b> reason <b>Rabbi Shimon deems valid</b> a bill of divorce that was signed on the day after it was written, because he holds that the rights to the produce of usufruct property revert to the woman the moment the bill of divorce is written. She is therefore within her rights to collect these monies from the date written in the bill of divorce, even if it was given at a later date. <b>However, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who holds that the reason for writing the date is to prevent the husband from shielding his wife from punishment for her infidelity, <b>what is the reason that Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>valid?</b> There is still a concern that he will have the bill of divorce written and dated earlier in order to protect her.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you: I am not speaking in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> as he clearly is not concerned with the husband’s shielding his wife from punishment. <b>When I speak,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that if the bill of divorce was signed on the night following its writing, it is invalid.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, this is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon and</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. However, according to Reish Lakish, what</b> difference <b>is there between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis?</b>
The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> pertains to the <b>produce</b> of the wife’s property <b>from the time of</b> the <b>writing until the time of</b> the <b>signing.</b> According to the Rabbis, the rights to the produce revert to the wife only once the bill of divorce is signed, and the bill of divorce must be dated then. According to Rabbi Shimon, the woman’s rights to the produce go into effect the moment the bill of divorce is written, and the date on which it was signed is irrelevant.
The Gemara challenges the explanation as to why Rabbi Yoḥanan does not agree with Reish Lakish: <b>But didn’t we hear</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish <b>say the opposite</b> of this? <b>As it is stated</b> that they had a dispute with regard to the question: <b>From when does</b> the court <b>remove</b> the property from the possession of the husband, i.e., when does he lose his right <b>to</b> the <b>produce? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From the time of</b> the <b>writing</b> of the bill of divorce, <b>and Reish Lakish said: From the time of</b> the <b>giving</b> of the bill of divorce. This does not accord with what was stated above, that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that the husband retains the rights to the produce until the bill of divorce is given and Reish Lakish holds that the wife regains the rights beforehand. Here, their opinions are the opposite of the way the Gemara explained earlier.
The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the opinions in this final dispute so that it is Reish Lakish who holds that the rights to the produce revert to the woman at the time of writing and it is Rabbi Yoḥanan who holds that it is at the time of giving the divorce.
§ The Gemara records a series of questions with regard to the parameters of the ordinance that bills of divorce should be dated. <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef:</b> It was taught in a mishna (86a): <b>Three bills of divorce are invalid, but if</b> a woman <b>married</b> after she received one of these bills of divorce then <b>the offspring is</b> of <b>unflawed</b> lineage, meaning that the husband and wife are divorced after the fact. One of the three bills of divorce listed is a bill of divorce that does not have a date. Abaye asks: Being that the divorce does take effect, <b>what did the Sages accomplish with their ordinance</b> requiring that the date appear on a bill of divorce? Either way the bill of divorce is valid after the fact without a date. The Gemara answers: <b>It is effective</b> in <b>that she may not marry <i>ab initio</i></b> as a result of receiving this bill of divorce, which consequently limits the usage of such a bill of divorce.
Abaye continued to ask of Rav Yosef: If the husband <b>cut out its date</b> after the dated bill of divorce was written <b>and gave it to her, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? May the bill of divorce be used <i>ab initio</i>? <b>He said to him: We are not concerned about a deceiver.</b> The ordinance requiring that the bill of divorce be dated does not apply in this case, as it was dated when it was written.
Abaye continued and asked: If the date <b>written in</b> the bill of divorce made reference only to the <b>seven-</b>year Sabbatical cycle in which it was written, or only to the <b>year,</b> or only to the <b>month,</b> or only to the <b>week,</b> but the precise date was not recorded, then <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? May such a bill of divorce be used <i>ab initio</i>? <b>He said to him:</b> It is <b>valid</b> to be used <i>ab initio</i>. Abaye asked him: If so, <b>what did the Sages accomplish with their ordinance</b> requiring the dating of the bill of divorce? Regardless of the reason for recording the date, such vague dating will not ameliorate the problem.
Rav Yosef answered: <b>It helps for the seven-year period before it and the seven-year period after it.</b> If witnesses testify that the woman committed adultery before this seven-year period, then she is liable; if the husband sells produce after this seven-year period, then the woman can recover it. The reason for this is <b>because if you do not say so,</b> i.e., that a limited benefit is enough to justify the ordinance, then on that <b>day itself, do we know if</b> it was written <b>in the morning or in the evening?</b> All of the issues that were mentioned before could apply also to that day itself. <b>Rather,</b> the date is effective <b>for the day before it and the day after it. Here also,</b> writing the seven-year period <b>is effective for the seven-year period before it and the seven-year period after it.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Rava:</b> If <b>he writes</b> the bill of divorce,

Daf 18a

<b>and puts it in his pocket</b> without giving it to her, as he thought <b>that if she appeases [<i>mippayyesa</i>]</b> him <b>he will be appeased, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> when he then does give it to her? Since the date on the document is incorrect, did the Sages institute an ordinance that such a bill of divorce should not be used?
Rava <b>said to him: A person does not hasten a calamity on himself</b> and will not ordinarily prepare a bill of divorce in advance. Rather, he will wait until he is ready to divorce his wife. Since this scenario is unlikely, the Sages did not see a need to institute an ordinance pertaining to it.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> When there are <b>bills of divorce that come from a country overseas which are written,</b> for example, <b>in</b> the month of <b>Nisan, and they do not reach</b> the woman <b>until</b> the month of <b>Tishrei, what did the Sages accomplish with their ordinance</b> to date the bill of divorce? All of the concerns about an undated bill of divorce still apply. <b>He said to him:</b> Concerning <b>these</b> bills of divorce from overseas, it is <b>public knowledge</b> that they do not take effect from the date on which they were written. Therefore, if there is a conflict over produce the husband has sold, the woman must bring witnesses to testify as to when she received her bill of divorce.
§ The Sages decreed that it is prohibited for a woman to remarry within three months of her divorce or her becoming a widow, in order to prevent a situation of doubt concerning the paternity of a child. <b>It was stated: From when</b> does one begin <b>counting</b> the three months <b>with regard to a bill of divorce? Rav says: From the time of</b> the <b>giving</b> of the bill of divorce, <b>and Shmuel says: From the time of</b> the <b>writing</b> of the bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Natan bar Hoshaya objects to this: According to</b> the statement of <b>Shmuel,</b> now people <b>will say:</b> If <b>two women</b> who live <b>in one courtyard</b> received their bills of divorce at the same time, but the first document was written at the time of the divorce and the second one was written earlier, then <b>this</b> woman <b>is</b> still <b>prohibited</b> from remarrying, as three months have not yet passed from when her bill of divorce was written; <b>and that</b> woman is already <b>permitted</b> to remarry. This does not seem reasonable. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> This is not difficult. With regard to <b>this</b> woman, <b>the date of her bill of divorce proves concerning her</b> that she may not remarry yet; <b>and</b> with regard to <b>that</b> woman, <b>the date on her bill of divorce proves concerning her</b> that she may remarry already.
The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav,</b> and it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel.</b> The Gemara explains: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav</b> that the three-month count begins from when the bill of divorce is given: In the case of <b>one who sends a bill of divorce to his wife, and the agent tarries on the way for three months, once the bill of divorce reaches her hand she must wait three months</b> before remarrying. <b>And one need not be concerned that</b> it is <b>an outdated bill of divorce,</b> i.e., that the husband and wife were secluded after it was written, rendering the bill of divorce invalid, <b>because he was not secluded with her</b> during the time the bill of divorce was being delivered.
It <b>is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel</b> that the count begins from the time of the writing: In the case of <b>one who</b> is about to travel and <b>deposits a bill of divorce for his wife</b> with a trustee <b>and says to him: Give it to her only after three months, once he gives it to her, she is permitted to marry immediately</b> and is not required to wait an additional three months. <b>And one need not</b> be <b>concerned that</b> it is <b>an outdated bill of divorce, as he was not secluded with her</b> in the interim.
It is told that <b>Rav Kahana and Rav Pappi and Rav Ashi would in practice</b> count three months <b>from the time of</b> the <b>writing,</b> but <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, would in practice</b> count these three months <b>from the time of</b> the <b>giving. And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that the counting begins <b>from the time of</b> the <b>writing.</b>
§ The Gemara discusses another dispute between Rav and Shmuel with regard to documents. According to the terms of a marriage contract, a widow is entitled to payment of its value upon the death of her husband. By Torah law, all outstanding debts are canceled at the close of the Sabbatical Year. A woman need not take her marriage settlement as soon as her husband dies. The issue at hand is at what point the marriage contract generates a concrete debt that will be canceled by the Sabbatical Year. <b>It was stated: From when</b> is the debt established by <b>a marriage contract canceled</b> in the Sabbatical Year?
<b>Rav says:</b> The marriage contract becomes like a debt and will be canceled in the Sabbatical Year <b>from</b> the time <b>when</b> the woman <b>collects partial payment and establishes</b> the rest as a debt in court. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> This occurs when <b>she</b> either <b>collects partial payment although she did not establish</b> it as debt, or <b>she established</b> the entire value of the marriage contract as a debt in court <b>although she did not collect partial payment.</b>
With regard to this dispute, it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav,</b> and it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel.</b> It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav: From when is</b> the debt established by <b>a marriage contract canceled? From when she accepts partial payment and establishes</b> the rest as a debt in court. However, if <b>she accepted partial payment but did not establish</b> the debt, or <b>established</b> the debt <b>but did not accept partial payment,</b> then <b>it is not canceled until she accepts partial payment and establishes</b> the debt.
It <b>is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel:</b> If the fine and damages paid by one who commits <b>rape; or</b> the <b>fine</b> paid by one who falsely claims his wife was not a virgin at the time of their wedding; <b>or</b> the fine paid for <b>seduction; or</b> the debt established by <b>a woman’s marriage contract was established as a loan,</b> then the Sabbatical Year <b>cancels it. And if</b> one did <b>not</b> establish these payments as loans, then the Sabbatical Year <b>does not cancel them. From when</b> is it considered that these payments <b>have been established as a loan? From the time of standing trial,</b> because the abstract obligation to pay becomes a debt once the court ruled that one is required to pay.
§ The Gemara discusses other aspects of the marriage contract. <b>Shmuel said: A marriage contract is</b> considered to be <b>like a court enactment. Just as court enactments may be written during the day and</b> then <b>signed at night,</b> and the fact that the writing and signing were not performed on the same day does not present a problem, <b>so too, a marriage contract may be written during the day and</b> then <b>signed at night.</b> It is told: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Rav’s marriage contract was written during the day and</b> then <b>signed at night,</b> and <b>Rav was there and he did not say anything to</b> the people who wrote and signed it. This indicates that Rav agrees with the ruling of Shmuel.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel?</b> The Gemara rejects this: This cannot be proven from here because the scribe and witnesses <b>were</b> continuously <b>engaged in that matter</b> of writing the marriage contract, from when it was written in the day until they signed it at night, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Tzadok said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that a document written during the day and signed at night is invalid <b>only when</b> the scribe and witnesses <b>were not</b> continuously <b>engaged in that matter, but</b> if they <b>were</b> continuously <b>engaged in that matter</b> until nightfall, then it is <b>valid.</b>
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabbi Shimon deems valid</b> a bill of divorce written during the day and signed at night. <b>Rava said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon?</b> He <b>holds</b> that <b>once</b> the husband <b>has decided to divorce her, he no longer has</b> the rights to <b>the produce</b> from his wife’s property, and it is clear that he has decided to divorce her when he writes a bill of divorce. Consequently, the woman obtains the rights to the produce from the moment the bill of divorce was written, regardless of when it was signed.
<b>Reish Lakish says: Rabbi Shimon deems</b> such a bill of divorce <b>valid only</b> if it is signed <b>immediately,</b> when the witnesses signed the bill of divorce during the night after it was written. <b>However,</b> if the delay in signing was <b>from now,</b> i.e., when the bill of divorce was written, <b>until ten days</b> have elapsed, i.e., when there is an extended delay, he does <b>not</b> deem it valid.

Daf 18b

Why not? Because <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he appeased</b> his wife and engaged in sexual intercourse with her, thereby invalidating the bill of divorce. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even</b> if the delay in signing was <b>from now until ten days</b> later Rabbi Shimon deems it valid. There is no concern that he appeased her because <b>if it is so</b> that <b>he appeased</b> her, then <b>the matter</b> becomes <b>public knowledge,</b> and all would hear of it.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish disagreed with regard to the following case: If the husband <b>says to ten</b> men: <b>Write a bill of divorce for my wife, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He means that all of them should sign the bill of divorce. <b>Two</b> of them function <b>as witnesses, and all</b> the rest <b>of them</b> sign the bill of divorce only <b>due to</b> the <b>stipulation</b> that the husband had stated. He made the bill of divorce dependent upon all of them signing, but he did not mean that ten men need to actually function as witnesses. <b>And Reish Lakish says: All of them</b> function <b>as witnesses.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in which all of them have to sign? <b>If we say</b> that <b>he did not say to them: All of you,</b> but just said to them: You should write a bill of divorce for my wife, <b>didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (66b) that if <b>one said to ten</b> people: <b>Write a bill of divorce for my wife,</b> then <b>one</b> would <b>write, and two</b> would <b>sign,</b> and not all ten of them are required to sign. <b>Rather,</b> the case of their dispute is <b>when he said to them: All of you</b> write a bill of divorce for my wife, and in this instance is was taught later on in that mishna that one person writes the bill of divorce and everyone else must sign it.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish; what is the difference if the rest of the men function as witnesses or just in order to fulfill the man’s stipulation? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> in a case <b>where two of them signed on that day and the rest</b> signed not on the day it was written but <b>from now until ten days</b> later. According to <b>the one who says</b> that the other signatures are <b>due to the stipulation,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>valid,</b> because two witnesses signed the bill of divorce on the same day that it was written, and the stipulation was also fulfilled. <b>And</b> according to <b>the one who says</b> that all these people sign <b>due to</b> his wish that they all function as <b>witnesses,</b> it is <b>invalid</b> because not all the witnesses signed the bill of divorce on the day it was written.
<b>Alternatively,</b> there is another difference between them, in a case <b>where one of these</b> ten people <b>is found</b> to be <b>a relative</b> of the husband or wife, <b>or</b> is otherwise found to be <b>disqualified</b> to serve as a witness. <b>According to the one who says</b> that the other signatures are <b>due to the stipulation,</b> this bill of divorce is <b>valid</b> because the disqualified person did not serve as a witness. He just signed the bill of divorce in order to fulfill the stipulation, and the bill of divorce has the signature of two qualified witnesses. <b>According to the one who says</b> that all these people sign <b>due to</b> the man’s wish that they all function as <b>witnesses,</b> the bill of divorce would be <b>invalid,</b> as is the case whenever one member of a group of witnesses is disqualified.
The Gemara adds another point of dispute: According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who holds that the other witnesses sign due to the husband’s stipulation, <b>if a relative or</b> other <b>disqualified</b> witness <b>signed at the beginning,</b> before two valid witnesses had signed, then <b>some say</b> the bill of divorce is <b>valid and some say</b> that it is <b>invalid. Some say</b> that it is <b>valid</b> because the request for ten signatures <b>is a stipulation.</b> Since these ten people are not meant to serve as witnesses and are meant only to fulfill the stipulation, it makes no difference if they signed at the beginning or at the end. <b>Some say</b> that it is <b>invalid</b> because there is a concern that the courts <b>will come to confuse it with typical documents,</b> and they will rely on disqualified witnesses in those cases.
It is told: There was <b>a certain person who said to ten</b> men: <b>Write a bill of divorce for my wife. Two of them signed that day and the others</b> signed after a delay <b>from now until ten days</b> later. <b>He came before Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> to ask what the <i>halakha</i> is with regard to such a bill of divorce. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him:</b>

Daf 19a

<b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who permitted using a bill of divorce that was written during the day and signed at night, <b>is worthy of being relied upon in exigent circumstances.</b> Therefore, once such a bill of divorce has been written and given, the woman is divorced.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But didn’t Reish Lakish say: Rabbi Shimon deemed</b> such a bill of divorce <b>valid only</b> if it was signed <b>immediately, but</b> after a delay <b>from now until ten days, no.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to that</b> question, whether the others must sign immediately, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who holds that they may sign after a delay.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Two</b> of them function <b>as witnesses, and all</b> the rest <b>of them</b> sign the bill of divorce only <b>due to</b> the <b>stipulation?</b> It is clear that Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi does not hold in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi is concerned about the other witnesses and deems the bill of divorce valid only due to exigent circumstances. The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to this,</b> i.e., why the additional people must sign, <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> that all of them function as witnesses.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may write</b> a bill of divorce <b>with any</b> material that can be used for writing: <b>With <i>deyo</i>, with paint [<i>sam</i>], with <i>sikra</i>, with <i>komos</i>, with <i>kankantom</i> or with anything that</b> produces <b>permanent</b> writing. However, <b>one may not write with</b> other <b>liquids, nor with fruit juice, nor with anything</b> that does <b>not</b> produce <b>permanent</b> writing.
Similarly, with regard to the document itself, <b>one may write on anything,</b> even <b>on an olive leaf, or on the horn of a cow. And</b> the latter is valid if <b>he gives her the</b> entire <b>cow.</b> Likewise, one may write a bill of divorce <b>on the hand of a slave, and</b> that is valid if <b>he gives her the slave. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> disagrees and <b>says: One may not write</b> a bill of divorce <b>on any living thing, nor</b> may it be written <b>on food.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara begins by explaining the terms used in the mishna: <b><i>Deyo</i></b> refers to what is called <b><i>deyota</i>,</b> ink, in Aramaic. <b><i>Sam</i></b> refers to <b><i>samma</i>,</b> arsenic. With regard to <b><i>sikra</i>, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: Its name</b> in Aramaic is <b><i>sikreta</i>,</b> red dye, derived from minium, which is also known as red lead. <b><i>Komos</i>,</b> tree resin, is known as <b><i>kuma</i></b> in Aramaic. With regard to <b><i>kankantom</i>, Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This is the <b>black</b> substance <b>used by cobblers,</b> iron sulfate.
The mishna taught that one is allowed to write a bill of divorce <b>with anything</b> that produces <b>permanent</b> writing. The Gemara asks: This statement is meant <b>to add what?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>To add what Rabbi Ḥanina taught:</b> If <b>he wrote it with <i>mei teriya</i> or</b> water in which <b>gallnuts [<i>aftza</i>]</b> were soaked, then it is <b>valid,</b> as the writing is permanent. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> If <b>he wrote it with lead, with coals, or with black paint</b> then it is <b>valid.</b>
§ <b>It was stated</b> that there was a related discussion about different types of writing: In the case of <b>one who passes ink over</b> letters written in <b>red dye on Shabbat, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both say</b> that he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings for this: <b>One due to</b> violating the prohibition against <b>writing</b> on Shabbat, because he is now writing letters in ink, <b>and one due to</b> violating the prohibition against <b>erasing</b> on Shabbat, because as he writes he erases what is written in red dye. They also agree in the case of <b>ink</b> written <b>on top of ink,</b> or <b>red dye on top of red dye,</b> that according to everyone he is <b>exempt,</b> because he changed nothing with his writing. However, if he wrote with <b>red dye on top of ink,</b> then <b>some say</b> that he is <b>liable and some say</b> that he is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara explains these opinions: <b>Some say</b> that he is <b>liable</b> because <b>it is erasing,</b> as he erases the higher-quality, original writing. <b>Some say</b> that he is <b>exempt</b> because <b>he is destroying</b> and one who acts destructively is exempt, as he has not performed planned, constructive labor on Shabbat.
This dispute pertains to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat. With regard to the signing of documents, <b>Reish Lakish raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If there are <b>witnesses who do not know how to sign</b> their names, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>: May their names <b>be written for them with red dye,</b> and afterward they <b>will sign</b> on top of it in ink? The question is: Is <b>the upper writing,</b> which was not directly on the document but on top of other ink, considered to be <b>writing, or is it not writing? He said to him: It is not writing.</b> Consequently, this may not be done for witnesses who do not know how to sign.
Reish Lakish <b>said to him: Didn’t our master,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>teach us</b> that the <b>upper writing</b> is considered to be <b>writing with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat?</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: And because we compare</b> the <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to bills of divorce to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, <b>shall we perform an action</b> and teach that a bill of divorce may be written in this manner?
§ <b>It was stated</b> that there was a dispute with regard to the following question: What should be done for <b>witnesses who do not know</b> how <b>to sign? Rav says: One tears blank paper for them,</b> meaning that a stencil of their names is fashioned from blank paper and placed on the bill of divorce. The witnesses then <b>fill in the gaps</b> with <b>ink</b> so that their names appear on the document. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> One first writes their names on the document <b>with lead,</b> and the witnesses write over those letters.
The Gemara asks: Would it <b>enter your mind</b> to say that they actually write for them <b>with lead? But didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach:</b> If <b>he wrote it with lead, with coals, or</b> with <b>black paint,</b> then it is <b>valid?</b> It can be seen from this <i>baraita</i> that writing with lead is considered to be a valid form of writing, and, as Rabbi Yoḥanan taught, if one writes on top of other writing then the second writing is not accepted for the signing of documents. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult: This,</b> that Shmuel allowed the witnesses to sign on top of lead writing, applies only when the first writing was done <b>with lead</b> itself, which is not considered to be writing on its own. <b>That,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya’s statement that it is valid for writing a bill of divorce, applies only when the first writing was done <b>using lead water,</b> i.e., water colored black with lead.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> A solution would be to write the names for these witnesses <b>with gall water</b> [<b><i>mei milin</i></b>] and have them trace their names with ink. The Gemara challenges: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Ḥanina teach</b> that if <b>he wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>with <i>mei teriya</i> or</b> water in which <b>gallnuts</b> were soaked it is <b>valid?</b> As this is so, any additional writing over the writing in gall water should not be accepted as a valid signature.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> suggestion of Rabbi Abbahu, that the document be prepared with the names of the witnesses written with gall water, refers to a case where the parchment was processed <b>with gallnuts. That</b> statement of Rabbi Ḥanina, that gall water may be used on its own to write a bill of divorce, refers to a case where the parchment was <b>not</b> processed <b>with gallnuts.</b> The reason for the difference is <b>because gall water is not</b> permanent when applied <b>on top of gall water,</b> i.e., on parchment that was processed with gallnuts. Therefore, if the parchment was processed using gallnuts, the writing of the names of the witnesses, done with gall water, will not be permanent, and the witnesses may sign their names on top of that writing. When the <i>baraita</i> states that witnesses may sign their names with gall water, it is referring to a case where the parchment was not processed with gallnuts, so the gall water signature will be permanent.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> A solution would be to write the names for these witnesses <b>with saliva</b> and have them trace their names with ink. <b>And so Rav Pappa instructed Pappa the ox herder,</b> who did not know how to sign his name, that the court should write his name <b>with saliva</b> and he should trace it with ink. The Gemara comments: <b>This matter,</b> the leniency to have the witnesses trace their names, applies only <b>to bills of divorce,</b> as there is a concern that witnesses will not be found, and the woman will be unable to remarry. <b>However, for</b> financial <b>documents,</b> the Sages did <b>not</b> allow this, and one must instead find witnesses who know how to sign their names.
It is told <b>that</b> there was <b>a certain person who performed an action</b> and allowed witnesses to trace their names <b>in</b> a case of <b>other documents,</b> which were not bills of divorce, and <b>Rav Kahana</b> ordered that <b>he be flogged</b> for doing so.

Daf 19b

It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav:</b> In the case of <b>witnesses who do not know</b> how <b>to sign, one tears a blank</b> piece of <b>paper for them,</b> and they <b>fill</b> in <b>the gaps</b> with <b>ink.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? For bills of divorce. However, for</b> bills <b>of manumission and</b> for <b>all other documents, if</b> the witnesses <b>know</b> how <b>to read and</b> how <b>to sign,</b> then <b>they sign, and if</b> they do <b>not</b> know how to read and sign <b>they do not sign.</b>
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>reading, who mentioned anything about it?</b> Why does Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel mention the need for witnesses to be able to read when the discussion is about a witness who does not know how to sign? The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete, and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> In the case of <b>witnesses who do not know</b> how <b>to read, one reads</b> the document <b>in their presence and they sign. And</b> in the case <b>where they do not know</b> how <b>to sign,</b> then one tears paper in the form of a stencil and they fill in the gaps with ink. With regard to this, <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? For bills of divorce. However, for</b> bills <b>of manumission and</b> for <b>all other documents, if</b> the witnesses <b>know</b> how <b>to read and</b> how <b>to sign,</b> then <b>they sign, and if not they do not sign.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar says: What is the reason of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> who permitted this only for bills of divorce? He holds that there is reason to be lenient with bills of divorce, <b>so that the daughters of Israel should not be deserted.</b> Requiring literate witnesses for bills of divorce could lead to a scenario in which a husband wishes to travel and wants to give his wife a bill of divorce in case he shall not return, but if he does not find literate witnesses he may leave without divorcing her, leaving her unable to remarry.
<b>Rava says: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. And Rav Gamda said in the name of Rava: The <i>halakha</i> is not</b> in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is the <i>halakha</i>? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and it is permitted to do this for any document?
<b>But wasn’t</b> there <b>a certain person who performed an action,</b> and allowed witnesses to trace their names <b>in</b> a case of <b>other documents</b> that were not bills of divorce, and <b>Rav Kahana</b> ordered that <b>he be flogged</b> for doing so? The Gemara answers: Rav Gamda <b>interpreted</b> the statement of Rava only <b>with regard to reading,</b> meaning that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the Rabbis and not Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel only with regard to the question of whether other documents may be read to the witnesses, but not with regard to whether they may sign other documents by means of a stencil.
It is told that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> was nearly blind in his old age. He could barely read and he <b>took great pains</b> to <b>read and sign</b> documents as a witness or a judge. <b>Ulla said to him: It is not necessary for you</b> to do this, <b>as</b> the court scribes <b>would read in the presence of Rabbi Elazar the master,</b> i.e., the halakhic authority <b>of Eretz Yisrael, and he would sign; and the court scribes would read</b> documents <b>before Rav Naḥman and he would sign;</b> and you may do the same. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> this was done <b>specifically</b> in a case like that of <b>Rav Naḥman and the court scribes, as they had fear</b> of him because he was a great man and a judge to whom they were subservient. Therefore, there was no concern that they would not read it correctly. <b>However,</b> for <b>Rav Naḥman and other scribes,</b> or <b>the court scribes and another person, no;</b> the document may not be read to the witness, as the scribes may read it incorrectly to him.
The Gemara recounts the behavior of another <i>amora</i> who had documents read to him: <b>When documents</b> that were written in <b>Persian</b> and <b>that were produced in gentile courts came before Rav Pappa,</b> who did not know how to read Persian, he would <b>have it be read by two gentiles, each one not in the presence of the other</b> and in a way that each one would <b>speak offhandedly,</b> without knowing that they were giving testimony. Once he clarified what was written in the document <b>he would collect</b> payment <b>with it</b> even <b>from liened</b> property that had been sold, as he held that such a document is entirely valid with regard to monetary law.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav Huna bar Natan said to me</b> that <b>so said Ameimar:</b> With regard to <b>this Persian document, on which Jews are signed as witnesses,</b> the court is able to <b>collect</b> payment <b>with it,</b> even <b>from liened</b> property that had been sold.
The Gemara asks: <b>But they don’t know how to read,</b> as most Jews did not read Persian. The Gemara answers: Ameimar’s statement applies <b>when they know</b> how to read Persian. The Gemara questions how the court can rely upon such a document: <b>But don’t we require</b> all legal documents to be written in <b>a writing that cannot be forged; and it is not</b> so in documents produced by Persians, as the Persians were not particular about this when writing their legal documents. The Gemara answers: His statement applies <b>in</b> a case where the paper of the documents was processed <b>with gall.</b> Consequently, it is not possible to forge the writing. <b>But we require</b> a document <b>to recap the</b> essential <b>topic of the document in its last line; and it is not</b> so in the case of Persian documents. The Gemara answers: Ameimar’s statement applies <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> the document <b>recapped</b> the essential topic of the document in the final line.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if Ameimar’s statement applies only when all these conditions are met, then <b>what is he teaching us, that</b> a document that is properly written in <b>any language</b> is <b>valid? We</b> already <b>learned</b> in a mishna (87b): In the case of <b>a bill of divorce that he wrote</b> in <b>Hebrew and its witnesses</b> signed in <b>Greek,</b> or one that he wrote in <b>Greek and its witnesses</b> signed in <b>Hebrew,</b> it is <b>valid.</b> If this is written in the mishna, Ameimar’s statement would not simply repeat it.
The Gemara answers: This cannot serve as a clear proof, because <b>if</b> the only source for this <i>halakha</i> were <b>from that</b> mishna then <b>I would say: This statement</b> applies only <b>for bills of divorce,</b> where the Sages were lenient so that a woman would not be unable to remarry. <b>However, for other documents, no.</b> Consequently, Ameimar <b>teaches us</b> that other types of documents are valid if they are written in other languages as well.
§ <b>Shmuel says:</b> If a man <b>gave</b> his wife <b>a blank</b> piece of <b>paper and said to her: This is hereby your bill of divorce,</b> then <b>she is divorced.</b> Why? <b>We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he wrote it with gall water,</b> rendering it a valid bill of divorce, and the writing was subsequently absorbed into the paper so that it was no longer visible.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 8:2): If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is hereby your bill of divorce, and</b> instead of opening it and looking at it <b>she took it and threw it into the sea, or into a fire, or into anything that destroys</b> it; <b>and he later said:</b> It wasn’t actually a bill of divorce, rather <b>it is a document of appeasement</b> [<b><i>shetar passim</i></b>], a symbolic promissory note meant only for display so that the person holding it will be considered to be wealthy; or he said: <b>It is a document of trust,</b> which is a false promissory note given by one person to another, trusting that he will not make use of it until there has been an actual loan; then <b>she is divorced. And he does not have</b> the power <b>to make her forbidden</b> to everyone else as a married woman by saying that it was not a bill of divorce and they are still married.
The Gemara makes an inference from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The reason</b> she is divorced is because this bill of divorce <b>has writing,</b> and there is no way to ascertain what was written, <b>but</b> if it did <b>not</b> have <b>writing,</b> then <b>no,</b> there is no concern that perhaps it was a valid bill of divorce written with gall water. This runs counter to the statement of Shmuel. The Gemara answers: <b>When Shmuel said</b> that the woman was divorced with a blank piece of paper, it was in a case <b>where we check</b> the paper <b>with a colored liquid</b> [<b><i>maya denara</i></b>]. <b>If</b> the paper <b>expels</b> the writing, then <b>it expels</b> it and it is a valid bill of divorce. <b>And if it does not expel</b> it, then the document <b>is nothing</b> and she is not divorced.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if</b> the paper <b>expels</b> the writing, <b>what of it?</b> It is possible <b>that</b> only <b>now it expels</b> the writing and the letters become visible, but from the beginning there was no legible writing and therefore the document should be considered invalid. The Gemara answers that <b>even Shmuel said</b> only: <b>We are concerned,</b> and he does not hold that it is a valid bill of divorce. Rather, the court takes into account the possibility that what he gave her in the beginning was a valid bill of divorce, and the <i>halakha</i> is that it is uncertain if she is divorced.
<b>Ravina said: Ameimar said to me</b> that <b>so said Mareimar in the name of Rav Dimi: These two</b> witnesses who testify <b>that the bill of divorce was given in their presence are required to read it.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If a man says to a woman: <b>This is hereby your bill of divorce, and</b> instead of opening it and looking at it <b>she took it and threw it into the sea, or into a fire, or into anything that destroys</b> it, <b>and he later said:</b> It wasn’t actually a bill of divorce, but rather, <b>it is a document of appeasement,</b> or <b>it is a document of trust;</b> then <b>she is divorced, and he does not have</b> the power <b>to make her forbidden</b> to everyone else as a married woman by saying that it was not a bill of divorce and they are still married. <b>And if you say</b> that the witnesses <b>need to read</b> the bill of divorce, then <b>is</b> the husband <b>able to say this to her after they read it?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for Rav Dimi to teach his <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where after they read it,</b> the husband <b>placed it under his arm,</b> and later <b>took it out,</b> and gave it to the woman without it being read again. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>he switched it</b> with another document, and what he gave her was not a bill of divorce but a document of appeasement or trust as he claims, Rav Dimi <b>teaches us</b> that the court need not be concerned that he switched it.
The Gemara tells: There was <b>a certain man who threw</b> what he claimed was <b>a bill of divorce to his wife,</b> into her courtyard, <b>among the barrels,</b> and in the end <b>a <i>mezuza</i> was found</b> there. The question is: Is there a concern that he threw her a bill of divorce, and the bill of divorce was destroyed, and the <i>mezuza</i> happened to be in the same location? Or perhaps he threw her the <i>mezuza</i> and only claimed that it was a bill of divorce. <b>Rav Naḥman said: A <i>mezuza</i> is infrequently</b> placed <b>among the barrels,</b> and it can be assumed that he threw the <i>mezuza</i> and not a bill of divorce.
The Gemara comments: <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>when one</b> <i>mezuza</i> <b>was found. However,</b> if <b>two</b> or <b>three</b> <i>mezuzot</i> were found, then the assumption is that <b>as this,</b> the other <i>mezuza</i>, <b>was</b> there, <b>this</b> <i>mezuza</i> <b>was also</b> there before the husband came, <b>and</b> as to <b>the bill of divorce, say</b> that the <b>mice</b> later <b>took it,</b> and the woman was already divorced from the moment it reached her courtyard.
It is told: There was <b>a certain man who entered the synagogue, took a Torah scroll,</b> and <b>gave it to his wife. And he said to her: This is your bill of divorce. Rav Yosef said: For what</b> is there <b>to be concerned for it? If</b> you say that there should be a concern <b>due to gall water,</b> that perhaps he wrote a bill of divorce on the outside of the Torah scroll’s parchment with gall water, and this writing is now invisible, <b>gall water is not</b> permanent when applied <b>on top of gall water.</b> Since parchment for the Torah scroll is processed with gall water, it is not possible to write something with gall water that will remain permanently on the parchment itself. Therefore, there is no concern that he wrote a bill of divorce on the parchment.

Daf 20a

<b>If</b> there is a concern that the Torah scroll can effect a divorce <b>due to</b> the verses concerning <b>severance</b> of marriage <b>that there are in</b> it, as it is written: “And he writes her a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1), this is also not problematic, since <b>it is required,</b> as it states: <b>“And he writes her.”</b> This indicates that the bill of divorce must be written <b>for her sake,</b> i.e., it must be written for the express intent of being used to effect divorce between this specific man and this specific woman, <b>and</b> this is <b>not</b> so in the case of a Torah scroll.
<b>And if you would say</b> that there is reason <b>to be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he first gave a dinar to the scribe at the outset,</b> when he wrote the Torah scroll, and told him to write the verses discussing divorce for his wife’s sake, <b>isn’t there a need</b> for other things to be written in a bill of divorce as well, as the mishna (80a) teaches: If the scribe <b>changed his name or her name, the name of his city or the name of her city,</b> then the bill of divorce is invalid. The validity of a bill of divorce depends upon these details being written, <b>and</b> they are <b>not</b> in the Torah scroll.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>what is Rav Yosef teaching us</b> with his statement? It seems obvious that there is no reason why a Torah scroll could be used as a bill of divorce. The Gemara says: He is teaching us that <b>gall water is not</b> permanent when applied <b>on top of gall water.</b> The novel idea is that there is no need to be concerned that the scribe wrote a bill of divorce in gall water on the outside of the Torah scroll.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If <b>a bill of divorce was written not for her sake, and</b> the scribe <b>passed over it</b> with <b>a reed</b> pen, meaning that he wrote on top of what was already written, <b>for her sake,</b> then here <b>we have arrived at the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a scribe writing a Torah scroll was at a point in the text <b>that he needed to write the name</b> of God, spelled <i>yod</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>heh</i>; and he erred <b>and intended to write Yehuda,</b> spelled <i>yod</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>vav</i>, <i>dalet</i>, <i>heh</i>, <b>but he made a mistake</b> when writing Yehuda <b>and did not place a <i>dalet</i> in</b> the word, thereby unintentionally writing the name of God in the correct place, then <b>he should pass over it with a reed</b> pen. He writes over what was written <b>and sanctifies it</b> with the intention that he is writing the name of God. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say:</b> Even if he adds a second layer of ink, <b>the name</b> has <b>not</b> been written <b>in the optimal manner.</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, one can supply the intention of writing the name of God for its own sake even when adding a second layer of writing over the first, while according to the Rabbis one cannot. The same dispute would presumably apply in the case of a bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Perhaps</b> that <b>is not so,</b> and <b>the Rabbis say only there,</b> in the case of a Torah scroll, that one may not write the name of God in this manner, <b>because it is required</b> that one perform anything sacred, including the writing of a Torah scroll, in accordance with the verse: <b>“This is my God, and I will glorify Him”</b> (Exodus 15:2). This verse requires that mitzvot be performed in a way that is glorious and aesthetically pleasing, <b>and</b> rewriting in this manner is <b>not</b> considered beautiful. <b>But here,</b> with regard to a bill of divorce, there is <b>no</b> requirement that the bill of divorce be written beautifully, and therefore writing over the bill of divorce is acceptable according to the Rabbis as well.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda said: I am able to invalidate all the bills of divorce in the world.</b> Most bills of divorce are written in a way that they could be declared invalid. If one were to be particular about certain details, then there would be no valid bills of divorce. <b>Rava said to him: What is the reason</b> that you could invalidate them? <b>If we say:</b> Most bills of divorce are invalid <b>because it is written</b> in the Torah: <b>“And he writes</b> her a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and here,</b> in the case of most bills of divorce, <b>she writes</b> it <b>for him,</b> as it is customary for a woman to pay a scribe to write the bill of divorce, <b>but</b> then <b>perhaps</b> it could be maintained that <b>the Sages transferred</b> the ownership of the bill of divorce <b>to him,</b> and it is considered as if he wrote it.
<b>But rather,</b> you might say that it is <b>because it is written: “And gives”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), which is usually understood to mean that the item given must have some monetary value, <b>and here</b> in the case of most bills of divorce <b>he doesn’t give her anything</b> of value. <b>Perhaps the</b> mere <b>giving of the bill of divorce is</b> the giving mentioned in the Torah, even if it does not have any monetary value. <b>Know</b> that it is not a requirement that the bill of divorce have monetary value, as the Sages <b>sent</b> this message <b>from there,</b> from Eretz Yisrael: If <b>he wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>on items from which benefit is forbidden,</b> then although the bill of divorce is completely lacking monetary value, the bill of divorce is <b>valid.</b>
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself:</b> The Sages <b>sent</b> this message <b>from there,</b> from Eretz Yisrael: If <b>he wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>on items from which benefit is forbidden,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>valid. Rav Ashi said: We, too, learn</b> in the mishna that a bill of divorce may be written <b>on an olive leaf,</b> which has virtually no monetary value. This teaches that the bill of divorce need not have any value on its own, and even forbidden items, which have no value at all, may be used as the base on which the bill of divorce is written. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps an olive leaf is different,</b> because <b>it can combine</b> with more leaves, and they will add up to have monetary value. However, an item from which one is prohibited from benefiting lacks value entirely, even in large quantities.
With regard to the same <i>halakha</i>, the Gemara quotes an additional source. It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> If the scribe <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>on items from which benefit is forbidden,</b> it is <b>valid. Levi went out</b> and <b>expounded</b> upon <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in the name</b> of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and they did not praise him.</b> He then expounded this <i>halakha</i> <b>in the name of the majority,</b> as an unattributed <i>halakha</i>, <b>and they praised him. Apparently, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. Therefore, when he stated the <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, an individual, which may have led the listeners to think that it was a minority opinion and not the accepted <i>halakha</i>, they did not praise him.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> that it is said in the Torah with regard to a bill of divorce: <b>“And he writes</b> her a scroll of severance,” in order to emphasize that one must write the document <b>and not chisel</b> it. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that chiseling is not writing? And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a slave is emancipated</b> through a bill of manumission that was <b>written</b> by being chiseled <b>on a slate [<i>tavla</i>]</b> or on a <b>tablet [<i>pinekas</i>],</b> then <b>he goes free. However, he does not</b> go free <b>through writing on a cap or</b> on <b>an embroidered adornment.</b> If the master embroidered the bill of manumission onto a cloth and gave it to the slave, this is not considered to be like the writing of a document. In any case, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that a bill of manumission that is chiseled onto a slate is valid.
<b>Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> It is <b>not difficult. This</b> case, where the document is not valid because engraving is not considered to be writing, occurs <b>when</b> the scribe <b>chiseled</b> the area <b>surrounding</b> the letters, i.e., he chiseled on the surface around the shape of the letters, leaving the letters raised on the tablet. <b>This</b> case, where the document is valid because chiseling is considered to be writing, occurs <b>when he chiseled the parts</b> of the letters, i.e., he chiseled the shape of the letters themselves onto the slate. Since he formed the letters directly, it is considered like writing.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if he chiseled the area <b>surrounding</b> the letters, is this <b>not</b> considered to be writing at all? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what was taught: <b>The writing</b> of the High Priest’s frontplate <b>was not embedded,</b> i.e., it was not carved into the frontplate; <b>rather, it protruded like</b> the form on <b>gold dinars. And isn’t</b> the shape on <b>gold dinars</b> formed by chiseling the area <b>surrounding</b> the letters, by applying pressure around the shape, so that the image and writing protrudes, and yet this is considered to be writing?
The Gemara answers: It means that the frontplate was fashioned <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars</b> but <b>not</b> entirely <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars.</b> It was fashioned <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars</b> in that the writing <b>protrudes, but</b> it was <b>not</b> fashioned <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars</b> entirely, <b>as there,</b> in the case of gold dinars, they chiseled the area <b>surrounding</b> the letters. <b>Here,</b> when making the frontplate, the inscription was done by chiseling <b>the parts</b> of the letter, i.e., they would carve the letters from the back of the frontplate so that they protruded from the front. Since the letters were carved directly, it was considered to be writing.
With regard to this issue, <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> Does the <b>press</b> that forms a metal coin <b>carve out</b> the background in the metal and the image of the coin is formed on its own, <b>or does it compress</b> the metal inward toward the empty space in the press and the letters are formed through this? <b>He said to him:</b> It <b>carves out</b> the background.
<b>He raised an objection to his</b> opinion based on what was taught earlier: <b>The writing</b> of the High Priest’s frontplate <b>was not embedded,</b> i.e., it was not carved into the frontplate; <b>rather, it protruded like</b> the form on <b>gold dinars. And if it enters your mind</b> to say that a press only <b>carves out</b> the background,

Daf 20b

<b>isn’t there a need</b> to write it, as the verse states with regard to the frontplate: “Wrote upon it <b>a writing,</b> like the engravings of a signet” (Exodus 39:30), <b>and there is no</b> writing here? The Gemara answers: It means that the frontplate was fashioned <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars</b> but <b>not</b> entirely <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars.</b> It was fashioned <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars</b> in <b>that</b> the writing <b>protrudes. But</b> it was <b>not</b> fashioned <b>like</b> the form of <b>gold dinars</b> entirely, <b>as there,</b> in the case of gold dinars, the pressing of the stamp is done <b>from the inside,</b> by pushing back the surrounding area to allow the form to be visible, <b>and here,</b> when fashioning the frontplate, it was done <b>from the outside,</b> by applying pressure to the opposite side so that the letters were pushed outward. Since the letters were carved directly, it was considered to be writing.
§ <b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> In the case of a husband who <b>wrote for her a bill of divorce on a plate [<i>tas</i>] of gold and said to her: Receive your bill of divorce and</b> also <b>receive</b> the payment of <b>your marriage contract</b> through this act, as the piece of gold is worth enough to pay for the value of her marriage contract, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Her bill of divorce has been received and</b> the payment of <b>her marriage contract has been received.</b>
Rava <b>raised an objection to his</b> statement from a <i>baraita</i>: If a husband gave his wife a bill of divorce on an oversized paper and said to her: <b>Receive your bill of divorce, and the remainder</b> of the paper, on which nothing is written, is designated <b>for</b> the payment of <b>your marriage contract,</b> then <b>her bill of divorce has been received and the remainder</b> should be <b>for</b> the payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b>
The Gemara explains the objection: This indicates that <b>the reason</b> why the material upon which the bill of divorce is written may also serve as the payment for her marriage contract is <b>that there is</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the paper, on which the bill of divorce was not written. If <b>there is not</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the paper, then <b>no,</b> the bill of divorce may not serve as payment of the marriage contract. This is because the husband must give the bill of divorce to his wife for it to become hers. If so, even if the bill of divorce was written on a plate of gold, if there was no part of the plate of gold other than the space where the bill of divorce was written, it should not serve as payment of her marriage contract.
Rav Naḥman responded: <b>The same is true although there is no remainder</b> of the paper, and he wrote the bill of divorce on the entire paper. <b>And</b> by stating the <i>halakha</i> in a case where there was an additional part of the paper, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us this: Although there is</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the paper upon which nothing is written, <b>if he</b> explicitly <b>said to her</b> that it should be for the payment of her marriage contract, <b>yes,</b> it is considered to be a payment for her marriage contract. <b>If</b> he did <b>not</b> say this explicitly, then <b>no,</b> it is not for the payment of her marriage contract, and he must give her the value of her marriage contract in its entirety through a separate payment.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? If he did not explicitly say that the remainder of the paper is designated toward the payment of her marriage contract, then the remainder is considered to be <b>the margin</b> around the border <b>of the scroll,</b> and all of the paper constitutes the bill of divorce. Therefore, it is necessary to inform her that the remainder of the paper is for the payment of her marriage contract.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If the husband said to his wife: <b>Behold this is your bill of divorce,</b> but <b>the paper</b> on which it is written <b>is</b> still <b>mine,</b> then <b>she is not divorced,</b> as he must give her the actual bill of divorce in order for the divorce to take effect. Since the paper still belongs to him, it is as if he had given her only the writing. But if he said to her: Behold this is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you return the paper to me,</b> then <b>she is divorced.</b> The bill of divorce belongs entirely to her, and the returning of the paper is only a stipulation that must be fulfilled later.
<b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> If he said that the paper <b>between each line or between each word</b> in the bill of divorce will still belong to him but the paper where the words are written will be hers, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? A solution is not found for this question, and the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara asks: Why isn’t a solution offered for Rav Pappa’s question? <b>Let him derive</b> an answer to this question from elsewhere, as <b>the Merciful One speaks</b> of <b>one scroll</b> in regard to the bill of divorce in the Torah: “And he writes her a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and not two or three scrolls.</b> If the woman receives only the paper on which the words are written but the rest of the paper belongs to the man, then this is not viewed as a single scroll. Rather, it is multiple scrolls, thereby invalidating it. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to discuss the question in a case where the letters are <b>intertwined,</b> meaning that they were written in such a manner that even if the paper between them was removed, the writing in the bill of divorce would remain attached as a single entity.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma:</b> If the judges <b>had a presumption that a slave was his,</b> i.e., that it belonged to the husband; <b>and the bill of divorce</b> that this man gave his wife was <b>written on</b> that slave’s <b>hand; and</b> now the slave <b>emerges from her possession,</b> i.e., he is with the woman, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to this bill of divorce?
The Gemara explains the elements of the question: <b>Do we say that</b> the husband <b>transferred</b> the slave <b>to</b> his wife? Therefore, it is as though he gave her the bill of divorce in the proper manner, as is explained in the mishna, and she is divorced. <b>Or perhaps</b> we say that <b>he,</b> the slave, <b>entered</b> the possession of the woman <b>on his own,</b> because he prefers to be under her ownership rather than under her husband’s ownership, in which case the husband did not give him to the woman at all, and she is not divorced, as the husband needs to give the bill of divorce to the woman?
<b>Rava said: And let</b> Rami bar Ḥama <b>derive</b> an answer to his question from a different reason, <b>that</b> writing on a person’s body <b>is writing that can be forged,</b> as it is easily erased and replaced with other writing, and a bill of divorce that is written in a manner susceptible to forgery is invalid. The Gemara clarifies: <b>But according to Rava,</b> who raised this challenge, <b>the mishna</b> is <b>difficult,</b> as it taught that a bill of divorce may be written <b>on a slave’s hand.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Granted, the mishna</b> is <b>not difficult for Rava,</b> as it is possible to say that the mishna is referring to a case where the husband gave her the slave <b>with witnesses</b> present <b>who observe the transmission of a legal document.</b> In other words, they were present when the slave, who has the legal document written on him, was given to the woman. <b>And it is</b> in accordance with <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who holds that the essential witnesses are those who witness the delivery, and since they witnessed the delivery, she is divorced. <b>However, for Rami bar Ḥama</b> it is <b>difficult.</b> In his case, there were no witnesses to the transfer of the slave, so the possibility that the writing was forged should invalidate it.
The Gemara answers: <b>According to Rami bar Ḥama</b> it is <b>also not difficult,</b> as he did not ask his question in a case where the bill of divorce was written on the slave with ink but <b>with regard to</b> a case where it was <b>written as a tattoo,</b> so the writing certainly cannot be erased and forged. The Gemara notes: <b>Now that you have arrived at this, the mishna,</b> which deemed valid a bill of divorce that was written on the hand of the slave, <b>will not</b> be <b>difficult</b> for Rava <b>either,</b> as it is also stating the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> a case where <b>it was written as a tattoo.</b>
In any case, Rami bar Ḥama’s question remains unresolved. If so, <b>what</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof based on <b>that</b> which <b>Reish Lakish says: With regard to livestock, there is no presumption</b> of ownership, since they wander from place to place. Therefore, a person cannot claim that his mere possession of livestock demonstrates ownership, because they may have wandered into his property on their own. The same <i>halakha</i> should apply to a slave. If there are no witnesses who saw the transfer to the woman, then her mere possession of the slave should not serve as proof that the slave, and by extension the bill of divorce, was given to her, and consequently the woman is not divorced.
