<b>Rami bar Ḥama raises</b> another <b>dilemma:</b> If the judges <b>had a presumption that a slate was hers, and a bill of divorce was written on it, and</b> now this slate <b>emerges from his possession,</b> and he wants to divorce his wife by giving her the slate, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say that she transferred the ownership</b> of the slate <b>to him,</b> and he may give it to her as a bill of divorce, and the divorce takes effect? <b>Or perhaps</b> a woman <b>does not understand</b> how <b>to transfer</b> an object that will be given back to her, and she believes it is a formality and not an actual legal transfer. If this were to be the case, they would not be divorced, as the slate did not in fact belong to the husband.
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof based on what is stated in a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 2:3): <b>Even he,</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava, who was quoted earlier in this mishna, <b>testified about a small village that was adjacent to Jerusalem, and there was an old man there who would lend</b> money <b>to all the residents of the village. And he would write</b> the documents <b>in his handwriting and others</b> would <b>sign. And the incident came before the Sages and they deemed it valid. And why</b> did they deem it valid? <b>Isn’t there a need</b> to fulfill this verse: “I took the <b>deed of purchase”</b> (Jeremiah 32:11), requiring that the document itself be transferred from the seller to the buyer, <b>and</b> this is <b>not</b> the case here, as the document attesting to the loan was in the possession of the creditor the entire time?
<b>Rather, is it not because we say</b> that he certainly <b>transferred</b> the ownership of the documents <b>to them</b> in a legally binding manner, although he knew that they would be returned to him immediately afterward. The same should apply in this case, and the assumption should be that the woman transferred ownership of the slate to the husband, and he then gave it back to her.
<b>Rava said: And what</b> is the <b>difficulty?</b> How can one prove anything from the mishna? <b>Perhaps</b>

Daf 21a

a knowledgeable <b>old man is different, as he understands</b> the need <b>to transfer</b> the documents, and this may not be true in the case of a woman and the bill of divorce.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> A proof may be brought <b>from here:</b> If there was <b>a guarantor</b> whose commitment <b>emerged after the</b> promissory <b>note was signed,</b> then the creditor may <b>collect</b> only <b>from</b> the guarantor’s <b>unsold property.</b> However, he does not have a lien on the guarantor’s property with which he could collect from property sold after he signed on as a guarantor. Rava’s proof is that it must be that ownership of the promissory note was transferred to the guarantor before he signed it, in order for his commitment to take effect. It may therefore be seen from this <i>baraita</i> that the participants understand the need to transfer ownership of the document.
<b>Rav Ashi said: What is the difficulty</b> raised by this <i>baraita</i>? <b>Perhaps a man is different,</b> in <b>that</b> he <b>understands</b> the need <b>to transfer</b> the document, and the question of the Gemara pertains to a woman, who may not be as well versed in the minutiae of monetary law. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> There is a proof <b>from</b> what was taught <b>here</b> (22b): <b>A woman may write her bill of divorce</b> on her own or allow a scribe to write it on her behalf, and then give it to her husband, so that he will give it to her. Similarly, <b>a man may write his receipt</b> that he will receive from the woman after paying her marriage contract, <b>as the ratification of a bill of divorce is only through its signatories,</b> i.e., the witnesses who sign it, and the mere writing of the document or its receipt has no legal ramifications and may be done by anyone. In any case, it is clear from here that a woman understands the need to transfer the bill of divorce that will be given to her by her husband in the future.
§ <b>Rava says:</b> If <b>he wrote her a bill of divorce and placed it in the hand of his slave, and he wrote her a deed of gift with regard to</b> the slave, then <b>she acquired</b> the slave due to the document, <b>and she is divorced</b> immediately <b>by the</b> bill of divorce that is in his hand. The slave is considered to be like her property, and it is as though the husband had placed the bill of divorce in her domain at the time that he transferred the slave to her, and she acquires the bill of divorce as though it were in her courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> does she acquire the bill of divorce? The slave <b>is</b> considered <b>a mobile courtyard, and a mobile courtyard does not acquire</b> property. One’s courtyard can acquire items for him only when the courtyard is fixed in its location. Since a slave is considered to be like land with regard to other areas of <i>halakha</i>, he should also be defined as a mobile courtyard, as he can move from place to place. <b>And if you would say</b> that Rava was referring <b>to a</b> slave who happens to be <b>standing,</b> who is not mobile, <b>but didn’t Rava say: Anything that does not acquire when moving</b> also <b>does not acquire</b> when it is <b>standing or sitting.</b> The fact that the slave could move gives him the status of a moving courtyard, regardless if he is currently moving or not. The Gemara answers: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> taught by Rava could apply <b>in</b> a case where the slave was <b>bound</b> and unable to move, as in that case he is not even able to move, and is not considered to be a mobile courtyard.
<b>And Rava</b> also <b>says:</b> If <b>he wrote her a bill of divorce and placed it in his courtyard, and he wrote a deed of gift with regard to</b> the courtyard, then <b>she has acquired</b> the courtyard <b>and is divorced</b> immediately <b>by the</b> bill of divorce in the courtyard.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for Rava to teach his <i>halakha</i> both with regard to a slave and with regard to a courtyard. One could not have been learned from the other, <b>as had he taught us</b> only about <b>a slave, I would say</b> that the husband may transfer the bill of divorce to his wife <b>specifically</b> through <b>a slave, but</b> in the case of <b>a courtyard</b> the Sages may decide <b>to enact a decree</b> that this should not be a valid bill of divorce, <b>due to</b> the case of <b>her courtyard that comes afterward.</b> People may not differentiate between this case and a similar case, where the husband places the bill of divorce in the courtyard of a third party, and that courtyard is subsequently acquired by her. In that case, the couple is not divorced, as the bill of divorce was not given by the husband to the wife. Therefore, Rava has to teach that the Sages did not make this decree, and in this case, where the husband gave the courtyard together with the bill of divorce, it is valid.
<b>And had</b> Rava <b>taught us</b> only about <b>a courtyard,</b> then <b>I would say</b> that a woman is divorced <b>specifically</b> if her husband placed the bill of divorce in <b>a courtyard, but</b> in the case of <b>a slave</b> the Sages may decide <b>to decree</b> with regard to <b>a bound</b> slave that the divorce will not take effect, <b>due to</b> the similarity to <b>an unbound</b> slave, where the divorce would not take effect, as explained above. Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that it is a valid bill of divorce in both cases.
<b>Abaye said</b> as a challenge to Rava: <b>Now, from where was a courtyard included?</b> What is the source for the <i>halakha</i> that a man can divorce a woman by placing a bill of divorce in her courtyard? This can be derived <b>from</b> the phrase: “And gives it in <b>her hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), and the Sages derived that this is not limited to her actual hand but also includes anything that is an extension of her hand, such as her courtyard.
Consequently, the following reasoning should apply: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>her hand, that it</b> acquires property for her <b>whether with her consent or against her will, so too,</b> with regard to <b>her courtyard,</b> it should be <b>that it</b> acquires property for her <b>whether with her consent or against her will. And</b> with regard to <b>a gift, it is</b> so that she acquires it <b>with her consent,</b> but <b>it is not</b> so that she acquires it <b>against her will.</b> Therefore, a courtyard that a husband transfers to his wife as a gift along with a bill of divorce is not the same as a bill of divorce that he gives into her hand. As a courtyard is different from her hand in this sense, it should not be able to be used as a means of transferring a bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi objects to</b> the reasoning of Abaye: <b>But</b> what of <b>agency for receipt</b> of the bill of divorce, where the woman appoints an agent to receive a bill of divorce on her behalf, concerning <b>which</b> the agent can act <b>with her consent,</b> but <b>not against her will.</b> No one other than the wife can appoint an agent to receive the bill of divorce, and despite this <b>he is an agent for receipt.</b> Yet a woman is able to appoint an agent for receipt. Evidently, the comparison of other methods of acquisition to acquisition by placing the bill of divorce in her hand is not absolute.
<b>And Abaye</b> would respond: <b>Is that to say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>agency is included from</b> the words <b>“her hand”?</b> It is not learned from there; rather, it <b>is included</b> based on the additional wording of the verse, as the verse does not state: <b>And he sent [<i>veshillaḥ</i>].</b> Rather, it states: <b>“And sends her out [<i>veshilleḥa</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1). The expanded term teaches that a woman can also appoint an agent to receive a bill of divorce on her behalf. Since agency has a different source in the Torah, it is not impacted by the limitations of her hand. The <i>halakha</i> that a bill of divorce can be given to her by placing it in her courtyard is an extension of the <i>halakha</i> that it can be placed in her hand and does carry the limitations of her hand. Therefore, it must be able to work whether with her consent or against her will.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> a different answer: <b>We also have found</b> that <b>agency for receipt</b> can be effective <b>against her will.</b> How so? <b>As</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>a father can receive a bill of divorce for his minor daughter against her will.</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of agency are therefore consistent with the <i>halakhot</i> with regard to her hand, and Abaye’s objection stands.
§ The mishna taught that a bill of divorce may be written <b>on an olive leaf,</b> on the horn of a cow, or on the hand of a slave, provided that the husband then gives her the slave or the cow. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to <b>the hand of a slave,</b>

Daf 21b

<b>it is not possible to cut it off,</b> as it is certainly prohibited to cut off the hand of a slave, and he therefore must give her the slave. <b>But</b> if he wrote the bill of divorce on <b>the horn of a cow, let him cut it off and give it to her.</b> Why does the mishna state that he must give her the cow?
The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states: “And he writes</b> her a scroll of severance, <b>and gives it</b> in <b>her</b> hand” (Deuteronomy 24:1), meaning that <b>something</b> is valid as a bill of divorce <b>when it is lacking only writing and giving, excluding this,</b> a cow’s horn, <b>which is lacking writing, cutting, and giving.</b> Since the additional step of cutting would be required in order for him to give her the horn alone, the horn would not be a valid bill of divorce, so he must give her the cow.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says</b> that a bill of divorce may not be written on something living, nor on food. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s</b> opinion? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is said in the Torah with regard to a bill of divorce: “And he writes her <b>a scroll</b> of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1). From the word “scroll,” <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>a scroll</b> is valid; <b>from where</b> do I derive that it is correct <b>to include all objects</b> as valid materials upon which a bill of divorce may be written? <b>The verse states: “And he writes her,” in any case,</b> i.e., a bill of divorce can be written on any type of surface. <b>If so, what is</b> the meaning when <b>the verse states “scroll”?</b> This teaches: <b>Just as a scroll is neither alive nor food, so too,</b> a bill of divorce may be written on <b>any object that is neither alive nor food.</b> This is why Rabbi Yosei HaGelili deems invalid a bill of divorce written on a living being.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree and say that a bill of divorce may be written even on a living creature or on food, interpret the verse? They contend: <b>If</b> the verse <b>were written:</b> And he shall write for her <b>in the scroll [<i>besefer</i>],</b> then it would be <b>as you said,</b> and it would indicate the type of surface on which the bill of divorce may be written. <b>Now that it is written: “Scroll [<i>sefer</i>],” it comes to</b> teach that a mere <b>account of the matters [<i>sefirat devarim</i>]</b> is required. In other words, <i>sefer</i> is referring not to the surface on which a bill of divorce must be written, but rather, to the essence of the bill of divorce. The verse teaches that the bill of divorce must contain particular content.
The Gemara continues: <b>And the Rabbis, what do they do with this</b> phrase in the verse: <b>“And he writes</b> her”? The Gemara answers: <b>For them,</b> that phrase <b>is required</b> to teach the principle that a woman <b>is divorced</b> only <b>via writing,</b> i.e., a bill of divorce, <b>and she is not divorced via</b> giving <b>money.</b> It might <b>enter your mind to say: I should juxtapose leaving</b> marriage, i.e., divorce, <b>to becoming</b> married, i.e., betrothal, and I will say that <b>just as becoming</b> married <b>is</b> effected <b>with</b> giving <b>money, so too, leaving</b> marriage can <b>also</b> be effected <b>with</b> giving <b>money.</b> Therefore, the Torah <b>teaches us:</b> “And he writes her”; divorce can be effected only with a written bill of divorce.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, from where does he derive this reasoning? <b>He derives it from</b> the phrase <b>“scroll of severance,”</b> which teaches that <b>a scroll,</b> i.e., a written document, <b>severs her</b> from her husband <b>and nothing else severs her</b> from him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> those who hold <b>the other</b> opinion, the Rabbis, how do they explain this phrase? <b>For them,</b> the phrase “scroll of severance” <b>is required</b> to teach that a bill of divorce must be <b>a matter that severs</b> all connection <b>between him and her, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce, on the condition that you will not</b> ever <b>drink wine,</b> or <b>on condition that you will never go to your father’s house, that is not severance,</b> and the bill of divorce is not valid. If a bill of divorce imposes a condition upon the woman that permanently binds her to her husband, her relationship with her husband has not been completely severed, which is a prerequisite for divorce. If, however, he imposes a condition <b>until thirty days</b> have passed, or for any other limited period of time, <b>that is severance.</b> The bill of divorce is valid, as the relationship will be completely terminated at the end of the thirty-day period.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, from where does he derive that a stipulation without a termination point invalidates the divorce? <b>From</b> the fact that instead of using the term <b><i>karet</i>,</b> the verse uses the more expanded term <b><i>keritut</i>.</b> Inasmuch as both terms denote severance, using the longer term teaches us two things: Divorce can be effected only via writing and not through money, and divorce requires total severance.
<b>And the other,</b> the Rabbis, what do they derive from this? The Gemara answers: <b>They do not derive</b> anything from the expansion of <b><i>karet</i></b> to <b><i>keritut</i>.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may not write</b> a bill of divorce <b>on</b> anything that is <b>attached to the ground.</b> If <b>one wrote it on</b> something that was <b>attached</b> to the ground, and afterward he <b>detached it, signed it, and gave it to her,</b> then it is <b>valid. Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> a bill of divorce <b>invalid unless its writing and its signing</b> were performed when it was already <b>detached.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: One may not write</b> a bill of divorce <b>on erased paper or on unfinished leather</b> [<b><i>diftera</i></b>], <b>because</b> writing on these surfaces <b>can be forged. And the Rabbis deem valid</b> a bill of divorce that was written on either of these items.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna taught: If <b>one wrote it on</b> something that was <b>attached</b> to the ground, and detached it before he gave it to her, then it is valid. The Gemara challenges: <b>But didn’t you say</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna that <b>one may not write</b> a bill of divorce on something that is attached to the ground? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The mishna’s statement that if something was detached and signed then it is a valid bill of divorce <b>is</b> applicable only <b>when one left a place for the essential</b> part of the document. He did not write the entire bill of divorce while it was attached to the ground. Rather, he wrote only the standard part of the bill of divorce. However, he left a place for the essential part of the bill of divorce, which includes the names of the man and woman, and wrote that part only after it was detached.
<b>And so Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says: And this is</b> a case <b>where he left a place for the essential</b> part of the document. <b>And so Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And this is when he left a place for the essential</b> part of the document. <b>And</b> all these Sages hold that the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce. It is not the signatures of the witnesses on a bill of divorce that validate it. Rather, the divorce is effected by the transmission of the document in the presence of witnesses. Therefore, the phrase: “And he writes” (Deuteronomy 24:1), must be referring to the writing of the bill of divorce and not to the signing of the witnesses, and the restrictions derived from this verse will apply to the writing of the bill of divorce, so the essential part may not be written on something that is attached to the ground.
<b>And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: One may not write</b> even the <b>standard</b> part on something that is attached to the ground <i>ab initio</i>, <b>lest he write</b> the <b>essential</b> part of the document in this manner as well. However, if <b>he wrote the standard</b> part while it was attached to the ground, <b>and then detached it, wrote the essential</b> part, <b>and gave it to her,</b> it is <b>valid.</b>
<b>And Reish Lakish says:</b> The mishna should not be understood in that way, where the phrase: And signed it, is referring to the writing of the essential part, since <b>we learned</b> that <b>they signed it,</b> which is referring to the signatures of the witnesses. And <b>it is</b> taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who <b>says</b> that <b>the signatory witnesses</b> on the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce.
<b>And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: One may not write the essential</b> part on something that is attached to the ground due to a rabbinic <b>decree, lest he</b> also <b>have</b> the witnesses <b>sign</b> while it is attached. However, even if <b>he wrote the essential</b> part while it was attached, then <b>detached it, had it signed, and gave it to her,</b> it is <b>valid.</b> According to Rabbi Meir, when the verse states: “And he writes her,” it is referring to when he has the bill of divorce signed. Therefore, by Torah law, the limitation that it not be attached while he writes applies only to the signing but not to the writing. The Sages decreed that the essential part of the bill of divorce also not be written while it is attached to the ground, but if he violated this decree, it is still valid after the fact.
§ In connection with this discussion, the Gemara mentions several <i>halakhot</i> that are affected by items being attached to the ground or detached. If <b>he wrote</b> the bill of divorce <b>on the clay of a perforated pot [<i>atzitz</i>],</b> which is considered to be attached to the ground, then it is <b>valid, as he</b> can <b>take</b> this pot <b>and give it to her.</b> However, if he wrote it <b>on a leaf of</b> a plant growing in <b>a perforated pot,</b> then what is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Abaye says:</b> It is <b>valid. And Rava says:</b> It is <b>invalid.</b> The Gemara clarifies their dispute in detail: <b>Abaye says</b> that it is <b>valid</b>

Daf 22a

<b>as he</b> can <b>take</b> the pot with the leaf inside it <b>and give it to her. Rava says</b> that it is <b>invalid.</b> Although it should be valid if he gave her the leaf together with the potted plant, the Sages instituted <b>a decree</b> that it is invalid, <b>lest one detach</b> the leaf and give it to her. In that case, all agree that a bill of divorce that is fully written while attached is invalid.
§ The Gemara has another discussion with regard to a perforated pot: In the case of <b>a pot</b> that <b>belongs to one</b> person <b>and the plants</b> in it <b>belong to another</b> person, if the <b>owner of</b> the <b>pot sold</b> it <b>to</b> the <b>owner of</b> the <b>plants,</b> then <b>once</b> the owner of the plants <b>pulled</b> the pot, <b>he has acquired</b> the pot, as it is a movable object, which can be acquired via pulling. However, if the <b>owner of</b> the <b>plants sold</b> the plants <b>to</b> the <b>owner of</b> the <b>pot,</b> then the owner of the pot <b>does not acquire</b> the plants <b>until he takes possession of the plants</b> themselves, e.g., by raking or weeding the dirt surrounding them. Since the plants are considered to be attached to the ground, as they are in a perforated pot, they are considered to be part of the ground, which cannot be acquired by pulling.
If <b>the pot and plants belong to one</b> person, <b>and he sold them to another</b> person, then once the buyer <b>took possession of the plants</b> and acquired them, <b>he acquired the pot</b> as well. <b>And this is</b> an example of the principle <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kiddushin</i> 26a): <b>Property that does not serve as a guarantee,</b> i.e., movable property, <b>can be acquired with property that serves as a guarantee,</b> i.e., land, <b>through</b> the giving of <b>money, or with a document, or by taking possession.</b> Therefore, once one takes possession of the plants, which are considered to be like land, he also acquires the pot, which is a movable object.
However, if the buyer <b>took possession of</b> just <b>the pot,</b> then <b>he does not even acquire the pot,</b> as movable property cannot be acquired through taking possession, <b>until he takes possession of the plants.</b> To acquire the pot, one must either perform an act of acquisition specific to movable items, such as pulling, or acquire the plants through taking possession of them, resulting in the acquisition of the pot, as stated earlier.
The Gemara discusses another issue with regard to perforated pots: If a perforated pot was on the border of Eretz Yisrael, and <b>its perforation was in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>but its branches</b> were <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, then what is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to mitzvot that apply to produce grown in Eretz Yisrael, such as <i>terumot</i> and tithes? <b>Abaye said: We follow its perforation,</b> and it is considered to be growing in Eretz Yisrael. <b>Rava said: We follow its branches,</b> and it is considered to be growing outside of Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara notes: <b>In</b> a case <b>where</b> the plant in the pot <b>took root</b> in the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that it has the status of a plant that grows in the place where its roots are. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where it did not take root.</b> Since its roots are contained within the pot, there is a disagreement whether we follow the perforation or the branches in determining its status.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And do they not disagree with regard to</b> a case <b>where it took root?</b> Do all agree that its status is determined by where the roots are? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 118b): In a case of <b>two gardens</b> that belong to two different people that are on adjacent terraces <b>one above the other, and leafy vegetables</b> are growing <b>between them</b> on the wall of the step between the two gardens, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> These leafy vegetables <b>belong to</b> the owner of the <b>upper</b> garden, and <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> These leafy vegetables <b>belong</b> to the owner of the <b>lower</b> garden. In this case, the roots emerge from the upper garden, but the vegetables grow into the airspace of the lower garden. This seems to be analogous to the case where the roots are in Eretz Yisrael and the branches are outside of Eretz Yisrael, or vice versa, and there is a dispute as to who is the owner of the vegetables.
The Gemara makes a distinction between the two cases: <b>There,</b> in the case cited in the mishna in <i>Bava Metzia</i>, <b>the reason</b> for that <i>halakha</i> is <b>as is taught</b> in the mishna, that <b>Rabbi Meir said: What if</b> the owner of the <b>upper</b> garden <b>would wish to take his earth?</b> This would result in a situation where <b>there are no</b> more <b>vegetables,</b> as the vegetables would not have earth from which to draw nutrients. The fact that the owner of the upper garden has the ability to destroy the vegetables is an indication that he is the owner.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: What if</b> the owner of the <b>lower</b> garden <b>would wish to fill</b> the airspace above <b>his garden</b> with <b>earth?</b> This would result in a situation where <b>there are no</b> more <b>vegetables,</b> as they would be covered in the earth added by the owner of the lower garden. The fact that the owner of the lower garden has the ability to destroy the vegetables is an indication that he is the owner. Their dispute is not with regard to how to define where the vegetables are growing; rather, they disagree with regard to who has control over the continued existence of these plants. Therefore, this dispute is not related to the issue of the plant that is growing on the border.
The Gemara asks: <b>But still, do they not disagree with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> the plant <b>took root? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ma’asrot</i> 2:22): If there is <b>a tree,</b> and <b>part of it</b> is <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and part of it</b> is <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, then <b>untithed produce and non-sacred produce are mixed together</b> in each one of these tree’s fruits; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The fruits in the part of the tree that is <b>growing in</b> a place that has <b>an obligation</b> to separate tithes, in Eretz Yisrael, are <b>obligated. And</b> the fruits that are <b>growing in</b> a place that has an <b>exemption</b> from separating tithes, outside of Eretz Yisrael, are <b>exempt.</b>
<b>What, is it not</b> discussing a case <b>where some of its branches are in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and some of its branches are outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, although its roots are in one of the two locations, and both Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel agree that the place of the roots does not define the status of the tree?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it discusses a case where <b>some of the roots</b> are <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and some of the roots</b> are <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reasoning of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel?</b> It is not possible to determine which fruits drew nutrients from which roots, so how can he rule that some of the fruits are obligated in tithes and some are not? The Gemara answers: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s statement is referring to a case where <b>a rock divides</b> the roots up to the trunk, and therefore it is possible to distinguish between the parts of the tree that draw nutrients from Eretz Yisrael and the parts that draw nutrients from outside of Eretz Yisrael.
The Gemara asks: If it is so that the roots are clearly distinguishable, <b>what is the reasoning of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? Why does he view the fruits as being a mixture? The Gemara answers: He holds that although there is a division between the roots, they cannot be distinguished from one another, <b>as they then become mixed</b> in the body of the tree.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds: The air</b> above the ground <b>mixes</b> the nutrients, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds: This</b> part of the tree <b>stands alone and this</b> part of the tree <b>stands alone.</b> From the roots up to the branches, it is as if the tree were cut along the line of the border.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says</b> that one may not write a bill of divorce on a material that enables forgery. Consequently, one may not write a bill of divorce on erased paper or on unfinished leather. The Gemara now clarifies what is defined as unfinished leather. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ami said in the name of Ulla: There are three hides,</b> i.e., three stages in the process of tanning hides. At each stage, the hide has a different name: <b><i>Matza</i>, <i>ḥifa</i>, and <i>diftera</i>.</b>
<b><i>Matza</i>, as per its plain meaning,</b> with no additives. It is <b>not salted, and not treated with flour, and not treated with gallnuts.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> is this type of leather mentioned? There is a <i>halakha</i> that mentions the minimum measure of this type of leather <b>for</b> which one is liable if he <b>carries</b> it <b>out</b> from one domain to another on <b>Shabbat. And how much is the measure</b> that determines liability for carrying out this hide on Shabbat? <b>As Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda teaches:</b> It is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to wrap</b> around <b>a small weight. And how</b> big is this small weight? <b>Abaye said: A quarter of a quarter of</b> a <i>litra</i> in the system of weights in use in <b>Pumbedita.</b>
<b><i>Ḥifa</i></b> is hide <b>that is salted, and not treated with flour, and not treated with gallnuts. For what <i>halakha</i></b> was this type of leather mentioned? There is a <i>halakha</i> that mentions the minimum measure of this type of leather <b>for</b> which one is liable if he <b>carries</b> it <b>out</b> from one domain to another on <b>Shabbat. And how much is the measure</b> that determines liability for carrying out this hide on Shabbat? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shabbat</i> 78b): The measure that determines liability for carrying out this <b>hide</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an amulet.</b>
<b><i>Diftera</i></b> is hide <b>that is salted, and treated with flour, and not treated with gallnuts. For what <i>halakha</i></b> was this type of leather mentioned? There is a <i>halakha</i> that mentions the minimum measure of this type of leather <b>for</b> which one is liable if he <b>carries</b> it <b>out</b> from one domain to another on <b>Shabbat. And how much is the measure</b> that determines liability for carrying out this hide on Shabbat? The measure that determines liability for carrying it out is <b>equivalent to</b> the amount <b>on which a bill of divorce is written.</b>
The mishna taught that <b>the Rabbis deem valid</b> bills of divorce that were written on erased paper or on unfinished leather. The Gemara asks: <b>Who are</b> these <b>Rabbis?</b> The <i>amora</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b>

Daf 22b

<b>It is</b> the opinion of the <i>tanna</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce. Since the witnesses read the bill of divorce before it is transmitted in their presence, they may be relied upon to confirm the contents of the bill of divorce in court. Therefore, even if it was written on erased paper, there is no possibility that it would be forged, as the witnesses read what was written before it is given.
<b>And</b> the <i>amora</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar deemed</b> such a bill of divorce <b>valid only</b> when it was taken to court in order to confirm the contents <b>immediately</b> after it was transferred to the woman. <b>However,</b> if the witnesses testify <b>from now until ten days,</b> i.e., sometime later, he did <b>not</b> deem it valid. Why? <b>We are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the bill of divorce <b>had a stipulation</b> written on it <b>and she forged it</b> by erasing the stipulation, as this bill of divorce was written on material that enables a person to easily alter what is written. Only if the witnesses testify immediately can the court be sure that they did not forget what is written.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even</b> if they testify <b>from now until ten days</b> it is valid, as, <b>if it is so that it had a stipulation,</b> then the witnesses <b>will remember</b> it, as they would not forget something so obvious. Therefore, if the woman erased the stipulation, the witnesses would not verify the bill of divorce.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar</b> the <i>amora</i> also <b>says:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar deemed valid</b> a document that is written on these surfaces <b>only with regard to bills of divorce but not for other documents, as it is written</b> with regard to a deed of purchase: <b>“And put them in an earthen vessel; so that they will remain many days”</b> (Jeremiah 32:14). This indicates that a deed of purchase and other similar documents must be made from a material that will last for a long time without being changed. A document that can be forged may not be relied upon long term.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Rabbi Elazar deemed these surfaces valid <b>even in</b> the case of other <b>documents.</b> The Gemara asks with regard to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion: <b>But isn’t it written: “So that they will remain many days”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> the verse <b>teaches us good advice,</b> but it is not a halakhic requirement. It advised that the document be written in such a manner that it can remain for an extended period of time, as it may be needed to prove ownership of the land.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Anyone is qualified to write a bill of divorce, even a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor.</b> Additionally, <b>a woman may write her</b> own <b>bill of divorce</b> and give it to her husband so that he can present it to her. <b>And a man may write his</b> own <b>receipt,</b> which must be given to him by the woman to confirm that he has paid her the value of her marriage contract. This is because <b>the ratification of a bill of divorce is only through its signatories,</b> and it is irrelevant who wrote it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how can a deaf-mute, imbecile, or a minor write a bill of divorce? <b>They are not</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> and they are not capable of writing a bill of divorce with the intent that it be for a particular woman. <b>Rav Huna says:</b>

Daf 23a

<b>And that</b> is the case only when <b>there was an adult standing over him.</b> When the adult supervises the writing, and instructs him to write it for her sake, it will be valid.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to him: If that is so,</b> that anyone who is disqualified from writing a bill of divorce may do so with an adult supervising him, then if the one writing is <b>a gentile, and a Jew stands over him</b> and instructs him to write it for her sake, would you <b>also</b> say <b>that</b> it is <b>valid? And if you would say that</b> it is <b>also</b> valid, <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A gentile is disqualified</b> from writing a bill of divorce in any event? Rav Huna answered: <b>A gentile acts</b> based on <b>his own will.</b> Since he is halakhically competent, he will have his own intentions while writing and may not be relied upon to carry out the intentions of the supervisor. In the case of the mishna, since those doing the writing are not halakhically competent, they will write according to the instructions of the supervisor.
<b>Rav Naḥman then said: What I said</b> when I raised a challenge from a case involving a gentile <b>is not correct,</b> as <b>from the fact</b> that the mishna later <b>disqualifies a gentile with regard to</b> acting as an agent in <b>the bringing</b> of the bill of divorce, one can learn <b>by inference</b> that he is <b>qualified with regard to writing,</b> where he is not listed among those who are disqualified.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>a gentile is disqualified</b> from writing a bill of divorce? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, and when the verse states: “And he writes her” (Deuteronomy 24:1), which is the source for the <i>halakha</i> that the writing needs to be done for her sake, it is referring to the writing of the bill of divorce and not to its signing. Therefore, <b>we need</b> the <b>writing</b> to be <b>for her sake, and certainly a gentile acts</b> based on <b>his own will</b> and may not be relied upon to write the bill of divorce according to the instructions of a supervisor.
With regard to the requirement that a bill of divorce be written for her sake, <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir would have said: Even if</b> the husband <b>found</b> the bill of divorce <b>in the garbage</b> dump, and the names written on it happened to be the same as his and his wife’s names, if <b>he had it signed</b> by witnesses <b>and he gave it to her,</b> then it is <b>valid,</b> because the essential requirement is that it be signed for her sake.
<b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the statement of <b>Rav Naḥman:</b> The verse states: <b>“And he writes her,”</b> which is interpreted to mean that it must be written <b>for her sake. What, is it not</b> referring to the actual <b>writing of the bill of divorce,</b> that it must be written with the intent that it be used to sever this particular marriage? The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is referring to the <b>signing of the witnesses.</b>
<b>Rava raised</b> another <b>objection to him</b> based on what was taught in a mishna (24a): <b>Any bill of divorce that was not written for the sake of</b> a specific <b>woman</b> is <b>invalid.</b> He responded: <b>Say</b> that according Rabbi Meir the mishna teaches: Any bill of divorce <b>that was not signed for the sake of</b> a specific <b>woman</b> is <b>invalid.</b>
Rava <b>raised</b> another <b>objection to him</b> based on another <i>baraita</i>: <b>When he writes it,</b> it is <b>as though he writes it for her sake,</b> meaning that writing one part for her sake makes it as if the entire document were written for her sake. <b>What, it is not</b> stating that <b>when he writes the essential</b> part of the document, which includes the names of the spouses; the date on which it was written; and the expression: Behold you are permitted to any man, <b>for her sake,</b> then <b>is it as though he writes the standard</b> part of the bill of divorce, containing the rest of the information, <b>for her sake?</b> This <i>baraita</i> indicates that there is a requirement that the bill of divorce, not just the signatures, be written for her sake.
Rav Naḥman rejects this: <b>No,</b> Rabbi Meir would explain that this <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where he</b> has witnesses <b>sign it for her sake; it is as though he wrote it for her sake. And if you wish, say: Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of <b>these <i>baraitot</i></b> from which you raised challenges? <b>They are</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who said: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce. According to him, the verse is referring to the writing and not the signing of the bill of divorce, and the writing must be for her sake.
<b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel</b> says: <b>And</b> the statement of the mishna that one who is not halakhically competent is qualified to write a bill of divorce is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when he left</b> unwritten <b>the essential</b> part of the document, which will be written later by a halakhically competent person, as only the essential part must be written for her sake. <b>And so Rabbi Ḥagga says in the name of Ulla: And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when he left the essential</b> part of the document unwritten, <b>and</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> that the writing of the essential part must be done for her sake.
<b>And Rabbi Zerika says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says: <b>It is not Torah.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is meant by the expression: <b>It is not Torah? Rabbi Abba says: Here</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>informs you that there is no force</b> to a requirement that a bill of divorce be written <b>for her sake,</b> as only the signing needs to be done for her sake. <b>And it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who <b>says: Signatory witnesses</b> on the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say</b> earlier that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar?</b> How, then, can Rabbi Abba say that according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir? The Gemara answers: <b>They are <i>amora’im</i> and</b> disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> whether he explains the mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir or that of Rabbi Elazar.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Anyone is fit</b> to serve as an agent <b>to bring a bill of divorce</b> to a woman <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, or a blind person, or a gentile.</b>
If <b>a minor received</b> the bill of divorce <b>and</b> then <b>reached</b> the age of <b>majority,</b> or one received it when he was <b>a deaf-mute and</b> then <b>became able to hear,</b> or one received it when he was <b>blind and</b> then <b>became able to see,</b> or one received it when he was <b>an imbecile and</b> then <b>became</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> or one received it when he was <b>a gentile and</b> then <b>converted,</b> in all of these cases he is <b>unfit</b> to bring the bill of divorce.
<b>However,</b> if one received it when he was <b>able to hear, and</b> then <b>became a deaf-mute, and</b> then <b>again became able to hear;</b> or if one received it when <b>he was able to see, and</b> then <b>became blind, and</b> then <b>again became able to see;</b> or one received it when he was halakhically <b>competent, and</b> then <b>became an imbecile, and</b> then <b>again became</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> in all of these cases he is <b>fit</b> to bring the bill of divorce. <b>This is the principle: Anyone who is</b> halakhically <b>competent in the beginning and in the end</b> is <b>fit,</b> even if there was time in the interim when he was unfit.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks with regard to those the mishna lists as not being qualified to bring a bill of divorce: <b>Granted, a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor</b> are not qualified because <b>they are not</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> and only one who is competent can be appointed as an agent. Additionally, <b>a gentile also</b> is not qualified, <b>as he is not subject to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> that <b>permit</b> a woman to remarry via a bill of divorce. A person cannot serve as an agent for a matter that does not apply to him. <b>But why isn’t a blind person</b> qualified to bring a bill of divorce? <b>Rav Sheshet says: Because he does not know from whom he takes it and to whom he gives it,</b> and since he is unaware of this he will not be able to testify about it.
<b>Rav Yosef objects to this:</b> If there is a concern that a blind person cannot distinguish between different people, then <b>how is a blind man permitted to</b> have sexual relations with <b>his wife?</b> How does he know that she is in fact his wife? Similarly, <b>how are</b> all <b>people permitted to</b> have sexual relations with <b>their wives at night?</b> If it is dark, they cannot see them. <b>Rather,</b> you must say that they are permitted <b>through voice recognition [<i>teviut eina dekala</i>].</b> They can recognize each other based on their voices. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to a blind person, he can recognize the giver and receiver of the bill of divorce <b>through voice recognition.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef says: Here we are dealing with</b> a husband who sends a bill of divorce to his wife <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>where</b> the agent <b>needs to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, and</b> a blind man <b>cannot say</b> this because he is unable to see it being written or signed.
<b>Abaye said to him: However, if that is so,</b> then a person who <b>is able to see</b> when he receives the bill of divorce <b>and</b> then <b>becomes blind, who can say:</b> It was written and signed in my presence, as he was able to see when it was written and signed, would you say that he is <b>also fit</b> to bring the bill of divorce? <b>But it is taught</b> in the mishna: If one received it when <b>he was able to see, and</b> then <b>became blind, and</b> then <b>again became able to see,</b> then he is <b>fit</b> to bring the bill of divorce. It can be inferred from here that only when <b>he again became able to see, yes,</b> he may bring it. But if <b>he did not again become able to see,</b> then <b>no,</b> he may not bring it.
The Gemara answers this question: In fact, with regard to a blind person, <b>the same is true, that although he did not again become able to see</b> he can serve as an agent to bring the bill of divorce and testify that it was written and signed in his presence. <b>And</b> why does it teach that the blind man became able to see again? <b>Since</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that one who received the bill of divorce when he was halakhically <b>competent, and</b> then <b>became an imbecile, and</b> then <b>again became</b> halakhically <b>competent</b> is qualified to bring the bill of divorce. And in that case, <b>the reason</b> why he is qualified is specifically <b>that he again became</b> halakhically <b>competent, but if he did not again become</b> halakhically <b>competent,</b> then he is <b>not</b> qualified. Therefore, the mishna <b>also teaches</b> with regard to <b>one who was able to see</b> that he then <b>became blind and</b> then <b>again became able to see.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches</b> that <b>this is the principle: Anyone who is</b> halakhically <b>competent in the beginning and in the end</b> is <b>fit, and it does not teach: Anyone who is fit in the beginning and the end</b> is <b>fit. Learn from</b> the mishna that it is not necessary for him to be fit in the beginning and the end, as there are times that being fit in the beginning is sufficient, as in the case of one who became blind after witnessing the writing and signing of the bill of divorce. However, it is clear that he must be halakhically competent both in the beginning and the end, which a blind person is.
§ <b>They raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ami:</b> With regard to <b>a slave, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Can he be made an agent to receive a woman’s bill of divorce from the hand of her husband?</b> Is he qualified to act as an agent or not? <b>He said to them: From</b> the fact that the mishna <b>disqualified a gentile,</b>

Daf 23b

one can learn <b>by inference</b> that <b>a slave is fit. Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A slave cannot become an agent to receive a bill of divorce for a woman from the hand of her husband, because he is not</b> included <b>in the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce and betrothal,</b> and one can act as an agent only in a matter that applies to him.
<b>Rabbi Elazar objects to this</b> explanation as to why a slave cannot act as an agent: <b>The reason</b> that a slave is unfit is that this agency <b>pertains to a matter whose</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>he is not</b> included in, <b>but for a matter whose</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>he is</b> included in, i.e., a mitzva that applies to a slave, is he <b>fit</b> to serve as an agent?
<b>But</b> what of <b>a gentile and a Samaritan,who are</b> included <b>in the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>teruma</i> with regard to their own</b> produce, i.e., they must designate a portion of it for the priest, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 3:9): With regard to <b>a gentile and a Samaritan that separated</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>from their own</b> produce, <b>their <i>teruma</i> is considered <i>teruma</i>. And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a different mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 1:1): In the case of <b>a gentile who separated <i>teruma</i> from a Jew’s</b> produce, i.e., acted as his agent, <b>even</b> if he did so <b>with permission</b> from the Jew, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is not <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Is it not because it is written “you”</b> in the verse that is the source for the <i>halakhot</i> of agency: <b>“So you also</b> shall set apart a gift unto the Lord of all your tithes” (Numbers 18:28), and the Sages expound the expression “so you also” to mean the following: <b>Just as you,</b> the ones appointing the agents, <b>are Jews, so too, your agents</b> must be <b>Jews.</b> Since slaves are not full-fledged Jews, they should be disqualified from ever acting as agents, even in a matter in which they are included in its <i>halakhot</i>.
The Sages <b>from the school of Rabbi Yannai say: No,</b> the verse should be expounded in the following manner: <b>Just as you,</b> the ones appointing the agents, <b>are members of the covenant, so too, your agents</b> must be <b>members of the covenant.</b> Gentiles cannot serve as agents because they are not members of the covenant. Slaves, whose masters are commanded to circumcise them and who are obligated in some of the mitzvot, are members of the covenant, and they can serve as agents in a matter in which they are included in its <i>halakhot</i>.
The Gemara quotes a related statement: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A slave cannot become an agent to receive a bill of divorce for a woman from the hand of her husband, because he is not</b> included <b>in the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce and betrothal. And although we learned:</b> If a person said to his female slave: <b>Behold you are</b> still <b>a maidservant and your</b> unborn <b>child is a freeman, if she was pregnant</b> at that time, then <b>she acquired</b> freedom <b>for</b> the unborn child.
The Gemara first clarifies: <b>What</b> is the connection between the initial statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan and the clause: <b>If she was pregnant</b> at that time, <b>she acquired</b> freedom <b>for</b> the unborn child? <b>When Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda came, he said: Rabbi Yoḥanan said two</b> distinct statements: The first statement was that a slave cannot be appointed as an agent to receive a bill of divorce for a woman from her husband, and the other was: <b>It appears that a slave can receive a bill of manumission for his fellow</b> slave <b>from the hand of his fellow’s master, but not from the hand of his own master</b> if both of them are enslaved by the same person.
<b>And if a person will whisper</b> a question <b>to you, saying: This</b> ruling, that a slave cannot receive a bill of manumission for his fellow slave from their common master, is difficult, as <b>a <i>halakha</i> was taught</b> that states the opposite: <b>If</b> a maidservant <b>was pregnant</b> at that time, then <b>she acquired</b> freedom <b>for</b> the unborn child, and the child and mother both belong to the same master, then <b>say to him</b> that <b>two greats of the generation</b> already <b>explained the matter,</b> and they are <b>Rabbi Zeira and Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak.</b>
<b>One</b> of them <b>said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who says:</b> With regard to <b>one who emancipates half of his slave,</b> the slave <b>acquires</b> freedom for half of himself, <b>and one</b> of them added an explanation and <b>said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>for this</b> ruling? <b>He holds: A fetus is</b> considered as <b>its mother’s thigh,</b> i.e., a part of its mother’s body, <b>and it is as though</b> the master <b>transferred</b> ownership of <b>one of her limbs to her.</b> Since the maidservant is pregnant, the child is considered to be a part of her, and it is as though he emancipated a portion of her body. Therefore, the mother is not acting as an agent for the child, and this <i>halakha</i> does not present a difficulty for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are instances in which a woman’s testimony that another woman’s husband has died is not deemed credible (<i>Yevamot</i> 117a). If there is a presumption that due to their familial relationship the two women hate each other, there is concern that the woman is testifying falsely in order to harm the other woman. By doing so, she can cause the other woman to remarry. If her original husband then proves to be living, she will be required to leave her second husband. This mishna teaches: <b>Even the women who are not deemed credible to</b> testify on behalf of a woman and <b>say: Her husband died,</b> and she is permitted to remarry, <b>are deemed credible to bring her bill of divorce.</b> The relatives of the woman who are not deemed credible to testify that her husband has died are: <b>Her mother-in-law; and her mother-in-law’s daughter; and her rival wife,</b> i.e., another wife of her husband’s; <b>and her <i>yevama</i>,</b> i.e., her husband’s brother’s wife; <b>and her husband’s daughter.</b>
The mishna explains: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between a bill of divorce and death,</b> that certain women are deemed credible to testify about one but not the other? With regard to a bill of divorce, it is so <b>that the writing proves</b> that the husband is divorcing his wife, and the testimony is needed only to supplement the bill of divorce. Similarly, <b>the woman herself may bring her</b> own <b>bill of divorce, provided that she is required</b> by the court <b>to state</b> in its presence: <b>It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence,</b> as the Gemara will explain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just as</b> these women <b>are not deemed credible to say: Her husband died, so too, they are not deemed credible to bring her bill of divorce. Rav Yosef said:</b> It is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> this mishna is referring to a case that took place <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael. <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case that took place <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara explains the difference: In a case that takes place <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>where,</b> to validate the bill of divorce <b>we do not rely on her statement</b> of: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, she serves only as an agent. Consequently, she is <b>deemed credible</b> to bring the bill of divorce. However, <b>in</b> a case that takes place <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>where we rely on her statement</b> of: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, and no one can contest the validity of the bill of divorce after her statement has been accepted, <b>she is not deemed credible,</b> as there is a concern that this woman may be intentionally lying in order to cause harm.
<b>Abaye said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is</b> more <b>reasonable,</b> and the distinction should be: <b>In Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>where if</b> the <b>husband</b> were to <b>come and contest</b> the validity of the bill of divorce, <b>we</b> would <b>pay attention to him</b> and rule that they are not divorced, <b>where it could be said</b> that the woman who hates her <b>intends to</b> do her <b>harm</b> by having her remarry based on a bill of divorce that was later contested, <b>she is not deemed credible.</b> However, <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>where if</b> the <b>husband</b> were to <b>come and contest</b> the validity of the bill of divorce, <b>we</b> would <b>not pay attention to him,</b> she is <b>deemed credible,</b> as she does not have the power to make trouble for the other woman and cause her to have to leave her second husband.
The Gemara notes that it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Abaye</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:6): <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Akiva: A woman is deemed credible to bring her</b> own <b>bill of divorce through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as women</b> about <b>whom the Sages said:</b> They <b>are not deemed credible to say: Her husband died, are</b> nevertheless <b>deemed credible to bring her bill of divorce,</b> with regard to the woman herself, <b>who is deemed credible to say</b> that <b>her husband died, is it not right that she is deemed credible to bring her</b> own <b>bill of divorce?</b>

Daf 24a

<b>And from the place that you came,</b> i.e., from this inference itself, one establishes: <b>Just as there,</b> those who bring the bill of divorce <b>must say: It was written in our presence and it was signed in our presence, so too, she</b> herself <b>must say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence.</b> This <i>baraita</i> must be referring to a case in which the wife brought the bill of divorce from outside of Eretz Yisrael, as it is only then that she must state that it was written and signed in her presence. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> supports the opinion of Abaye.
<b>Rav Ashi said: The mishna is also precisely</b> formulated in a way that supports Abaye’s opinion, <b>as it teaches: The woman herself may bring her</b> own <b>bill of divorce, provided that she is required</b> by the court <b>to say:</b> It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence. <b>Learn from</b> the mishna that it is referring to a case outside of Eretz Yisrael, as Abaye explained.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rav Yosef,</b> is it possible to say that <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna (23a): Anyone is fit to serve as an agent to bring a bill of divorce, <b>and the last clause</b> of the mishna (23b): The woman herself may bring her own bill of divorce, discuss a case that takes place <b>in</b> a location <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, and <b>the middle clause:</b> Even the women who are not deemed credible, discusses a case that takes place <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, the first clause and the last clause</b> discuss a case that takes place <b>in</b> a location <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, but <b>the middle clause</b> discusses a case that takes place <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara explains: <b>From where</b> does Rav Yosef infer this? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it teaches</b> in the mishna: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between a bill of divorce and death,</b> that certain women are deemed credible to testify about one but not the other? With regard to a bill of divorce, it is so <b>that the writing proves</b> that the husband is divorcing his wife. The mishna does not teach <b>that the writing and statement prove</b> this. Consequently, the statement of: It was written in my presence, is not needed. This indicates that the mishna is discussing a case that takes place in Eretz Yisrael.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>the woman herself may bring</b> her own bill of divorce and state that it was written and signed in her presence. The Gemara asks: Why does she need to bring it and testify that it was written and signed in her presence? With regard to this <b>woman, once her bill of divorce reaches her hand, she is divorced. Rav Huna says:</b> This mishna is referring <b>to one who says</b> to his wife: <b>You will be divorced through it only in the presence of such and such court,</b> and the divorce does not take effect when she receives the bill of divorce. The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately, once she arrives there,</b> to that court, <b>she is</b> immediately <b>divorced through it,</b> as she has fulfilled the condition set forth by her husband. Why, then, is it necessary for her to bring the bill of divorce and to testify?
<b>Rather, Rav Huna bar Manoaḥ said in the name of Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika:</b> This mishna is referring to a case <b>where he said to her: When you arrive there, place</b> the bill of divorce <b>on the ground and take it.</b> Consequently, the divorce does not take effect immediately upon her arrival.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If that is so, isn’t it</b> like the case where he said to his wife: <b>Take your bill of divorce from off the ground, and Rava says:</b> If a husband says to his wife: <b>Take your bill of divorce from off the ground,</b> then it is as though <b>he said nothing.</b> He is not considered to have given her a bill of divorce; rather, she has taken it on her own.
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna should be explained as follows: This is referring to a case <b>where he said to</b> his wife: <b>Be</b> my <b>agent for delivery</b> of the bill of divorce <b>until you arrive there. And when you arrive there, be</b> your own <b>agent for receipt, and receive your bill of divorce</b> as an agent.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But the agency has not returned to the husband.</b> In other words, the first agency, where she acted as the agent for delivery, has not ended, because an agent must have the ability to complete his involvement in the act, return to the person who appointed him, and inform him that the agency has been carried out. In this case, once she arrives at the court, her agency ends when she assumes the role of the recipient of the bill of divorce, and her involvement does not end. Therefore, the appointment of the agent itself is deficient, and the divorce should not take effect. Rather, the mishna should be explained that he <b>said to her: Be an agent for delivery until you arrive there, and when you arrive there, appoint an agent for receipt</b> on your behalf and give him the bill of divorce.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who said: A woman can appoint an agent to receive her bill of divorce from the hand of the agent of her husband,</b> and it is not required that she receive the bill of divorce herself. <b>However, according to the one who says: A woman cannot appoint an agent to receive her bill of divorce from the hand of the agent of her husband, what can be said?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>What is the reason</b> of the one who said that the woman cannot appoint an agent to receive her bill of divorce from the agent of her husband? <b>Because there is degradation of the husband</b> in doing this, as he wishes to give the bill of divorce directly to the woman and not to an agent. <b>And here the husband is not particular</b> about the matter, as he instructed her to do so.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>This works out well according to the one who said:</b> The reason for this <i>halakha</i> is <b>due to</b> the concern about the <b>degradation of the husband. But according to the one who says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is a decree <b>due to</b> the case of <b>her courtyard that comes afterward, what can be said?</b> Some say that the reason for the <i>halakha</i> that the woman cannot appoint an agent to receive the bill of divorce from the agent of her husband is that there was a concern that if she were able to do so, then the courts may eventually allow her to be divorced by purchasing a courtyard into which her husband had placed the bill of divorce. In the latter case, the divorce does not take effect. The courtyard needs to be an extension of the hand of the woman, into which the husband places the bill of divorce, but it does not act as her agent. In any event, according to this opinion, the fact that the husband is not particular does not prevent this <i>halakha</i> from applying, as it does not depend on him.
The Gemara answers: According to this opinion, the mishna should be explained as discussing a case <b>when he said to her: Be an agent for delivery</b> of this bill of divorce <b>until you arrive there, and when you arrive there, appoint</b> another <b>agent for delivery, and receive your bill of divorce from him.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>he said to her: Be an agent for delivery until you arrive there, and when you arrive there, say before the court: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence, and you should</b> then <b>appoint the court as an agent, and they will give</b> the bill of divorce <b>to you.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any bill of divorce that was not written for the sake of</b> a specific <b>woman</b> is <b>invalid. How so?</b> In a case of a man who <b>was passing through the marketplace and heard the sound of scribes</b> who write bills of divorce <b>dictating</b> the text to their students: The <b>man so-and-so divorces so-and-so from the place</b> of <b>such and such; and</b> the man <b>said: This is my name and that is the name of my wife,</b> and he wishes to use this bill for his divorce, this bill is <b>unfit</b> for him <b>to divorce</b> his wife <b>with it,</b> as it was not written for the sake of any woman.
<b>Moreover,</b> if one <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce with which <b>to divorce his wife but</b> later <b>reconsidered,</b> and <b>a resident of his town found him and said to him: My name is</b> the same <b>as your name, and my wife’s name is</b> the same <b>as your wife’s name,</b> and we reside in the same town; give me the bill of divorce and I will use it; the bill of divorce is <b>unfit</b> for the second man <b>to divorce</b> his wife <b>with it.</b>

Daf 24b

<b>Moreover,</b> if <b>one had two wives and their names were identical,</b> and he <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>to divorce the older</b> one and then reconsidered, <b>he may not divorce the younger</b> one <b>with it.</b>
<b>Moreover,</b> if <b>he said to the scribe: Write</b> a bill of divorce <b>for whichever</b> one of them <b>that I will want</b> and <b>I will divorce</b> her with it, this bill of divorce is <b>unfit</b> for him <b>to divorce</b> either wife <b>with it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The second clause of the mishna considers a case where one <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce with which <b>to divorce his wife but</b> later <b>reconsidered,</b> and a resident of his town with identical personal details found him and desired to use the bill of divorce. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> then <b>with what</b> case is the <b>first clause</b> of the mishna, where a man discovers that a scribe had written a bill of divorce with identical personal details to his own, dealing; isn’t that also a case of a bill of divorce that was written for someone else? Why did the <i>tanna</i> cite two seemingly identical cases?
<b>Rav Pappa said: We are dealing with scribes who are practicing</b> writing; the bill of divorce in the first case was written as an exercise and not because someone requested that it be written. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches: Scribes dictating,</b> i.e., to their students, <b>and it does not teach: Scribes reading</b> the names on their own. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from</b> this phrasing that this is the correct understanding of the mishna.
By employing the introductory term: Moreover, the mishna indicates that each case teaches an additional novelty beyond that of the previous case. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> novel element warrants the use of the term: <b>Moreover?</b> The Gemara answers by quoting a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that <b>not</b> only <b>this</b> bill of divorce, which was written for practice and <b>which was not written for the sake of divorce,</b> is unfit, <b>but even that</b> bill of divorce, <b>which was written for the sake of divorce</b> but the husband then reconsidered and did not use it, is <b>unfit</b> to be used by someone else.
<b>And not</b> only <b>this</b> bill of divorce, <b>which was not written for the sake of his own divorce,</b> is unfit, <b>but even that</b> bill of divorce, <b>which was written for the sake of his own divorce,</b> albeit for a particular wife, is <b>unfit</b> to be used for divorcing his other wife. <b>And not</b> only <b>this</b> bill of divorce, <b>which was not written for the sake of this</b> wife’s <b>divorce, but even that</b> bill of divorce, <b>which was written for this</b> wife’s <b>divorce,</b> as he instructed the scribe to write the bill of divorce for the sake of whichever wife he decides to divorce, is <b>unfit</b> to use in divorce.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that a bill of divorce must be written for the sake of the woman who is being divorced? It is stated in the verse that deals with divorce: “And he writes for her a scroll of severance and gives it in her hand” (Deuteronomy 24:1). This teaches the following: <b>If</b> the Merciful One had <b>written</b> only: <b>And he gives a scroll of severance in her hand, I would say</b> that the verse serves <b>to exclude this</b> case of the <b>first</b> clause of the mishna, <b>where it was done not for the sake of severance,</b> as the scribe wrote the bill of divorce as a mere exercise; <b>however,</b> if one <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>to divorce his wife but</b> then <b>reconsidered, where</b> it was <b>done for the sake of severance,</b> I would <b>say</b> that it is <b>valid</b> for another man to use for divorcing his wife. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah: <b>“And he writes,”</b> meaning that the bill of divorce must be written exclusively for the sake of his own divorce.
The Gemara continues the explanation: <b>If the Merciful One</b> had <b>written</b> only: <b>And he writes, I would say</b> that the verse serves <b>to exclude this</b> case mentioned previously, <b>where</b> the man using the bill of divorce <b>was not the one who wrote it; but</b> if a man <b>has two wives</b> with the same name, so <b>that</b> the man using the bill of divorce <b>is writing it, say</b> that it is a <b>valid</b> bill of divorce. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah: “And he writes <b>for her,”</b> teaching that a bill of divorce must be written <b>for the sake of</b> a specific wife.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need <b>the last clause</b> of the mishna, which deals with a man who writes a bill of divorce for whichever wife he later chooses? The earlier clauses made clear that one must write the bill of divorce for the sake of the woman who is being divorced. The Gemara answers: <b>This teaches us that there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification,</b> i.e., that one does not say that since he gave the bill of divorce to this wife, it is clarified retroactively that he had written the bill of divorce for her sake; rather, he must write it for her sake from the outset.
§ The mishna teaches: If he <b>wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>to divorce the older</b> of his two wives and then reconsidered, he <b>may not divorce the younger</b> wife <b>with it,</b> even though the two wives share the same name. The Gemara deduces from this: <b>It is the younger</b> one <b>whom he is not able to divorce with it, but he is able to divorce the older</b> wife <b>with it,</b> as it was written for her from the outset. This is the case even though the younger wife would be able to collect payment of her marriage contract and remarry if she were to present this bill of divorce, as the court would think it was written for her.
<b>Rava said: That is to say</b> that one of <b>two</b> people with identical names, e.g., <b>Yosef ben Shimon, who live in one city, can present a promissory note</b> to claim a debt from <b>others,</b> and the borrower cannot claim that the promissory note was written for the other Yosef ben Shimon.
<b>Abaye said to him: If that is so,</b> then according to your reasoning, from <b>the earlier clause</b> of the mishna <b>that teaches</b> that if one man requests a bill of divorce from another, saying: <b>My name is</b> the same <b>as your name,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>unfit</b> for the second person <b>to divorce</b> his wife <b>with it,</b> one could infer that the <b>second</b> man <b>is</b> the one <b>who is not able to divorce with it, but</b> the <b>first</b> man <b>is able to divorce with it</b> even though they have the same names. <b>But didn’t we say</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 172a): With regard to two people with identical names, neither of them can present a promissory note to the other, <b>and another</b> person <b>cannot present a promissory note to them,</b> as each one can deny that he is the one who owes the money? Here too, there is a concern lest the wife of the other use the bill of divorce to collect payment of her marriage contract even though the bill of divorce was not written for her.
<b>Rather, what have you to say</b> to explain how the first man can divorce his wife with this bill of divorce, and how it can be used as a reliable proof of divorce? One can say that the ruling of the mishna applies <b>in</b> a case where there are <b>witnesses who observe the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce, and they confirm in court which woman was given the bill of divorce. <b>And this</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who holds that presence of witnesses at the transmission of the bill of divorce is essential to its taking effect, so there is no concern that the wife of the other man will claim payment of her marriage contract.
<b>Here too,</b> in the case of two wives of the same man who have the same name, the ruling of the mishna applies <b>in</b> a case where there are <b>witnesses who observe the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce. <b>And this</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> and there is no concern that the other wife will claim payment of her marriage contract. Therefore, one should not deduce from this, as Rava did, that one of two people with the same name can present a promissory note to claim a debt from others.
§ <b>Rav says: All</b> of the bills of divorce that the mishna categorizes as unfit to use for divorce still <b>disqualify</b> the women who receive them from marrying <b>into</b> the <b>priesthood,</b> as she is considered a divorced woman with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of marrying a priest, <b>except for the first</b> bill of divorce mentioned in the mishna. Unlike the other cases, that one was not written for the sake of divorce at all but was written only as part of a scribe’s training. <b>And Shmuel says: Even</b> the <b>first</b> bill of divorce <b>disqualifies</b> her from marrying into the priesthood.
<b>And Shmuel follows his</b> own line of <b>reasoning, as Shmuel says: Any place where the Sages taught</b> in a mishna: <b>An invalid bill of divorce,</b> it indicates both that it is <b>invalid</b> to be used as a bill of divorce <b>and</b> that it nevertheless <b>disqualifies</b> the one who receives it from marrying a priest. Similarly, where the Sages taught: <b>An invalid <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> it indicates both that the <i>ḥalitza</i> is <b>invalid and</b> that it nevertheless <b>disqualifies</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>from</b> entering into levirate marriage with <b>the</b> other <b>brothers.</b>
<b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they say in the name of Rabbi Elazar:</b> If <i>ḥalitza</i> was performed on the <b>left</b> foot of the <i>yavam</i>, <b>or</b> at <b>night,</b> these acts of <i>ḥalitza</i> are <b>invalid, and</b> they nevertheless <b>disqualify</b> the <i>yevama</i> from entering into levirate marriage with the other brothers.

Daf 25a

However, if the <i>yavam</i> was <b>a minor, or</b> if the <i>yevama</i> performed <i>ḥalitza</i> while he was wearing <b>a soft shoe made of cloth [<i>anpileya</i>]</b> and not the shoe used for <i>ḥalitza</i>, then these acts of <i>ḥalitza</i> are <b>invalid, and</b> in these cases <b>they do not disqualify</b> her from entering into levirate marriage.
The Gemara quotes another opinion with regard to the question of which of the bills of divorce mentioned in the mishna would disqualify the woman from marrying a priest. <b>Ze’eiri says:</b> Reception of <b>any</b> of the bills of divorce mentioned in the mishna <b>does not disqualify</b> the woman from marrying a priest <b>except</b> in <b>the final</b> case, where the husband instructed the scribe to write a bill of divorce for one of his wives and explained that he would later decide which wife would be given the bill of divorce.
<b>And similarly, Rav Asi says:</b> Reception of <b>any</b> of the bills of divorce mentioned in the mishna <b>does not disqualify</b> the woman from marrying a priest <b>except</b> in <b>the final</b> case. <b>But Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even</b> in <b>the final</b> case, that bill of divorce <b>does not disqualify</b> her from marrying a priest <b>as well,</b> as even that bill of divorce is not a bill of divorce at all. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, there is no concern that retroactive clarification will determine that the bill of divorce was written for the sake of the woman who received it, while the <i>amora’im</i> who hold that the woman is disqualified from marrying a priest in the final case of the mishna regard the efficacy of retroactive clarification to be uncertain.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> own line of <b>reasoning.
