As Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Brothers who divided</b> property they received as an inheritance <b>are</b> considered <b>purchasers</b> from each other, <b>and</b> as purchasers of land <b>they must return</b> the portions <b>to each other in the Jubilee</b> Year. In the Jubilee Year, all land that had been purchased since the previous Jubilee Year reverts to the possession of the original owner. In this case, the land the brothers inherited from their father reverts to their joint ownership. Evidently, when they divided the land, this is not viewed as if it is retroactively clarified who inherited which portion from their father.
<b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan to state that there is no retroactive clarification both with regard to inheritance and with regard to a bill of divorce, <b>as, if it were stated</b> only <b>with regard to this</b> case, that of a bill of divorce, then one could say that <b>with regard to this Rabbi Yoḥanan said that there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification because we require</b> that the bill of divorce be written in accordance with the verse: “He writes <b>for her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:3), i.e., <b>for her sake; but there,</b> in the case of inheritance, one could say: <b>It is</b> only in the case of <b>a sale that the Merciful One states that it will be returned in the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>but an inheritance and a gift</b> will <b>not</b> be returned.
<b>And if he</b> had <b>taught us</b> that there is no retroactive clarification only with regard to the inheritance of <b>a field,</b> then one could say that this is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> he holds that they must redistribute the property only <b>as a stringency,</b> but he would hold that in this case one must also be stringent and be concerned that it is a divorce. <b>Alternatively,</b> perhaps Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling was not because there is no retroactive clarification but because the <i>halakha</i> of the Jubilee Year requires that all land be returned to its state <b>as</b> it was <b>initially,</b> when the land had been divided among the tribes; <b>but here,</b> with regard to a bill of divorce, <b>say</b> that this consideration is <b>not</b> relevant, and there is retroactive clarification. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan to rule that there is no retroactive clarification in each case separately.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the final case of the mishna. <b>Rav Hoshaya asked of Rav Yehuda:</b> If a husband <b>said to a scribe: Write</b> a bill of divorce <b>for whichever</b> of my wives <b>emerges</b> from <b>the entrance first, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: You learned it</b> already in the mishna: <b>Moreover,</b> even if he <b>said to the scribe: Write</b> a bill of divorce <b>for whichever</b> one of them <b>that I will want</b> and <b>I will divorce</b> her with it, it is <b>unfit</b> for him <b>to divorce</b> either wife <b>with it. Apparently, there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification.</b>
Rav Hoshaya <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Yehuda’s answer based on a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 89a): In the case of <b>one who says to his children: I am slaughtering the Paschal offering on behalf of whichever of you goes up first to Jerusalem, once</b> the <b>first</b> of the children <b>has entered</b> with <b>his head and the majority of his</b> body into Jerusalem, <b>he has acquired his portion and acquires</b> the portions of <b>his brothers</b> together <b>with him</b> on their behalf. This mishna indicates that there is retroactive clarification, as it becomes clear retroactively that the father slaughtered the Paschal offering on behalf of this son.
Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: Hoshaya, my son, what do Paschal offerings have to do with bills of divorce? Wasn’t it stated concerning this</b> mishna that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The mishna is not based on retroactive clarification; rather, the father included all his children in his Paschal offering from the outset. He created this competition only <b>in order to galvanize them,</b> so that they would be expeditious <b>in</b> their fulfillment of <b>mitzvot.</b>
The Gemara comments that according to the explanation of Rabbi Yoḥanan, the language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches: Once</b> the <b>first</b> of the children <b>has entered</b> with <b>his head and the majority of his</b> body into Jerusalem, <b>he has acquired his portion and acquires</b> the portions of <b>his brothers</b> together <b>with him</b> on their behalf. <b>Granted, if you say that</b> the father <b>registered them initially,</b> before slaughtering the Paschal offering, the ruling is <b>well</b> understood. <b>But if you say that he did not register them</b> initially, <b>can they</b> then <b>be registered after the slaughter</b> of the Paschal offering? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 89a): People may <b>be registered and withdraw themselves from</b> being registered for a Paschal offering <b>until it is slaughtered,</b> but not after? Clearly, then, the children must have already been registered before the father said his statement.
<b>That</b> the competition was meant only to galvanize his children to be expeditious in their fulfillment of mitzvot <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that records this type of competition: There was <b>an incident</b> such as this, <b>and the daughters preceded the sons. And the daughters were found</b> to have demonstrated that they were <b>enthusiastic,</b> whereas <b>the sons</b> were found to have demonstrated that they were <b>lazy.</b> The <i>baraita</i> is critical of the sons but does not say that they did not partake of the Paschal offering. Evidently the father slaughtered the offering for them as well.
Questioning Rav Yehuda’s original answer to Rav Hoshaya, <b>Abaye said:</b> He <b>asks him</b> about a case where one <b>makes</b> the clarification <b>dependent on the decision of others, but he resolves it</b> based on a case where the husband <b>makes</b> the clarification <b>dependent on his own decision.</b> Rav Hoshaya asked about a bill of divorce written for whichever wife exits first, which depends on someone other than the husband, and Rav Yehuda resolved the question based on the mishna where the husband reserved the right to decide which wife he will divorce with the bill of divorce, which depends on his own decision. <b>And then</b> Rav Hoshaya <b>raised an objection to him</b> based on the mishna concerning the Paschal offering, where <b>one makes</b> the clarification <b>dependent on the decision of others.</b>
<b>Rava said: What is the difficulty</b> here? <b>Perhaps</b> it is so <b>that</b> for the <b>one who accepts</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification,</b> it <b>is no different</b> if one <b>makes it dependent on his own decision, and</b> it <b>is no different</b> if one <b>makes it dependent on the decision of others.</b> In either case, <b>he accepts</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification. And</b> according to the <b>one who does not accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification,</b> it <b>is no different</b> if one <b>makes it dependent on his own decision, and</b> it <b>is no different</b> if one <b>makes it dependent on the decision of others.</b> In either case, <b>he does not accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification.</b>
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya said to Rava:</b> The issue of retroactive clarification is contingent upon the question of on whom the outcome is dependent. <b>But</b> isn’t there the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who in a case <b>where</b> one <b>makes it dependent on his own decision, he does not accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification, but</b> when one <b>makes it dependent on the decision of others, he accepts</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification?</b>
The Gemara elaborates: When one <b>makes it dependent on his own decision,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>does not accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification, as it is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Demai</i> 8:7): In the case of <b>one who purchases wine from among the Samaritans,</b> about whom it is assumed that they did not separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes, and he is not in a position to now separate <i>teruma</i>, he acts as follows: If there are, for example, one hundred <i>log</i> of wine in the barrels, he <b>says: Two <i>log</i> that I will separate in the future are <i>teruma</i>,</b> as the mandated average measure of <i>teruma</i> is one-fiftieth; <b>ten</b> <i>log</i> are <b>first tithe;</b> and one-tenth of the remainder, which is approximately <b>nine</b> <i>log</i>, are <b>second tithe.</b>

Daf 25b

<b>And he deconsecrates</b> the second tithe that he will separate in the future, transferring its sanctity to money, <b>and</b> he may <b>drink</b> the wine <b>immediately,</b> relying on the separation that he will perform later, which will clarify retroactively which <i>log</i> he designated for the tithes and for <i>teruma</i>. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> this practice, as they hold that in this case there is no retroactive clarification. It is therefore evident that according to Rabbi Yehuda, there is no retroactive clarification where one makes the clarification dependent on his own decision.
By contrast, in a case where one <b>makes</b> the outcome <b>dependent on the decision of others,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>accepts</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification, as we learned</b> in a mishna (73a): In a case where an ill husband says to his wife: This is your bill of divorce from now if I die due to this illness, if he dies, the bill of divorce takes effect from the time of his statement. The mishna asks: <b>What</b> is the halakhic status of the wife <b>in those days</b> between when the bill of divorce was given but before the husband died?
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: She is like a married woman with regard to all of her matters,</b> and she remains forbidden to other men; <b>and when he will die, it is a bill of divorce.</b> Death is equivalent to a matter that is dependent on the decision of others. Since Rabbi Yehuda agrees that the bill of divorce takes effect retroactively, as it cannot take effect after the death of the husband, he evidently holds that there is retroactive clarification where one makes the clarification dependent on the decision of others.
Furthermore, <b>Rav Mesharshiyya said to Rava: But</b> isn’t there <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who, in a case <b>where</b> one <b>makes</b> the outcome <b>dependent on his own decision, does not accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification, but</b> when one <b>makes it dependent on the decision of others, he accepts</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification?</b>
The Gemara elaborates: When one <b>makes</b> the outcome <b>dependent on his own decision,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>does not accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification.</b> This is understood from <b>that which we said</b> in the case of wine purchased from Samaritans. When <b>one makes</b> the outcome <b>dependent on the decision of others,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>accepts</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Kiddushin</i> 3:7): If a man said to a woman: <b>I am engaging in sexual intercourse with you</b> for the purpose of betrothal <b>on the condition that</b> my <b>father will desire</b> our betrothal, and then he married her without specification, then <b>even if the father did not desire</b> it <b>she is</b> nevertheless <b>betrothed</b> through this act of intercourse. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> If <b>the father desires</b> it, <b>she is betrothed,</b>

Daf 26a

and if <b>the father does not desire</b> it, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> It is therefore evident that according to Rabbi Shimon, there is retroactive clarification when one makes the outcome dependent on the decision of others, as in this case whether or not this betrothal takes effect is dependent on the desire of the father.
Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Mesharshiyya: <b>Whether</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> or <b>whether</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> it <b>is no different</b> if one <b>makes</b> the outcome <b>dependent on his own decision, and it is no different</b> if one <b>makes it dependent on the decision of others; they</b> both <b>accept</b> the principle of retroactive <b>clarification.</b>
Rava explains: <b>And there,</b> in the mishna about one who purchases wine from Samaritans, they do not prohibit him from relying on the separation that he will later perform because they do not accept the principle of retroactive clarification. Rather, the <b>reason</b> they do not prohibit him from relying on the separation that he will later perform is <b>as</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Demai</i> 8:7) <b>teaches:</b> The Sages <b>said to Rabbi Meir: Don’t you concede</b> that <b>perhaps the wineskin will burst</b> before he manages to separate the <i>teruma</i>, <b>and this</b> person <b>will have been found retroactively</b> to be <b>drinking untithed produce?</b> Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: When it</b> actually <b>bursts,</b> there will be a concern. In any event, from the question that they addressed to Rabbi Meir, it is clear that they would accept the principle of retroactive clarification in this case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a scribe <b>who writes the standard</b> part <b>[<i>tofes</i>] of bills of divorce</b> in advance, so that when one requests a bill of divorce, he will need to add only the details unique to this case, <b>he must leave</b> empty the <b>place</b> in the bill of divorce for the name <b>of the man, and</b> the <b>place</b> for the name <b>of the woman, and</b> the <b>place for the date.</b>
If a scribe writes the standard part of <b>loan documents, he must leave</b> empty the <b>place</b> of the name <b>of the lender,</b> the <b>place</b> of the name <b>of the borrower,</b> the <b>place</b> of the amount <b>of the money</b> being loaned, and the <b>place of the date.</b>
If the scribe writes the standard part of <b>documents of sale</b> of land, <b>he must leave</b> empty the <b>place</b> for the name <b>of the purchaser, and</b> the <b>place</b> for the name <b>of the seller,</b> the <b>place</b> for the amount <b>of the money</b> for which the land is being purchased, the <b>place</b> for the description <b>of the field</b> that is being purchased, <b>and</b> the <b>place of the date</b> when the sale occurs. This is necessary <b>due to the ordinance,</b> as the Gemara will explain.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda invalidates all of</b> these documents if their standard parts were written in advance. <b>Rabbi Elazar deems all of them valid except for bills of divorce, as it is stated</b> in the Torah: <b>“And he writes for her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), indicating that he must write the bill of divorce <b>for her sake.</b> Therefore, one may not write even the standard part of the bill of divorce in advance, as that would not qualify as writing the bill of divorce for her sake.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> One writing a bill of divorce in advance <b>must also leave</b> the <b>place</b> on the standard portion of the bill of divorce to write the essential phrase <b>of: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man. And</b> the unattributed opinion of the mishna <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, <b>and we require</b> the <b>writing</b> of the essential part of the bill of divorce to be <b>for her sake.</b> If one holds the other opinion, that signatory witnesses on the bill of divorce effect the divorce, then the words “And he writes for her” are referring to the signing of the bill of divorce, and the writing itself need not be done for her sake.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for Shmuel to mention that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar in this mishna, as well as Rabbi Elazar’s opinion in the previous chapter with regard to the <i>mishnayot</i> that discuss writing a bill of divorce on a surface that is attached to the ground (21b) and the writing of a bill of divorce by a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor (22b).
<b>As, if</b> he had <b>taught us</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar only with regard to <b>this first</b> mishna (21b), which discusses writing a bill of divorce on a surface that is attached to the ground, one could have said <b>it is</b> only <b>that</b> mishna <b>that can be interpreted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, as that</b> mishna <b>teaches: One may not write</b> a bill of divorce on anything that is attached to the ground, <b>and it teaches</b> in the next clause: If <b>one wrote it</b> on something that is attached to the ground; and there the Gemara proves from the comparison between these two clauses that the mishna must be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar.
<b>However,</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the next mishna (22b), <b>which teaches</b> that the reason a bill of divorce may be written by a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor is that <b>the ratification of a bill of divorce is only through its signatories,</b> one could <b>say</b> that <b>this is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: Signatory witnesses</b> on the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, and the mishna is discussing a case where the entire bill of divorce was written by the deaf-mute, imbecile, or minor. Therefore, it was necessary for Shmuel to state that this mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar and is discussing a case where the essential part of the bill of divorce was left empty.
<b>And if</b> he had <b>taught us with regard to that</b> mishna (22b), then it would be possible to say: <b>That</b> mishna <b>can also be interpreted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> as it is explained that the mishna is referring to the writing of the standard portion, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>this</b> mishna here, <b>say: Since the last clause is</b> explicitly attributed to <b>Rabbi Elazar, the first clause</b> must <b>not</b> be in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b> Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> for Shmuel to note that each of three <i>mishnayot</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar.
The mishna teaches that the scribe may write the standard part of the document in advance, leaving empty the essential part, <b>due to the ordinance.</b> The Gemara asks: To <b>what ordinance</b> is the mishna referring? <b>Rabbi Yonatan says: Due to the ordinance</b> for the benefit <b>of a scribe,</b> i.e., to enable a scribe to write the standard part of a document in advance so that when a customer arrives he will not need to write the document hurriedly. <b>And it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce. <b>And</b> according to Rabbi Elazar’s opinion, <b>by right it</b> should have been <b>that</b> the scribe <b>would not write even</b> the <b>standard</b> part of the document in advance, as that part must also be written for her sake, <b>but due to the ordinance</b> for the benefit <b>of scribes, the Sages permitted</b> it.
The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Yehuda invalidates all of</b> these documents, not only bills of divorce, even if only their standard parts were written in advance. The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yehuda <b>decreed</b> that one may not write the <b>standard</b> part of a document in advance <b>due to</b> the concern lest the scribes eventually come to write the <b>essential</b> part of a document <b>[<i>toref</i> ]</b> in advance as well. Similarly, <b>he decreed</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to all <b>documents,</b> which need not be written for anyone’s sake, <b>due to bills of divorce.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>And Rabbi Elazar deems all of them valid except for bills of divorce.</b> The Gemara explains his reasoning: Rabbi Elazar <b>decreed</b> that one may not write the <b>standard</b> part of a document in advance <b>due to</b> the concern lest the scribes eventually come to write the <b>essential</b> part of the document in advance. However, <b>he did not decree</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to all <b>documents,</b> which need not be written for anyone’s sake, <b>due to bills of divorce.</b>
The mishna teaches that Rabbi Elazar invalidates bills of divorce when the standard part of the document was written in advance, <b>as it is stated</b> in the Torah: <b>“And he writes for her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), which teaches that it must be written for her sake. The Gemara asks: <b>But when it is written:</b> “And he writes <b>for her,”</b> it is <b>about</b> the <b>essential</b> part of a document <b>that it is written,</b> and not about the standard part.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, say</b> that Rabbi Elazar invalidates bills of divorce when the standard part of the bill of divorce is written in advance <b>because it is stated</b> with regard to the essential part of the bill of divorce: <b>“And he writes for her,”</b> which teaches that it must be written <b>for her sake.</b> In other words, Rabbi Elazar decrees that even the standard part of the document must be written for her sake, due to the fact that the Torah delineates this requirement with regard to the essential part of the bill of divorce.

Daf 26b

The Gemara asks: If the first clause of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, this is <b>difficult,</b> as there is a contradiction between the explicit statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar</b> in the last clause of the mishna, where he rules that a scribe may not write the standard part of a bill of divorce in advance, <b>and</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Elazar</b> in the first clause of the mishna that a scribe may write the standard part of a bill of divorce in advance. The Gemara answers: There are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar.</b>
The Gemara returns to discussing the ordinance mentioned in the mishna. <b>Rabbi Shabbetai</b> says that <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> The ordinance mentioned in the mishna was not instituted for the benefit of scribes, allowing them to prepare the standard part of bills of divorce in advance. The ordinance was instituted <b>due to</b> the desire to prevent <b>a quarrel, and it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who says: Signatory witnesses</b> on the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, and there is no need for the bill of divorce to be written for the sake of the woman.
He continues to explain the ordinance: <b>And by right it</b> should have been <b>that</b> the scribe would be permitted <b>to write even</b> the <b>essential</b> part of the bill of divorce <b>as well. But sometimes</b> there might be a wife <b>who hears the scribe who</b> by chance <b>is writing</b> in advance a bill of divorce with her name, <b>and she thinks that</b> her husband <b>told him</b> to write the bill of divorce on his behalf, <b>and she will have a quarrel with him.</b> Therefore, the Sages instituted an ordinance that the scribe may not write the essential part of the bill of divorce in advance, as it includes the names of the husband and the wife.
The Gemara suggests another understanding of the ordinance mentioned in the mishna. <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Avimi</b> said: The reason for the ordinance is <b>due to</b> the desire to provide <b>a remedy for deserted wives.</b> How so? <b>Some say</b> that he explained the mishna in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and some say</b> that he explained it in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Some say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: Signatory witnesses</b> on the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce; <b>and by right it</b> should have been <b>that</b> the scribe would be permitted <b>to write,</b> in advance, <b>even</b> the <b>essential</b> part of the bill of divorce <b>as well. But sometimes</b> there could be a situation <b>when</b> the husband <b>has a quarrel with</b> his wife <b>and becomes angry with her, and he</b> might <b>throw</b> the bill of divorce <b>to her and desert</b> her <b>and leave her</b> divorced because he possessed a bill of divorce that had been prepared in advance. The Sages therefore instituted that a complete bill of divorce may not be prepared in advance to ensure that it would take time for the husband to obtain one, in the hope that he would calm down in the interim and reconsider.
<b>Some say</b> that he explains the mishna in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who said: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce; <b>and by right it</b> should have been <b>that</b> scribes would <b>not</b> be permitted <b>to write</b> in advance <b>even</b> the <b>standard</b> part of the bill of divorce <b>as well,</b> due to a decree lest they come to write the essential part in advance. <b>But sometimes</b> the husband <b>needs to travel to a country overseas, and he will not find a scribe</b> who can write the bill of divorce for him, <b>and he will abandon her and go and desert</b> her <b>and leave her</b> in this position. The Sages instituted that scribes may write the standard part of the bill of divorce in advance, so that they can finish it quickly by simply adding the essential part.
§ The mishna teaches that the scribe must leave a place for the names <b>and a place for the date.</b> The Gemara comments: The <i>tanna</i> <b>categorically teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i>; it <b>is no different</b> if the divorce is <b>from the</b> state of <b>marriage, and it is no different</b> if the divorce is <b>from the</b> state of <b>betrothal.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Granted,</b> in the case of a divorce <b>from the</b> state of <b>marriage,</b> it is understood why the bill of divorce must be dated. <b>Whether according to the one who said</b> that the reason for writing the date on a bill of divorce is <b>due to</b> a situation where one marries <b>the daughter of his sister,</b> to prevent the husband from protecting her if she commits adultery by giving her an undated bill of divorce and claiming that they had been divorced before she committed adultery with the other man, <b>there is</b> a reason to record the date, or <b>whether according to the one who said</b> that it is <b>due to</b> a concern for her <b>produce,</b> to enable her to collect the produce of her usufruct property from the moment they are divorced, <b>there is</b> a reason to record the date.
<b>But</b> in the case of a divorce <b>from the</b> state of <b>betrothal, granted, according to the one who said</b> that the date is written on a bill of divorce <b>due to</b> a situation where one marries <b>the daughter of his sister, there is</b> the same concern where she is divorced after being betrothed, as the <i>halakhot</i> of adultery take effect from the time of betrothal. <b>But according to the one who said</b> that it is <b>due to</b> a concern for her <b>produce, does a betrothed woman have produce?</b> In any case, the husband has a right to use his wife’s property only after they are married. Therefore, it is not necessary to protect her rights by dating the bill of divorce to show when the husband’s rights to her property terminate.
<b>Rav Amram said: I heard this matter from Ulla, who said</b> that the date is written on the bill of divorce <b>for the benefit of</b> the <b>child, and I did not know what this</b> benefit <b>is. Once I heard that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who says: Write a bill of divorce for my betrothed, as when I will bring her in</b> to my home in marriage <b>I will divorce her</b> with it, <b>it is not a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce. And Ulla said: What</b> is the <b>reason</b> that it is not a valid bill of divorce? Since once he marries her she may become pregnant, there is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> due to the concern <b>lest they say</b> that receipt of <b>her bill of divorce precedes</b> conception of <b>her son,</b> as it was written while they were betrothed. <b>Here too,</b> the reason the scribe must leave the place of the date in a bill of divorce for a betrothed woman is that the husband may marry her before divorcing her, and there is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> due to the concern <b>lest they say</b> that receipt of <b>her bill of divorce precedes</b> conception of <b>her son.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba bar Sheila says</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna Sava says</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> with regard to writing the standard portion of the bill of divorce in advance is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> that such a bill of divorce is invalid. Upon hearing this ruling, <b>Rav proclaimed about Rabbi Elazar:</b> He is <b>the most gratified of</b> the <b>Sages,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar <b>even with regard to other documents as well,</b> that it is permitted for scribes to write the standard portion of other documents in advance? <b>But didn’t Rav Pappi say in the name of Rava:</b> With regard to <b>this ratification of judges,</b> which serves to confirm the authenticity of a promissory note <b>that was written before the witnesses had testified about their signatures</b> on the promissory note, it is <b>invalid,</b> even if the witnesses later attested that those were their signatures. <b>Apparently</b> it has the <b>appearance of falsehood,</b> because the court ratified the document before hearing the testimony. <b>Here too,</b> if one writes the documents in advance, they have the <b>appearance of a falsehood.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> Rav Pappi’s statement that all documents written in advance are invalid because they have the appearance of falsehood <b>is not</b> accepted, <b>because</b> of the statement <b>of Rav Naḥman. As Rav Naḥman said: Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that signatory witnesses on the bill of divorce effect the divorce, <b>would say: Even</b> if a husband <b>found</b> an unsigned bill of divorce <b>in the garbage,</b> and <b>he had it signed and gave it to</b> his wife, it is <b>valid,</b> as he holds that the manner of the writing of the bill of divorce does not affect whether or not it is a valid bill of divorce. <b>And even the Rabbis disagree with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir only with regard to bills of divorce,</b> as they hold <b>that we require</b> the <b>writing</b> to be <b>for her sake; but with regard to other documents,</b> they do <b>not</b> disagree.
The Gemara comments: The proof of this is <b>that Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of a promissory <b>note with which one borrowed</b> money <b>and</b> the borrower then <b>repaid</b> the debt, <b>he may not borrow money again with it.</b> The reason is <b>that its lien has already been forgiven.</b> Once the debt has been repaid, the lien resulting from the loan is no longer in force. The witnesses did not sign the document again at the time of the second loan, so the lien will not be in effect, and the loan will have the status of one by oral agreement. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that he cannot reuse the document is <b>that its lien has been forgiven,</b> so that the document is no longer accurate. <b>But as</b> for the fact that it has the <b>appearance of falsehood,</b> as it was written prior to the second loan, <b>we are not concerned.</b>

Daf 27a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce and it</b> was <b>lost from him,</b> if he <b>finds it immediately</b> then the bill of divorce is <b>valid. But if not,</b> then it is <b>invalid,</b> as it is possible that the bill of divorce that he found is not the same one that he lost, and this second bill of divorce belongs to someone else whose name and wife’s name are identical to the names of the husband and wife in the lost bill of divorce. However, if <b>he found it in a <i>ḥafisa</i> or in a <i>deluskema</i></b> that he knows is his, or <b>if he recognizes</b> the actual bill of divorce, then it is <b>valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if a bill of divorce was lost before being received by the woman it is invalid unless it was found immediately. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 18a): If <b>one found bills of divorce, or</b> bills <b>of manumission, wills [<i>dayetikei</i>],</b> deeds of <b>gifts, or receipts, this</b> finder <b>should not return</b> these items to the one who is presumed to have lost them, <b>as I say</b> it is possible that <b>they were written and</b> then the writer <b>reconsidered about them</b> and decided <b>that he would not give them.</b> One could infer from this mishna as follows: <b>But</b> if the writer <b>said: Give</b> these found documents to the intended recipient, <b>one gives</b> them, <b>and</b> this is true <b>even</b> if <b>a long time</b> passed since they were lost, and there is no concern that perhaps this document belongs to someone else with the same name.
<b>Rabba said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the mishna that rules that the bill of divorce cannot be used unless it was found immediately, it is stated <b>with regard to a place where caravans are</b> frequently <b>found,</b> and there is a concern that the found bill of divorce belongs to someone else with the identical name. <b>There,</b> in the mishna in tractate <i>Bava Metzia</i>, it is stated <b>with regard to a place where caravans are not</b> frequently <b>found,</b> so one may return the document if he knows that the writer did not reconsider.
The Gemara comments: <b>And even in a place where caravans are</b> frequently <b>found,</b> there is not always a concern that the bill of divorce may belong to another man with an identical name, <b>but</b> this concern <b>is</b> only <b>where it has been established</b> that there are <b>two</b> men named, e.g., <b>Yosef ben Shimon, in</b> that <b>one town.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> that this concern is taken into account only in a place where it is known that there are two people with the same name, then there is a <b>difficulty</b> presented in the form of a contradiction between this statement <b>of Rabba and</b> another statement <b>of Rabba. As</b> there was <b>a certain bill of divorce that was found,</b> i.e., brought, in <b>the court of Rav Huna, and</b> the name of the place that <b>was written in it</b> was: <b>In Sheviri the city, which is on the Rakhis River. And Rav Huna said: One is concerned about</b> the possibility of the existence of <b>two</b> cities called <b>Sheviri,</b> and it is possible that this bill of divorce belongs to another man with an identical name.
The Gemara continues: <b>And Rav Ḥisda said to Rabba,</b> who was then a student: <b>Go out and examine this</b> <i>halakha</i>, <b>as Rav Huna</b> will <b>ask you about it at night.</b> Rabba <b>went out, examined</b> it, <b>and discovered</b> a relevant source. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 20a): <b>One should return all court enactments,</b> i.e., promissory notes that have been authenticated by the court, to their owner, and there is no concern that perhaps there are two towns with the identical name and that the promissory note belongs to someone else.
The Gemara explains: <b>But isn’t the court of Rav Huna comparable to a place where caravans are</b> frequently <b>found,</b> as there were always many people present there? <b>And</b> yet Rabba <b>resolved</b> the question and ruled that <b>one should return</b> the document to the owner, which appears to contradict his earlier ruling that one should not return a document found in a place where caravans are frequently found. <b>Apparently</b> he holds that <b>if it is established</b> that there are <b>two</b> people named <b>Yosef ben Shimon in one town,</b> then <b>yes,</b> there is a concern and the document should not be returned, <b>but if not,</b> there is <b>no</b> concern.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabba performed an action,</b> i.e., issued a practical ruling, <b>with regard to a certain bill of divorce that was found in the flax house in</b> the city of <b>Pumbedita, in accordance with his</b> ruling of <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> As to the details of this incident, <b>there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this was <b>in the place where</b> people <b>soaked flax, and although it was established</b> that there were two people with the same name living in the city mentioned in the bill of divorce, he ruled this way since it was a place <b>where caravans are not</b> frequently <b>found. And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this occurred <b>in a place where</b> people <b>sold flax, and it was not established</b> that two people with the same name lived in the city where the bill of divorce was written, <b>and</b> this occurred in a place where <b>caravans are</b> frequently <b>found.</b>
Concerning this issue, the Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a contradiction</b> between <b>the mishna and a <i>baraita</i> and</b> then <b>answers</b> it: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce and it</b> was <b>lost from him, if he finds it immediately</b> then the bill of divorce is <b>valid. And if not,</b> it is <b>invalid. And</b> he <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that states: If one <b>found a woman’s bill of divorce in the marketplace,</b> then <b>when the husband admits</b> that he wrote it and gave it, the finder should <b>return</b> it <b>to the woman.</b> If <b>the husband does not admit</b> to this, then he should <b>not return</b> it, <b>not to this</b> man <b>and not to this</b> woman. One can infer from here: <b>But</b>

Daf 27b

<b>when the husband admits</b> that he wrote it, <b>in any event</b> he should <b>return</b> it <b>to the woman, and</b> by omission this appears to be the <i>halakha</i> <b>even if a long time</b> has passed since the bill of divorce was lost. <b>And</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>answers: Here,</b> in the mishna where it states that he should not return it, it is stated <b>with regard to a place where caravans are</b> frequently <b>found; there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> where it states that he should return it, it is stated <b>with regard to a place where caravans are not</b> frequently <b>found.</b>
The Gemara compares the rulings of Rabba and Rabbi Zeira. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> with regard to Rabbi Zeira’s statement that he should not return it in a place where caravans are frequently found: <b>And this is</b> the case <b>when it is established</b> that there are two people in the town with the identical name. In <b>that</b> case, Rabbi Zeira holds <b>that it should not be returned, and this is</b> the same ruling as that <b>of Rabba. And there are</b> those <b>who say:</b> In a place where caravans are frequently found, <b>even though it is not established</b> that there are two people with identical names, <b>it should not be returned, and</b> he <b>disagrees with</b> the ruling <b>of Rabba.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Granted that Rabba did not say</b> a discourse <b>like</b> that of <b>Rabbi Zeira</b> and raise a contradiction from the <i>baraita</i>, as <b>he</b> holds that it is <b>a stronger</b> challenge <b>to raise a difficulty</b> from <b>the mishna</b> in tractate <i>Bava Metzia</i> because the Mishna, redacted by Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, employs more precise language than <i>baraitot</i>. <b>But what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Zeira did not say</b> a discourse <b>like</b> that of <b>Rabba</b> and raise a contradiction from the mishna in tractate <i>Bava Metzia</i>?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Zeira could have <b>said to you: Does</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that <b>if he said: Give</b> the found document to the intended recipient, <b>one gives</b> it, <b>and</b> this is so <b>even</b> if <b>a long time</b> passed? This was only an inference from the mishna. <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna should be interpreted differently, so as to teach: <b>If he said: Give</b> it, then <b>one gives</b> it, but this is only <b>as we maintain</b> in the mishna, when it is found <b>immediately,</b> not if a long time has passed.
The Gemara offers an alternative resolution to the contradiction between the mishna here, on the one hand, and the mishna in tractate <i>Bava Metzia</i> and the <i>baraita</i>, on the other hand. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> It is possible to resolve the contradiction in a different way: The latter permit one to return a lost bill of divorce only in a case <b>where</b> the <b>witnesses</b> who signed the bill of divorce <b>say: We have never signed a bill of divorce of Yosef ben Shimon other than</b> this <b>one,</b> in which case there is no concern that the bill of divorce belongs to someone else.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> that one returns the bill of divorce? Since it clearly belongs to her, there is no question that it must be returned to her. The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>one should be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps it happened</b> that another bill of divorce was written in which <b>the names</b> of the husband and the wife <b>are identical to the names</b> of the husband and wife of the second bill of divorce, <b>and</b> the names of the <b>witnesses</b> on that bill of divorce <b>are identical to</b> the names of the <b>witnesses</b> on this bill of divorce, when in fact they are different witnesses. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that this is not a concern.
The Gemara suggests an alternative resolution to the contradiction. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> When do the mishna in tractate <i>Bava Metzia</i> and the <i>baraita</i> rule that one should return the bill of divorce? It is in a case <b>where</b> the one who lost it <b>says: There is a hole in</b> the bill of divorce, <b>next to such and such a letter, as this is a clear-cut distinguishing mark for him.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> Rav Ashi permits the returning of such a bill of divorce <b>specifically</b> when one says that the hole is <b>next to such and such a letter, as that is a clear-cut distinguishing mark for him. But</b> if he said <b>only</b> that it had <b>a hole</b> without mentioning its precise location, then one should <b>not</b> return the bill of divorce, as that is not considered a clear-cut distinguishing mark.
The Gemara explains: Rav Ashi <b>is uncertain</b> with regard to <b>whether</b> the obligation to return a lost item to its owner on the basis of <b>distinguishing marks</b> is <b>by Torah law</b> or <b>if</b> it is <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Therefore, in the case of a bill of divorce, he holds that one may rely only on a clear-cut distinguishing mark, as everyone agrees that the requirement to return a lost item to its owner on the basis of a clear-cut distinguishing mark is by Torah law.
Apropos this discussion the Gemara relates an incident: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana lost the bill of divorce</b> that he was transmitting, when he was <b>in the study hall. He said: If</b> they request <b>a distinguishing mark, I have</b> one <b>for it. If</b> it depends on <b>visual recognition, I have</b> methods of recognition <b>for it. They returned</b> the bill of divorce <b>to him. He said</b> afterward: <b>I do not know if they returned it due to the distinguishing mark</b> that I supplied, <b>and they hold that distinguishing marks</b> are used to return lost items <b>by Torah law,</b> or <b>if it was due to</b> my <b>visual recognition, and</b> it is <b>specifically Torah scholars [<i>tzurva miderabbanan</i>]</b> like me who are relied upon when they say that they recognize an item, <b>but an ordinary man</b> would <b>not</b> be relied upon to recognize the item and have it returned to him.
§ The mishna teaches that if one found the bill of divorce immediately, it is valid, <b>but if not,</b> then it is <b>invalid. The Sages taught: What is</b> considered <b>not immediately? Rabbi Natan says:</b> It is <b>when</b> there was <b>a delay equivalent</b> to the amount of time it would take <b>for a caravan to pass</b> by <b>and camp</b> there. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> There is no fixed amount of time; rather, it is within the category of immediately <b>as</b> long as <b>there will be a person</b> that <b>stands and sees that no</b> other <b>person passed there. And some say</b> that he said: It is as long <b>as no person stopped there. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It is within the category of immediately if there was not a delay <b>equivalent</b> to the amount of time it would take <b>to write the bill of divorce. Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> It is equivalent not to the amount of time needed write the bill of divorce, but <b>equivalent</b> to the amount of time it would take <b>to read it. Others say:</b> It is <b>equivalent</b> to the amount of time it would take <b>to write it and to read it.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>And even</b> if there was <b>a delay and</b> the bill of divorce <b>has distinguishing marks on it,</b> the marks <b>attest to it</b> and it is considered a valid bill of divorce. This is the <i>halakha</i> where the distinguishing marks are clear-cut, e.g., <b>when they say: It has a hole next to such and such a letter. And one may not testify with regard to distinguishing marks of the</b> physical description of the bill of divorce <b>itself,</b> e.g., <b>where they say:</b> This bill of divorce is <b>long or short,</b> as these are not considered distinguishing marks.
In a case where one found a bill of divorce <b>tied</b> up <b>in a pouch</b> or <b>in a purse [<i>arnaki</i>], or</b> encircled <b>in a ring,</b> and he recognizes the document,

Daf 28a

<b>or</b> in a case <b>where he found it among his utensils</b> in his house, then <b>even</b> if <b>a long time</b> passed, the bill of divorce is <b>valid.</b>
<b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the <i>halakha</i> in this dispute: <b>Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that the bill of divorce is valid as long <b>as no person stopped there. Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> says that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that the bill of divorce is valid as long <b>as no</b> other <b>person passed there.</b>
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to state the actual opinion? <b>Let</b> this <b>Sage,</b> Rav Yehuda citing Shmuel, <b>say</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of this <b>Sage,</b> the opinion cited as: Some say; <b>and</b> let this <b>Sage,</b> Rabba bar bar Ḥana citing Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel, say that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of this <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> there are those <b>who reverse</b> the opinions of the <i>tanna’im</i>, they needed to state the opinions explicitly so that there would be no mistake with regard to the <i>halakha</i>.
§ The mishna teaches that if one <b>found</b> the bill of divorce <b>in a <i>ḥafisa</i> or in a <i>deluskema</i>,</b> then it is valid. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the word <b><i>ḥafisa</i>? Rabba bar bar Ḥana says:</b> It is <b>a small flask. What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>deluskema</i>?</b> It is <b>a purse [<i>telika</i>] of the elderly.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce</b> to a woman, <b>and</b> when <b>he had left</b> the husband was <b>elderly or sick,</b> the agent <b>gives her</b> the bill of divorce <b>based on</b> the <b>presumption that</b> the husband <b>is</b> still <b>alive,</b> and there is no concern that in the meantime he has died, thereby canceling the bill of divorce.
Similarly, with regard to <b>an Israelite woman who is married to a priest</b> and may therefore partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and her husband went to a country overseas, she may</b> continue to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i> based on</b> the <b>presumption that</b> her husband <b>is</b> still <b>alive.</b> Similarly, in the case of <b>one who sends his sin</b>-<b>offering from a country overseas,</b> the priests may <b>offer it</b> on the altar <b>based on</b> the <b>presumption that</b> the one who sent it <b>is</b> still <b>alive.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rava says: They taught</b> that this presumptive status exists <b>only</b> concerning <b>an elderly man who has not reached</b> his years of <b>strength,</b> i.e., the age of eighty, <b>and</b> an ordinary <b>sick person, as</b> the <b>majority of sick</b> people continue <b>to live</b> and recover from their illnesses. <b>But</b> if the husband was <b>an elderly man who had reached</b> his years of <b>strength, or</b> if he was <b>moribund,</b> then, <b>as the majority of moribund</b> people proceed <b>to die,</b> he does <b>not</b> have this presumptive status.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rava’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce and left</b> the husband when he was <b>old, even one hundred years old, he gives</b> the bill of divorce <b>to</b> the wife, <b>based on</b> the <b>presumption that</b> her husband <b>is</b> still <b>alive.</b> The Gemara concludes: This is <b>a conclusive refutation,</b> and Rava’s statement is rejected.
The Gemara comments: <b>And if you wish, say</b> that this is not a conclusive refutation. In the case of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>since</b> it is so <b>that</b> the man <b>reached an exceptionally</b> old age, one cannot apply the general presumptions to him and must instead apply presumptions that are for one who has <b>reached an exceptionally</b> old age. However, in a case where someone has not demonstrated that he is an exception to the rule, once he reaches the age of eighty there is a concern that perhaps he has died in the interim.
§ <b>Abaye raises a contradiction before Rabba: We learned</b> in the mishna that in the case of an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce</b> to a woman <b>and left</b> the husband when he was <b>elderly or sick,</b> the agent <b>gives her</b> the bill of divorce <b>based on</b> the <b>presumption that</b> the husband <b>is</b> still <b>alive. And</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:11) that states: If one is leaving his place of residence, and in order to preclude a situation where his wife would have the status of a deserted wife he gives her a conditional bill of divorce and stipulates: <b>This is your bill of divorce</b> that will take effect <b>one hour prior to my death, it is immediately prohibited for her to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> due to the concern that he may die immediately after an hour has passed. Apparently, there is a concern that one may die at any point.
Rabba <b>said to him:</b> Do <b>you raise a contradiction</b> from the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>teruma</i> to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>bills of divorce?</b> Concerning <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> it is <b>possible</b> for the wife to eat only non-sacred produce in order to be stringent due to the possibility that her husband may die. However, concerning <b>a bill of divorce it is not possible</b> to take into account the possibility that her husband may die, as there would then be no way for a husband to send a bill of divorce to her with an agent.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>teruma</i></b> in the mishna <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>teruma</i></b> in a <i>baraita</i>. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>an Israelite woman who is married to a priest</b> and may therefore partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and her husband went to a country overseas, she may</b> continue to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i> based on</b> the <b>presumption that</b> her husband <b>is</b> still <b>alive.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If one says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce</b> that will take effect <b>one hour prior to my death, it is immediately prohibited for her to partake of <i>teruma</i></b> due to the concern that he may die immediately after an hour has passed. These two <i>halakhot</i> appear to contradict one another.
<b>Rav Adda, son of Rav Yitzḥak, said:</b> It <b>is different there, as he rendered her forbidden to himself one hour prior to his death,</b> meaning that she will definitely be prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i> at some point. Therefore, it is considered to be an uncertainty immediately. <b>Rav Pappa objects to this</b> answer: <b>From where</b> is it known <b>that he will die first</b> and she will be prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i>? <b>Perhaps she will die first,</b> and the bill of divorce will never take effect.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that this is <b>not difficult: This</b> mishna, which permits the woman to partake of <i>teruma</i>, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who is not concerned about</b> potential <b>death. That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits the woman from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who is concerned about</b> potential <b>death.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Demai</i> 8:7): In the case of <b>one who purchases wine from among the Samaritans,</b> about whom it is assumed that they did not separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes, and he is not in a position to separate <i>teruma</i>, he acts as follows: If there are, for example, one hundred <i>log</i> of wine in the barrels, <b>he says: Two <i>log</i> that I will separate in the future are <i>teruma</i>,</b> as the mandated average measure of <i>teruma</i> is one-fiftieth; <b>ten</b> <i>log</i> are <b>first tithe;</b> and one-tenth of the remainder, which is approximately <b>nine</b> <i>log</i>, are <b>second tithe. And he deconsecrates</b> the second tithe that he will separate in the future, transferring its sanctity to money, <b>and</b> he may <b>drink</b> the wine <b>immediately,</b> relying on the separation that he will perform later, which will clarify retroactively what he designated for the tithes and for <i>teruma</i>. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: However, <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> this practice. These Sages, Rabbi Yehuda among them, were concerned that perhaps the wineskin would burst before he would manage to separate the <i>teruma</i>, whereas Rabbi Meir is not concerned about this occurring. Similarly, it is said that Rabbi Meir is not concerned about potential death, and Rabbi Yehuda is concerned.
<b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 28b

There is a different distinction: <b>We are not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he</b> has already <b>died,</b> which is why the mishna rules that she may continue to partake of <i>teruma</i>. However, in the case of one who stipulates that the bill of divorce will take effect one hour before his death, <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he will die</b> at an unknown moment in the future and she will no longer be permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to Rava: But</b> the concern in the case of the <b>wineskin</b> is that it might burst before one is able to separate the <i>teruma</i> and tithes, <b>which is similar</b> to the concern that <b>perhaps he will die,</b> as both are concerns with respect to the future, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Meir <b>disagree. Rav Yehuda of Diskarta said: A wineskin is different, as it is possible to give it to a watchman</b> who will protect it from bursting, which is why Rabbi Meir is not concerned that it might burst. This reasoning does not apply to the concern that the husband might die.
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya objects to this</b> answer: <b>Your guarantor</b> himself <b>needs a guarantor,</b> as there is no way of knowing that the guardian will not be negligent, so the wineskin may burst. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> Everyone agrees that <b>we are not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps he</b> has already <b>died,</b> in accordance with the mishna here. As to the issue of whether there is a concern that <b>perhaps he will die,</b> as in the case of the <i>baraita</i>, this <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that in the case of <b>one who sends his sin-offering from a country overseas,</b> the priests may sacrifice it on the altar, based on the presumption that the one who sent it is still alive. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> an offering <b>require</b> the <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on the head of an offering by the one who brings the offering? In this case the owner of the offering is elsewhere and cannot place his hands on the offering. <b>Rav Yosef says:</b> The mishna states this ruling <b>with regard to the offering of women,</b> as women are not required to place their hands on the head of their offerings. <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The mishna states this ruling <b>with regard to a bird</b> sacrificed as <b>a sin-offering,</b> where it is not required that the owner place his hands on the head of the offering.
Noting that the mishna states the same <i>halakha</i>, that the presumption is that one remains alive, in three different contexts, the Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to state this in all three cases, <b>as, if it</b> had <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>a bill of divorce,</b> one might have said that it is <b>due to</b> the fact that it is <b>not possible</b> to take into account the possible death of the husband, as there would then be no way for the husband to send a bill of divorce to his wife with an agent. That is why the presumption that the husband is alive is relied upon. <b>But</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>, where</b> it is <b>possible</b> for the wife to partake of non-sacred produce, <b>say</b> the presumption is <b>not</b> relied upon, and there is a concern that he died.
<b>And if it</b> had <b>taught us</b> also the case of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> one might have said <b>that</b> there are <b>times that</b> it is <b>not possible</b> for the wife to avoid partaking of <i>teruma</i>, e.g., if she does not have sufficient non-sacred produce. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a bird</b> sacrificed as <b>a sin-offering,</b> one might say that <b>for</b> a situation of <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether the sin-offering may be sacrificed, since its owners might not be alive, <b>one should not bring non-sacred</b> animals, i.e., an animal that may not be sacrificed, <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to mention all of these cases.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Perata said three statements before the Sages</b> as testimony from previous generations, <b>and they upheld his statements:</b> He spoke <b>concerning</b> the residents of <b>a town that was surrounded</b> by <b>a camp of besiegers [<i>karkom</i>]; and concerning the</b> travelers in <b>a ship that is cast about in the sea; and concerning one who is going out to be judged</b> in a capital case; <b>that they are</b> all <b>presumed to be alive.</b>
<b>However,</b> concerning the residents of <b>a town that was conquered</b> by <b>a camp of besiegers; and</b> the travelers on <b>a ship that was lost at sea; and one who is going out to be executed</b> after receiving his verdict; in these cases <b>one applies to them the stringencies of</b> the <b>living and the stringencies of</b> the <b>dead.</b> How so? <b>An Israelite woman</b> married <b>to a priest</b> in one of these situations <b>or a daughter of a priest</b> married <b>to an Israelite</b> in one of these situations <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The first woman may not do so because she may partake of <i>teruma</i> only while her husband is alive, and the second may not do so because she may partake of <i>teruma</i> only if he has died.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yosef says: They taught</b> that one applies the stringencies of the living <b>only</b> to one who is being taken to be executed <b>in a Jewish court,</b> where even once he is being taken to be executed, he will be released if the court finds evidence for his innocence; <b>but in a court of the nations of the world, once he is sentenced to death, he is killed</b> in any case. Therefore, he should be considered as a dead man in every regard.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> In <b>a court of the nations of the world as well,</b> perhaps they will not execute him, <b>as they accept bribes.</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: When they take</b> a bribe, it is only <b>before the verdict [<i>puresei shenmag</i>] has been sealed;</b> but <b>after the verdict has been sealed, they do not take</b> bribes.
According to Rav Yosef, in a Jewish court, even after one’s verdict is complete the presumption is that he is alive. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this from a mishna (<i>Makkot</i> 7a) concerning one who fled from the court after his verdict had been issued: <b>Any place where two</b> witnesses <b>arise and say: We testify about so-and-so that his judgment was finalized in the court of so-and-so, and so-and-so and so-and-so</b> were <b>his witnesses,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>this</b> person <b>should be killed.</b> It is evident from the mishna in tractate <i>Makkot</i> that there is no concern that the court may have later found a reason to release him. The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps one who flees is different,</b> as the court will not reconsider his verdict once he has fled.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If one <b>heard from a Jewish court that they were saying:</b> The <b>man so-and-so died,</b> or: The <b>man so-and-so was killed,</b> then the court allows <b>his wife to marry.</b> If he heard <b>from a gentile judicial registrar [<i>komentirisin</i>]:</b> The <b>man so-and-so died,</b> or: The <b>man so-and-so was killed,</b> then the court does <b>not</b> allow <b>his wife to marry.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> does it mean when it says: <b>Died, and what</b> does it mean when it says: <b>Was killed? If we say</b> that: <b>Died,</b> means that he <b>actually died, and: Was killed,</b> means that he <b>was actually killed,</b> such <b>that</b> the case <b>concerning the gentiles</b> is stated in <b>a similar manner,</b> i.e., that he heard from the gentile registrar that the person was actually dead, <b>why</b> may the court <b>not</b> allow <b>his wife to marry? Don’t we maintain that</b> with regard to <b>any</b> gentile who <b>speaks offhandedly,</b> the Sages <b>deemed him credible?</b> Therefore, the gentile should be deemed credible when he says that someone died or was killed.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> necessary to explain that when it says: <b>Died,</b> it means that he is <b>going out to die,</b> and when it says: <b>Was killed,</b> it means <b>going out to be executed. And</b> it <b>teaches</b> that if it occurred <b>in a Jewish court</b> then the court allows <b>his wife to marry,</b> as it is assumed that he was already executed, contrary to the statement of Rav Yosef.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it can be explained that he <b>actually died, and actually was killed. And</b> with regard to <b>that which you said:</b> Such <b>that</b> the case <b>concerning the gentiles</b> is stated in <b>a similar manner, why</b> may the court <b>not</b> allow his wife to marry? <b>Don’t we maintain that</b> with regard to <b>any</b> gentile who <b>speaks offhandedly,</b> the Sages <b>deemed him credible?</b> The answer is that <b>this</b> credibility <b>applies</b> only <b>in a matter that is not relevant to</b> the gentiles; <b>but in a matter that is relevant to</b> the gentiles, such as here, where they desire to publicize that they carried out their verdict, it is <b>common for them to reinforce their false</b> verdict, i.e., once they reach a verdict they will say that the accused was killed. Therefore, one cannot rely on their statements.
This is one version of the discourse; there is also another version: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rav Yosef said: They taught</b> that one applies the stringencies of the living and the dead <b>only in a court of the nations of the world;</b>

Daf 29a

<b>but in a Jewish court, once his verdict to be executed has emerged, they execute him.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> In <b>a Jewish court as well, it is possible that</b> the court will <b>see</b> fit to <b>acquit him</b> afterward and he will be released. Rav Yosef said: When the court <b>sees</b> fit to <b>acquit him,</b> it is <b>before the verdict; after the verdict</b> the court will <b>not further see</b> fit to <b>acquit him,</b> as it is uncommon for the court to find a reason to acquit him after his verdict has been delivered.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that a mishna (<i>Makkot</i> 7a) <b>supports</b> Rav Yosef’s opinion: Concerning one who fled from the court after his verdict was issued, the mishna states: <b>Any place where two</b> witnesses <b>arise and say: We testify about so-and-so that his verdict was finalized in the court of so-and-so, and so-and-so and so-and-so</b> were <b>his witnesses,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>this</b> person <b>should be killed.</b> It is evident from the mishna in tractate <i>Makkot</i> that there is no concern that the court might later have found a reason to release him. The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps one who flees is different,</b> as the court will not reconsider his verdict once he has fled.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If one <b>heard from a Jewish court that they were saying:</b> The <b>man so-and-so died,</b> or: The <b>man so-and-so was killed,</b> then the court allows <b>his wife to marry.</b> If he heard <b>from a gentile judicial registrar:</b> The <b>man so-and-so died,</b> or: The <b>man so-and-so was killed,</b> then the court does <b>not</b> allow <b>his wife to marry.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> does it mean when it says: <b>Died, and what</b> does it mean when it says: <b>Was killed? If we say</b> that it means that he <b>actually died, and</b> that he <b>actually was killed,</b> such <b>that</b> the case <b>concerning the gentiles</b> is stated in <b>a similar manner,</b> i.e., that he heard from the gentile registrar that the person was actually dead, <b>why</b> may the court <b>not</b> allow <b>his wife to marry? Don’t we maintain that</b> with regard to <b>any</b> gentile who <b>speaks offhandedly,</b> the Sages <b>deemed him credible?</b> Therefore, the gentile should be deemed credible when he says that someone died or was killed.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> necessary to explain that when it says: <b>Died,</b> it means that he is <b>going out to die, and</b> when it says: <b>Was killed,</b> it means that he is <b>going out to be executed. And</b> it <b>teaches:</b> If one heard <b>in a Jewish court</b> then the court allows <b>his wife to marry,</b> as it is assumed that he was already executed, in support of the statement of Rav Yosef.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it can be explained that he <b>actually died, and was actually killed;</b> and with regard to that which you said: Such <b>that</b> the case <b>concerning the gentiles</b> is stated in <b>a similar manner, why</b> may the court <b>not</b> allow his wife to marry? <b>Don’t we maintain that</b> with regard to <b>any</b> gentile who <b>speaks offhandedly,</b> the Sages <b>deemed him credible?</b> The answer is that <b>this</b> credibility <b>applies</b> only <b>in a matter that is not relevant to</b> the gentiles; <b>but in a matter that is relevant to</b> the gentiles, such as here, where they desire to publicize that they carried out their verdict, it is <b>common for them to reinforce their false</b> verdict.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce in Eretz Yisrael,</b> where his only responsibility is to transmit the bill of divorce to the wife, <b>and</b> the agent <b>became sick, this</b> agent may <b>send it in the possession of another</b> agent. <b>But if</b> the husband <b>said to</b> the agent: When you transmit the bill of divorce to my wife, <b>take for me such and such an item from her</b> that I left with her as a deposit, then <b>he may not send it in the possession of another</b> agent. This is because it is assumed <b>that it is not</b> the <b>desire</b> of the husband <b>that his deposit be in the possession of another</b> person whom he did not appoint as his agent.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Kahana said: We learned</b> in the mishna that the agent <b>became sick;</b> otherwise, he may not appoint a second agent. The Gemara asks: This <b>is obvious, as</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> explicitly that the agent <b>became sick.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>the same is true,</b> i.e., that he may transfer the bill of divorce to another agent, <b>even though</b> the agent <b>did not become sick, and</b> the reason <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> specifically that <b>he became sick</b> is that the mishna <b>teaches the matter in the manner in which it</b> typically occurs, as an agent typically fulfills his agency, barring unavoidable circumstances, therefore, Rav Kahana <b>teaches us</b> that an agent may appoint another agent only when he becomes sick.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of his appointment as an agent? <b>If</b> this is a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>said to</b> the agent: <b>Deliver</b> this bill of divorce to my wife, then <b>even though</b> the agent <b>did not become sick,</b> he may <b>also</b> appoint an agent in his place, as the husband did not state that he must be the one to deliver the bill of divorce. <b>And if</b> this is a case <b>where he said to</b> the agent: <b>You, deliver</b> this bill of divorce to my wife, then <b>even</b> if <b>he became sick, he also may not</b> appoint a second agent in his place, as the husband specified that he must be the one to deliver the bill of divorce. <b>And if</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> then <b>even</b> if <b>he became sick</b> he <b>also may not</b> appoint a second agent, no matter what the husband said.
The Gemara explains: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (2:13): If the husband said to an agent: <b>Deliver this bill of divorce to my wife,</b> then <b>this</b> agent <b>may send it in the possession of another</b> agent. However, if the husband said: <b>You, deliver this bill of divorce to my wife,</b> then <b>this</b> agent <b>may not send it in the possession of another</b> agent. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Whether</b> the husband said it <b>like this or</b> whether the husband said it <b>like that, the agent may not designate another agent.</b> Therefore, Rav Kahana’s statement is difficult.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where the husband said to his agent: <b>Deliver</b> the bill of divorce, without specifying that he must be the one to do so, and Rav Kahana understood the <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>And this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that he may send it in the possession of another agent, applies only <b>when</b> the agent <b>became sick. And if you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where the husband said: <b>You deliver, but one who became sick is different,</b> and it is assumed that under those circumstances the husband would allow him to designate another agent. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that the mishna <b>is</b> even in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that an agent is ordinarily not permitted to designate another agent. <b>But</b> a case where the agent <b>became sick is different,</b> and the agent may designate another agent.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce in Eretz Yisrael, and</b> the agent <b>became sick, this</b> agent may <b>send it in the possession of another</b> agent. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna (66a): If the husband <b>said to two</b> people: <b>Give a bill of divorce to my wife, or</b> if he said <b>to three</b> people: <b>Write a bill of divorce and give</b> it <b>to my wife,</b> then <b>these</b> people <b>should write</b> it <b>and give</b> it. The Gemara infers from the mishna: <b>They</b> themselves, <b>yes,</b> they should do so, <b>but</b> one whom they appoint as <b>an agent</b> may <b>not</b> do so.
<b>Abaye said: There, what is the reason</b> that an agent may not be appointed? It is <b>due to degradation of the husband,</b> who does not want the matter to become known, and therefore they may not designate another agent. However, <b>here,</b> after he has already sent the bill of divorce, the <b>husband is not particular</b> that word not spread, and therefore the agent may designate another agent in his place.
<b>Rava said:</b> There is a different reason that in the case of the mishna (66a) the agent may not appoint another to write the bill of divorce; it is <b>because</b> of the fact <b>that</b> in the case there, the husband’s instructions <b>are</b> mere <b>words, and</b> verbal <b>directives cannot be delegated to an agent,</b> i.e., an agent cannot be deputized to give instructions on behalf of another. Therefore, they cannot take their oral instructions and transfer them to another. In the case of the mishna here, the agent is able to give the physical bill of divorce to another agent and thereby transfer his agency.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the explanations offered by Abaye and Rava? The Gemara answers: There is a practical difference <b>between them</b> in the case of <b>an agent</b> appointed to write a deed of <b>a gift, and</b> their disagreement is parallel <b>to the dispute of Rav and Shmuel. Rav says:</b> A deed of <b>gift is not like a bill of divorce,</b> as the gift giver does not care who writes the deed. Since it is not degrading to him if another agent writes the deed of gift instead of the agent that he appointed, the agent may appoint another agent. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> A deed of <b>gift is like a bill of divorce,</b> as the mere words instructing the agent to write the deed cannot be transferred to another agent.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>But if</b> the husband <b>said to</b> the agent: When you transmit the bill of divorce to my wife, <b>take for me such and such an item from her,</b> then the agent may not appoint a second agent, as it is not the desire of the husband that his deposit be in the possession of another. <b>Reish Lakish says: Here, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught</b> that <b>a borrower is not allowed to lend</b> the item that he borrowed to someone else, <b>and a renter is not allowed to rent out</b> the item that he rented to someone else. In those cases, the same reasoning applies, i.e., that it is not the desire of the owner that his item be in the possession of another.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: Even schoolchildren know this</b> <i>halakha</i>, and this is not the novel idea expressed in the mishna. The novel idea expressed in the mishna is as follows: Not only is it not permitted for an agent to appoint another agent in this case, as it violates the desire of the husband, <b>but sometimes</b> it happens <b>that the bill of divorce is also not</b> valid if a second agent is appointed. This is <b>because</b> the first agent <b>becomes as one that</b> it <b>was said to him: Divorce her only in the house, and he divorced her in the attic;</b> or the husband said: <b>Divorce her only with</b> your <b>right</b> hand, <b>and he divorced her with</b> his <b>left</b> hand. Here as well, since the agent violated the instructions the divorce will not be valid.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that <b>when</b> it happens <b>that</b> the wife <b>went out to</b> greet <b>him and gave him the item</b> that the husband requested, <b>and then</b> she <b>took the bill of divorce from him,</b> in this case <b>everyone agrees that the bill of divorce is a proper bill of divorce. When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>when</b> the husband <b>said to</b> the agent:

Daf 29b

<b>Take an item from her and then give her the bill of divorce, and he went and gave her the bill of divorce and then took the item from her. Rabbi Yoḥanan invalidates</b> the bill of divorce even when given <b>by</b> the first agent, as he deviated from the husband’s instructions, and his agency is canceled, <b>and all the more so</b> does Rabbi Yoḥanan invalidate the bill of divorce when delivered <b>by</b> the first agent’s <b>agent. And Reish Lakish deems</b> the bill of divorce <b>valid</b> when it is delivered <b>by</b> the first agent’s <b>agent, and all the more so</b> when it is delivered <b>by</b> the first agent <b>himself.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an agent <b>who is bringing a bill of divorce from a country overseas,</b> who must attest to the fact that he witnessed the writing and signing of the bill of divorce, <b>and he became sick</b> and cannot complete his agency, <b>he appoints another agent in court and sends him. And</b> the first agent <b>says before</b> the court: <b>It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence,</b> and on the basis of this the court deems the bill of divorce to be valid. <b>And the final agent does not need to say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence. Rather,</b> it is sufficient that <b>he says: I am an agent of the court.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages said to Avimei, son of Rabbi Abbahu: Raise</b> the following <b>dilemma before</b> your father, <b>Rabbi Abbahu: Can an agent of</b> the first <b>agent</b> also <b>appoint</b> another <b>agent, or not? He said to them: You should not raise this dilemma. From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches: The final agent does not</b> need to say, as opposed to: The second agent does not need to say, it can be seen <b>by inference that</b> the second agent <b>can appoint an agent,</b> resulting in the existence of a final agent, not just a second agent.
<b>Rather, when you raise the dilemma,</b> this is what you should ask: <b>When</b> the second agent <b>appoints</b> another <b>agent,</b> does he need to appoint him specifically <b>in court, or</b> can he do so <b>even while not in court? They said to him: We do not raise this dilemma,</b> as <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches: Rather, he says: I am an agent of the court,</b> it is clear that any agent in this role must be appointed in court.
