The Gemara cites another version of the discussion. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> would <b>teach like this: The Sages said to Avimei, son of Rabbi Abbahu: Raise</b> the following <b>dilemma before</b> your father, <b>Rabbi Abbahu:</b> When the <b>agent of</b> the first <b>agent appoints</b> another <b>agent,</b> does he need to appoint him specifically <b>in court, or</b> can he do so <b>even while not in court?</b>
<b>He said to them: And you should raise the dilemma</b> as to <b>whether generally</b> the agent of the first agent <b>can appoint</b> another <b>agent. They said to him: We do not raise this dilemma, as we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The final agent does not</b> need to say, and <b>by inference</b> it can be seen <b>that</b> the second agent <b>can appoint an agent. Rather, when the dilemma was raised to us,</b> it was with respect to whether this must take place <b>in court, or</b> if it can take place <b>while not in court. He said to them: You should also not raise this dilemma, as</b> the mishna <b>teaches: Rather, he says: I am an agent of the court,</b> which shows that the subsequent appointments must take place in court.
§ <b>Rabba says: An agent in Eretz Yisrael can appoint several agents,</b> i.e., he can appoint an agent, and the second agent can appoint another agent in his place. All of this can take place outside of court, because when a bill of divorce is sent within Eretz Yisrael there is no need to testify that it was written and signed in the agent’s presence. <b>Rav Ashi says: If</b> the <b>first</b> agent <b>died,</b> then <b>they are all canceled,</b> as all the agents act on the basis of the first agent. With his death, the agency is canceled.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said: This</b> statement <b>of</b> my <b>father is</b> from the time <b>of his youth,</b> and it is not correct, as, <b>if</b> the <b>husband dies,</b> even if all of the agents are alive, <b>is there is any significance to</b> any of <b>them? All of them, from whose authority do they come</b> to deliver the bill of divorce? <b>They come from the husband’s authority.</b> Therefore, if the <b>husband is</b> alive, then <b>they are all</b> able to act as agents; if the <b>husband is not</b> alive, then <b>they are all not</b> agents. The status of the agents is dependent on the husband, not on the first agent.
§ The Gemara relates: There was an incident involving <b>a certain man who sent a bill of divorce to his wife</b> with an agent. <b>The agent said: I do not know her.</b> The husband <b>said to him: Go give</b> the bill of divorce <b>to Abba bar Minyumi, as he knows her, and he will go and give it to her.</b> The agent <b>came and did not find Abba bar Minyumi,</b> and he did not know what to do. <b>He found Rabbi Abbahu and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa, and Rav Safra was sitting among them.</b> The agent asked them what he should do. The first three Sages <b>said to him: Transfer your words,</b> i.e., your agency, <b>before us, as when Abba bar Minyumi comes, we will give</b> the bill of divorce <b>to him, and he will go and give it to her.</b>
<b>Rav Safra said to them: But isn’t he an agent who is not granted</b> the ability <b>to</b> effect <b>divorce,</b> as he was given only the authority to transfer the bill of divorce to Abba bar Minyumi? Therefore, he cannot transfer the agency to another person. These Sages <b>were embarrassed</b> that they ruled improperly.
<b>Rava said: Rav Safra struck [<i>kappeḥinhu</i>]</b> a blow <b>to three ordained Sages,</b> as although he was from Babylonia and not ordained, he was correct. <b>Rav Ashi said: With what did he strike them?</b> He did not conclusively refute their opinion, as, <b>did</b> the husband <b>say to the</b> agent: <b>Abba bar Minyumi</b> should deliver the bill of divorce <b>and not you?</b> Rather, he appointed this agent to deliver the bill of divorce, and added that if he cannot find the wife, then he can transfer the bill of divorce to Abba bar Minyumi.
The Gemara cites another version of the discussion: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rava said: Rav Safra struck three ordained Sages mistakenly. Rav Ashi</b> questioned Rava and <b>said: What</b> was <b>the mistake?</b> After all, <b>what did</b> the husband <b>say to</b> the agent? He said that <b>Abba bar Minyumi</b> should give his wife the bill of divorce, meaning that he <b>and not you</b> should give it, and Rav Safra’s ruling was correct.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was an incident involving <b>a certain man who sent a bill of divorce to his wife</b> with an agent. <b>He said to the agent: Do not give</b> the bill of divorce <b>to her until thirty days</b> have passed. <b>Circumstances</b> occurred <b>within</b> the <b>thirty days that were beyond</b> the agent’s <b>control,</b> and he saw that he would not be able to wait and give the wife the bill of divorce after thirty days, as per the husband’s instructions.
The agent <b>came before Rava</b> and asked what he should do. <b>Rava said: What is the reason</b> that the mishna permits an agent who <b>became sick</b> to appoint another agent in his place? It is <b>because he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control,</b> and in the case of <b>this</b> one <b>as well, he is a victim of circumstances beyond his control.</b> Rava <b>said to</b> the agent: <b>Transfer your words,</b> i.e., your agency, <b>before us</b> and we will serve as a court, so <b>that after thirty days we will appoint an agent and he will give</b> the bill of divorce <b>to her. The Sages said to Rava: But isn’t he an agent who is not granted</b> the ability <b>to</b> effect <b>divorce,</b> as within the thirty days he does not have the authority to divorce her? <b>He said to them: Since</b> it is so <b>that after thirty days he is able to divorce</b> her, <b>he is considered an agent who is granted</b> the ability <b>to</b> effect <b>divorce.</b>
The Sages challenged Rava again: <b>But</b> in any case where an agent does not deliver a bill of divorce immediately, <b>let there be a concern</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the husband <b>was mollified</b> and decided not to divorce his wife, thereby canceling the bill of divorce. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (76b): If, before traveling, a husband gives his wife a bill of divorce and says that it takes effect <b>from now if I do not arrive from now until twelve months</b> have passed, <b>and he died within</b> the <b>twelve months,</b> then <b>this is a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce?</b>
<b>And we discussed</b> this <i>halakha</i>: <b>And let there be a concern</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the husband <b>was mollified</b> and decided not to divorce his wife, and canceled the bill of divorce. <b>And Rabba bar Rav Huna said: This</b> is what <b>my father, my master,</b> Rav Huna, <b>said in the name of Rav:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>says:</b> My wife <b>is deemed credible to say that I did not arrive.</b> Since the husband abrogated his right to contest the validity of the divorce by granting absolute credibility to his wife, there is no concern that he may have canceled the bill of divorce, as even if he were to claim that he had done so, his claim would not be accepted. By contrast, in this incident, where the wife was never granted such credibility, there is a concern that perhaps he canceled the bill of divorce.
Rava <b>was embarrassed</b> that he ruled incorrectly. <b>Ultimately, the matter was revealed that</b> this woman <b>was</b> the husband’s <b>betrothed</b> and that they had not married. <b>Rava said: If they said</b> that there is a concern <b>with regard to a married woman</b> that perhaps he was mollified, <b>would they say</b> the same <b>with regard to a betrothed woman,</b> whom he does not know well? Therefore, my ruling was correct.
<b>Rava said: We certainly raise this dilemma:</b>

Daf 30a

<b>When the court appoints</b> a second <b>agent,</b> must they do so <b>in</b> the <b>presence of</b> the first agent, <b>or</b> may it be when <b>not in his presence? He then resolves it:</b> The second agent may be appointed <b>either in his presence and not in his presence.</b> Similarly, <b>they sent from there,</b> from Eretz Yisrael, this ruling: The court may appoint another agent <b>either in the presence</b> of the first agent <b>or not in his presence.</b>
§ The Gemara relates another incident, involving <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said</b> to the agents with whom he entrusted a bill of divorce: <b>If I do not arrive</b> from now <b>until thirty days</b> have passed, <b>let this be a bill of divorce. He came</b> at the end of the thirtieth day, <b>but he was prevented</b> from crossing the river <b>by the</b> fact that the <b>ferry</b> was located on the other side of the river, so he did not cross the river within the designated time. <b>He said to</b> the people across the river: <b>See that I have arrived, see that I have arrived. Shmuel said:</b> That <b>is not considered</b> to be <b>an arrival,</b> even though it is clear that he intended to arrive, so the bill of divorce is valid.
The Gemara relates: There was an incident involving <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> agents with whom he had deposited a bill of divorce: <b>If I do not appease</b> my wife <b>within thirty days, let this be a bill of divorce. He went</b> to <b>appease her, but she was not appeased. Rav Yosef said: Did he give her</b> a large <b>vessel [<i>tarkeva</i>]</b> full <b>of dinars but she was not appeased?</b> Although his inability to appease her was a result of his lack of financial means, since he did not properly fulfill his condition to appease her, the bill of divorce is valid.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of the statement, that <b>Rav Yosef said: Did he need to give her a vessel</b> full <b>of dinars</b> in order to appease her? This is a situation where <b>he</b> attempted to <b>appease her, but she was not appeased.</b> Therefore, he did fulfill his condition, and the bill of divorce is not effective, as it is not his fault that she was not appeased.
The Gemara explains the difference between the first and second versions of Rav Yosef’s statement: <b>This</b> second version, in which the bill of divorce does not take effect, is <b>according to the one who says: Circumstances beyond</b> one’s <b>control have</b> legal standing <b>with regard to bills of divorce.</b> Therefore, the bill of divorce is not valid, as the husband did all he could to appease her. <b>This</b> first version, in which the bill of divorce is valid, is <b>according to the one who says: Circumstances beyond</b> one’s <b>control</b> have <b>no</b> legal standing <b>with regard to bills of divorce.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna continues the discussion of the presumption that a person remains alive. With regard to <b>one who lends money to a priest, or to a Levite, or to a poor person,</b> with the understanding that <b>he will separate their portion</b> of the <i>teruma</i> and tithes from his produce <b>on the basis of that</b> money, i.e., he will subtract from the debt owed by the priest or Levite the value of the <i>teruma</i> and tithes separated from the produce, <b>he may separate</b> the <i>teruma</i> and tithes from his produce <b>on the basis of that</b> money <b>with the presumption that they are</b> still <b>alive, and he need not be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the priest or the Levite died</b> in the interim, <b>or</b> that <b>the poor person became rich</b> and is no longer eligible to be given the poor man’s tithe. The priest or Levite benefits from this arrangement, as he receives his gifts up front in the form of a loan. The Israelite benefits in that he does not need to seek out a priest or Levite each time he has produce from which he must separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes.
If in fact <b>they died,</b> then <b>he must obtain permission from the heirs</b> in order to continue the arrangement. However, <b>if he lent</b> money <b>to</b> the deceased, and he stipulated <b>in the presence of the court</b> that the debt would be repaid in this manner, then <b>he does not need to obtain permission from the heirs.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna assumes that the priest, Levite, and poor person acquire the <i>teruma</i> and tithes that the creditor separates from his produce, but they agree at the time of the loan that the tithes and <i>teruma</i> will then be acquired by the creditor as payment of their debt. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> can the priest, Levite, and poor person transfer possession of the <i>terumot</i> or tithes back to the creditor <b>even though</b> the produce <b>did not come into their possession?</b>
<b>Rav says:</b> This is stated <b>with regard to associates of the priesthood and the Levites,</b> i.e., people who have an arrangement with a specific priest or Levite to give him their <i>teruma</i> or tithes. The specific priest or Levite therefore has a presumptive status of ownership of the tithes or <i>teruma</i> and is considered to have acquired them. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> This is stated <b>with regard to</b> one who <b>has</b> the priest or Levite <b>acquire</b> the gifts <b>through</b> the act of acquisition of <b>others,</b> who acquire the <i>teruma</i> and tithes on their behalf. The lender is then able to reclaim the gifts as repayment of the loan. <b>Ulla said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who says</b> in other contexts: The Sages, by means of an ordinance, <b>rendered one who does not acquire like one who acquires.</b> Here, too, the Sages instituted an ordinance to enable this arrangement.
The Gemara explains why each of the aforementioned Sages disagreed with the others. <b>All</b> the other Sages, i.e., Shmuel and Ulla, <b>do not state</b> their opinions <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> because the mishna <b>does not teach</b> explicitly that the <i>halakha</i> is stated <b>with regard to associates</b> of the priesthood and the Levites. Rav and Ulla <b>do not state</b> their opinions <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel</b> because the mishna <b>does not teach</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is stated <b>with regard to</b> one who <b>has</b> the priest or Levite <b>acquire</b> the gifts <b>through</b> the act of acquisition of <b>others.</b> Rav and Shmuel <b>also do not state</b> their opinions <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla</b> because <b>we do not establish</b> the mishna to be stated <b>in accordance</b> with <b>an individual</b> opinion, in this case Rabbi Yosei; rather, the assumption is that the ruling of the mishna is written in accordance with the majority opinion.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:1): With regard to <b>one who lends money to a priest, or to a Levite, or to a poor person</b> with the understanding that <b>he will separate their portion</b> of the <i>teruma</i> and tithes from his produce <b>on the basis of that</b> money, <b>he may separate</b> the <i>teruma</i> and tithes from his produce <b>on the basis of that</b> money, <b>with the presumption that they are</b> still <b>alive.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And he may contract with them according to the low</b> market <b>rate,</b> i.e., he may set a price for the gifts that he will separate in the future based on either their value at the time of the loan, or their value when they will be separated, whichever is lower. <b>And this is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>interest,</b> meaning that if the market rate falls, it will not be considered as though they are repaying in excess of the amount of the loan. <b>And the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>does not cancel</b> this loan; even after the Sabbatical Year, the lender may continue to collect his debt in this manner.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And if</b> the lender <b>seeks to renege</b> on this agreement, <b>he may not renege.</b> If <b>the owner despaired</b> of retrieving the loan, as he thought that he would not need to separate any <i>teruma</i> or tithes and therefore thought that he would not collect payment for the loan, although it later became clear that he was mistaken, <b>he may not separate</b> the <i>teruma</i> and tithes from his produce <b>on the basis of that</b> money, <b>because one may not separate</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>on the basis of</b> one’s loan that one had thought <b>lost.</b> Once he despaired of retrieving the loan, the sum of the loan is permanently acquired by the borrowers and the lender may not use the tithes and <i>teruma</i> to serve as repayment.
The Gemara clarifies the rulings of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said: He may contract with them according to the low</b> market <b>rate.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>obvious?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This teaches us</b> that <b>even though he did not contract</b> explicitly that he would use the lower market price, he is <b>considered like one who did</b> so <b>contract</b> and may do so anyway.
The <i>baraita</i> also teaches: <b>And this is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>interest.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers: <b>Since, when</b> the priest or Levite <b>has no</b> <i>teruma</i> or tithes that he received from the creditor, e.g., when the grain in the field did not sprout due to a drought, <b>he does not give</b> anything to the creditor in repayment of the loan, this indicates that it is not a true loan. Therefore, <b>when</b> the priest or Levite <b>has</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes, this <b>also is not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>interest.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> also teaches: <b>And the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>does not cancel</b> this loan. The Gemara explains: The reason <b>is that concerning this</b> loan, <b>one cannot read</b> the verse stated with regard to the cancellation of debts by the occurrence of the Sabbatical Year: <b>“He shall not exact</b> it of his neighbor and his brother; because the Lord’s release has been proclaimed” (Deuteronomy 15:2). Since in any event one cannot claim repayment of this type of loan, it is not addressed by the verse in question.
The <i>baraita</i> also teaches: <b>And if</b> the lender <b>seeks to renege</b> on this agreement, <b>he cannot renege. Rav Pappa said: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a homeowner,</b> i.e., an owner of produce, who wishes to renege on his agreement <b>with a priest.</b> In that situation, the homeowner cannot demand repayment of the loan with money. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a priest</b> who wishes to renege on his agreement <b>with a homeowner, if he seeks to renege, he may renege.</b> What is the reason for this? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 44a): In any transaction, if the purchaser <b>gave</b> the seller <b>money but did not</b> yet <b>pull</b> the <b>produce,</b> then the seller <b>can renege</b> on the sale. Here, since the priest received money and the homeowner did not yet formally acquire the produce, the priest can renege on the agreement.
The <i>baraita</i> also teaches: If <b>the owner despaired</b> of retrieving the loan, <b>he may not separate</b> the <i>teruma</i> and tithes from his produce <b>on the basis of that</b> money <b>because one may not separate</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>on the basis of</b> a loan that he had thought <b>lost.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>obvious,</b> as he is no longer owed the money? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where</b> the seeds <b>produced stalks</b> and became dried out. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>growth of stalks is</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> as there is a chance that the produce will still grow and so he does not fully despair, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that even in such a situation, since the produce is very unlikely to recover, he does despair of retrieving the loan.
§ It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:1) that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> With regard to <b>one who lends money to a priest or to a Levite in court and they died</b> before repaying the loan, <b>he separates</b> <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>on the basis of that</b> money <b>with the presumption</b> that there is one from <b>that tribe</b> who inherited from them, and he need not confirm that the deceased priest or Levite has immediate heirs. He then continues the arrangement based on the transfer of the debt to the heirs. <b>And</b> if he lent money <b>to a poor person in court, and</b> the poor person <b>died</b> before repaying the loan, the creditor <b>separates</b> tithes <b>on the basis of that</b> money <b>with the presumption</b> that <b>the poor of the Jewish people</b> would agree to continue the arrangement. <b>Rabbi Aḥai says:</b> It is <b>with the presumption</b> that <b>the poor of the world</b> would agree to continue the arrangement.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov and the opinion of Rabbi Aḥai? Rabbi Aḥai too must have meant only poor Jews and not poor gentiles, who are not given tithes.

Daf 30b

The Gemara answers: There is a difference <b>between them</b> where the only poor people to be found are <b>poor Samaritans.</b> According to Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, they are not considered to be converts (see <i>Kiddushin</i> 75b), and one may not continue the arrangement with them serving as the poor people. According to Rabbi Aḥai, they are considered converts, and one may continue the arrangement with them serving as the poor people.
It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:1) that if <b>the poor person became wealthy</b> then the homeowner <b>may no</b> longer <b>separate</b> tithes <b>based on his</b> outstanding loan, <b>and</b> the borrower, who is now wealthy, <b>acquires</b> the money remaining <b>in his possession.</b> This is because from the outset the understanding was that the loan would be repaid only by separating the poor man’s tithe.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the Sages, what is different about death,</b> when the poor man dies, <b>that they instituted an ordinance</b> to enable the homeowner to continue to separate tithes based on other poor people, <b>and what is different about wealth,</b> when the poor man becomes wealthy, <b>that they did not institute an ordinance?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Death is common,</b> whereas <b>wealth is not common,</b> and the Sages did not enact an ordinance for an uncommon circumstance. <b>Rav Pappa said: This</b> explains the folk saying <b>that people say:</b> If one says to you that <b>your friend died,</b> then <b>believe</b> it; but if one says to you that your friend <b>became wealthy, do not believe</b> it until it has been proven.
§ The mishna teaches that if the priest or Levite <b>died,</b> the lender <b>needs to obtain permission</b> from the heirs to continue the arrangement. It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:1): <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that this is referring to <b>heirs who inherited.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And are there heirs who do not inherit?</b> What is meant by the expression: Heirs who inherit? <b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This means heirs <b>who inherited land,</b> as one can collect debts from land bequeathed by a borrower, <b>and not</b> heirs <b>who inherited money,</b> as lenders cannot collect debts from money bequeathed by a borrower.
With regard to this matter <b>Rabbi Yonatan says:</b> If the priest <b>left</b> his heirs enough land <b>to fill a needle,</b> i.e., a minimal amount, then the homeowner <b>collects,</b> i.e., separates <i>teruma</i>, in the amount of produce that has the value of <b>a full needle</b> of land. If he left enough land <b>to fill an ax,</b> i.e., a larger amount, then the homeowner <b>collects</b> the value of <b>a full ax</b> of land. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even</b> if he <b>left</b> for his heirs enough land <b>to fill a needle,</b> the homeowner <b>collects</b> the value of <b>a full ax</b> of land.
<b>And this is like the incident</b> involving <b>the small</b> portion of land in the court <b>of Abaye.</b> The children of a deceased man had inherited a small field that was worth only a fraction of the debt that their father had owed. The creditor seized the land in payment of the debt, and Abaye ruled that even after the orphans pay the creditor the value of the land to repurchase it, the creditor can seize the land again and the orphans will have to pay for it again, to have it returned, until the entire debt has been repaid.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:2): With regard to <b>an Israelite who said to a Levite: There is tithe of yours in my possession</b> that I separated from my produce on your behalf, <b>one is not concerned about</b> the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe that is in it,</b> i.e., the one-tenth of the tithe that is given to the priest and forbidden to both the Levite and the Israelite; rather it is assumed to be only first tithe. However, if he said to him: <b>There is a <i>kor</i> of tithe of yours in my possession,</b> then <b>one is concerned about</b> the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe that is in it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying? Abaye said: This is what it is saying:</b> In the case of <b>an Israelite who said to a Levite: There is tithe of yours in my possession, and here is money</b> in exchange for <b>it,</b> then <b>one is not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the Levite <b>converted</b> the tithe that is now in the possession of the Israelite into <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe for</b> tithes that he has <b>elsewhere.</b> Since the Israelite did not specify how much tithe of the Levite’s he had, the Levite would not know how much of his other tithe could be exempted from <i>teruma</i> of the tithe by converting this tithe into <i>teruma</i> of the tithe. But if an Israelite said to a Levite: <b>There is a <i>kor</i> of tithe of yours in my possession, and here is money</b> in exchange for <b>it,</b> then <b>one is concerned</b> that since the Levite knows the amount of the tithe, <b>perhaps he converted it</b> into the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe for</b> tithes that he has <b>elsewhere.</b>
The Gemara questions Abaye’s explanation: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>we are dealing with wicked</b> people, <b>who take money</b> in exchange for the tithe <b>and</b> afterward <b>convert it</b> into the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe?</b> Once the Levite takes money in exchange for the tithe, it is no longer his to convert it into <i>teruma</i> of the tithe. Why would the <i>baraita</i> address the case of a Levite who acts in this fashion?
<b>Rather, Rav Mesharshiyya, son of Rav Idi, said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> In the case of <b>an Israelite who said to the son of a Levite:</b> There is <b>tithe of your father’s in my possession,</b> about which I had informed him while he was still alive; <b>here is money</b> in exchange for <b>it,</b> one is <b>not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> before his death <b>his father converted it</b> into <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe for</b> tithes that he had <b>elsewhere,</b> and the son may accept the money. But if an Israelite said to the son of a Levite: There is <b>a <i>kor</i> of tithe of your father’s in my possession, and here is money</b> in exchange for <b>it;</b> then one <b>is concerned</b> that <b>perhaps his father converted it</b> into <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe for</b> tithes that he has <b>elsewhere,</b> and the son may not accept the money.
The Gemara questions Rav Mesharshiyya’s explanation: Why is there a concern that the father may have converted it into <i>teruma</i> of the tithe for tithes that he had elsewhere? If one has produce that needs to have <i>teruma</i> or <i>teruma</i> of the tithe separated from it, and he wants to perform the separation from other produce, to exempt all the produce, the Sages established that the other produce must be situated nearby. <b>And are <i>ḥaverim</i>,</b> who are meticulous in their observance of mitzvot, especially the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>teruma</i> and tithes, <b>suspected of separating</b> <i>teruma</i> from produce <b>that is not situated near</b> the produce they seek to exempt?
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>the son of an Israelite who said to a Levite: This is what my father told me,</b> that there is <b>tithe of yours in my possession, or</b> that there is <b>tithe of your father’s in my possession,</b> then one <b>is concerned about</b> the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe that is in it</b> that presumably was never separated. <b>Since it is not a set</b> amount, <b>the homeowner would not have rendered</b> the tithe <b>fit for him</b> by separating the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe. But if the son of an Israelite said to a Levite: My father told me that there is <b>a <i>kor</i> of tithe of yours in my possession, or</b> that there is <b>a <i>kor</i> of tithe of your father’s in my possession,</b> then one is <b>not concerned about</b> the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe that is in it. Since it is a set</b> amount, <b>the homeowner</b> is assumed to have <b>rendered</b> the tithe <b>fit</b> by separating the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.
The Gemara questions Rav Ashi’s explanation: <b>And does the homeowner have permission to separate</b> the <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe</b> from the tithe of the Levite? The Levite is the one who is required to separate the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe and to give it to a priest. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes;</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Elazar ben Gamla. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Elazar ben Gamla says:</b> The verse states concerning the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe: <b>“And the gift that you set apart [<i>terumatkhem</i>] shall be reckoned to you,</b> as though it were the grain of the threshing floor” (Numbers 18:27).

Daf 31a

<b>The verse speaks of two <i>terumot</i></b>; <b>one</b> is <b>standard <i>teruma</i> and one</b> is <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe.</b> Since they are mentioned together, they can be compared: <b>Just as standard <i>teruma</i> is taken by estimate,</b> as there is no requirement for the amount separated to be measured precisely, <b>and</b> it can be taken <b>by thought,</b> as one is not required to physically separate it before consuming the remaining produce, <b>so too, <i>teruma</i> of the tithe may be taken by estimate and by thought. And</b> this comparison also teaches that <b>just as the homeowner has permission,</b> i.e., the right, <b>to separate standard <i>teruma</i>, so too, the homeowner has permission to separate <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who sets aside produce</b> with the understanding that <b>he will separate <i>terumot</i> and tithes with it,</b> so that when he has untithed produce he can render it fit by declaring that the <i>teruma</i> and tithes that must be separated will be from the produce that he had set aside for this purpose, or one who sets aside <b>money</b> with the understanding that <b>he will separate</b> and to redeem <b>second tithe with it,</b> then he may later <b>separate</b> the <i>teruma</i> or tithe <b>with them, based on the presumption that</b> the produce or the money <b>are extant.</b> He need not be concerned that perhaps the produce or money was lost in the meantime. <b>If</b> he discovers that <b>they were lost,</b> then <b>he must be concerned</b> that the produce or money that he set aside was lost, <b>from the time until the</b> same <b>time,</b> as will be explained in the Gemara, and he must separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes from the produce a second time; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One checks the wine</b> that is set aside to be used for separating <i>terumot</i> and tithes for other wine to see if it has turned to vinegar, which would render it unfit for this purpose, <b>at three times</b> during the year: <b>When the east wind</b> blows <b>at the conclusion of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>and when the</b> blossoms fall and the <b>grape buds emerge</b> and appear as small clusters, <b>and at the time</b> when <b>water enters</b> and fills <b>the unripe grape.</b> Since there is a change in the weather at these times, one should check to ensure that the wine has not turned to vinegar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna taught that if the produce or money was lost, then one must be concerned that it occurred from the time until the same time. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: <b>From the time until the</b> same <b>time? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It means <b>from the time</b> it was <b>checked</b> and found to be lost, <b>until the</b> same <b>time</b> of day on the previous day. If one had used that produce to render fit other produce within the twenty-four hours before noticing that it had been lost, one must separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes for that produce again. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Antigonus says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yannai:</b>

Daf 31b

It means <b>from the time</b> that it was <b>set aside until the</b> same <b>time</b> the day after it was set aside. In other words, he must be concerned about all of the untithed produce that he had rendered fit after the first twenty-four hour period from when he set aside the produce or money had passed.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>If</b> he discovers that <b>they were lost,</b> then <b>he must be concerned</b> that the produce or money that he set aside was lost <b>from the time until the</b> same <b>time. Granted, according to the one who said</b> that this means <b>from the time</b> it was <b>checked</b> and found to be lost <b>until the</b> same <b>time</b> of day on the previous day, it works out <b>well,</b> as the wine is presumed to have turned to vinegar from that moment.
<b>But according to the one who said</b> that this means <b>from the time</b> that it was <b>set aside until the</b> same <b>time</b> the day after it was set aside, <b>this</b> expression: <b>From the time until the</b> same <b>time,</b> is imprecise, as the presumption is that the wine turned to vinegar dating back to the day after it had been set aside. Therefore, it <b>should have</b> said: One is concerned going back <b>until</b> then <b>from the time</b> it was set aside <b>to the</b> same <b>time</b> the following day, i.e., twenty-four hours after it had been set aside. The Gemara comments: The wording of the mishna is <b>difficult</b> according to that opinion.
The mishna teaches that this is <b>the statement of</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b> The <i>amora</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Rabbi Elazar’s colleagues disagree with him, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 2:2): In the case of <b>a ritual bath</b> that was known to have contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i>, <b>which was</b> then <b>measured and found deficient</b> in its quantity of water, <b>all pure items that had been rendered</b> pure <b>in it, retroactive</b> to when the ritual bath was last measured, <b>whether</b> this ritual bath is found <b>in the private domain or in the public domain, are impure.</b>
The Gemara comments: It <b>is obvious that</b> those who ascribe to the statement of that mishna <b>disagree</b> with Rabbi Elazar the <i>tanna</i>. What novel idea is Rabbi Elazar the <i>amora</i> teaching? The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>what</b> the term <b>retroactive</b> is referring to is any item that was immersed and purified <b>from the time</b> it was found to be deficient <b>until the</b> same <b>time</b> the previous day, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar. Therefore, he <b>teaches us</b> that in fact they disagree and deem impure all items immersed from the time that the ritual bath had last been checked.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One checks the wine <b>at three times</b> during the year. One of these times is when the east wind blows at the conclusion of the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>. A Sage <b>taught:</b> It is checked <b>when the east wind blows at the conclusion of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i> <b>in</b> the <b>season</b> of <i>Tishrei</i>, i.e., autumn. However, if the summer continues until the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>, then in the event of this unusual occurrence one does not check the wine.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>at three times</b> during the year <b>one sells the grain: Before</b> the time of <b>the sowing, and during the time of the sowing, and before the</b> festival of <b>Passover. And at three times</b> of the year <b>one sells the wine: Before the</b> festival of <b>Passover, and before</b> the festival of <b><i>Shavuot</i>, and before the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>. <b>And oil</b> is sold <b>from</b> the festival of <b><i>Shavuot</i> and onward.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? One may sell these products whenever he so desires. <b>Rava said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Pappa</b> who said: This <i>halakha</i> was stated <b>with regard to partners,</b> as one partner may sell these products without the permission of the other only at these times of the year. At other times, he must first receive permission from his partner. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> i.e., after the latest of the three times has passed, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rava said: Every day is its time</b> to be sold.
§ Having mentioned the east wind, the Gemara quotes a related verse: <b>“And it came to pass, when the sun arose, that God prepared a vehement [<i>ḥarishit</i>] east wind”</b> (Jonah 4:8). The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the word <b>“<i>ḥarishit</i>”? Rav Yehuda says:</b> It means a wind that plows [<i>ḥoreshet</i>], as <b>at the time that</b> the wind <b>blows, it forms many furrows in the sea,</b> as though it were plowing the sea.
<b>Rabba said to him: If that is so,</b> then <b>that which is written</b> in the continuation of the verse: <b>“And the sun beat upon the head of Jonah and he fainted”</b> (Jonah 4:8), is difficult; it seems from the continuation of the verse that the wind was not extremely hot, not strong. <b>Rather, Rabba says: At the time that it blows, it silences all the winds before it.</b> Therefore, it is called <i>ḥarishit</i>, because all other winds are silent [<i>maḥarishot</i>] before it. Since only this wind was blowing, it became very hot. <b>And this is as it is written: “You whose garments are hot, when the earth is still by reason of the south wind”</b> (Job 37:17). <b>Rabbi Taḥalifa bar Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> in explanation of this verse: <b>When are your garments hot,</b> i.e., when is there the greatest heat? It is <b>when the earth is still by reason of the south wind, as at the time that</b> the southern wind <b>blows, it silences all the winds before it.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda were sitting,</b> and <b>Geneiva passed by them. One said to the other: Let us stand before him, as he is a son of</b> the <b>Torah. The other said to him: Shall we stand before a quarrelsome</b> person? <b>In the meantime,</b> Geneiva <b>came to them</b> and <b>said to them: With what were you dealing</b> when you were sitting together? <b>They said to him:</b> We were dealing <b>with winds.</b>
<b>He said to them: This is what Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says</b> that <b>Rav says: Four winds blow on each day, and the north wind blows</b> together <b>with each of</b> the other three; <b>as, if this were not so</b> and the northern wind did not blow, then <b>the world would not survive</b> for <b>even one hour. And the south wind is harsher than all of them, and were it not</b> for the angel called <b>Ben Netz,</b> who <b>stops it</b> from blowing even harder, then it would <b>destroy the entire world before it, as it is stated: “Does the hawk [<i>netz</i>] soar by your wisdom, and stretch her wings toward the south?”</b> (Job 39:26).
The Gemara also relates that <b>Rava and Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak were sitting,</b> and <b>Rav Naḥman bar Ya’akov was passing</b> by them <b>while sitting on a gilt carriage [<i>goharka</i>] and</b> with <b>a green cloak [<i>sarbela</i>] spread over him. Rava went to him,</b> but <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak did not go to him. He said: Perhaps they are members of the house of the Exilarch. Rava needs them,</b> but <b>I do not need them.</b>
<b>When he saw that it was Rav Naḥman bar Ya’akov, he</b> also <b>went to him.</b> Rav Naḥman bar Ya’akov <b>uncovered his arm</b> due to the heat and <b>said:</b> The wind called <b>Shadya is blowing. Rava says</b> that <b>this is</b> what <b>Rav says</b> about this wind: <b>A woman miscarries in its</b> wake. <b>And Shmuel says: Even a pearl [<i>margalit</i>] that is in the sea decomposes in its</b> wake. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even the semen that is in a woman’s womb putrefies in its</b> wake.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak,</b> who was present, <b>said</b> about their statements: <b>And the three of them derived</b> their statements <b>from one verse,</b> as it is stated: <b>“For though he be fruitful among the reed-plants, an east wind shall come, the wind of the Lord coming up from the wilderness, and his spring shall become dry,</b> and his fountain shall be dried up; he shall spoil the treasure of all precious vessels” (Hosea 13:15). The statement that a woman miscarries in its wake is based on the phrase <b>“His spring shall become dry,”</b> as <b>this</b> is referring to <b>a woman’s womb.</b> With regard to the phrase <b>“And his fountain shall be dried up,” this</b> is referring to the <b>semen that is in a woman’s womb.</b> And with regard to the phrase <b>“He shall spoil the treasure of all precious vessels,” this</b> is referring to <b>a pearl in the sea.</b>
<b>Rava says: This</b> Sage <b>is from Sura, as they are precise</b> with <b>verses.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>“Though he be fruitful [<i>yafri</i>] among the reed-plants”? Rava said: Even</b>

Daf 32a

<b>the handle in the hole [<i>kofina</i>] of the hoe [<i>mara</i>] becomes loose [<i>rafya</i>],</b> as he understands the word <i>yafri</i> to refer to separating connected items. Similarly, <b>Rav Yosef said: Even the peg</b> hammered <b>into the wall becomes loose. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Even the reed</b> woven <b>into the basket becomes loose.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who sends a bill of divorce to his wife</b> with an agent, <b>and he reached the agent, or where he sent</b> another <b>agent after him, and he said to</b> the agent delivering the bill of divorce: <b>The bill of divorce that I gave you, it is void,</b> then <b>this</b> bill of divorce <b>is hereby void.</b> Similarly, if the husband reached <b>his wife before</b> the bill of divorce reached her, <b>or</b> in a case <b>where he sent an agent to her, and he said,</b> or had the agent say, <b>to</b> his wife: <b>The bill of divorce that I sent to you, it is void,</b> then <b>this</b> bill of divorce <b>is hereby void.</b> However, <b>if</b> he stated this <b>once the bill of divorce had entered her possession, he can no longer render it void,</b> as the divorce had already taken effect.
The mishna relates that <b>initially,</b> a husband who wished to render the bill of divorce void <b>would convene a court elsewhere and render</b> the bill of divorce <b>void</b> in the presence of the court before it reached his wife. <b>Rabban Gamliel the Elder instituted</b> an ordinance <b>that one should not do this, for the betterment of the world.</b> The Gemara will explain what this means.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that if one sends a bill of divorce with an agent and then meets the agent and renders void the bill of divorce in his presence, then it is void. The Gemara points out: The mishna <b>does not teach: He reached</b> the agent after pursuing <b>him; rather: He reached</b> the agent, meaning <b>and even</b> if he reached him <b>incidentally,</b> without intent, he renders the bill of divorce void with his statement. <b>And we do not say</b> that in that case <b>he intends</b> only <b>to vex</b> his wife and does not actually intend to render the bill of divorce void.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna to state that the bill of divorce is void when he reached the agent, <b>or</b> in a case <b>where he sent</b> another <b>agent after him?</b> The legal status of a person’s agent is like that of himself, so it seems obvious that just as the husband can nullify the agency of the first agent, so too, can the second agent nullify the agency of the first agent. The Gemara answers: This principle was stated <b>lest you say</b> that <b>the agency of the latter,</b> the second agent, <b>is not stronger than the agency of the former,</b> and <b>that</b> the latter agent cannot <b>nullify</b> the agency of the first agent and only the husband can nullify it. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the second agent can nullify the agency of the first agent.
The Gemara continues and asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna to teach a case where a husband reached <b>his wife before</b> the bill of divorce reached her? It is obvious that a husband can render void the bill of divorce before it reaches his wife. The Gemara explains: This principle was stated <b>lest you say</b> that <b>when we don’t say</b> that he <b>intends</b> only <b>to vex her</b> like in the case above, and the bill of divorce is in fact void, <b>this matter applies</b> only when he said <b>to the agent</b> that the bill of divorce is void; <b>however,</b> if he said that <b>to her, he certainly intends</b> only <b>to vex her,</b> and he does not actually intend to render the bill of divorce void. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that even in this case the bill of divorce is void.
The Gemara continues and asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna to state: <b>Or where he sent an agent to her,</b> which, as stated above, means that the legal status of a person’s agent is like that of himself? The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that only <b>he would not exert</b> himself <b>with the</b> sole <b>intent to vex her,</b> by informing her falsely that the bill of divorce is void; <b>however,</b> with regard to the <b>agent, as</b> the husband <b>does not care</b> if <b>he exerts</b> himself for no reason, and the husband <b>certainly intends</b> only <b>to vex her</b> when he sends an agent and not actually to render the bill of divorce void. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that in this case as well the bill of divorce is void.
The mishna states further: <b>If</b> he stated this <b>once the bill of divorce had entered her possession, he can no longer render it void,</b> as the divorce had already taken effect. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>obvious?</b> Once the bill of divorce has entered her possession, they are divorced. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to state that even in a case <b>where he was going around searching for</b> the bill of divorce <b>from the beginning</b> in order <b>to render it void</b> before it reached his wife, once it enters her possession it is too late. <b>Lest you say:</b> Once he renders the bill of divorce void, even after it had entered her possession, <b>it has become clear retroactively that he rendered it void</b> from the beginning, before it reached his wife, therefore the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that since the bill of divorce was rendered void only after it had entered her possession, they are divorced.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If a husband made one of the following statements with regard to a bill of divorce that he sent: <b>It is void [<i>batel hu</i>],</b> or: <b>I do not desire it,</b> then <b>his statement takes effect</b> and the bill of divorce is void. However, if he said: <b>It is invalid,</b> or: <b>It is not a bill of divorce,</b> then it is as though <b>he said nothing,</b> as the bill of divorce has nothing disqualifying it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> the formulation: <b><i>Batel</i>, is a</b> prescriptive <b>formulation that means: Let it become void,</b> and not a descriptive formulation that means that the bill of divorce is already void? <b>But didn’t Rabba bar Aivu say</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said, and some say</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> With regard to <b>one who receives a gift, who, after the gift had entered his possession, said: This gift is rendered void;</b> or if he said: <b>Let it become void;</b> or if he said: <b>I do not desire it,</b> it is as though <b>he said nothing.</b> He has already acquired the gift, and he cannot undo his acquisition. However, if he said: <b>It is void [<i>betela he</i>],</b> or: <b>It is not a gift, his statement is effective,</b> as these formulations indicate that he had never agreed to acquire the gift in the first place. <b>Apparently,</b> the formulation: <b><i>Batel</i>, means</b> that it is void <b>from the beginning,</b> and not that it should become void, in opposition to the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The formulation: <b><i>Batel</i>,</b>

Daf 32b

<b>has two</b> potential <b>meanings,</b> depending on the context. <b>It means that</b> it was <b>void</b> already, <b>and it</b> also <b>means that it will become void</b> in the future. <b>With regard to a bill of divorce, he stated the formulation that is effective with regard to it,</b> and since his statement can be understood to mean that the bill of divorce should be void from that point onward, it is interpreted as such. <b>With regard to a gift, he stated the formulation that is effective with regard to it,</b> and since one cannot nullify the acquisition of a gift after taking possession of it, his intention was that the gift was void from the outset, and his statement is interpreted as such.
Additionally <b>Abaye said</b> with regard to the relationship between a bill of divorce and a gift that <b>we have a tradition: An agent</b> sent to deliver <b>a gift is</b> considered <b>like an agent</b> sent to deliver <b>a bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>The practical difference</b> that is learned from this is <b>that</b> if one says to his agent: <b>Take</b> this gift to so-and-so, <b>it is not considered as</b> if he said to him: <b>Acquire</b> the gift on his behalf. Therefore, as long as the gift has not yet reached the intended recipient, the one who sent the gift can retract it, and it is not as if the intended recipient had taken possession of the gift from the moment that it was given to the agent.
The Gemara relates: <b>Ravina found Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak as he was leaning on the bar of a door</b> deep in thought, <b>and</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>was considering</b> the following <b>dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if a husband said only: This bill of divorce is <b>void,</b> but did not say: This bill of divorce, it is void? Does he mean to render the bill of divorce void from that point onward, which he has the ability to do, or is he merely noting the fact that this bill of divorce is void, in which case his statement does not affect the validity of the document? No answer is given to this question and therefore the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Sheshet says, and some say</b> that <b>it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>,</b> that if the husband said one of these phrases: <b>This bill of divorce shall not be effective, shall not release, shall not cause to leave, shall not send away, shall not divorce, shall be pottery,</b> or <b>shall be like pottery,</b> in all of these cases <b>his statement is effective,</b> and the bill of divorce is rendered void.
If, however, the husband used one of the following formulations: This bill of divorce <b>has no effect, does not release, does not cause to leave, does not send away, does not divorce, it is pottery,</b> or <b>it is like pottery,</b> then it is as though <b>he said nothing.</b> The husband has the authority only to render the bill of divorce void. However, his descriptive statements with regard to the legal standing of the bill of divorce are meaningless.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he said: <b>It is hereby pottery?</b> Is his intention to make a descriptive statement, that the bill of divorce is not valid, or does he intend to render it void? <b>Ravina said to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this formulation <b>different from</b> saying about one’s property: <b>It is hereby consecrated</b> property, or: <b>It is hereby ownerless</b> property, where it is clear that his intention is to designate the items as consecrated or ownerless property? With regard to bills of divorce as well, his statement is effective and it renders the bill of divorce void.
§ The Gemara asks: If the husband rendered void a bill of divorce, can he <b>go back and divorce</b> his wife <b>with it,</b> since perhaps he did not actually render void the bill of divorce but only nullified the agency for its delivery, so it can be used again in the future; <b>or may he not go back and divorce with it,</b> as the bill of divorce itself was rendered void? <b>Rav Naḥman says: He may go back and divorce with it, and Rav Sheshet says: He may not go back and divorce with it.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Naḥman,</b> that the bill of divorce may be used.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But don’t we maintain</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said:</b> If a man gives a woman money for betrothal and says that the betrothal will take effect after thirty days, the woman <b>can retract</b> her agreement within the thirty days and decide that she does not wish to be betrothed. Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that as long as the change in status had not yet taken effect, she may nullify her earlier agreement by stating a retraction. Therefore, here too, when the husband states that the bill of divorce should be rendered void, since the divorce had not taken effect, it should be rendered void.
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of betrothal, <b>it is speech</b> that accepts the betrothal <b>and speech</b> that retracts her acceptance; therefore, her <b>speech comes and nullifies</b> her previous <b>speech,</b> as the woman first stated that she agreed and then stated afterward that she retracted her agreement. <b>But here,</b> even <b>though</b> it is true <b>that</b> the husband <b>rendered void the agency of the agent, does</b> he also <b>render void the bill of divorce itself?</b> Since the bill of divorce is a tangible object, it cannot be made void through speech alone.
§ The mishna taught that <b>initially</b> a husband who wished to render void the bill of divorce <b>would convene</b> a court, even if he had already sent the document with an agent, and render the bill of divorce void in the presence of the court. <b>It was stated:</b> When the husband would state that the bill of divorce should be void, <b>in the presence of how many</b> people <b>must he render it void? Rav Naḥman says:</b> He must render it void <b>in the presence of two</b> people. <b>Rav Sheshet says:</b> He must render it void <b>in the presence of three</b> people.
The Gemara explains the reasoning of each <i>amora</i>: <b>Rav Sheshet said</b> that he must do so <b>in the presence of three</b> people, because the mishna <b>teaches</b> that this takes place in the presence of a <b>court,</b> and a court consists of three judges. <b>And Rav Naḥman said</b> that it may be done <b>in the presence of two</b> people, as <b>two</b> people <b>are also called a court,</b> and in exigent circumstances one may rely on this. <b>Rav Naḥman said: From where do I say</b> that two people are also called a court? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:4): When one creates a document that prevents the Sabbatical Year from abrogating an outstanding debt [<i>prosbol</i>], he states: <b>I transfer</b> to you <b>in your presence,</b>

Daf 33a

<b>so-and-so and so-and-so the judges, in such and such a place,</b> in order that I will collect any debt that I am owed by so-and-so whenever I wish. Despite the fact that the <i>prosbol</i> mentions only two people, it nevertheless refers to them as judges, in accordance with the statement of Rav Naḥman.
<b>And Rav Sheshet</b> would respond to this: <b>Is that to say that the <i>tanna</i> should have continued counting</b> judges <b>like a peddler?</b> The <i>tanna</i> twice used the expression so-and-so because he wished to note that one should mention the judges’ names; he did not intend to teach anything about the number of judges.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: From where do I say</b> that two judges are also considered a court? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna with regard to a <i>prosbol</i> (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:4): <b>The judges sign below</b> the text of the <i>prosbol</i>, <b>or the witnesses</b> do so. <b>What, is it not</b> possible to deduce: The mishna means that <b>judges are similar to witnesses? Just as</b> there are <b>two witnesses, so too,</b> there are <b>also two judges. And Rav Sheshet</b> would respond to this: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case of the judges is <b>as it is, and that</b> case of the witnesses is <b>as it is,</b> each one with its respective requirement of three or two members.
The Gemara asks with regard to the mishna in <i>Shevi’it</i>: <b>Why do I</b> need the <i>tanna</i> <b>to teach</b> that it can be signed by <b>judges,</b> and <b>why do I</b> need him <b>to teach</b> that it can be signed by <b>witnesses</b> as well? Why is it necessary to mention both? The Gemara answers: <b>This teaches us that</b> there <b>is no difference</b> if the <i>prosbol</i> <b>is written in the terminology of judges and witnesses sign</b> it, <b>and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> if it <b>is written in the terminology of witnesses and judges sign</b> it. What is important is that the <i>prosbol</i> was written and then signed by the court, and the precise wording is not important.
§ The mishna taught that Rabban Gamliel the Elder instituted that one may not render a bill of divorce void in a court elsewhere <b>for the betterment of the world.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> problem did Rabban Gamliel ameliorate that this is considered to be <b>for the betterment of the world? Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This is <b>for the benefit of</b> potential <b>children born from an adulterous relationship [<i>mamzerim</i>],</b> as the husband might render a bill of divorce void unbeknownst to his wife. She might remarry after having received the void bill of divorce, when in fact she is still married to her first husband, and children born from the second marriage will be <i>mamzerim</i>. To prevent this, Rabban Gamliel instituted that one may not render the bill of divorce void when not in the location of his wife. <b>Reish Lakish says: For the betterment of deserted wives,</b> lest women who received their bill of divorce by means of the husband’s agent refrain from remarrying out of the concern that perhaps their husband rendered the bill of divorce void.
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who <b>says</b> the reason for this ordinance is <b>for the betterment of</b> potential <b><i>mamzerim</i>, holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman, who says</b> that the husband can render void the bill of divorce even <b>in the presence of two</b> people. <b>And</b> since matters that occur in the presence of <b>two people do not</b> generate <b>publicity,</b> it is possible that <b>she does not hear</b> that the bill of divorce was rendered void. <b>And</b> since <b>she does not know</b> that her husband rendered the bill of divorce void, <b>she will go and marry, and there are <i>mamzerim</i></b> as a result of second marriages like these.
<b>And Reish Lakish,</b> who <b>says</b> that the reason is <b>for the betterment of deserted wives, holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Sheshet, who says:</b> One can render void a bill of divorce only <b>in the presence of three</b> people. <b>And since</b> matters that occur in the presence of <b>three</b> people do generate <b>publicity, she does hear and know</b> that her husband rendered void the bill of divorce, <b>and she would not marry</b> again. Therefore, there is no concern that this will result in <i>mamzerim</i>, <b>but there is</b> a need to institute this ordinance for the <b>betterment of deserted wives,</b> as explained above.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> Even after Rabban Gamliel the Elder instituted that a husband cannot render void a bill of divorce when not in the presence of the wife or the agent, if <b>he</b> nevertheless <b>rendered it void,</b> the bill of divorce <b>is rendered void;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He is unable to render it void, and</b> he also <b>cannot add on to his condition</b> if the bill of divorce contained some condition, <b>as if so,</b> i.e., if he can render it void, <b>what advantage does the court have,</b> if an ordinance of the court of Rabban Gamliel can be ignored?
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there anything that by Torah law renders the bill of divorce void</b> and the wife remains married, <b>and due to</b> the reasoning of: <b>What advantage does the court have, we</b> do not recognize that the bill of divorce is void and <b>permit a married woman to</b> marry <b>anyone?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, anyone who betroths</b> a woman <b>betroths</b> her contingent <b>upon the will of the Sages, and</b> when one fails to conform to their will in matters of marriage and divorce <b>the Sages expropriated his betrothal from him</b> retroactively.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> This <b>works out well</b> in a case <b>where he betrothed</b> his wife <b>with money,</b> as it is possible to say that the Sages expropriated the money used for the betrothal from the possession of its owner, resulting in a retroactive cancellation of the betrothal. But if <b>he betrothed</b> her <b>by means of sexual intercourse</b> then <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages declared his sexual intercourse</b> to be <b>licentious sexual intercourse,</b> which does not create a bond of betrothal.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If a husband <b>said to ten</b> people: <b>Write a bill of divorce for my wife,</b> in which case any one of them may write the bill of divorce and two others will serve as witnesses, <b>he can render</b> his instructions <b>void</b> before <b>this</b> one, i.e., any one of them, by stating: Do not write the bill of divorce, even though it is <b>not before that</b> one, i.e., any other one of them; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He can render</b> his instructions <b>void only</b> when <b>this</b> one <b>is before that</b> one of them, meaning that all ten people must be present.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds: Testimony that was partially invalidated</b>

Daf 33b

<b>is not entirely invalidated; and</b> therefore, even though the husband nullified the agency of part of the group, <b>if these</b> other people whose agency was never nullified <b>go</b> and <b>write</b> the bill of divorce <b>and give</b> it to the wife, <b>let them write and give</b> the bill of divorce. There is nothing to be concerned about, as their agency was never nullified. Since the bill of divorce that they deliver is valid, there is no reason to institute an ordinance that a husband can nullify the agency only in the presence of the entire group.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> disagrees and <b>holds: Testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated. And</b> if the agency of part of the group was nullified when those agents were not in the presence of the rest of the group, then <b>those</b> others <b>do not know</b> that their agency has been nullified as well. <b>And</b> they might then <b>go and write</b> a bill of divorce <b>and give</b> it, <b>and they</b> will cause the court to mistakenly <b>permit a married woman to</b> marry <b>anyone.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone</b> agrees that <b>testimony that was partially invalidated is not entirely invalidated; and here, this is the reason of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> that the husband can nullify his instructions only in the presence of all of the agents: <b>He holds</b> that <b>a matter that is performed in the presence of ten</b> people <b>requires</b> the presence <b>of ten</b> people <b>to revoke it.</b> Since the husband instructed ten people to write the bill of divorce, he cannot revoke his instructions in the presence of only a portion of them.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If the husband said to them: <b>All of you</b> should write a bill of divorce for my wife, in which case all of them must sign the bill of divorce, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> according to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel? The Gemara elaborates: Is the <b>reason of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> for prohibiting the husband from nullifying the instructions that he had given to ten people <b>because he holds</b> that <b>testimony that was partially invalidated is entirely invalidated,</b> and one should be concerned that the rest of the group will not know that their agency was nullified? <b>And these</b> people, <b>since he said to them</b> explicitly: <b>All of you</b> should write the bill of divorce, the rest of the group <b>are not able</b> to <b>write and give</b> the bill of divorce on their own. Therefore, the husband should be able to nullify his instructions when not in the presence of the entire group, as no mistake can occur because of his action.
<b>Or perhaps the reason of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> is <b>be-cause he holds</b> that <b>a matter that is performed in the presence of ten</b> people <b>requires</b> the presence <b>of ten</b> people <b>to revoke it. And therefore, even</b> if he said: <b>All of you</b> should write the bill of divorce, he must nullify his instructions in all ten people’s presence <b>as well.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 4:1): If <b>one said to two</b> agents: <b>Give a bill of divorce to my wife, he can render</b> his instructions <b>void</b> before <b>this</b> one, i.e., either of them, even though it is <b>not before that</b> one, i.e., the other one; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He can render</b> his instructions <b>void only</b> when <b>this</b> one <b>is before that</b> one, i.e., when the two of them are together. The Gemara now states the attempted proof. <b>But two are equivalent to: All of you,</b> as the bill of divorce cannot be written and given by fewer than two people, and there is no concern that perhaps one will sign without the other. <b>And</b> yet Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel still <b>disagree,</b> proving that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s reason is that the husband can nullify his instructions only in the same manner that he gave them.
<b>Rav Ashi said: If</b> the <i>baraita</i> was speaking of <b>witnesses of</b> the <b>writing</b> of the bill of divorce, both of whom must sign the bill of divorce, this would <b>indeed</b> resolve the question. However, <b>here we are dealing with witnesses of</b> the <b>delivery</b> of the bill of divorce. In that case there is no need for two agents, so there is a concern that if the husband nullifies their agency in the presence of only one of them, then the second agent could mistakenly deliver the bill of divorce to the wife.
The Gemara comments: <b>This too, stands to reason, as the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> If <b>one said to this</b> one <b>on his own and to that</b> one <b>on his own,</b> then <b>he can nullify</b> each of their agencies before <b>this</b> one even though it is <b>not before that</b> one. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that this is referring <b>to witnesses of</b> the <b>delivery</b> of the bill of divorce, this works out <b>well,</b> as they need not be appointed together. <b>However, if you say</b> that this is referring <b>to witnesses of</b> the <b>writing, can they combine together</b> if they were appointed separately? <b>But doesn’t the Master say: The testimony of</b> two witnesses <b>does not combine together until the two of them see</b> the event <b>as one,</b> together? The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Perhaps he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa,</b> who holds that in order for the witnesses to combine together and present their testimony it is not necessary for them to witness the event together.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda said: I heard from Rabbi Abba two</b> rulings with regard to these questions; in <b>one</b> he ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and</b> in <b>one</b> he ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and I do not know which is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and which is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Let us see</b> ourselves which argument was decided in favor of whom based on other sources, <b>as when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> There was <b>an incident and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>acted in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis. Rabbi Perata,</b> the <b>son of Rabbi Elazar ben Perata</b> and the <b>son of the son of Rabbi Perata the Great, said before</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>If so, what advantage does the court have? And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>reversed</b> his ruling <b>and acted in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b> The claim of: If so, what advantage does the court have, is the reason behind Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s opinion with regard to the question of whether, in a case where the husband violates the ordinance and renders the bill of divorce void in the presence of a court but not before the agent, it is void after the fact.
<b>And from</b> the fact <b>that this</b> dispute is decided <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi retracted his opinion and acted in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, by inference, in the case of <b>that</b> disagreement, with regard to one who gives instructions to ten people, the <i>halakha</i> must be <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Yoshiya from</b> the city of <b>Usha also holds</b> that <b>one</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and one is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. As Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: We were five elders</b> sitting <b>before Rabbi Yoshiya from Usha. A certain man came before him, and</b> Rabbi Yoshiya <b>extracted</b> the authorization to write <b>a bill of divorce from him against his will.</b> Rabbi Yoshiya <b>said to us: Go hide and write for her</b> a bill of divorce, so that the husband will not find you and render the bill of divorce void after it has been written.
The Gemara explains the inference as to the ruling of Rabbi Yoshiya: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that he rules <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, that if a husband renders a bill of divorce void when not in the presence of the agent then the bill of divorce is void, then <b>if they hide, what of it?</b> The man could simply render the bill of divorce void in the presence of others. <b>Rather, learn from it</b> that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that one can render the bill of divorce void only in the presence of the agents.
The Gemara explains the second element: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that with regard to <b>the other</b> dispute, where one instructs ten people to write the bill of divorce, he <b>also</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> then <b>why would they need to hide? Let them scatter,</b> and since the husband will not find all of them together, he will be unable to render the bill of divorce void. <b>Rather, learn from it</b> that he holds in <b>one</b> case <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and</b> in <b>one</b> case <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b> This is one opinion with regard to the <i>halakha</i> in the two disputes of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>And Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman</b> says: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>in both</b> cases. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rav Naḥman</b> accept the argument that <b>the court</b> should <b>have an advantage? But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say</b> that <b>Shmuel says,</b>

Daf 34a

with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of a steward who cares for the estate of orphans: In the case of <b>orphans who came to divide their father’s property, the court appoints a steward</b> [<b><i>apotropos</i></b>] <b>for them, and they select for them,</b> i.e., for each of the orphans, <b>a fine portion.</b> When the orphans <b>have grown up,</b> they <b>can protest</b> the division and demand the redistribution of the property. <b>And Rav Naḥman said his own</b> statement: <b>When they have grown up, they cannot protest, for if so, what advantage</b> does <b>the court have?</b> This demonstrates that Rav Naḥman agrees with the principle of: If so, what advantage does the court have?
The Gemara answers: There is no contradiction between Rav Naḥman’s statement concerning the inheritance of orphans and his statement with regard to rendering a bill of divorce void. <b>There,</b> in the former case, it is in the realm of <b>monetary matters,</b> and the preservation of the court’s honor is more important than the accurate distribution of the property. <b>Here,</b> in the case of divorce, it is in the realm of matters of <b>prohibition,</b> and one would not permit a married woman to remarry in order to strengthen the authority of the court.
§ The Gemara relates: A man named <b>Giddul bar Re’ilai sent a bill of divorce to his wife. The agent went</b> and <b>found that she was sitting and weaving</b> [<b><i>navla</i></b>]. <b>He said to her: This is your bill of divorce. She said to him: At least go</b> away <b>from here now and come tomorrow</b> to give me the bill of divorce. The agent <b>went to</b> Giddul bar Re’ilai <b>and told him</b> what had occurred. Giddul bar Re’ilai <b>opened</b> his mouth <b>and said: Blessed is He Who is good and does good,</b> as he was happy that the bill of divorce was not delivered.
The Sages disagreed with regard to the status of this bill of divorce. <b>Abaye said</b> that he said: <b>Blessed is He Who is good and does good,</b> as he was happy that it was not delivered, <b>but the bill of divorce is not rendered void</b> through this statement. <b>Rava said</b> that he said: <b>Blessed is He Who is good and does good, and the bill of divorce is rendered void.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They disagree in</b> their understanding of <b>disclosure of intent with regard to a bill of divorce,</b> i.e., when the husband demonstrates that he does not desire the bill of divorce to be delivered, but does not render it void explicitly. <b>As Abaye holds: Disclosure of intent with regard to a bill of divorce is not a</b> significant <b>matter</b> and does not render it void, <b>and Rava holds: Disclosure of intent with regard to a bill of divorce is</b> a significant <b>matter,</b> and does render it void.
<b>Rava said: From where do I say</b> this <i>halakha</i>? From a case <b>where Rav Sheshet extracted</b> the authorization to write <b>a bill of divorce from a certain man against his will, and</b> that man then <b>said to the witnesses: This</b> is what <b>Rav Sheshet said to you: Let the bill of divorce be rendered void, and Rav Sheshet required him</b> to write <b>another bill of divorce.</b> Evidently, though the man did not explicitly render the bill of divorce void with his statement, but only demonstrated that he did not want the bill of divorce to be given, Rav Sheshet considered the bill of divorce to be rendered void.
<b>And Abaye</b> would respond: <b>Is that to say Rav Sheshet would render void the bills of divorce of</b> other <b>people?</b> Rather, the husband <b>rendered void</b> the bill of divorce himself. <b>And</b> the reason <b>why he told them this,</b> that it was Rav Sheshet’s instructions that the bill of divorce be rendered void, was <b>due to</b> the <b>lashes</b> that he would have received from the court appointees if he said that he was rendering the bill of divorce void against the wishes of Rav Sheshet.
<b>And Abaye said: From where do I say</b> that disclosure of intent with regard to bills of divorce is disregarded? From the case <b>where Rav Yehuda extracted</b> the authorization to write <b>a bill of divorce from the son-in-law of Rabbi Yirmeya Bira’a, and</b> the man <b>rendered</b> the bill of divorce <b>void.</b> Rav Yehuda <b>again extracted</b> the authorization to write a bill of divorce, <b>and</b> the man <b>rendered</b> the bill of divorce <b>void.</b> Rav Yehuda <b>returned</b> and <b>again extracted</b> the authorization to write a bill of divorce <b>against his will, and said to the witnesses: Place</b> pieces of <b>gourd in your ears and write</b> the bill of divorce <b>for him,</b> so that you will not hear if he renders the bill of divorce void again. Abaye states his proof: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>disclosure of intent with regard to bills of divorce is a</b> significant <b>matter,</b> in this case <b>the witnesses see that he is running after them</b> even though they do not hear him, so the bill of divorce should be rendered void.
<b>And Rava</b> would respond: Since they cannot hear him, his intent is not disclosed; <b>this, that he is running after them,</b> does not prove that he wishes to render the bill of divorce void, as it could be <b>that</b> he wishes <b>to say to them: Make haste</b> [<b><i>ashur</i></b>], <b>give her</b> the bill of divorce <b>speedily</b> [<b><i>hayya</i></b>] <b>in order to end the pain of that man,</b> i.e., my pain, that I am divorcing my wife.
