<b>And Abaye said</b> further: <b>From where do I say</b> that disclosure of intent with regard to bills of divorce is disregarded? From the case <b>where</b> there was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> the agents with whom he entrusted the bill of divorce: <b>If I do not arrive</b> from now <b>until thirty days</b> have passed, <b>let this be a bill of divorce. He came</b> after thirty days had passed, <b>but was prevented</b> from crossing the river <b>by the ferry</b> that was located on the other side of the river, so he did not arrive within the designated time. <b>He said to</b> the people across the river: <b>See that I have arrived, see that I have arrived, and Shmuel said:</b> It <b>is not considered</b> to be <b>an arrival,</b> even though it is clear that this was his intention, and the bill of divorce is not void.
<b>And Rava</b> said: This case cannot serve as a proof; <b>is that to say</b> that <b>there he desires to render the bill of divorce void? There,</b> in that case, <b>he desires to fulfill his stipulation, and he did not fulfill his condition,</b> as he did not arrive. Therefore, the bill of divorce remains valid.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> witnesses when he gave a bill of divorce to his betrothed: <b>If I do not marry</b> her within <b>up to thirty days,</b> then this <b>will be a bill of divorce. When thirty days arrived, he said to them: I took the trouble</b> but I did not succeed in marrying her.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> need we <b>be concerned</b> in the case of this bill of divorce? <b>If</b> we are concerned <b>because</b> he attempted to marry her and there were <b>circumstances beyond his control</b> that prevented him from doing so, isn’t there a principle that <b>unavoidable circumstances</b> have <b>no</b> legal standing <b>with regard to bills of divorce? If</b> the concern is <b>due to disclosure of intent with regard to bills of divorce,</b> and the husband demonstrated that he does not want the bill of divorce to take effect, then <b>this is a dispute of Abaye and Rava,</b> and, as the Gemara explains later, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Abaye.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who said to</b> witnesses: <b>If I do not marry</b> my betrothed <b>by the New Moon of Adar</b> then this <b>will be a bill of divorce. When the New Moon of Adar arrived, he said to them: I said by the New Moon of Nisan. With regard to what</b> need we <b>be concerned? If</b> we are concerned <b>because</b> he attempted to marry her and there were <b>circumstances beyond his control</b> that prevented him from doing so, isn’t there a principle that <b>unavoidable circumstances</b> have <b>no</b> legal standing <b>with regard to bills of divorce? If</b> the concern is <b>due to disclosure of intent</b> with regard to bills of divorce, and the husband demonstrated that he does not want the bill of divorce to take effect, then <b>this is a dispute of Abaye and Rava,</b> and, as the Gemara explains later, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Abaye.
The Gemara states several conclusions: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rav <b>Naḥman,</b> who ruled that one can render a bill of divorce void in the presence of two people. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rav <b>Naḥman,</b> who ruled that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi in both of his disputes with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.

Daf 34b

<b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Naḥmani,</b> i.e., Abaye, that disclosure of intent with regard to bills of divorce is disregarded.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Initially,</b> the husband <b>would change his name and her name,</b> from the names by which they were known where they formerly lived to the names by which they were known where the bill of divorce was written, and write <b>the name of his city and the name of her city.</b> One was not required to list all of the names by which the husband and the wife were known, but only the names in the place where the bill of divorce was being written. <b>Rabban Gamliel the Elder instituted that</b> the scribe <b>should write</b> in the bill of divorce: The <b>man so-and-so, and any</b> other <b>name that he has,</b> and: The <b>woman so-and-so, and any</b> other <b>name that she has.</b> The reason for this ordinance was <b>for the betterment of the world,</b> as perhaps the people of a different city would not recognize the name written in the bill of divorce, and would claim that this bill of divorce does not belong to her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: The residents of a country overseas sent</b> an inquiry <b>to Rabban Gamliel:</b> With regard to <b>people who come from there,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>to here,</b> for example, someone <b>whose name is Yosef but</b> here <b>they call him Yoḥanan,</b> or someone whose name is <b>Yoḥanan, but</b> here <b>they call him Yosef, how do they</b> write bills of divorce to effectively <b>divorce their wives? Rabban Gamliel arose and instituted that they should write:</b> The <b>man so-and-so, and any</b> other <b>name that he has,</b> the <b>woman so-and-so, and any</b> other <b>name that she has, for the betterment of the world. Rav Ashi said: And this</b> applies only <b>when he is known by two names. Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi: Rabbi Mari and Rabbi Elazar hold in accordance with your</b> opinion.
The Gemara adds: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ashi:</b> If a husband <b>has two wives, one in Judea and one in the Galilee; and he has two names, one</b> that he is known by <b>in Judea and one</b> that he is known by <b>in the Galilee; and he divorces his wife who is in Judea with</b> a bill of divorce listing the <b>name that</b> he is known by <b>in Judea, and</b> he divorces <b>his</b> other <b>wife who is in the Galilee with</b> a bill of divorce listing the <b>name that</b> he is known by <b>in the Galilee,</b> then <b>neither</b> of his wives <b>is divorced until he divorces his wife who is in Judea with</b> a bill of divorce listing <b>the name that</b> he is known by <b>in Judea and</b> the <b>name</b> used by the people <b>of the Galilee</b> appended <b>to it, and</b> he also divorces <b>his wife who is in the Galilee with the name</b> that he is known by <b>in the Galilee and</b> the <b>name</b> used by the people <b>of Judea</b> appended <b>to it.</b> If <b>he leaves to a different place, and divorces</b> his wife <b>with</b> a bill of divorce listing <b>one of</b> these names, then <b>she is divorced.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say</b> that even in Judea his <b>name</b> used by people <b>of the Galilee</b> must be appended <b>to it?</b> Why then is he not required to list all of the names that he is known by? <b>Rather, learn from it</b> that there is a difference between the two cases: <b>This</b> former case is one <b>where he is known</b> to have several names, for example when those in Judea are aware that the husband is known by a different name in the Galilee. And <b>this</b> latter case is one <b>where he is not known</b> to have two names, as he traveled to a place where he was not known. Therefore, he is required to write only the name that he is known by in that place. The Gemara determines: <b>Conclude from it</b> that one must list all of the names that he is known by only if it is known that he has several names.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> woman <b>who</b> many people <b>called Miriam, and a few</b> people called her <b>Sara;</b> the Sages <b>of Neharde’a said:</b> In her bill of divorce, one must write: <b>Miriam, and any</b> other <b>name that she has, and</b> one should <b>not</b> write: <b>Sara, and any</b> other <b>name that she has,</b> as one must use the name that she is primarily known by.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A widow can collect</b> payment of her marriage contract <b>from the property of orphans only by</b> means of <b>an oath</b> that she did not receive any part of the payment of the marriage contract during her husband’s lifetime. The mishna relates: The courts <b>refrained from administering an oath to her,</b> leaving the widow unable to collect payment of her marriage contract. <b>Rabban Gamliel the Elder instituted that she should take, for</b> the benefit of <b>the orphans, any vow that</b> the orphans <b>wished</b> to administer to her, e.g., that all produce will become prohibited to her if she received any payment of her marriage contract, <b>and</b> after stating this vow, she <b>collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b>
The mishna lists additional ordinances that were instituted for the betterment of the world: <b>The witnesses sign</b> their names <b>on the bill of divorce,</b> even though the bill of divorce is valid without their signatures, <b>for the betterment of the world,</b> as the Gemara will explain. <b>And Hillel instituted a document that prevents the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>from abrogating an outstanding debt [<i>prosbol</i>] for the betterment of the world,</b> as the Gemara will explain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> discuss <b>specifically a widow?</b> This <i>halakha</i> should apply to <b>everyone, as we maintain</b> that anyone <b>who comes to collect</b> payment <b>from the property of orphans can collect only by</b> means of <b>an oath.</b> The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> the mishna to mention <b>a widow,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say:</b>

Daf 35a

<b>Due to</b> the increased <b>desirability</b> that this would bring her when trying to remarry, since this would ensure she would bring assets with her into a new marriage, <b>the Sages were lenient with her,</b> as the Sages issued several decrees in connection with the marriage contract in order to enable women to collect more easily. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
§ The mishna taught that the court <b>refrained from administering an oath to her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that they refrained from administering oaths to widows? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>because</b> of the statement <b>of Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana says, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Yehuda</b> who <b>says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a person during years of famine who deposited a gold dinar with a widow, and she placed</b> the gold dinar <b>in a jug of flour and</b> unwittingly <b>baked it in</b> a loaf of <b>bread</b> along with the flour, <b>and</b> she <b>gave</b> the bread as charity <b>to a poor man.</b>
<b>After a period of time, the owner of the dinar came and said to her: Give me my dinar. She said to him: May poison benefit,</b> i.e., take effect on, <b>one of the children of that woman,</b> i.e., my children, <b>if I derived any benefit from your dinar. It was said: Not</b> even <b>a few days</b> passed <b>until one of her children died, and when the Sages heard of</b> this <b>matter, they said: If one who takes an oath truthfully</b> is punished in <b>this</b> way for sin, <b>one who takes an oath falsely, all the more so.</b>
The Gemara first clarifies the details of the incident: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>she was punished</b> if she in fact did not derive any benefit from the dinar? The Gemara answers: <b>Because she benefited</b> [<b><i>ishtarshi</i></b>] <b>from the place of the dinar,</b> as the dinar took up space in the bread, enabling her to use less flour. Therefore, she did derive some small benefit from the dinar.
The Gemara asks: If she in fact did derive benefit from the dinar, then <b>what</b> is meant by the statement: <b>One who takes an oath truthfully?</b> Wasn’t her oath actually false? The Gemara answers: It means that she was <b>like one who took an oath truthfully,</b> as her oath was truthful to the best of her knowledge. In any case, this woman was punished severely for a small mistake. The severity of taking a false oath, even inadvertently, is why the Sages ceased administering oaths to widows.
The Gemara questions if this could be the reason for the ordinance: <b>If</b> they refrained from administering oaths <b>due to this</b> reason, then <b>why</b> would this be limited <b>specifically</b> to <b>a widow? Even a divorcée</b> should not be allowed to take an oath to collect her marriage contract <b>as well. Why</b> then does <b>Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Shmuel says: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a widow; however,</b> with regard to <b>a divorcée,</b> the court does <b>administer an oath to her?</b> Why would this concern not apply in the case of a divorcée as well?
The Gemara answers: <b>A widow is different,</b> as she continues to live in the house with the orphans and performs many services for them in the running of the home. Therefore, there is a concern that <b>due to the benefit</b> they receive from her as a result of <b>the efforts</b> she exerts <b>for the orphans, she will rationalize and permit</b> herself to take an oath that she had not collected any of her marriage contract, when in fact she had received a part of it.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said:</b> It is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say</b> that <b>they taught only</b> that an oath is not administered to the widow <b>in court,</b> as the oath that one takes in court is a severe oath, which involves the mentioning of God’s name and the holding of a sacred object. <b>However, outside of court,</b> where an oath is not taken in this manner, the judges <b>administer an oath to her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But Rav does not collect</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract for a widow</b> because she has not taken an oath, which indicates that he also would not administer an oath to her outside of the court. The Gemara answers: This is <b>difficult,</b> as it contradicts the statement of Rav Yehuda.
<b>In</b> the city of <b>Sura they taught</b> the statement with regard to the opinions of Rav and Shmuel <b>like this,</b> as stated above. However, <b>in</b> the city of <b>Neharde’a they taught</b> the statement with regard to the opinions of Rav and Shmuel <b>like this: Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says</b> that <b>they taught only</b> that an oath is not administered to the widow <b>in court; however, outside of court</b> the judges <b>administer an oath to her. And Rav says: Even outside of court as well,</b> the judges <b>do not administer an oath to her.</b>
The Gemara points out that according to this version of their statements, <b>Rav</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as Rav does not collect</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract for a widow</b> in any case. The Gemara asks with regard to Rav’s practice: <b>Let him administer a vow</b> to the widow, instead of an oath, <b>and collect</b> the marriage contract in accordance with the mishna, which states that a widow can take a vow in place of the oath. The Gemara answers: <b>In Rav’s time vows were</b> treated <b>lightly,</b> and Rav was concerned that widows would not treat the prohibition created by the vow with appropriate severity. This would result in the orphans losing out on part of their inheritance, and the widows violating the prohibitions created by their vows.
The Gemara relates: There was an incident involving <b>a certain</b> widow <b>who came before Rav Huna</b> and attempted to collect payment of her marriage contract from the orphans. <b>He said to her: What can I do for you, as Rav does not collect</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract for a widow.</b> The widow <b>said to him: Isn’t the reason</b> that I cannot collect payment <b>only</b> because of a concern that <b>perhaps I</b> already <b>took some</b> payment <b>of my marriage contract?</b> I swear <b>as the Lord of Hosts lives that I did not</b> derive <b>any benefit from my marriage contract. Rav Huna says:</b> Even though the court does not administer an oath to a widow, <b>Rav concedes with regard to one who leaps</b> and takes an oath of her own initiative that her oath is accepted, and she can collect payment of her marriage contract.
The Gemara relates: There was an incident involving <b>a certain</b> widow <b>who came before Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> to collect payment of her marriage contract. <b>He said to her: What can I do for you, as Rav does not collect</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract for a widow, and my father, my master,</b> i.e., Rav Huna, <b>does not collect</b> payment of <b>a marriage contract for a widow?</b>
<b>She said to him:</b> If I cannot collect payment of the marriage contract, then <b>provide sustenance</b> for <b>me</b> from my husband’s property, to support me until I remarry. <b>He said to her: You also do not have</b> any right to <b>sustenance, as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: One who demands</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract in court has no</b> right to receive <b>sustenance</b> any longer. The husband committed to provide for her sustenance only as long as she does not wish to remarry. Generally, once a widow demands payment of her marriage contract, she demonstrates that she wishes now to remarry and is no longer entitled to receive sustenance from her deceased husband’s property.
The widow became angry and <b>said to</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna: <b>May his chair be overturned,</b> i.e., he should fall from his position of power, as <b>he ruled for me in accordance with</b> the different opinions of <b>two</b> people. Since Rabba bar Rav Huna was concerned about her curse, <b>he overturned his chair</b> in order to fulfill the curse literally, <b>and</b> then <b>stood it</b> up, <b>and even so, he was not saved from</b> the <b>weakness</b> that resulted from her curse.
With regard to this issue, the Gemara recounts: <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> the student of Shmuel, <b>said to Rav Yirmeya Bira’a:</b> If a widow comes to collect payment of her marriage contract, <b>administer a vow in court and administer an oath outside of court,</b> and <b>let the report be received in my ears</b> that you did so, <b>as I desire to perform an action,</b> i.e., to enable a widow to collect payment of her marriage contract, in contrast to the statements of Rav’s students, who hold that a widow cannot collect payment of her marriage contract.
§ The Gemara returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself.</b> The mishna taught that the court does not administer an oath to a widow in order to enable her to collect payment of her marriage contract. <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a widow; however,</b> with regard to <b>a divorcée,</b> the court does <b>administer an oath to her.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is that to say that if the court <b>administered a vow</b> to <b>a divorcée</b> and not an oath, then this is <b>not</b> sufficient to enable her to collect payment of her marriage contract? <b>But didn’t they send from there,</b> from Eretz Yisrael, a document that states the following: <b>How so-and-so, the daughter of so-and-so, received a bill of divorce from the hand of Aḥa bar Hidya, who is called Ayya Mari, and she took a vow and prohibited the produce of the world to herself,</b> based on the truth of her statement <b>that she did not receive from her marriage contract anything other than one coat</b> [<b><i>gelofkera</i></b>], <b>and one book of Psalms, and a book of Job, and</b> a book of <b>Proverbs,</b> all of which were <b>worn out.</b>

Daf 35b

<b>And we appraised them,</b> and found that their value <b>is five hundred dinars. When she comes to you</b> with this document, <b>collect the rest</b> of the payment <b>for her</b> from her husband’s property in Babylonia. This demonstrates that it is also sufficient for a divorcée to take a vow. <b>Rav Ashi said: That</b> bill of divorce <b>was a levirate bill of divorce</b> that she received from the brother of her deceased husband and not a standard bill of divorce. She therefore took a vow, and not an oath, in the manner of all widows, as she was demanding payment of her marriage contract from the property of her deceased husband.
§ The mishna taught: <b>Rabban Gamliel the Elder instituted that she should take,</b> for the benefit of the orphans, <b>any vow</b> that the orphans wished to administer to her. <b>Rav Huna says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case where <b>she did not marry</b> again; <b>however,</b> if <b>she married</b> again, <b>they do not administer a vow to her.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>What is the reason</b> that a widow who <b>married</b> again may not take a vow in order to collect? It is because of a concern that perhaps she is lying and is not concerned about the vow that she took, as she relies on the fact <b>that her husband will nullify</b> her vow. If so, <b>when she is not married</b> one should <b>also</b> be concerned that she may rely on the fact <b>that when she will marry</b> again, <b>her husband will nullify</b> her vow. The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> is that <b>the husband does not</b> have the ability <b>to nullify with regard to</b> vows his wife took <b>prior</b> to their marriage.
The Gemara asks: <b>But let us be concerned that perhaps</b> she in fact received payment of her marriage contract, and she relies on the fact that <b>she will go to a halakhic authority and he will dissolve</b> the vow <b>for her.</b> The Gemara answers: Rav Huna <b>holds</b> that one who wishes to have a vow dissolved <b>must detail the vow</b> before the halakhic authority who dissolves it. There is no concern that the halakhic authority, knowing that she vowed in order to collect the payment of the marriage contract, will dissolve it.
<b>Rav Naḥman</b> disagreed with Rav Huna and <b>said: Even</b> if <b>she married</b> again, the orphans can have the court administer a vow to the widow. The Gemara asks: If <b>she married,</b> then her <b>husband will certainly nullify</b> this vow. The Gemara answers <b>that we,</b> the court, <b>administer the vow in public,</b> and therefore her husband cannot nullify the vow.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Huna from a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>she married</b> again, <b>she collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract if she has taken a vow. What, is it not</b> the case that <b>she takes a vow now,</b> after she has remarried? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is possible to explain that it is referring to <b>when she took a vow initially,</b> before remarrying.
The Gemara raises another difficulty for Rav Huna: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>she married</b> again, <b>she takes a vow and collects</b> payment of <b>her marriage contract.</b> Here, it is clear that she takes the vow after remarrying. The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as there is one who says: A vow that was taken in public has</b> the possibility of <b>nullification</b> by the husband, and therefore, even if the widow takes the vow in public, her husband can nullify it. As a result, she can collect payment of her marriage contract only if she takes a vow before she remarries. <b>And there is one who says:</b> A vow that was taken in public <b>does not have</b> the possibility of <b>nullification.</b> Therefore, even after the widow remarries, she is still able to take a vow and collect payment, as she takes the vow in public.
§ Since Rav Huna’s statement included the fact that one who requests that a halakhic authority dissolve his vow must detail the vow, the Gemara mentions that <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does one who comes to a halakhic authority and requests that he dissolve his vow <b>need to detail the vow, or does he not need</b> to do so? <b>Rav Naḥman says: He does not need</b> to detail the vow. <b>Rav Pappa says: He needs</b> to detail the vow.
The Gemara explains each one’s reasoning: <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>he does not need</b> to detail the vow, <b>as if you say</b> that <b>he needs</b> to do so, <b>sometimes</b> the person who took the vow <b>will cut short his statement</b> and not provide all of the details of the vow, <b>and the halakhic authority dissolves</b> only <b>what he hears</b> and does not dissolve the vow in its entirety. Nevertheless, the one who took the vow will act as though the vow has been dissolved entirely. Therefore, it is preferable that he just report that he took a vow, and the halakhic authority will dissolve it entirely, whatever it is.
<b>Rav Pappa says</b> that <b>he needs</b> to detail the vow, <b>because</b> the vow might concern <b>a matter that</b> is <b>prohibited,</b> such as the case of the mishna here where it is essential that the vow not be dissolved, as the purpose of the vow is to ensure that the widow will not lie. In such a case, if the halakhic authority is not aware of the circumstances that prompted the widow to take the vow, he could mistakenly dissolve it.
The Gemara attempts to bring a proof that one must detail the vow: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 45b): A priest <b>who marries women in transgression</b> of a prohibition is <b>disqualified</b> from taking part in the Temple service <b>until he takes a vow</b> not to derive <b>benefit</b> from his wives, thereby requiring him to divorce them. <b>And it is taught with regard to this: He takes a vow and</b> immediately <b>serves</b> in the Temple. <b>He</b> then <b>descends</b> from the service <b>and divorces</b> his wives. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>he does not need to detail the vow,</b> then <b>let us be concerned lest he go to a halakhic authority and</b> the halakhic authority <b>dissolve</b> the vow <b>for him.</b> He would then remain married to the women who are prohibited to him, and serve in the Temple despite being disqualified from doing so.

Daf 36a

The Gemara answers <b>that we administer the vow</b> to the priest <b>in public.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>a vow that was taken in public has no</b> possibility of <b>nullification</b> by a halakhic authority, <b>but according to the one who says it has</b> the possibility of <b>nullification, what can be said?</b>
The Gemara answers <b>that we administer the vow to</b> the priest based <b>on the consent of the public,</b> making it a type of vow that cannot be dissolved without their consent. <b>As Ameimar said,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is as follows: <b>Even according to the one who says</b> that <b>a vow that was taken in public has</b> the possibility of <b>nullification,</b> if it was taken based <b>on the consent of the public,</b> it <b>has no</b> possibility of <b>nullification.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And this matter applies</b> only to when the nullification of a vow is in order to enable one <b>to</b> perform <b>an optional matter, but to</b> enable one to perform <b>a matter of a mitzva, it has</b> the possibility of <b>nullification.</b> This is <b>like</b> the incident involving <b>a certain teacher of children,</b> upon <b>whom Rav Aḥa administered a vow</b> based <b>on the consent of the public</b> to cease teaching, <b>as he was negligent with regard to the children</b> by hitting them too much. <b>And Ravina</b> had his vow nullified and <b>reinstated him, as they did not find</b> another teacher <b>who was as meticulous as he</b> was.
§ The mishna taught: <b>And the witnesses sign the bill of divorce for the betterment of the world.</b> The Gemara asks: Is the reason that the witnesses sign the bill of divorce <b>for the betterment of the world? It is by Torah law</b> that they must sign, <b>as it is written: “And subscribe the deeds, and sign</b> them, and call witnesses” (Jeremiah 32:44).
<b>Rabba said: No,</b> it is <b>necessary according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, who says: Witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, and not the witnesses who sign the bill of divorce, and by Torah law it does not need to be signed. Nevertheless, <b>the Sages instituted signatory witnesses for the betterment of the world, as sometimes</b> it occurs <b>that the witnesses</b> who witnessed the transmission of the bill of divorce <b>die, or sometimes</b> it occurs <b>that they go overseas,</b> and the validity of the bill of divorce may be contested. Since they are not present, there are no witnesses who can ratify the bill of divorce. Once the Sages instituted that the witnesses’ signatures appear on the bill of divorce, then the bill of divorce can be ratified by authenticating their signatures.
<b>Rav Yosef said: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that it is <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> that signatory witnesses on the bill of divorce effect the divorce, and the mishna should be understood as follows: <b>They instituted that the witnesses must specify their</b> full <b>names on bills of divorce</b> and not merely sign the document, <b>for the betterment of the world.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 9:13): <b>At first,</b> the witness <b>would write</b> only: <b>I, so-and-so, signed</b> as <b>a witness,</b> but they did not state their full names. Therefore, the only way to identify the witness was to see if an identical signature could be found on a different document that had been ratified in court. Therefore, <b>if</b> another copy of a witness’s <b>signature is produced from elsewhere,</b> i.e., another court document, it is <b>valid, but if not,</b> then the bill of divorce is <b>invalid</b> even though it is possible that he was a valid witness, and as a result of this women were left unable to remarry.
<b>Rabban Gamliel said: They instituted a great ordinance that</b> the witnesses <b>must specify their</b> full <b>names on bills of divorce,</b> stating that they are so-and-so, son of so-and-so, and other identifying features, <b>for the betterment of the world.</b> This made it possible to easily clarify who the witnesses were and to ratify the bill of divorce by finding acquaintances of the witnesses who recognized their signatures.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> is it <b>not</b> sufficient to sign <b>with</b> a pictorial <b>mark? But Rav drew a fish</b> instead of a signature, <b>and Rabbi Ḥanina drew a palm branch</b> [<b><i>ḥaruta</i></b>]; <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> drew the letter <b><i>samekh</i>, and Rav Hoshaya</b> drew the letter <b><i>ayin</i>;</b> and <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna drew a sail</b> [<b><i>makota</i></b>]. None of these Sages would sign their actual names. The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages are different, as</b> everyone is <b>well versed in their</b> pictorial <b>marks.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Initially, with what did they publicize</b> these marks, as they could not use them in place of signatures before people were well versed in them? The Gemara answers: They initially used their marks <b>in letters,</b> where there is no legal requirement to sign their names. Once it became known that they would use these marks as their signatures, they were able to use them as signatures even on legal documents.
§ The mishna taught that <b>Hillel</b> the Elder <b>instituted a document that prevents the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>from abrogating an outstanding debt [<i>prosbol</i>]. We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:3): If one writes <b>a <i>prosbol</i>,</b> the Sabbatical Year <b>does not abrogate</b> debt. <b>This is one of the matters that Hillel the Elder instituted because he saw that</b> the people of <b>the nation were refraining from lending to one another</b> around the time of the Sabbatical Year, as they were concerned that the debtor would not repay the loan, <b>and they violated that which is written in the Torah: “Beware that there be not a base thought in your heart,</b> saying: The seventh year, the year of release, is at hand; and your eye be evil against your needy brother, and you give him nothing” (Deuteronomy 15:9). <b>He arose and instituted</b> the <b><i>prosbol</i></b> so that it would also be possible to collect those debts in order to ensure that people would continue to give loans.
<b>And this is the essence of the</b> text of the <b><i>prosbol</i>: I transfer to you, so-and-so</b> the <b>judges, who are in such and such a place,</b> so <b>that I will collect any debt that I am owed by so-and-so whenever I wish,</b> as the court now has the right to collect the debts. <b>And the judges or the witnesses sign below,</b> and this is sufficient. The creditor will then be able to collect the debt on behalf of the court, and the court can give it to him.
The Gemara asks about the <i>prosbol</i> itself: <b>But is there anything</b> like this, <b>where by Torah law the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>cancels</b> the debt <b>but Hillel instituted that it does not cancel</b> the debt? <b>Abaye said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>in the present,</b> and <b>it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The verse states in the context of the cancellation of debts: <b>“And this is the manner of the abrogation: He shall abrogate”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:2). <b>The verse speaks of two</b> types of <b>abrogation: One</b> is <b>the release of land and one</b> is the <b>abrogation of monetary</b> debts. Since the two are equated, one can learn the following: <b>At a time when you release land,</b> when the Jubilee Year is practiced, <b>you abrogate monetary</b> debts; <b>at a time when you do not release land,</b> such as the present time, when the Jubilee Year is no longer practiced, <b>you</b> also <b>do not abrogate monetary</b> debts.

Daf 36b

<b>And the Sages instituted that</b> despite this, the Sabbatical Year still <b>will abrogate</b> debt in the present, in <b>remembrance of the</b> Torah-mandated <b>Sabbatical</b> Year. <b>Hillel saw that</b> the people of <b>the nation refrained from lending to each other</b> so <b>he arose and instituted</b> the <b><i>prosbol</i>.</b> According to this explanation, the ordinance of Hillel did not conflict with a Torah law; rather, he added an ordinance to counter the effect of a rabbinic law.
According to this explanation, the Sages instituted that even in the present the Sabbatical Year would bring a cancellation of debt, despite the fact that by Torah law the debt still stands. The Gemara asks: <b>But is there anything</b> like this, <b>where by Torah law the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>does not cancel</b> the debt, <b>and the Sages instituted that it will cancel?</b> It is as though the Sages are instructing the debtors to steal from their creditors, as by Torah law they still owe the money.
<b>Abaye says:</b> This is not actual theft; <b>it is</b> an instruction to <b>sit</b> passively <b>and not do</b> anything. The Sages have the authority to instruct one to passively violate a Torah law, so long as no action is taken. <b>Rava says:</b> The Sages are able to institute this ordinance because <b>property</b> declared <b>ownerless</b> by <b>the court</b> is <b>ownerless. As Rabbi Yitzḥak says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that property</b> declared <b>ownerless</b> by <b>the court</b> is <b>ownerless? As it is stated: “And whoever did not come within three days according to the counsel of the princes and the Elders, all of his property shall be forfeited, and he shall be separated from the congregation of the captivity”</b> (Ezra 10:8).
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that property declared ownerless by the court is ownerless is derived <b>from here:</b> The verse states: <b>“These are the inheritances, which Eleazar the priest, and Joshua the son of Nun, and the heads of the fathers’ houses</b> of the tribes of the children of Israel <b>distributed for inheritance”</b> (Joshua 19:51). The Gemara asks: <b>What do the heads have to do with the fathers?</b> It comes <b>to tell you: Just as fathers transmit anything that they wish to their children, so too, heads</b> of the nation <b>transmit to the people anything that they wish.</b> This demonstrates that the court has the authority to take property from one person and to give it to another; therefore, the Sages have the authority to decide that all debts are canceled.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>When Hillel instituted</b> the <b><i>prosbol</i>,</b> was it <b>for his generation</b> alone <b>that he instituted</b> it, and the custom developed to continue using it, <b>or</b> did he <b>perhaps institute</b> it <b>also for all generations?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is there</b> whether it was instituted for his generation only or for all generations when either way, it is still in use? The Gemara explains: The difference arises with regard <b>to nullifying</b> the institution of <i>prosbol</i>. <b>If you say</b> that it was <b>for his generation</b> alone <b>that he instituted</b> it, then <b>we can nullify it</b> if we desire. <b>But if you say</b> that <b>he instituted</b> it <b>also for all generations,</b> then there is a principle that <b>a court can nullify the action of another court only if it is greater than it in wisdom and in number.</b> Therefore, we would not be able to nullify the ordinance instituted by Hillel and his court. <b>What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests a resolution to the dilemma: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear that</b> which <b>Shmuel said: We write a <i>prosbol</i> only in the court of Sura or in the court of Neharde’a,</b> as they were the primary centers of Torah study, but not in any other court. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>he instituted</b> it <b>also for all generations,</b> then <b>let them write a <i>prosbol</i> in the other courts as well.</b>
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Perhaps when Hillel instituted</b> the <i>prosbol</i>, he did so <b>for all generations,</b> but only for courts <b>such as his court,</b> which was the primary court of his time, <b>and</b> courts <b>like</b> those of <b>Rav Ami and Rav Asi, as they have the power to remove money</b> from someone’s possession. <b>However, for all</b> other courts, which are not as authoritative, he did <b>not</b> institute this ordinance. Therefore, the statement of Shmuel cannot serve as a proof with regard to the manner in which the <i>prosbol</i> was instituted.
The Gemara suggests another proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear that</b> which <b>Shmuel said: This <i>prosbol</i> is an <i>ulbena</i> of the judges; if my strength increases I will nullify it.</b> The Gemara challenges this statement: How could Shmuel say: <b>I will nullify it? But isn’t</b> it the case that <b>a court can nullify the action of another court only if it is greater than it in wisdom and in number?</b> It must be that Shmuel holds that Hillel did not establish the <i>prosbol</i> for all generations, and in his time it carried the force of a mere custom. The Gemara rejects this proof: It can be explained that <b>this is what he said: If my strength increases</b> so that I become <b>greater than Hillel,</b> then <b>I will nullify</b> the <i>prosbol</i>.
By contrast, <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> If my strength increases, <b>I will uphold</b> the institution of the <i>prosbol</i>. The Gemara asks: What is meant by: <b>I will uphold it? Isn’t</b> it <b>upheld and standing?</b> Why does the <i>prosbol</i> require further support? The Gemara explains: <b>This is what he said:</b> If my strength increases, <b>I will say something about it,</b> and I will institute <b>that even though</b> the <i>prosbol</i> <b>was not written, it is considered as though it was written.</b> Then people would no longer need to write a <i>prosbol</i>, as it would be considered as if everyone wrote one.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>This <i>ulbena</i></b> of the judges that Shmuel speaks of, is it <b>a term of insolence,</b> in that the judges are, according to Shmuel, enabling lenders to insolently collect debts that are not due to them, <b>or a term of convenience,</b> in that the judges are saving themselves the inconvenience of having to actually collect the debts detailed in the promissory notes? The Gemara suggests a proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear that</b> which <b>Ulla said</b> in describing the Jewish people after they sinned with the Golden Calf immediately following the revelation at Sinai: <b>Insolent [<i>aluva</i>] is the bride who is promiscuous under her wedding canopy.</b>
<b>Rav Mari, son of Shmuel’s daughter, says: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived? <b>“While the king sat at his table, my spikenard sent forth its fragrance”</b> (Song of Songs 1:12). He understands the verse in the following manner: While the king was still involved in his celebration, i.e., God had just given the Torah, the perfume of the Jewish people gave off an unpleasant odor, i.e., they sinned with the Golden Calf. <b>Rava says:</b> Nevertheless, it is apparent from the verse that <b>the affection</b> of God <b>is still upon us, as it is written</b> euphemistically as <b>“sent forth</b> its fragrance” <b>and</b> the verse <b>is not written: It reeked.</b>
The Gemara continues discussing the meaning of the word <i>ulbena</i>. <b>The Sages taught: Those who are insulted [<i>ne’elavin</i>] but do not insult</b> others, <b>who hear their shame but do not respond, who act out of love and are joyful in</b> their <b>suffering, about them the verse states: “And they that love Him are as the sun going forth in its might”</b> (Judges 5:31).
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the word <b><i>prosbol</i>? Rav Ḥisda said: An ordinance [<i>pros</i>] of <i>bulei</i> and <i>butei</i>.</b>

Daf 37a

<b><i>Bulei</i>, these are</b> the <b>wealthy, as it is written: “And I will break the pride of your power”</b> (Leviticus 26:19), <b>and Rav Yosef taught</b> with regard to this verse: <b>These are the <i>bula’ot</i>,</b> the wealthy people, <b>of Judea. <i>Butei</i>, these are the poor,</b> who are in need of a loan, <b>as it is written:</b> “You shall not shut your hand from your needy brother; but you shall open your hand to him, and <b>you shall lend him [<i>ha’avet ta’avitenu</i>]</b> sufficient for his need” (Deuteronomy 15:7–8). Therefore, the <i>prosbol</i> was instituted both for the sake of the wealthy, so that the loans they would give to the poor person would not be canceled, and for the sake of the poor, so that they would continue to find those willing to lend them money. <b>Rava said to a foreigner</b> who spoke Greek: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the word <b><i>prosbol</i>? He said to him:</b> It means the <b>institution [<i>pursa</i>] of a matter.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Orphans do not require a <i>prosbol</i></b> in order to collect payment of debts owed to them. <b>And similarly, Rami bar Ḥama taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Orphans do not require a <i>prosbol</i>, as Rabban Gamliel and his court,</b> i.e., any rabbinic court, are considered <b>the fathers of orphans,</b> meaning that all matters that relate to orphans are already managed by the court, including their promissory notes.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:6): <b>One may write a <i>prosbol</i> only on</b> the basis of the debtor owning <b>land. If</b> the debtor <b>has no</b> land, then the creditor <b>transfers any amount of his own field to him</b> so that he can write a <i>prosbol</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> is sufficient to be classified as <b>any amount? Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi says</b> that <b>Rav says: Even</b> the amount of land sufficient to grow <b>a stalk of cabbage</b> is sufficient. <b>Rav Yehuda says: Even</b> if <b>he lent him a place</b> sufficient <b>for an oven and a stove, one</b> may <b>write a <i>prosbol</i> on</b> this basis.
The Gemara challenges this statement: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Hillel teach</b> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Shevi’it</i> 8:10): <b>One writes a <i>prosbol</i> only on</b> the basis of the debtor owning <b>merely a perforated pot</b> placed on the ground. This demonstrates that <b>a perforated</b> pot <b>can</b> serve as the basis for the writing of a <i>prosbol</i>, as it is considered to be part of the ground due to the perforation; however, a pot <b>that is not perforated cannot</b> serve as the basis for the writing of a <i>prosbol</i>.
The Gemara continues the question: Since Rav Yehuda stated that possession of the place occupied by the oven is also considered possession of the land underneath with regard to this issue, <b>why</b> can’t a non-perforated pot serve as the basis for a <i>prosbol</i>; <b>but isn’t there</b> the <b>place</b> where the pot is resting? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> one cannot compare the case of Rav Yehuda to this case, as it is <b>necessary</b> for Hillel to state his <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where</b> the pot <b>is resting on stakes</b> and the borrower has no possession of any land at all. Hillel teaches that even so, if the pot is perforated it is considered to be land and may serve as the basis for the writing of a <i>prosbol</i>.
The Gemara recounts a related incident: When <b>Rav Ashi</b> would lend money and wish to write a <i>prosbol</i> <b>he would transfer</b> to the borrower <b>a stump of a palm tree</b> that was still attached to the ground, <b>and he wrote a <i>prosbol</i></b> based <b>on this. The Sages of the school of Rav Ashi would transfer their matters,</b> i.e., their debts, <b>to each other</b> without writing a <i>prosbol</i>, by stating: You are hereby a court, and the debt is given over to you. <b>Rabbi Yonatan transferred a matter</b> by means of such a statement <b>to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba.</b> Rabbi Yonatan <b>said to him: Do I need anything else? He said to him: You do not need</b> anything else, as this statement alone is sufficient.
The Gemara discusses the requirement for the debtor to have land. <b>The Sages taught:</b> If the debtor <b>has no land but the guarantor has land</b> then <b>one writes a <i>prosbol</i> on</b> the basis of the land of the guarantor. If both <b>he and the guarantor have no land, but</b> another person <b>who is obligated</b> to pay money <b>to</b> the debtor <b>has land,</b> then <b>one writes a <i>prosbol</i> on</b> the basis of this land. This <i>halakha</i> is derived <b>from</b> a statement <b>of Rabbi Natan.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: From where</b> is it derived that <b>when one lends one hundred dinars to his friend, and</b> that <b>friend</b> lends an identical sum <b>to his</b> own <b>friend, that</b> the court <b>appropriates</b> the money <b>from this one,</b> the second debtor, <b>and gives it to that one,</b> the first creditor, without going through the middleman, who is both the first debtor and the second creditor? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to returning stolen property: <b>“And gives it to him in respect of whom he has been guilty”</b> (Numbers 5:7). The fact that the verse explains that the money is given to one: “In respect of whom he has been guilty,” indicates that the money should be given directly to the one to whom the money is ultimately owed. In this case as well, the second debtor possesses land, and as he owes money to the first debtor, it is considered as if the second debtor owes money to the first creditor, enabling the first creditor to write a <i>prosbol</i>.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:1): <b>The Sabbatical</b> Year <b>abrogates debt both</b> for loans that were contracted <b>with</b> a promissory <b>note and</b> for loans that were contracted <b>without</b> a promissory <b>note.</b> The <i>amora’im</i> disagree with regard to the interpretation of the mishna: It is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say:</b> Loans that were contracted <b>with</b> a promissory <b>note,</b> is referring to loans that were contracted with a promissory <b>note that contains a property guarantee;</b> loans that were contracted <b>without</b> a promissory <b>note,</b> is referring even to loans that were contracted with a promissory note <b>that does not contain a property guarantee. All the more so, a loan by oral</b> agreement is canceled by the Sabbatical Year.
By contrast, it is <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish who both say:</b> Loans that were contracted <b>with a</b> promissory <b>note</b> is referring to loans that were contracted with a promissory <b>note that does not contain a property guarantee,</b> whereas loans that were contracted <b>without</b> a promissory <b>note</b> is referring to <b>a loan by oral</b> agreement. <b>However,</b> the Sabbatical Year <b>does not abrogate</b> a loan contracted with a promissory <b>note that contains a property guarantee,</b> as it is as though the creditor had already taken possession of the debtor’s land.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish:</b> The Sabbatical Year <b>abrogates a promissory note, but if</b> the promissory note <b>contains a property guarantee</b> the Sabbatical Year <b>does not abrogate it.</b> Similarly, <b>it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: If the debtor <b>specified one field for</b> the repayment of <b>his loan,</b> then <b>it is not canceled. And not only that, but even</b> if <b>he wrote: All of my property is pledged and guaranteed to you,</b> then the Sabbatical Year <b>does not abrogate it,</b> even if he does not specify a field for the repayment of the loan.
The Gemara relates: <b>The relative of Rabbi Asi had a certain</b> promissory <b>note that had a property guarantee written in it. He came before Rabbi Asi</b> and <b>said to him:</b> Does the Sabbatical Year <b>abrogate</b> this loan, <b>or</b> does it <b>not abrogate</b> it? <b>He said to him:</b> It <b>does not abrogate</b> it. <b>He left</b> Rabbi Asi <b>and came before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> and asked him the same question. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: It does abrogate</b> it.
<b>Rabbi Asi came before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> and <b>said to him:</b> Does the Sabbatical Year <b>abrogate</b> this loan, <b>or</b> does it <b>not abrogate</b> it? <b>He said to him: It does abrogate</b> it. Rabbi Asi challenged him: <b>But wasn’t it</b> the <b>Master</b> himself <b>who said</b> that the Sabbatical Year <b>does not abrogate</b> a promissory note that contains a property guarantee? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: Because we think</b> that this should be the <i>halakha</i> should <b>we perform an action</b> based on this? Rabbi Asi <b>said to him: But isn’t it taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of</b> the <b>Master? He said to him: Perhaps that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, who say</b> more generally: <b>A</b> promissory <b>note that stands to be collected is considered as though it has been collected,</b> and this is why the loan is not abrogated, as it is considered as though the loan had already been repaid. And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai in that issue.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:2): With regard to <b>one who lends money to another</b> based <b>on collateral, and one who transfers his</b> promissory <b>notes to a court,</b> the debt owed to them <b>is not canceled.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the debt is not canceled when <b>one transfers his</b> promissory <b>notes to a court, as</b> the <b>court seizes</b> the promissory notes, and they are able to collect this debt. <b>But what is the reason</b> that the debt is not canceled for <b>one who lends</b> money based <b>on collateral?</b>
<b>Rava said: Due to</b> the fact that the creditor <b>has seized</b> an item that belongs to the debtor, it is considered as though the debt has already been collected. <b>Abaye said to him: If that is so,</b> then if a creditor <b>loaned money to</b> someone <b>and lives in his courtyard</b> as a collateral for the loan, <b>since</b> he <b>seizes</b> the courtyard, which belongs to the debtor, would you <b>also</b> say that the Sabbatical Year <b>does not abrogate</b> the debt? That would contradict the accepted <i>halakha</i> that in this case the debt is canceled.
Rava <b>said to him: Collateral is different, as</b> the creditor <b>acquires it</b> for himself, as learned <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a creditor acquires collateral</b> given to him and is considered its owner so long as the item is in his possession? <b>As it is stated</b> in the verse with regard to the obligation of a creditor to return collateral at night: <b>“And it shall be righteousness for you”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:13). Rabbi Yitzḥak infers: <b>If</b> the creditor <b>does not acquire</b> the collateral, then <b>from where</b> is the <b>righteousness</b> involved in returning it? He would be simply returning an item to its rightful owner. <b>From here</b> it is learned <b>that a creditor acquires the collateral.</b> Therefore, when he returns the collateral to the debtor he is performing an act of charity.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:8):

Daf 37b

In the case of <b>one who repays a debt to his friend during the Sabbatical</b> Year, the creditor <b>must say to him: I abrogate</b> the debt, <b>but if</b> the debtor then <b>said to him: Nevertheless,</b> I want to repay you, <b>he may accept it from him, as it is stated: “And this is the manner [<i>devar</i>] of the abrogation”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:2). From the fact that the verse employed a term, <i>devar</i>, that can also mean: This is the statement of the cancellation, the Sages derived that the creditor must state that he cancels the debt, but he is allowed to accept the payment if the debtor insists on repaying.
<b>Rabba said: And</b> the creditor is permitted <b>to lift up</b> his eyes <b>to him</b> hopefully, demonstrating that he wishes to accept the payment, <b>until</b> the debtor <b>says this,</b> that he nevertheless wishes to repay him. <b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rabba’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>When</b> the debtor <b>gives</b> the creditor payment for a debt that has been canceled <b>he should not say to him: I give</b> this <b>to you</b> in payment of <b>my debt; rather, he should say to him: This is my</b> money <b>and I give it to you as a gift.</b> This indicates that the debt is repaid only by the initiative of the debtor. Rabba <b>said to him:</b> The creditor is permitted to <b>lift up</b> his eyes <b>to him</b> hopefully <b>as well, until</b> the debtor <b>says this,</b> that he gives it as a gift, but the initiative may come from the creditor.
The Gemara relates: There was a man by the name of <b>Abba bar Marta, who is</b> also known as <b>Abba bar Minyumi, from whom Rabba was</b> attempting to <b>collect a debt. He brought it to him in the Sabbatical</b> Year. Rabba <b>said to him: I abrogate</b> this debt. Abba bar Marta <b>took</b> the money <b>and left. Abaye came</b> before Rabba and <b>found that he was sad.</b> Abaye <b>said to him: Why is</b> the <b>Master sad?</b> Rabba <b>said to him: This was the incident</b> that occurred, explaining that Abba bar Marta understood his statement literally and did not repay the debt.
Abaye <b>went to</b> Abba bar Marta, and <b>said to him: Did you bring the money to</b> the <b>Master? He said to him: Yes.</b> Abaye <b>said to him: And what did he say to you? He said to him</b> that Rabba had responded: <b>I abrogate</b> this debt. Abaye <b>said to him: And did you say to him: Nevertheless,</b> I want to repay you? Abba bar Marta <b>said to him: No.</b> Abaye <b>said to him: But if you had said to him: Nevertheless,</b> I want to repay you, <b>he would have taken it from you. Now, in any event, bring it to him and say to him: Nevertheless,</b> I want to repay you. Abba bar Marta <b>went</b> and <b>brought</b> the money <b>to</b> Rabba <b>and said to him: Nevertheless,</b> I want to repay you, and Rabba <b>took it from him.</b> In the end, Rabba <b>said: This Torah scholar was not knowledgeable from the beginning,</b> as it was necessary to teach him how to react.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says: A person is deemed credible to say: I had a <i>prosbol</i> and I lost it,</b> and collect payment of his debt. The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Since the Sages instituted</b> the <b><i>prosbol</i></b> in a manner that allows anyone to write one without difficulty, in a situation such as this <b>one does not leave aside a permitted</b> item, i.e., collecting a debt after having written a <i>prosbol</i>, <b>and eat a forbidden</b> item, i.e., collecting a debt without having written a <i>prosbol</i>.
<b>When they would come before Rav</b> with a case where a creditor who did not have a <i>prosbol</i> was demanding payment of a debt after the Sabbatical Year, <b>he</b> would <b>say to</b> the creditor: <b>Did you have any <i>prosbol</i> and it was lost?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>this is</b> a case <b>where</b> the directive of the verse: <b>“Open your mouth for the mute”</b> (Proverbs 31:8) is applicable; this is not considered an intervention on behalf of one party, as it is only providing assistance for someone who was unaware of a claim that he should make.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 89a): <b>And similarly, a creditor who presents a promissory note unaccompanied by a <i>prosbol</i>, these</b> debts <b>may not be collected.</b> This demonstrates that even if a creditor himself claims that he had written a <i>prosbol</i> but it was lost, his claim is not accepted and the debt is canceled.
The Gemara answers: It <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who presents a promissory note</b> after the Sabbatical Year, <b>he must</b> present <b>a <i>prosbol</i></b> along <b>with it</b> in order to collect payment, <b>and the Rabbis say: He does not need</b> to present a <i>prosbol</i>, as it is assumed that he wrote one.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a Canaanite <b>slave that was captured, and</b> Jews who had not owned him <b>redeemed him, if</b> he was redeemed <b>to be a slave</b> then <b>he will be a slave. If</b> he was redeemed <b>to be a freeman</b> then <b>he will not be a slave. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case <b>he will be a slave.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>With what are we dealing? If we say</b> that the slave was redeemed <b>before</b> the first owner reached a state of <b>despairing</b> with regard to recovering the slave, then even if he was redeemed <b>to be a freeman,</b> he should still belong to his first owner; <b>why</b> would the mishna state that <b>he will not be a slave? Rather,</b> we might say that the slave was redeemed <b>after</b> the <b>despairing</b> of the first owner. Then, even if he was redeemed <b>to be a slave, why will he be a slave?</b> After his owner despairs of recovering him, he becomes ownerless property and consequently acquires his own freedom.
<b>Abaye said: Actually,</b> the mishna is referring to a case where the slave was redeemed <b>before</b> the <b>despairing</b> of the owner. Therefore, according to the unattributed opinion of the mishna, if he was redeemed <b>to be a slave, he will be a slave to his first master.</b> If he was redeemed <b>to be a freeman, he will not be a slave, neither to his first master nor to his second master,</b> i.e., the one who redeemed him. He will <b>not</b> be a slave <b>to his second master because he redeemed him as a freeman</b> and cannot now demand that he become a slave. He will <b>also not</b> be a slave <b>to his first master lest</b> people <b>refrain from redeeming</b> slaves. If they know that a redeemed slave remains a slave of his original owner, they will not see any reason to redeem them from captivity.
Abaye continues his explication of the mishna: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case <b>he will be a slave</b> to his first master. The Gemara explains: <b>He holds</b> that <b>just as it is a mitzva to redeem freemen, so</b> too, <b>it is a mitzva to redeem slaves,</b> and there is no concern that people will refrain from redeeming captured slaves.
<b>Rava said:</b> The mishna should be understood differently. <b>Actually,</b> the mishna is referring to a case where the slave was redeemed <b>after</b> the <b>despairing</b> of the owner. <b>And</b> therefore, according to the unattributed opinion in the mishna, if he was redeemed <b>to be a slave</b> then <b>he will be a slave to his second master,</b> as his original owner had despaired of recovering him. If he was redeemed <b>to be a freeman</b> then <b>he will not be a slave, neither to his first master nor to his second master.</b> He will <b>not</b> be a slave <b>to his second master as he redeemed him as a freeman.</b> He will <b>also not</b> be a slave <b>to his first master, as</b> he <b>was</b> freed <b>after</b> the <b>despairing</b> of the first master.
Rava continues his explication of the mishna: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case <b>he will be a slave.</b> This should be understood <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Ḥizkiyya, as Ḥizkiyya said: For what</b> reason did <b>they say</b> that <b>both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case <b>he will be a slave?</b> They said it <b>so that each and every</b> slave <b>should not go and hand himself over to</b> gentile <b>troops, and</b> in this manner <b>release himself from the possession of his master.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rava’s explanation from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said to them: Just as it is a mitzva to redeem freemen, so</b> too, <b>it is a mitzva to redeem slaves. Granted, according to Abaye</b> this works out well <b>as he said</b> that the mishna is referring to a slave that was redeemed <b>before</b> the <b>despairing</b> of his owner, and the unattributed opinion of the mishna rules that he will not be a slave to his original owner due to a concern that people will refrain from redeeming slaves. <b>This is</b> the reason <b>that he said: Just as,</b> since he was explaining that this concern does not exist.
<b>However, according to Rava, who said</b> that the mishna is referring to a slave that was redeemed <b>after</b> the owner’s <b>despairing,</b> and the unattributed opinion of the mishna is not concerned that people will refrain from redeeming slaves, is <b>this</b> the rationale of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, that <b>just as</b> it is a mitzva to redeem freemen, so too, it is a mitzva to redeem slaves? His reason <b>is because</b> of the statement <b>of Ḥizkiyya.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel did not know what</b> exactly <b>the Rabbis said, and this is what he said to them: If you say</b> this ruling with regard to a slave who was redeemed <b>before</b> his owner’s <b>despairing, this is</b> my response, that <b>just as</b> it is a mitzva to redeem freemen, so too, it is a mitzva to redeem slaves. <b>If you say</b> that this case was <b>after</b> his owner’s <b>despairing,</b> then the reason that I disagree is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Ḥizkiyya.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rava, who said</b> that the mishna is referring to where the slave was redeemed <b>after</b> the <b>despairing</b> of the owner, <b>and</b> he will be a slave <b>to his second master,</b> one can ask: With regard to the <b>second master, from whom did he acquire</b> the slave? If you say that he acquired him <b>from the captor, did</b> the gentile <b>captor himself acquire</b> the slave? The ownership of the second master is contingent on his acquiring the slave from someone who himself had ownership over the slave.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, he acquired</b> ownership <b>with regard to his labor, as Reish Lakish says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a gentile can acquire</b> another <b>gentile</b> as a slave <b>with regard to his labor? As it is stated: “Moreover, of the children of the strangers who sojourn among you, of them you may acquire”</b> (Leviticus 25:45). This indicates that <b>you,</b> Jews, can <b>acquire</b> slaves <b>from them,</b>

Daf 38a

<b>but</b> the gentiles <b>cannot acquire</b> one <b>of you,</b> as they do not have the ability to acquire a Jew as a slave, <b>and they cannot acquire each other</b> as slaves. The Gemara begins to introduce a question: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they shall not</b> be able to <b>acquire each other.</b> The Gemara immediately clarifies its question: Can it be that one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they shall not</b> be able to <b>acquire each other;</b> but <b>didn’t you</b> already <b>say</b> that <b>they cannot acquire each other?</b> Rather, <b>this is what he said:</b> Gentiles <b>cannot acquire each other with regard to</b> the slave <b>himself.</b>
The Gemara now restates the question: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they shall not</b> be able to <b>acquire each other</b> as slaves even <b>for</b> the rights to <b>his labor.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>You can say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If <b>a gentile</b> can <b>acquire a Jew</b> for the rights to his labor, as stated explicitly in the Torah (Leviticus 25:47), <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that <b>a gentile</b> can acquire <b>a gentile?</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But I</b> could <b>say</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that a gentile can acquire a gentile as a slave for the rights to his labor, <b>applies</b> only to acquisition <b>via money. However, via</b> an act of <b>possession,</b> by taking him captive, he does <b>not</b> acquire him. <b>Rav Pappa says</b> in response: The land of <b>Ammon and Moab became purified through</b> the conquest of <b>Sihon.</b> After the conquest of Sihon, the land that had belonged to Ammon and Moab was considered the property of Sihon, and it was permitted for the Jewish people to conquer it although they had not been permitted to conquer the land of Ammon and Moab. In the same manner, a gentile can acquire a slave by taking possession of him as a captive.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for <b>a gentile</b> acquiring <b>a gentile</b> through conquest, which is an act of taking possession; <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>a gentile</b> can also acquire <b>a Jew</b> through the act of possession such as conquest? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written:</b> “And the Canaanites, who dwelt in the South, heard tell that Israel came by the way of Atharim; and he fought against Israel, <b>and took of them captive”</b> (Numbers 21:1). This indicates that even a Jew is acquired by a gentile through the act of possession, in this case, conquest in war.
§ <b>Rav Shemen bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A slave who escaped from prison is emancipated.</b> He is no longer subjugated to his owner, as it is assumed that his owner has despaired of retrieving him. <b>And moreover, his master is forced to write him a bill of manumission</b> so that he can marry a Jewish woman.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> with regard to a slave who was redeemed from captivity: <b>Both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case <b>he will be a slave. And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Every place where Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel taught</b> a ruling <b>in our mishna, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his</b> opinion, <b>except for</b> the following three cases: The responsibility of the <b>guarantor, and</b> the incident that occurred in the city of <b>Tzaidan, and</b> the dispute with regard to <b>evidence</b> in the <b>final</b> disagreement. Therefore, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel in the mishna here, as it is not one of those three cases. This contradicts the ruling of Rabbi Yoḥanan cited above concerning a slave who escapes prison.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye, he establishes</b> the mishna as referring to a slave who is redeemed <b>before</b> the owner’s <b>despair.</b> For this reason, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel rules that the redeemed slave is not emancipated, and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his ruling. <b>And this</b> statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan, that a slave who escapes from prison goes free, applies <b>after</b> the owner’s <b>despair.</b> Therefore, there is no contradiction between the two statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, who said</b> that the mishna here is referring to a slave who is redeemed <b>after</b> the <b>despair</b> of the owner, there is <b>a difficulty.</b> The difficulty is due to the contradiction between the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> in which he rules against the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, as he holds that a slave who escapes prison is emancipated, <b>and</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> in which he rules that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: What is the reason</b> that a slave who was redeemed is not emancipated? It is <b>because of</b> the concern expressed by <b>Ḥizkiyya,</b> that perhaps slaves would allow themselves to be captured by foreign troops in the hope that they would be redeemed and consequently emancipated. However, the case of one who <b>escapes</b> from prison <b>is different,</b> as the concern raised by Ḥizkiyya is not applicable. If <b>now</b> it is apparent that he is willing <b>to give himself over to death</b> to escape captivity, as he would be put to death for attempting to escape prison, is there a concern that <b>he will throw himself</b> willingly <b>into</b> captivity by allowing himself to be captured by foreign <b>troops?</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>The maidservant of Master Shmuel was taken captive.</b> Some people <b>redeemed her to be a maidservant and sent her to him. They sent him</b> the following message: <b>We hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> and therefore we hold that in any case she remains your maidservant. <b>Even if you hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> in the mishna, then you should know that <b>we redeemed her to be a maidservant,</b> and even the Rabbis would agree that she remains your maidservant.
The Gemara adds: <b>And they thought</b> that this <b>was before</b> his <b>despair, but</b> that <b>is not so. It was after</b> his <b>despair, and</b> when <b>Shmuel</b> received the maidservant, <b>it is not necessary</b> to say <b>that he did not enslave her. But also, he did not require her</b> to receive <b>a bill of manumission,</b> as he held that she was a free woman in every respect.
The Gemara comments: In this matter, <b>Shmuel</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as Shmuel says:</b> With regard to one <b>who renounces ownership of his slave,</b> the slave <b>is emancipated, and he does not</b> even <b>require a bill of manumission.</b> Shmuel cited a proof from that <b>which is stated: “But every slave man that is bought for money”</b> (Exodus 12:44). Does this apply only to <b>a slave</b> who is <b>a man, and not to a woman slave? Rather,</b> it means: The slave of a man, i.e., <b>a slave whose master has authority</b> and control <b>over him, is called a slave,</b> since he is the slave of a particular man. However, with regard to a slave <b>whose master does not have authority over him,</b> such as one who has been declared ownerless, he <b>is not called a slave</b> but a freeman. Therefore, once Shmuel despaired of retrieving his maidservant, she was no longer under his control and did not require a bill of manumission.
The Gemara relates: <b>The maidservant of Rabbi Abba bar Zutra was taken captive. A certain</b> gentile <b><i>tarmoda’a</i> redeemed her to be</b> his <b>wife.</b> The Sages <b>sent</b> a message <b>to</b> Rabbi Abba bar Zutra: <b>If you</b> wish to <b>act correctly, send her a bill of manumission.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> this is a situation <b>where</b> the Jews <b>are able to redeem her, why do I</b> need <b>a bill of manumission?</b> They should redeem her to be a maidservant. <b>If</b> this is a situation <b>where they are unable to redeem her, when he sends her a bill of manumission, what of it?</b> What effect will it have, as she is currently under the control of this gentile?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring to a situation <b>where they are able to redeem her</b> but are not doing so. <b>And since he sends her a bill of manumission,</b> the residents of the city <b>will join together and redeem her,</b> as she is now a full-fledged Jew, whereas they would not have redeemed her to be a maidservant. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they are unable to redeem her,</b> as the ransom was too expensive. <b>And once he sends her a bill of manumission, she will be disrespected in the eyes</b> of the gentile who redeemed her to marry her, as he will find out that she is a maidservant of a Jew, <b>and he will allow her to be redeemed.</b>
The Gemara challenges this statement: Would it be easier to redeem the maidservant once the gentile discovered that she is the maidservant of a Jew? <b>But didn’t the Master say: The animals of Jews are more beloved</b> to gentiles <b>than their</b> own <b>wives?</b> Apparently, the gentiles held the Jews in high regard, and the fact that she was a Jewish maidservant would not lower her in the gentile’s estimation. The Gemara answers: <b>This statement applies</b> only concerning matters that take place <b>in private; however, in public, the matter is disrespected,</b> and a gentile would not marry the maidservant of a Jew.
§ The Gemara relates: There was an incident involving <b>a certain maidservant in Pumbedita with whom people were performing prohibited</b> sexual <b>acts,</b> and her master was unable to prevent this. <b>Abaye said: If not</b> for the fact <b>that Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says</b> that <b>anyone who emancipates his slave violates a positive</b> mitzva, as it is written in the Torah: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” (Leviticus 25:46), <b>I would force her master, and he would write</b> and give <b>her a bill of manumission,</b> enabling her to marry a Jew, which would ensure that she would cease her promiscuous behavior. <b>Ravina said:</b> In a case <b>like that, Rav Yehuda concedes</b> that it is permitted to emancipate her, <b>due to the prohibited matter</b> that others are violating.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Abaye</b> hold that one <b>cannot</b> emancipate a slave even <b>due to a prohibition</b> that is being violated? <b>Didn’t Rav Ḥanina bar Rav Ketina say</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak says:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a woman</b> who was <b>a half-maidservant half-free woman,</b> as she had belonged to two masters and was emancipated by one of them,

Daf 38b

<b>and</b> the court <b>forced her master</b> to emancipate her, <b>and he made her a free woman. And Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> in explanation of why they forced him to do this: <b>They took liberties with her,</b> i.e., people engaged in sexual intercourse with her freely. This demonstrates that it is permitted to free a slave to prevent people from violating prohibitions.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of a half-maidservant half-free woman, <b>she is not fit for</b> marrying <b>a slave and she is not fit for</b> marrying <b>a freeman.</b> This is why she is available to all, and the only way to solve this problem is to emancipate her. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the maidservant, <b>it is possible</b> for the master <b>to assign her to</b> marry <b>his slave, and</b> that slave <b>will guard her</b> from people who wish to be promiscuous with her. Therefore, it is not necessary to emancipate her.
§ The Gemara returns to discussing <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> cited above. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Anyone who emancipates his slave violates a positive mitzva, as it is stated: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever”</b> (Leviticus 25:46). This is a positive mitzva requiring that one subjugate slaves their entire lives. Therefore, it is prohibited to emancipate them.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving Rabbi Eliezer, who entered a synagogue</b> to pray, <b>and he did not find</b> a quorum of <b>ten</b> men, <b>and he emancipated his slave and had him complete</b> a quorum of <b>ten.</b> This demonstrates that one is permitted to emancipate his slave. The Gemara answers: Freeing a slave to enable the performance of <b>a mitzva,</b> e.g., completing a quorum, <b>is different.</b> This does not demonstrate that in general one is permitted to emancipate his slave.
The Gemara raises an objection from a <i>baraita</i> to the proof citing the incident involving Rabbi Eliezer: <b>The Sages taught: “Of them may you take your bondmen forever,”</b> is <b>optional;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> It is <b>an obligation.</b> The Gemara now explains the Gemara’s objection: <b>But perhaps Rabbi Eliezer holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that it is <b>optional.</b> Therefore, the incident involving Rabbi Eliezer cannot serve as a proof that even those who hold that it is prohibited to free a slave would hold that it is permitted to free a slave to enable the performance of a mitzva.
The Gemara answers: It <b>cannot enter your mind</b> to say that Rabbi Eliezer holds that enslaving them permanently is optional, <b>as it is taught explicitly</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> “Of them may you take your bondmen forever” is <b>an obligation.</b>
In connection with this issue, <b>Rabba said: With these three matters homeowners become impoverished: That they emancipate their slaves; and that they inspect their property on Shabbat; and that they set their meals on Shabbat at the time of</b> the sermon in <b>the study hall,</b> so that they miss it, <b>as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There were two families in Jerusalem, one</b> that <b>set its meal on Shabbat and one</b> that <b>set its meal on the eve of Shabbat, and both of them were uprooted.</b> One family was uprooted because they caused the suspension of Torah study, and the other was uprooted because by eating their meal on Shabbat eve, they did not properly distinguish between Shabbat and Shabbat eve.
