The Gemara answers: His statement necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>with regard to this, Rabbi Yosei holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who says: It is a proper bill of divorce, and she is not even required to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> Therefore, Rav Huna <b>teaches us that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Yosei does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. Each has a unique, albeit similar, opinion.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, as it teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the husband said: This is your bill of divorce from today and after my death, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: A case <b>like this</b> is a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> and there is no need for the wife to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. By emphasizing the term: Like this, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi intends <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei,</b> who is uncertain with regard to the matter. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>Rabbi Yosei did not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it teaches</b> in a mishna: Rabbi Yosei says: A case <b>like this</b> is a valid <b>bill of divorce, to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara cites the <i>baraita</i> and mishna that demonstrate the difference of opinion between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Yosei. <b>What is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a husband says to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>from today and after</b> my <b>death,</b> then there is uncertainty whether <b>it is a bill of divorce or</b> whether <b>it is not a bill of divorce,</b> and the wife must perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. This is <b>the statement of the Rabbis. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi disagrees and <b>says:</b> A case <b>like this</b> is a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> without any uncertainty, and there is no need for the wife to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>.
<b>What is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei? As we learned</b> in a mishna (76b): If one says: <b>Write and give a bill of divorce to my wife if I have not come from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months,</b> and the court <b>wrote</b> the bill of divorce <b>within twelve months and gave</b> it to the wife <b>after twelve months, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. Rabbi Yosei</b> disagrees and <b>says: A case like this</b> is a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If one says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce from today if I die from this illness,</b> and he recovered, <b>and he arose and walked in the market</b> and became ill again and died, then it must be assessed whether he died from the first illness and it is therefore a valid bill of divorce. But if he did not die from this illness then it is not a valid bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to a person on his deathbed, the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>his bill of divorce</b> are the same <b>as</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>his gift.</b> The Sages instituted that when a person on his deathbed gives a gift, no formal act of acquisition is required. <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>his gift, if he arose</b> and was cured from his illness the gift he granted while on his deathbed is <b>retracted,</b> as he gave it only based on the assumption that he was about to die, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>his bill of divorce, if he arose</b> and was cured from his illness, the bill of divorce is <b>retracted</b> and nullified, as he gave his wife her bill of divorce only because he thought he was about to die and he wanted to exempt her from a levirate bond.
Rav Huna continues: <b>And just as</b> in the case of <b>his bill of divorce,</b> where, <b>even though he did not explicitly say</b> his full intention, <b>once he said: Write</b> the bill of divorce, his statement is interpreted to mean that the court should give the bill of divorce to his wife <b>even though he did not say: Give</b> the bill of divorce to my wife, which a healthy man would need to state, <b>so too,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his gift. Once he said: Give</b> the gift, then <b>even though</b> the recipients <b>did not acquire</b> it <b>from him,</b> which finalizes a gift from a healthy person, because he is dying the <i>halakha</i> takes into account his intention without all the necessary legal requirements.
The Gemara challenges: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If a man said: <b>This is your bill of divorce from today if I die from this illness,</b> and he recovered, <b>and he arose and walked in the market, but</b> then <b>became ill</b> again <b>and died,</b> the court <b>assesses him. If he died because of the first illness</b> then <b>this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> but <b>if not</b> then it is <b>not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. And if you say</b> that <b>if he arose</b> and was cured of his illness the bill of divorce is <b>retracted,</b> then <b>why do I</b> need <b>assessment</b> at all? <b>He arose</b> from his sickbed, so the bill of divorce should automatically be nullified.
<b>Mar, son of Rav Yosef, says in the name of Rava:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where,</b> instead of recovering completely, <b>he proceeded from</b> one <b>illness</b> immediately <b>to</b> another <b>illness,</b> and the assessment is to ascertain whether he died from the first illness or from the second one.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the mishna: <b>He arose</b> from his illness, which indicates that he was completely cured? The Gemara answers: No, it means that he <b>arose from this illness but fell into another illness.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it</b> also <b>taught</b> in the mishna: <b>He walked in the market?</b> The Gemara answers: This means that <b>he walked with his staff</b> for support, meaning that he was not fully recovered from his illness but was able to walk only with assistance.

Daf 73a

<b>And this teaches us that we require assessment</b> only in a case <b>where he walked with his staff.</b> But in <b>another</b> case, where he did not arise from his illness and walk but immediately became ill again, <b>we do not even require assessment,</b> as it is clear that his death from the second illness was a result of the first illness.
The Gemara asks: Can <b>you conclude from it</b> that in the case of <b>a person on his deathbed who proceeded from</b> one <b>illness</b> immediately <b>to</b> another <b>illness, his gift</b> is a valid <b>gift,</b> as he ultimately died as a result of the first illness? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as Rabbi Elazar says in the name of Rav:</b> In the case of <b>a person on his deathbed who proceeded from</b> one <b>illness</b> immediately <b>to</b> another <b>illness, his gift</b> is a valid <b>gift.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>Rabba and Rava do not hold</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> stated <b>by Rav Huna,</b> that if the husband was healed of his illness then the bill of divorce is nullified even if did not specify such a condition. They hold that there is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> in place <b>lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>there</b> can be a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> given <b>after death.</b> Since people will see that in this case the bill of divorce took effect only once the husband died, in the future they may mistakenly consider a bill of divorce to be valid even though the husband explicitly made a condition that it would take effect only after his death.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there anything that by Torah law is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce, but due to a</b> rabbinic <b>decree we permit a married woman to</b> marry <b>anyone,</b> even though by Torah law she remains married to her husband? Both Rabba and Rava agree that by Torah law the bill of divorce is nullified once the husband is healed from his illness, yet they treat the bill of divorce as valid. How can this be?
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> the Sages have the ability to nullify even a marriage that took effect by Torah law, because <b>anyone who betroths</b> a woman <b>betroths</b> her contingent <b>upon the will of the Sages, and</b> when one fails to conform to their will in matters of marriage and divorce <b>the Sages expropriated his betrothal from him</b> retroactively. Consequently, it is permitted for the woman to remarry.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> This <b>works out well</b> in a case <b>where he betrothed</b> his wife <b>with money,</b> as it is possible to say that the Sages expropriated the money used for the betrothal from the possession of its owner, resulting in a retroactive cancellation of the betrothal. But if <b>he betrothed</b> her <b>by means of sexual intercourse</b> then <b>what is there to say?</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: The Sages declared his sexual intercourse</b> to be <b>licentious sexual intercourse,</b> which does not create a bond of betrothal.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:2): If a husband says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce from today if I die from this illness, and the house collapsed on him or a snake bit him,</b> then <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> But if he said: This is your bill of divorce <b>if I will not arise</b> healthy <b>from this illness, and the house collapsed on him or a snake bit him,</b> then <b>this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in <b>the first clause</b> such that the bill of divorce is not valid <b>and what is different</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> that the bill of divorce is valid? In neither case did he die from the illness. The Gemara gives no answer to this question.
<b>They sent</b> a ruling to Babylonia <b>from there,</b> from Eretz Yisrael: If the husband said: This is your bill of divorce if I am not healed from this illness, and <b>a lion ate him,</b> then <b>we do not</b> need to be concerned about this bill of divorce, for it is certainly not valid.
It is related: There was <b>a certain man who sold land to another,</b> and he <b>accepted upon himself</b> the responsibility for <b>any unavoidable accident that may happen</b> to the land. In such a case he would reimburse the buyer for the damage. <b>In the end they diverted a river into it,</b> meaning the government decided to make a new canal through the land that he sold.
The buyer <b>came before Ravina</b> to lodge a claim. Ravina <b>said to</b> the seller: <b>Go pacify him,</b> i.e., reimburse him, <b>as you accepted upon yourself</b> responsibility for <b>any unavoidable accident that might happen. Rav Aḥa bar Taḥalifa</b> disagreed and <b>said to Ravina: It is an uncommon, unavoidable accident,</b> and the condition of the sale should not apply in such a case.
<b>The matter was circulated,</b> as this ruling was never finalized, <b>and it came before Rava. He said to them: It is an uncommon, unavoidable accident,</b> and the seller should not have to pay. <b>Ravina raised an objection to Rava:</b> Isn’t it taught that if the husband said: This is your bill of divorce <b>if I am not healed from this illness, and the house collapsed on him or a snake bit him</b> then <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce?</b> These cases are both uncommon, unavoidable accidents, yet the bill of divorce is valid.
<b>Rava said to him: But</b> you can <b>say</b> an opposite inference <b>from the first clause:</b> If a husband says: This is your bill of divorce from today if I die from this illness, and the house collapsed on him or a snake bit him, then <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> Apparently, an uncommon, unavoidable accident is not included within his condition. If so, the inference from first clause of the <i>baraita</i> contradicts the inference from latter clause and it cannot be used to prove either opinion.
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: And because</b> there is <b>a difficulty</b> presented by the contradiction between <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>and the latter clause, can we no</b> longer <b>raise an objection from it?</b> Seemingly, the challenge raised by Ravina from the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> is still valid.
Ravina <b>said to him: Yes,</b> Rava was correct. <b>Since</b> there is <b>a difficulty</b> presented by the contradiction between <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>and the latter clause,</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>was</b> never <b>stated</b> in <b>the study hall and it is corrupted.</b> As it is not possible to rely on this <i>baraita</i> one must <b>follow reason,</b> and the most reasonable interpretation is that his condition would not include an uncommon and unavoidable accident.
It is related that <b>Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, purchased sesame on the bank of the Malka River. They hired sailors to cross them</b> to the other side of the river, and the sailors <b>accepted upon themselves</b> responsibility for <b>any unavoidable accident that might occur. In the end the Malka River was dammed</b> so that the merchandise could not be transported by river.
The two Sages <b>said to them: Hire donkeys and release them to us</b> in order to transport the sesame, <b>as you accepted upon yourself</b> responsibility for <b>any unavoidable accident that might arise.</b>
The two Sages <b>came</b> to court <b>before Rava</b> and <b>he said to</b> them: <b>You white geese [<i>kakei ḥivarei</i>],</b> referring to their long, white beards, <b>who strip men of their cloaks.</b> You are acting unfairly with the sailors. <b>It is an uncommon, unavoidable accident</b> for the Malka River to be dammed, and the sailors did not accept responsibility for this case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a woman’s ill husband gave her a bill of divorce, and made a condition that it should take effect from today if he dies from his illness, then <b>she may be secluded with him only in the presence of two witnesses,</b> lest they end up engaging in sexual intercourse.
This applies to being secluded in the presence of not only valid witnesses; it is permitted for her to be secluded with him <b>even in the presence of a slave</b> or <b>even in the presence of a maidservant, except for</b> the wife’s personal <b>maidservant.</b> And it is prohibited for the wife to be secluded in the presence of the latter <b>because she is accustomed to her maidservant,</b> and there is concern that she will engage in sexual intercourse with her husband even though the maidservant is present.
<b>What is</b> the halakhic status of the wife <b>during these days</b> between when the bill of divorce was given but before the condition has been fulfilled with the death of the husband? <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> She is

Daf 73b

<b>like a married woman with regard to all of her matters,</b> and she remains forbidden to other men. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> It is uncertain whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:4): If, after the giving of this bill of divorce witnesses <b>saw that she secluded herself with</b> her husband <b>in the dark, or that she slept with him under the foot of the bed, one is not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps they were engaged in another matter,</b> i.e., sexual intercourse. <b>And one is concerned due to</b> their action of <b>licentiousness but one is not concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions they performed <b>a betrothal. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: One is also concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions they performed <b>a betrothal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying? Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with her husband, then <b>there one is concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions there was <b>a betrothal</b> and perhaps through this act he intended to remarry her. If <b>he gave her money</b> immediately following the sexual intercourse <b>one is concerned due to licentiousness, wherein we say: He gave</b> this money <b>as hire for a prostitute, but one is not concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions they performed <b>a betrothal. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: Even in this</b> case <b>one is concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions they performed <b>a betrothal,</b> i.e., one is concerned that he gave her the money as betrothal.
Based on this explanation of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says,</b> that <b>the dispute</b> between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel (81a) is relevant only <b>when they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with her husband, but if <b>they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with him, <b>everyone agrees that she does not require a second bill of divorce from him?</b> In the case of a divorced woman who was secluded with her husband after the divorce, Beit Shammai are of the opinion that she does not require a second bill of divorce, while Beit Hillel are of the opinion that she does. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> is this?
The Gemara explains: It is <b>in accordance with everyone.</b> It is in accordance with the opinion of both the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who hold that when they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse one is not concerned that they are betrothed, and she does not need a second bill of divorce.
<b>Abaye objects to this</b> understanding of the <i>baraita</i>, according to which the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, disagree about a case where he gave her money after they engaged in sexual intercourse: <b>Is anything</b> with regard to <b>money taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>?
<b>Rather, Abaye said: This is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse one is concerned due to licentiousness, but one is not concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions there was <b>a betrothal. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: One is also concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions there was <b>a betrothal.</b>
If so, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The dispute</b> between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel applies only <b>when they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with him. <b>But</b> if <b>they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with him then <b>everyone agrees that she does not require a second bill of divorce from him.</b> In accordance <b>with whose</b> opinion is this statement?
It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as he holds in accordance with Beit Hillel, that if they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse one is concerned that she may be betrothed to him and she requires a second bill of divorce. By contrast, according to the first <i>tanna</i>, even when they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse one is not concerned that she may be betrothed.
<b>Rava objects to this: If so, what</b> is the meaning of the expression used by Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda: There is <b>also</b> concern that due to their actions they performed a betrothal? If there is concern about betrothal there should be no concern with regard to licentiousness.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that <b>this is</b> what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: Even</b> if <b>they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse, one is concerned</b> that <b>due to</b> their actions they performed <b>a betrothal.</b>
And if so, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The dispute</b> between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel applies only <b>where they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with him. <b>But</b> if <b>they did not see that she engaged in intercourse</b> with him, then <b>everyone agrees that she does not require</b> a second <b>bill of divorce from him.</b> In accordance <b>with whose</b> opinion is this statement?
This is <b>not in accordance with</b> any <b>one</b> of the <i>tanna’im</i>, for according to Rava the first <i>tanna</i> is not concerned about betrothal even when they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, is concerned even when they did not witness that she engaged in sexual intercourse.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>What is</b> her status <b>during these days? Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> She is <b>like a married woman with regard to all of her matters. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> It is uncertain whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced.</b>
The Sages <b>taught</b> in reference to the opinions of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei stated in the <i>baraita</i>: Their dispute with regard to her status in the interim is stated <b>provided that he dies.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>And when he dies, is</b> this a valid <b>bill of divorce?</b> Do they hold that the bill of divorce takes effect after the husband’s death? <b>But don’t we maintain that there is no bill of divorce after death? Rabba says</b> that this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>says:</b> This should be a valid bill of divorce <b>from</b> the last <b>moment that I am in the world,</b> meaning that it should take effect a moment before he dies.
<b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:4): In a case where the husband said: This is your bill of divorce from now if I die from this illness, <b>during the days between,</b> before he dies, <b>her husband is entitled to</b> anything that <b>she finds,</b> i.e., any lost item that cannot be returned to its owner, in accordance with the rabbinic principle that any lost item found by a wife belongs to her husband. <b>And</b> he is entitled to the profits from <b>her earnings, and</b> he is entitled to <b>annul her vows</b> (see Numbers 30:7–9), <b>and he inherits</b> from <b>her</b> if she predeceases him,

Daf 74a

<b>and he becomes ritually impure for her</b> if he is a priest. <b>The principle of the matter</b> is as follows: At that time <b>she is like his wife in every sense, but she does not require a second bill of divorce from him</b> when he dies. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> If she engages in sexual intercourse with another man, the legal status of <b>her sexual intercourse depends</b> on whether or not her husband dies from this illness. If he dies, she is considered to have been divorced from the time the bill of divorce was given, and her sexual intercourse is not deemed adulterous. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Her sexual intercourse</b> has an <b>uncertain</b> status. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> There is uncertainty whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced,</b> and this is an uncertainty <b>provided that he dies</b> from this illness. If he does not, they are certainly not divorced.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who says that the status of her sexual intercourse depends on whether or not her husband dies from his illness, <b>and</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who says that the status of her sexual intercourse is uncertain?
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The</b> practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to the bringing of <b>a provisional guilt-offering,</b> which is brought by one who is uncertain as to whether he committed a sin that requires a sin-offering. <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> the paramour <b>does not bring a provisional guilt-offering</b> (see Leviticus 5:17–19), because, although there was uncertainty at the time of the act of sexual intercourse, the matter will eventually be clarified once the husband either dies or recovers from his illness. If the husband survives her paramour must bring a sin-offering, and if the husband dies the other man is exempt from bringing any offering. <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> her status is uncertain, and even if the husband dies from this illness Rabbi Yosei is uncertain when the bill of divorce took effect. Therefore, her paramour must <b>bring a provisional guilt-offering.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> taught: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> There is uncertainty whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced.</b> The Gemara comments: Apparently, the opinion of <b>the Rabbis is</b> the same as the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> Why are they recorded as having a dispute? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the halakhic ruling transmitted <b>by Rabbi Zeira. As Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Wherever the Sages said:</b> There is uncertainty whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced, her husband is obligated to provide her</b> with <b>sustenance.</b> This formulation is stated only by the Rabbis, and Rabbi Zeira’s <i>halakha</i> would apply only according to them, not according to Rabbi Yosei.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a husband says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars,</b> then <b>she is divorced and must give</b> two hundred dinars in order to fulfill the condition of the bill of divorce.
If a husband says to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you will give me</b> money <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>thirty days, if she gives</b> the money <b>to him within thirty days she is divorced. And if not she is not divorced.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said:</b> There was <b>an incident in</b> the city of <b>Tzaidan involving one who said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me my coat [<i>itztaliti</i>], and she lost his coat,</b> so that she could not give it to him. <b>And the Rabbis said</b> that <b>she must give him the value</b> of the coat, and by doing so she fulfills the condition and is divorced.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: She is divorced and must give the money. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>And must give? Rav Huna says:</b> She is divorced immediately, once the bill of divorce has been given over to her, <b>and she must give</b> him the money subsequently in order to fulfill the condition. The bill of divorce takes effect retroactively, from the time when it was given, after she gives the money. <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> She is divorced only <b>when she gives</b> him this sum.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinion of Rav Huna and the opinion of Rav Yehuda? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them if the bill of divorce was torn or lost</b> after she received it but before she gave the money. According to the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> who <b>says: And she must give</b> but the bill of divorce takes effect retroactively, if it was torn or lost then <b>she does not require a second bill of divorce from him.</b> By contrast, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that the divorce takes effect only <b>when she gives</b> him the sum. Therefore, if the document is torn or lost <b>she requires a second bill of divorce from him,</b> as in his opinion it is not yet a valid bill of divorce until she has given him the money.
The Gemara comments: <b>And it was also taught</b> in the mishna <b>with regard to betrothal</b> that Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda also disagreed about <b>a case like this, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kiddushin</i> 60a): If <b>one says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me on the condition that I will give you two hundred dinars,</b> then <b>she is betrothed, and he must give</b> the sum. <b>And it was stated</b> that Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda disagreed with regard to <b>what</b> is the meaning of: <b>And he must give. Rav Huna says: And he must give,</b> meaning that she is betrothed immediately, provided that the husband gives what he promised. <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> She is betrothed only <b>when he gives.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between them?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> in a case <b>where she extended her hand and received betrothal from another</b> man before the first man gave her the money that he promised. <b>Rav Huna says: And he must give,</b> meaning that <b>it is merely a condition</b> that he accepted upon himself. <b>He fulfills his condition and moves on,</b> and the woman is betrothed to him immediately. Therefore, her betrothal to the second man has no validity. <b>Rav Yehuda says: When he gives,</b> which means that <b>when he gives her</b> the money <b>it will be</b> a valid <b>betrothal.</b> But <b>now it is not</b> a valid <b>betrothal</b> and therefore the betrothal from the second man takes effect.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to mention this dispute in both the case of divorce and the case of betrothal. <b>As if it would have taught us</b> their opinions only <b>with regard to betrothal,</b> then one may think that it is specifically <b>with regard to this</b> case that <b>Rav Huna says: And he should give, because he comes to draw her close</b> in marriage. Consequently, he does this willingly, and therefore there is an assumption that his intention was for the betrothal to take effect immediately. <b>But with regard to divorce, where he comes to distance her,</b> there is an assumption that he does so unwillingly, so that he makes the divorce dependent on a condition in order to delay the matter. Therefore, <b>say</b> that Rav Huna <b>concedes to Rav Yehuda</b> that the divorce does not take effect until the condition has been fulfilled.
<b>And if it would have taught us</b> their opinions only <b>with regard to divorce,</b> then one may think that it is specifically <b>with regard to this</b> case that <b>Rav Huna says: And she must give, because he is not embarrassed to demand</b> the money <b>from her</b> afterward to fulfill the condition of the bill of divorce, and his intent was to divorce her immediately. <b>But with regard to betrothal, where she is embarrassed to demand</b> the money that he promised would come <b>from him,</b> she may not agree to be betrothed to him until she actually receives the money. Therefore, you might <b>say</b> that Rav Huna <b>concedes to Rav Yehuda</b> that the betrothal is valid only once he gives her the money.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>if it would have taught us</b> their opinions only <b>with regard to betrothal,</b> then one may think that it is specifically <b>with regard to this</b> case that <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that the betrothal is valid only <b>when he gives</b> her the money, <b>because she is embarrassed to demand it from him</b> if he does not give it to her. Therefore, her intention is that she will be betrothed only once the condition is fulfilled. <b>But with regard to divorce, where</b> the husband <b>is not embarrassed to demand</b> the money <b>from her,</b> you might <b>say that</b> Rav Yehuda <b>concedes to Rav Huna</b> that the bill of divorce takes effect immediately.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>if it would have taught us</b> only <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>divorce,</b> then one may think that it is specifically <b>with regard to this</b> case that <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that the divorce is valid only <b>when she gives</b> him the money, <b>because</b> the husband <b>comes to distance her. But with regard to betrothal, where he comes to draw her close,</b> you might <b>say</b> that Rav Yehuda <b>concedes to Rav Huna.</b> Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state this dispute in both cases.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:5): If one says to a woman: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars,</b> then <b>even though the bill of divorce was torn or lost she is divorced. And she may not marry another</b> man <b>until she gives</b> her first husband the money.
<b>And it is taught further</b> in that same <i>baraita</i>: If one says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give two hundred dinars to me, and</b> the husband <b>died</b> childless, if she had already <b>given</b> him the money, then <b>she is not bound</b> with a levirate bond <b>to the <i>yavam</i></b> because she was already divorced from her husband through the bill of divorce that he gave her. But if <b>she had not given</b> him the money, then <b>she is bound</b> with a levirate bond <b>to the <i>yavam</i></b> because the bill of divorce did not take effect and she is a widow. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: She should give</b> the money <b>to</b> her late husband’s <b>father, or to his brother, or to one of the relatives</b> who inherit from him, and by doing so she fulfills the condition and is released from the levirate bond.
The Gemara notes: The first <i>tanna</i> and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>disagree only with regard to</b> the meaning of the condition. One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that when the husband said: On the condition that she will give <b>to me,</b> he meant: To me specifically <b>and not to my heirs.</b> Consequently, she cannot fulfill the condition by giving the money to his heirs. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds</b> that when the husband said that she will give the money <b>to me,</b> he meant <b>and even to my heirs. But in any event, everyone</b> agrees that this <b>is</b> a valid <b>condition,</b> yet its fulfillment does not change the date that the bill of divorce takes effect. This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Yehuda,</b> who said that the bill of divorce takes effect only when she gives.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yehuda</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Anyone who states</b> a condition employing the language: <b>On the condition,</b> is <b>like</b> one who <b>states:</b> The agreement will take effect retroactively <b>from now,</b> even though the condition is fulfilled only later on. <b>And the Rabbis disagree with him. And I say</b> my ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Zeira says: When we were in Babylonia we</b> would <b>say</b> with regard to <b>this</b> following statement <b>that Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Anyone who states</b> a condition employing the language: <b>On the condition,</b> is <b>like</b> one who <b>states:</b> The agreement will take effect retroactively <b>from now,</b> even though the condition is fulfilled only later on; we would say that <b>the Rabbis disagree with him. When I ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>I found Rabbi Asi, who was sitting and saying in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Everyone concedes that with regard to</b> anyone who <b>states</b> a condition employing the language: <b>On the condition,</b> he is <b>like</b> one who <b>states:</b> The agreement will take effect retroactively <b>from now;</b> and the Rabbis <b>disagreed</b> with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>only in</b> a case where the bill of divorce included the condition: <b>From today and after</b> my <b>death.</b>

Daf 74b

<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a husband says to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>from today and after</b> my <b>death,</b> then this is both a valid <b>bill of divorce and not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This is <b>the statement of the Rabbis. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi disagrees and <b>says:</b> A case <b>like this</b> is a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> without any uncertainty. This teaches that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis disagree only in this case, but everyone agrees that when he employed the language: On the condition, it is as though he stipulated: From now.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rav Yehuda, who said</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis <b>disagree about</b> one who employs the language: <b>On the condition, rather than disagreeing with regard to</b> the case where the husband said: <b>From today and after</b> my <b>death, let them disagree with regard to</b> the case where the husband said: <b>On the condition.</b> The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> uses this case <b>to inform you about the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who is certain that the bill of divorce is valid.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let them disagree about: On the condition, to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> who do not hold that the phrase: On the condition, is considered to be like the phrase: From now, as this ruling is a more general matter. The Gemara answers: It is <b>preferable</b> to emphasize <b>the power of leniency,</b> and therefore it is preferable to teach the degree to which Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is lenient.
§ The mishna teaches: If a husband said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you will give me</b> money <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>thirty days,</b> if she gives the money to him within thirty days she is divorced, and if not she is not divorced. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> that <b>obvious,</b> since everything depends on whether or not the condition was fulfilled? The Gemara answers: No, the <i>halakha</i> that the divorce does not take effect unless she gives the money by that time needs to be said, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>the concern</b> of the husband that his wife will give him the money within a specific time frame <b>is not</b> a real <b>concern,</b> and he <b>comes</b> only <b>to galvanize her.</b> Although he wishes to receive this money as soon as possible, in truth he does not care if he receives it later. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that his statement is a valid condition, and if she does not fulfill it then it is not a valid bill of divorce.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said:</b> There was <b>an incident in</b> the city of <b>Tzaidan</b> involving one who said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me my coat, and she lost his coat. And the Rabbis said that she should give him the value of that coat, and by doing so she fulfills the condition and is divorced. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> did Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>teach</b> before, such <b>that he</b> now <b>teaches</b> and cites <b>an incident</b> which is similar to it? This incident does not seem to be referring to what was stated immediately before in the mishna.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and this is what it is teaching: If</b> the husband <b>said to</b> his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you will give me my coat, and she lost his coat,</b> then since <b>he specifically stated to her:</b> Give me <b>my coat,</b> she cannot give him its value instead. And since she has lost the coat, the bill of divorce is not valid; this is the opinion of the Rabbis. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> In such a case <b>she can give him its value. And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said</b> in support of his statement: There was <b>an incident also in</b> the city of <b>Tzaidan involving one who said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me my coat, and she lost his coat. And the Rabbis said</b> that <b>she should give him its value.</b>
<b>Rabbi Asi raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars, and</b> afterward <b>he returned and said to her: It is waived for you,</b> then <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
He explained his question in detail: <b>Let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and <b>let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>Let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis:</b> One can say that <b>only there</b> do <b>the Rabbis state</b> their opinion that she is not divorced if the condition is not fulfilled and she gives him his coat, because <b>he did not waive</b> his claim to it; <b>but here he says to her: It is waived for you,</b> so they are divorced. <b>Or perhaps</b> one can say that <b>even Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel states</b> that she can be divorced even if he does not receive the coat <b>only there, as she appeases him by</b> giving him <b>money,</b> i.e., the condition is considered to be fulfilled due to the fact that he received the value of the coat; <b>but</b> in a case where he waives the condition <b>entirely, no,</b> because he does not receive anything from her. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>She is not divorced,</b> because the condition has not been fulfilled.
<b>He raised an objection to his</b> opinion from a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 63b): In the case of <b>one who says to another: Benefiting from me is <i>konam</i> for you,</b> meaning it is prohibited for you to derive benefit from me, <b>if you do not give my son one <i>kor</i> of wheat and two barrels of wine</b> as a wedding gift, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> It is <b>prohibited</b> for this other person to benefit from the person who took the vow <b>until he gives</b> his son the gift. <b>And the Rabbis say: Even this</b> individual who took the vow <b>can dissolve his vow without</b> the <b>consent of a halakhic authority, and</b> he does this by <b>saying: I hereby</b> consider it <b>as though I have received</b> the gift from you. Based on this mishna, it would seem that if the husband forgives his wife the money that she owes him, it should be considered as if he received it, and the bill of divorce should be valid.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of a bill of divorce, <b>he intends to vex her, and</b> until she pays him <b>he did not vex her.</b> If he forgives this condition, his initial intention has not been fulfilled. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the vow, the reason the father took the vow is <b>for the sake of profit;</b> he wants his son to receive a valuable gift, <b>but</b> subsequently the one who took the vow decides that <b>it was not necessary.</b> Therefore, he can waive his claim.
The Gemara relates an incident of <b>a certain man who said to his sharecropper: Everyone waters</b> the field <b>three</b> times during the season, <b>and they consume,</b> i.e., receive as payment, <b>one quarter</b> of the crops from the field. Will <b>you water four</b> times <b>and consume</b> as your payment <b>one-third</b> of the produce? <b>Ultimately, rain came</b> when the sharecropper would have needed to water a fourth time, and so he did not need to water the field a fourth time. The question was presented to the Sages: Is the sharecropper still entitled to receive one-third of the produce since he was prepared to water the field four times, although ultimately it was not necessary to do so?
<b>Rav Yosef said: But he did not water</b> the field a fourth time, so the condition was not fulfilled. Consequently, he deserves the same as the other sharecroppers, and receives only one quarter of the produce. <b>Rabba said: But it was not necessary</b> to water the field the fourth time because the rain fell to the benefit of the sharecropper, and therefore he should receive one-third of the produce.
The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say that Rav Yosef said</b> his ruling <b>in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who require that the condition of the bill of divorce be fulfilled, <b>and that Rabba said</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that it is not the fulfillment of the specifics of the condition that matter but the fulfillment of the intent of the condition?
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it in this way? <b>But don’t we maintain</b> that in all of their disputes <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabba</b> when he disagrees with Rav Yosef? <b>And with regard to this</b> <i>halakha</i> we maintain that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b> If so, this presents a contradiction between one <i>halakha</i> and another.
<b>Rather,</b> according to both opinions, this dispute is <b>actually in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. Rav Yosef</b> clearly rules <b>in accordance with the Rabbis. And Rabba</b> could have <b>said to you: I was saying</b> my statement <b>even according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> as <b>the Rabbis are saying there</b> that she is not divorced if she does not return the coat itself <b>only when</b> the husband <b>intends to vex her,</b> and if she does not need to give the coat itself she will not be vexed, as it is not difficult for her to give him its value. But <b>here,</b> in the case of watering the field, the reason the owner is making the condition <b>is</b> only <b>for the sake of</b> increasing his <b>profit, and it was not necessary</b> to actually water the field.
§ With regard to the redemption of houses in walled cities, <b>we learned elsewhere</b> in a mishna (<i>Arakhin</i> 31b) that if a house was sold and not redeemed by its owners within twelve months it remains permanently in the possession of the purchaser. The Gemara describes this: <b>At first</b> the purchaser <b>would hide</b> for all of the final <b>day of the twelfth month so that</b> the house would be <b>confirmed</b> as <b>his</b> (see Leviticus 25:29–30). Because the purchaser was in hiding, the seller would be unable to redeem the house from him. <b>Hillel the Elder instituted</b> an ordinance <b>whereby</b> the seller <b>may deposit [<i>ḥolesh</i>] his</b> redemption <b>money in</b> the Temple treasury <b>chamber, and</b> then <b>he may break the door</b> of his house <b>and enter</b> and take possession. <b>And when that</b> purchaser <b>wishes, he should come and take his money</b> from the Temple treasury.
<b>And Rava says: From the ordinance of Hillel we learn</b> that if one says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars, and she gave him</b> the money <b>with his consent,</b> then she is <b>divorced.</b> If she gave it to him <b>against his will</b> then <b>she is not divorced.</b>
How does Rava prove this? <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> it <b>was necessary for Hillel to institute</b> a unique ordinance in the case of houses in walled cities whereby <b>giving against the will</b> of the receiver <b>is</b> considered <b>giving.</b>

Daf 75a

This proves <b>by inference that generally, giving against</b> the recipient’s <b>will is not</b> considered valid <b>giving,</b> as if it were, then Hillel would not have needed to institute this ordinance.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi</b> who raises this objection: <b>And perhaps when it was necessary</b> for Hillel <b>to institute</b> an ordinance allowing the seller to repay the money against the will of the purchaser it was specifically in a case <b>where</b> he gives the money <b>not in</b> the <b>presence</b> of the purchaser. <b>But</b> when he repays him <b>in his presence, whether</b> the recipient was <b>willing</b> or <b>whether</b> it was <b>against his will, it is</b> considered valid <b>giving.</b> Accordingly, one cannot apply Hillel’s ordinance to the case of conditional bills of divorce.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of this discussion. <b>Rava says: From the ordinance of Hillel</b> it can be inferred that if one says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars, and she gave</b> it <b>to him, whether</b> it was <b>with his consent or whether</b> it was <b>against his will, it is</b> valid <b>giving. And</b> the case <b>where it was necessary for Hillel to institute</b> his ordinance was <b>when</b> the giving of the money <b>was not in his presence. But</b> if the repayment was <b>in his presence, whether</b> it was <b>with his consent</b> or <b>whether</b> it was <b>against his will, it is</b> considered valid <b>giving.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi</b> who raises this objection: <b>And perhaps even</b> in a case where she gives him the money <b>in his presence,</b> if she gives it <b>with his consent, yes,</b> it is valid. If she gives it <b>against his will, no,</b> it is not considered to be valid giving. <b>And Hillel</b> specifically <b>instituted what was necessary,</b> because in the case of a house in a walled city the purchaser would hide, and therefore that ordinance was necessary there.
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In <b>every place where Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel taught</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>in our</b> body of <b>Mishna, the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> his opinion, even though it is cited as an individual opinion, <b>except</b> for three cases. With regard to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a guarantor</b> (<i>Bava Batra</i> 173b), if the creditor stipulated that he can collect his debt from either the debtor or the guarantor, according to the Rabbis he can collect from the guarantor’s property even if the debtor has available property. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds that the creditor can collect the debt only from the debtor. <b>And</b> likewise the <i>halakha</i> is not like Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to the case mentioned here concerning the incident that occurred in <b>Tzaidan.</b>
<b>And</b> similarly, the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel concerning the dispute with regard to <b>evidence</b> in the <b>final</b> disagreement (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 31a), where the Rabbis hold that if one claims that he has no evidence or witnesses, but subsequently brings evidence to court, the judges do not accept it. According to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel they can accept it.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the husband said to his wife: <b>Behold this is your bill of divorce,</b> but <b>the paper</b> on which it is written <b>is</b> still <b>mine,</b> then <b>she is not divorced,</b> as he must give her the actual bill of divorce in order for the divorce to take effect. Since the paper still belongs to him, it is as if he had given her only the writing. But if he said to her: Behold this is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you return the paper to me,</b> then <b>she is divorced.</b> The bill of divorce belongs entirely to her, and the returning of the paper is only a stipulation that must be fulfilled later.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>and what is different</b> in <b>the latter clause?</b> In neither case does she have ownership of the bill of divorce. <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who says</b> with regard to his coat that <b>she</b> can <b>give him its value</b> and does not need to give the item itself in order to fulfill the condition. <b>Here also,</b> since <b>it is possible for her to appease him with money</b> and she may give him the value of the paper, therefore it is considered as though she received the paper.
<b>Abaye objects to this</b> answer: <b>Say that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that it is acceptable to give the value instead of the item itself <b>when</b> the item <b>is not extant,</b> because it is lost. But in a case <b>where it is extant,</b> such as the paper in this case, <b>did</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel actually <b>say</b> that giving the value of the item is sufficient?
<b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who says: We require</b> any stipulated condition to be structured as <b>a compound condition</b> describing both outcomes, meaning that the condition must mention what will happen both if the condition is fulfilled and if it is not fulfilled. <b>And here he did not compound his condition.</b> The husband said only: This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you return the paper to me. He did not specify that it will not be a valid bill of divorce if she does not return it.
<b>Rava objects to this</b> explanation: According to Abaye <b>the reason</b> the bill of divorce is valid is <b>that</b> the husband <b>did not compound his condition, but if</b> the husband did <b>compound his condition</b> then it <b>would not be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. Now, from where do we learn</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>all conditions?</b> They are derived <b>from the condition of the children of Gad and the children of Reuben.</b> Moses stipulated with them that if they fight the battles with the Jewish people in Eretz Yisrael, they will inherit the land of Gilead in the Transjordan, as they requested; but if they do not fight the battles with the Jewish people in Eretz Yisrael, they will not inherit that land (see Numbers, chapter 32).
<b>Just as there,</b> in the conditions that Moses made, the language of the <b>condition precedes the</b> consequent <b>action,</b> for he first stated the condition and afterward he described the result if they fulfill the condition: “And you shall give them the land of Gilead as an inheritance” (Numbers 32:29), <b>so too, any condition</b> is valid only when it is stated <b>before the</b> resultant <b>action.</b> And this serves <b>to exclude</b> the case mentioned <b>here, where the</b> resultant <b>action</b> of the giving of the bill of divorce <b>precedes the condition.</b> Consequently, according to Rabbi Meir this bill of divorce would not be valid, even if the husband had compounded the condition.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The condition does not apply and the woman is divorced <b>because</b> the <b>action</b> of giving the bill of divorce <b>precedes</b> the <b>condition.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava objects to this</b> explanation: <b>The reason</b> that the bill of divorce is valid is <b>that the action precedes the condition,</b> and the condition does not take effect. <b>But</b> if <b>the condition</b> were to <b>precede the action</b> then it would <b>not be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. Now, from where do we learn all</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>conditions?</b> They are derived <b>from the condition of the children of Gad and the children of Reuben. Just as there</b> it is <b>a condition with regard to one matter,</b> i.e., that they should fight along with the rest of the Jewish people, <b>and</b> a resultant <b>action with regard to another matter,</b> i.e., that they would receive the land of Gilead, <b>so too, every</b> other condition must follow this pattern. This serves <b>to exclude</b> the case mentioned <b>here,</b>

Daf 75b

<b>where the condition and the action are about the same matter,</b> the giving of the bill of divorce. Accordingly, the condition would not be valid even if one were to disregard the concern of the action preceding the condition. <b>Rather, Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> that this condition is void <b>because the condition and the action are about the same matter,</b> and therefore the bill of divorce is valid even without fulfillment of the condition.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: Anyone who states</b> a condition employing the language: <b>On the condition,</b> is <b>like</b> one who <b>states:</b> The agreement will take effect retroactively <b>from now,</b> even though the condition is fulfilled only later on. Consequently, the bill of divorce is effective immediately, even if the woman will later be required to return the document itself to him.
§ With regard to conditions in a bill of divorce, <b>Shmuel instituted</b> that <b>in a bill of divorce of a person on his deathbed</b> the following expression should be written: <b>If I do not die this will not be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce, and if I die it will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara asks about the wording used here: <b>But let us say</b> this statement in a more intuitive order: <b>If I die it will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce, and if I do not die this will not be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>A person does not hasten a calamity upon himself.</b> Consequently, he does not wish to mention his death first.
The Gemara asks: Why did Shmuel use this phrasing? <b>But let us</b> say the condition using the following formulation: <b>It will not be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce if I do not die,</b> and it will be a valid bill of divorce if I do die. The Gemara asks: When stipulating a condition, <b>we require the condition</b> to come <b>before the action,</b> but in this formulation the resultant action, that the bill of divorce is valid, precedes the condition, if I do not die.
<b>Rava objects to this</b> explanation: <b>Now, from where do we learn</b> the principles of <b>all conditions?</b> They are derived <b>from the condition of the children of Gad and the children of Reuben. Just as there, the affirmative precedes the negative,</b> meaning that the positive portion that speaks about what will occur if the condition is fulfilled appears before the negative portions that describe what will exist if the condition is not fulfilled, <b>so too, all</b> conditions must be formulated in this manner. This serves <b>to exclude</b> the case <b>here,</b> instituted by Shmuel, <b>where the negative precedes the affirmative.</b>
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that the condition in the bill of divorce of a dying man should be worded in the following manner: <b>If I do not die this will not be a bill of divorce. If I die this will be a bill of divorce,</b> and <b>if I do not die this will not be a bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara explains the necessity for such a formulation: The husband first says: <b>If I do not die this will not be a bill of divorce,</b> because <b>a person does not hasten a calamity upon himself.</b> Therefore, he first mentions the possibility that he will not die. Then he states the compound condition in the following order: <b>If I die this will be a bill of divorce,</b> and <b>if I do not die this will not be a bill of divorce.</b> This is because <b>we require</b> that <b>the affirmative precedes the negative.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a husband says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will serve</b> my <b>father,</b> or: <b>On the condition that you will nurse,</b> i.e., breastfeed, <b>my son,</b> without specifying a time period, <b>how long</b> is <b>she</b> required <b>to nurse him</b> in order to fulfill the condition? She is required to nurse the baby for <b>two years</b> from his birth, which is the length of time generally designated for nursing. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The time for nursing is only <b>eighteen months.</b> If <b>the</b> baby <b>son died or the</b> husband’s <b>father died, this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> even though the condition was not fulfilled.
But if the husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will serve</b> my <b>father</b> for <b>two years,</b> or: <b>On the condition that you will nurse my son</b> for <b>two years,</b> and <b>the son died</b> before she nursed him for two years, <b>or the father said: I do not want you to serve me,</b> then even if the father <b>did not</b> say this <b>in anger</b> and she did everything she was expected to do, it <b>is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> because the condition was not fulfilled.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> In a case <b>like this</b> it is a valid <b>bill of divorce. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel stated a principle:</b> If there is <b>any hindrance</b> to the fulfillment of the condition <b>that does not</b> result <b>from her,</b> then <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>But do we require</b> that she serve the father or nurse the son for <b>all of this</b> time that was stipulated? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nidda</i> 2:2): If <b>she served</b> the father for <b>one day</b> or <b>she nursed</b> the son for <b>one day it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that this is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and this</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> who disagreed in the previous mishna (74a) with regard to a coat that was lost. According to the opinion of the Rabbis there, if there is no possibility that the wife can fulfill the condition by returning the coat, as it was lost, the bill of divorce is not valid. According to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel there, she can give the husband the coat’s value and the bill of divorce is valid.
The Gemara explains: <b>The mishna</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> who claims that the wife can give the husband the equivalent of the stipulated item to render the bill of divorce valid, as the primary factor is his receiving the benefit he intended when stating his condition. Therefore, she must nurse the child for the standard length of time, as that is the benefit he intended when stating his condition, or else the bill of divorce is not valid. <b>And the <i>baraita</i></b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the wife must fulfill the literal terms of the condition. If she nurses the baby for even one day, or serves the father for a single day, the literal terms of the condition have been fulfilled.
The Gemara challenges: Is this explanation possible? <b>But from</b> the fact that <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>is</b> attributed to <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> it can be derived <b>by inference that the first clause</b> is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. Rather,</b> the <b><i>baraita</i> is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who is lenient with regard to a condition,</b> and interprets it so that it can be fulfilled. <b>The mishna</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who interpret the condition in an expanded manner.
<b>Rava</b> offered an alternative explanation and <b>said</b> that the apparent contradiction <b>is not difficult: Here,</b> in the mishna, where the husband spoke <b>without specification</b> and did not set a time, the Sages assigned what they understand to be the standard time for the stipulated action. <b>There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to where the husband said <b>explicitly</b> that she should perform the action for only one day.
<b>Rav Ashi</b> offered a different alternative explanation and <b>said: Any unspecified</b> statement is <b>also considered</b> to be <b>as though</b> he <b>explicitly</b> said <b>one day.</b> Since the husband did not mention a specific amount of time in which to perform the action, one day should be sufficient.
The Gemara challenges Rav Ashi’s explanation: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>How long</b> is <b>she</b> required <b>to nurse him</b> in order to fulfill the condition? She is required to nurse the baby for <b>two years</b> from his birth. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The time for nursing is only <b>eighteen months. Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> it <b>works out well</b> that if the husband does not specify the length of time, the wife must nurse the baby for the generally accepted time. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi, why do I</b> need her to nurse the baby for <b>two years</b> or <b>why do I</b> need her to nurse him for <b>eighteen months? One day</b> should <b>suffice</b> to fulfill the husband’s condition.
The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying</b> according to the opinion of Rav Ashi: How long is the wife required to nurse the baby? <b>One day from</b> within the <b>two years</b> of the baby’s birth, <b>to exclude</b> the case where the one day that she nursed him occurred <b>after</b> he was <b>two years</b> old, in which case the husband’s condition would <b>not</b> be fulfilled, for that is the accepted length of time for a mother to nurse a baby. Or according to Rabbi Yehuda <b>one day from</b> within the <b>eighteen months</b> of the baby’s birth, <b>to exclude</b> the case where the one day that she nursed him occurred after he was she nursed him occurred <b>after</b> he was <b>eighteen months</b> old, in which case the bill of divorce would not be valid.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Ashi from the latter clause of the mishna: If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will serve</b> my <b>father</b> for <b>two years,</b> or: This is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you will nurse my son</b> for <b>two years,</b> and <b>the son died or the father said: I do not want you to serve me,</b> then even though the father <b>did not</b> say this <b>in anger,</b> it <b>is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>

Daf 76a

<b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, the first clause</b> in the mishna is speaking <b>about</b> when the husband <b>did not explicitly mention</b> a period of time, and <b>the latter clause</b> is referring to when he did <b>explicitly mention</b> a period of two years.
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi,</b> who holds that when the husband does not mention a period of time the wife can fulfill her obligation by performing the action for even a single day, it is necessary to explain that the first clause in the mishna is referring to when she did fulfill the condition for even one day. And therefore, <b>what is different</b> in <b>the first clause and what is different</b> in <b>the latter clause?</b> The Gemara states: According to Rav Ashi’s opinion this <b>is difficult.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:6): If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will serve</b> my <b>father</b> for <b>two years, or</b> he said: This is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you will nurse my son</b> for <b>two years, even if the condition was not fulfilled it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce because he did not say to her: If you will serve</b> my father then this will be a valid bill of divorce, and <b>if you will not serve</b> him it will not be a valid bill of divorce, or: <b>If you will nurse</b> my son then this will be a valid bill of divorce, <b>and if you will not nurse</b> him it will not be a valid bill of divorce. And if he did not state his condition as a compound condition, stipulating both positive and negative outcomes, the condition is void and the bill of divorce is valid. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The condition is valid even if it the husband does not stipulate both positive and negative outcomes. Consequently, if <b>the condition was fulfilled this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce, and if</b> it was <b>not</b> fulfilled <b>this is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: You do not have a condition in the Bible that is not compounded.</b>
To which side of the dispute is Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s statement referring? <b>There are</b> those <b>who say: He is speaking to Rabbi Meir. And there are</b> those <b>who say: He is speaking to the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this means <b>he is speaking to Rabbi Meir and this is what he is saying to him: You do not have a condition in the Bible that is not compounded,</b> and therefore the compound conditions mentioned in the Torah <b>have</b> the status of <b>two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., to teach the same matter. <b>And any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> about other cases. Consequently, one cannot derive from them that every condition must be compounded.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say: He is saying</b> this <b>to the Rabbis, and this is what he is saying to them: There is no condition in the Bible that is not compounded, and we learn from</b> the conditions written in the Bible that a condition is not valid unless it is compounded.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:6): If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will serve</b> my <b>father</b> for <b>two years,</b> or he said to her: This is your bill of divorce <b>on the condition that you will nurse my son</b> for <b>two years,</b> and <b>the father died or the son died,</b> then <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> as its condition was not fulfilled. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: Even though the condition was not fulfilled it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> as <b>she could have said to him: Give me your father and I will serve him,</b> or: <b>Give me your son and I will nurse him.</b>
It is <b>difficult</b> to reconcile one statement <b>of Rabbi Meir with</b> the other statement made by <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> for the second <i>baraita</i> indicates that the husband’s condition does not need to be compounded. And it is <b>difficult</b> to reconcile one statement <b>of the Rabbis with</b> the other statement of <b>the Rabbis,</b> for in the second <i>baraita</i> they say that if the condition was fulfilled it is a valid bill of divorce, and if it was not fulfilled it is not a valid bill of divorce.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>not difficult</b> to reconcile one statement <b>of Rabbi Meir with</b> the other statement <b>of Rabbi Meir,</b> as <b>there,</b> in the case where the bill of divorce is valid, it is referring to <b>when he did not compound his condition. Here,</b> where the bill of divorce is valid, it is referring to <b>when he did compound his condition,</b> but the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> did not mention that fact explicitly.
<b>And</b> it is <b>not difficult</b> to reconcile one statement of <b>the Rabbis with</b> the other statement <b>of the Rabbis,</b> because <b>whose</b> is the opinion mentioned <b>here</b> anonymously as <b>the Rabbis? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who says:</b> If there is <b>any hindrance</b> to fulfilling the condition <b>that is not from her, it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
§ The Gemara continues discussing a conditional bill of divorce. <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:6): If a husband <b>said to</b> his wife <b>in the presence of two</b> people: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will serve</b> my <b>father</b> for <b>two years, and</b> afterward <b>he returned and said to her in the presence of two</b> other people: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars, the latter statement does not nullify the first</b> statement. Rather, he is giving her the choice, and if she fulfills either one of the conditions, the bill of divorce is valid. If <b>she wishes, she serves</b> his father and is divorced, or if <b>she wishes, she gives him two hundred dinars</b> and is divorced.
<b>But</b> if <b>he said to her in the presence of two</b> people: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me two hundred dinars, and</b> afterward <b>he returned and said to her in the presence of two</b> other people: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will give me three hundred dinars,</b> then <b>the latter statement nullifies the first</b> statement, and she is not divorced unless she gives him three hundred dinars. <b>And one of the first</b> pair of witnesses <b>and</b> one <b>of the last</b> pair of witnesses <b>cannot combine</b> their testimonies concerning the condition.
The Gemara asks: <b>To which</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i> is the statement that the witnesses cannot combine their testimonies referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to <b>the latter clause,</b> where the husband demanded an additional one hundred dinars, then it already said that the first condition <b>is nullified.</b> It is unnecessary to mention that the two pairs of witnesses cannot combine their testimonies, since the condition witnessed by the first witnesses no longer exists. <b>Rather,</b> it is referring <b>to the first clause.</b>
But <b>isn’t</b> it <b>obvious</b> that these two pairs of witnesses cannot combine their testimonies, since each of them are testifying about a different condition? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>all</b> of those who testify <b>to the existence of conditions can combine</b> their testimonies to testify that a bill of divorce was given with a condition, it <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a resident of the region of Judea intending to embark on a journey to the Galilee said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>thirty days, and</b> when <b>he was going from Judea to the Galilee</b> he <b>reached Antipatris and he returned</b> immediately, <b>his condition is void</b> and his wife is not divorced, even if he subsequently returns to the Galilee for longer than thirty days. The reason for this is because he reached the Galilee and returned to Judea within the time he had allotted.
Similarly, if a resident of the region of the Galilee intending to embark on a journey to Judea said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>thirty days, and he was going from the Galilee to Judea, and he reached Kefar Otnai and returned</b> immediately, <b>his condition is void</b> and his wife is not divorced, even if he subsequently returns to Judea for longer than thirty days.
Similarly, if a resident of Eretz Yisrael intending to embark on a journey to a country overseas said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>thirty days, and he was going to a country overseas, and he reached Akko and returned</b> immediately, <b>his condition is void</b> and his wife is not divorced, even if he subsequently travels to a country overseas for longer than thirty days.
If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce</b> if at <b>any time I will depart from your presence</b> for <b>thirty</b> consecutive <b>days,</b> then even if <b>he was</b> continually <b>going and coming, going and coming, since he was not secluded with her during these thirty days, this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that Antipatris was in the Galilee?</b> It appears from the mishna that Antipatris was on the border of the Galilee, since the condition of the resident of Judea became void by his reaching Antipatris and returning. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on what is taught in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:9): <b>Antipatris</b> is <b>in Judea, and Kefar Otnai</b> is <b>in the Galilee.</b> And with regard to the area <b>between them, a stringent</b> ruling <b>is placed on it,</b> and it is treated as though it is located in both Judea and the Galilee. If the husband who made such a condition reached this area and returned home, it is uncertain whether the condition attached to the bill of divorce was fulfilled. Therefore, there is uncertainty whether <b>she is divorced</b>

Daf 76b

<b>or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced.</b>
<b>Abaye said:</b> It may be that Antipatris is in Judea and Kefar Otnai is in the Galilee. The mishna can be explained as follows: The husband was <b>saying</b> a statement including <b>two conditions to her: If I arrive in the Galilee</b> then this <b>will be a bill of divorce immediately, or if I will tarry on the way for thirty days and I do not come</b> back home, this <b>will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> If <b>he reached Antipatris and returned</b> within thirty days, <b>as he did not arrive in the Galilee and he also did not tarry for thirty days,</b> then <b>his condition is void</b> and his wife is not divorced.
The continuation of the mishna taught: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>thirty days.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that Akko is in a country overseas,</b> and is not considered part of Eretz Yisrael? <b>But didn’t Rav Safra say: When the Sages would take leave from one another</b> before departing Eretz Yisrael, <b>they would take</b> their <b>leave in Akko, because it is prohibited to leave from Eretz Yisrael to</b> go <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael? This indicates that Akko is within Eretz Yisrael.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The husband was <b>saying</b> a statement including <b>two conditions to her: If I arrive in a country overseas,</b> then this <b>will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce immediately,</b> or <b>if I tarry thirty days on the way and I do not come</b> back home, this <b>will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> If <b>he reached Akko and returned, as he did not reach a country overseas and he also did not tarry for thirty days, his condition is void</b> and his wife is not divorced.
§ The continuation of the mishna states: If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce</b> if at <b>any time I will depart</b> from your presence for thirty consecutive days, then even if he was continually going and coming, going and coming, since he was not secluded with her during these thirty days this is a valid bill of divorce. The Gemara challenges: <b>But did he not pass</b> from her presence during this time, as he was going and coming the entire time? <b>Rav Huna said: What</b> is the meaning of the term <b>your presence</b> in this context? It means <b>sexual intercourse.</b> His actual condition was that if he will not engage in sexual intercourse with her for thirty days then the bill of divorce will be valid. <b>And why does he call</b> sexual intercourse <b>your presence? He employed a euphemistic expression</b> when he made his condition.
