<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> disagreed and <b>said: Actually,</b> the husband means <b>literally: Your presence,</b> i.e., that he would not be in his wife’s presence for thirty consecutive days. <b>Is</b> the mishna <b>teaching</b> that <b>she is divorced</b> immediately? No, it <b>is teaching</b> only that <b>this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This means that although the condition was not fulfilled during these thirty days, since he was not secluded with her this <b>is not considered</b> to be <b>an outdated bill of divorce,</b> which the Sages said may not be used for divorce. <b>And when,</b> at some point in the future, <b>the thirty days</b> during which he does pass from her presence <b>are fulfilled, this will be</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara comments that it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:10) <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If one says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce</b> if at <b>any time I will depart from your presence</b> for <b>thirty</b> consecutive <b>days, and he was going and coming, going and coming</b> for the entire thirty days, <b>since he was not secluded with her</b> during that time, <b>this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. And one is not concerned</b> that it is now considered <b>an outdated bill of divorce, because he was not secluded with her.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But let</b> there be a <b>concern</b> that <b>perhaps he appeased</b> his wife during this time that he was going and coming, and he was secluded with her. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said: So said my father, my teacher,</b> Rav Huna, <b>in the name of Rav:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a situation <b>where</b> the husband <b>says: She is deemed credible by me to say that I did not come.</b> Since the husband states explicitly that he believes her about this, if she said that he was not secluded with her then the bill of divorce remains valid.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who teach this</b> statement of Rav Huna in the name of Rav <b>with regard to the mishna</b> mentioned later on, which says that if the husband said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>from now if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within twelve months, this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But let</b> there be a <b>concern</b> that <b>perhaps he appeased</b> his wife during this time and was secluded with her. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said: So said my father, my teacher,</b> Rav Huna, <b>in the name of Rav:</b> The mishna is referring to a situation <b>where</b> the husband <b>says: She is deemed credible by me to say that I did not come,</b> and he did not appease her.
The Gemara comments: Concerning <b>the one who taught that</b> statement of Rav Huna in the name of Rav <b>with regard to the mishna, all the more so</b> would he teach this statement <b>with regard to the <i>baraita</i>.</b> Since he was constantly going and coming, the bill of divorce would be valid only if the husband stated that he trusts his wife to say that she was not secluded with him.
Concerning <b>the one who taught this</b> statement <b>with regard to the <i>baraita</i>,</b> it is possible that he taught this only with regard to the <i>baraita</i>, <b>but with regard to the mishna,</b> this is not the case, <b>as he did not come</b> back home within twelve months, but rather died. Therefore, even if he did not specify that he trusts his wife to say whether or not they were secluded, there is no concern that perhaps he was secluded with her without anyone knowing about it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a husband says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within twelve months, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This is because the bill of divorce cannot take effect after the husband’s death. As a result, she is bound by a levirate bond if her husband has no children.
By contrast, if he said to her: <b>This is your bill of divorce from now if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within twelve months, this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This is because the bill of divorce takes effect retroactively. Since he did not return within the year the condition was fulfilled.
If a husband said to others: <b>If I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, write and give a bill of divorce to my wife,</b> and <b>they wrote a bill of divorce during</b> the <b>twelve months and gave</b> it to her <b>after twelve months</b> had elapsed, <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> because he instructed them to write the bill of divorce only after twelve months had elapsed.
Similarly, if he said to others: <b>Write and give a bill of divorce to my wife if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months,</b> and <b>they wrote</b> it <b>during</b> the <b>twelve months but gave</b> it to her <b>after</b> the <b>twelve months, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> because he instructed them to write the bill of divorce only after twelve months had elapsed, when it was clear that he did not come back. <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> In a case <b>like this,</b> it is a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> as he did not tell them when to write the bill of divorce. Rather, he stipulated only the time of giving.
If <b>they wrote</b> the bill of divorce <b>after twelve months</b> had elapsed, <b>and gave</b> it <b>after twelve months</b> had elapsed, <b>but</b> in the interim the husband <b>died, if</b> the giving of <b>the bill of divorce</b> occurred <b>before</b> the husband’s <b>death this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. But if</b> the husband’s <b>death</b> occurred <b>before</b> the giving of <b>the bill of divorce</b> it <b>is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. And if it is not known</b> which occurred first, <b>this is</b> a case <b>where</b> the Sages <b>said</b> there is uncertainty whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that if a husband said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce if I do not come back from now until the conclusion of twelve months, and the husband died within that time, it is not a valid bill of divorce. With regard to this it is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Our Rabbis</b> disagreed and <b>permitted her to marry</b> without requiring <i>ḥalitza</i> because they hold that it is a valid bill of divorce.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>Who are our Rabbis</b> mentioned in this <i>baraita</i>? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> They are <b>the court that permitted</b> consuming <b>oil</b> manufactured by gentiles. Why do they hold that this is a valid bill of divorce? <b>They hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who says: The date</b> written <b>in a document proves</b> when <b>it</b> takes effect. Whenever a document is dated it is assumed that the intent is for it to take effect from that date even if it does not state explicitly: From now.
<b>Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yehuda Nesia, son of Rabban Gamliel</b> the <b>son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>taught</b> this matter, <b>and all of his colleagues [<i>siato</i>] did not concede to his</b> opinion. <b>And some say</b> that <b>all of his life [<i>she’ato</i>]</b> they did not concede to his opinion.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said to a certain elderly man</b> who was a member of Rabbi Yehuda Nesia’s court: <b>When you permitted</b> this woman to remarry, did <b>you permit her</b> to remarry <b>immediately</b> after her husband died <b>or did you permit her</b> only <b>after twelve months?</b> Did <b>you permit her</b> to remarry <b>immediately</b> after the husband died, <b>because he will</b> certainly <b>not come</b> back? <b>Or perhaps you permitted her</b> to remarry only <b>after twelve months, because</b> only then was the husband’s <b>condition fulfilled?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let his dilemma be raised</b> also with regard to <b>the mishna,</b> in the case where the husband said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce <b>from now if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months, and he died within</b> the <b>twelve months, this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. Is</b> the bill of divorce valid <b>immediately</b> once the husband dies, <b>because he will</b> certainly <b>not come</b> back? <b>Or perhaps</b> the bill of divorce is valid only <b>after twelve months</b> have elapsed, <b>because</b> only then was <b>his condition fulfilled?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, indeed so;</b> this question can be asked with regard to the case in the mishna. <b>And</b> Rabbi Elazar asked that particular elder <b>because</b> he <b>was</b> present <b>at that incident,</b> and he could answer based on what actually occurred.
§ <b>Abaye said: Everyone concedes</b> that in a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>said</b> to his wife that the bill of divorce will take effect <b>once the sun emerges from its sheath</b> [<b><i>minnartikah</i>],</b>

Daf 77a

<b>he is saying to her</b> that it will be valid <b>once</b> the sun <b>comes out</b> in the morning. <b>And</b> if the husband <b>dies during the night,</b> before sunrise, then this <b>will be</b> a <b>bill of divorce after</b> his <b>death</b> and is therefore invalid.
But if he said to her: <b>On the condition that the sun will emerge from its sheath,</b> then <b>he is saying to</b> his wife that the bill of divorce will take effect retroactively <b>from now</b> once the sun emerges. <b>As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: Anyone who states</b> a condition employing the language: <b>On the condition,</b> is <b>like</b> one who <b>states:</b> The agreement will take effect retroactively <b>from now.</b>
The <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagreed only in</b> the case of one who said to his wife: This will be your bill of divorce <b>if</b> the sun <b>emerges</b> from its sheath, and the husband died during the night. One <b>Sage,</b> referred to as: Our Rabbis, <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who says</b> that <b>the date</b> written <b>in a document proves</b> when <b>it</b> takes effect, <b>and it is as</b> if the husband said: <b>From today if I die,</b> or <b>as</b> if he said: <b>From now if I die.</b> And one <b>Sage,</b> the unattributed <i>tanna</i> of the mishna, <b>does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and it is as</b> if the husband said <b>only: If I die,</b> in which case the bill of divorce is not valid because it cannot take effect after the husband’s death.
§ The mishna states that if a husband says to others: <b>Write and give a bill of divorce to my wife if I do not come</b> back <b>from now until</b> the conclusion of <b>twelve months,</b> and <b>they wrote</b> it within the twelve months but gave it to her after twelve months, it is not a valid bill of divorce. Rabbi Yosei disagrees and says: It is a valid bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Yeimar said to Rav Ashi: Shall we say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that in general, if <b>he wrote a bill of divorce on condition</b> then it is <b>valid,</b> even if the condition was not fulfilled? Rav Ashi replied: <b>No, actually I</b> could <b>say to you</b> that according to Rabbi Yosei it is <b>invalid</b> if the condition is not fulfilled, <b>and here it is different. Since he could have said: If I do not come</b> back within twelve months, <b>write and give</b> the bill of divorce to my wife, which would emphasize that they may write the document only if he does not come; <b>but</b> instead <b>he said: Write and give</b> a bill of divorce <b>if I do not come</b> back, <b>this is what</b> the husband <b>is saying: Write</b> the bill of divorce <b>from now, and give</b> it to my wife <b>if I do not come</b> back within twelve months. <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> hold? They hold that <b>it is no different</b> whether the husband formulates his instructions like <b>this and it is no different</b> if the husband formulates his instructions like <b>that.</b> The court cannot differentiate based on the minor differences in the formulation.
§ Since the mishna discussed conditions dependent on time, the Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> on a similar topic. <b>The Sages taught:</b> If the husband said to his wife: This is your bill of divorce if I do not come back <b>after a seven-</b>year Sabbatical cycle, the word after means that the bill of divorce is not valid until a full <b>year</b> after the conclusion of the seven-year cycle. If he said: This is your bill of divorce if I do not come back <b>after</b> one <b>year,</b> it is not valid until one <b>month</b> after the end of that year. If he said: This is your bill of divorce if I do not come back <b>after</b> one <b>month,</b> it is not valid until one <b>week</b> after the end of the month.
The Gemara clarifies other similar cases not mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>. If the husband said: This is your bill of divorce if I do not come back <b>after a week,</b> then <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Zeira sat before Rabbi Asi, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Asi</b> who sat <b>before Rabbi Yoḥanan, and he said</b> the following: <b>Sunday and Monday and Tuesday</b> are called <b>after Shabbat. Wednesday and Thursday and Friday</b> are all called <b>prior to Shabbat.</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> If a man says: This is your bill of divorce if I do not come back <b>after the pilgrimage Festival,</b> then the document is valid only <b>thirty days</b> after the festival. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya went out</b> and <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> in public <b>in the name of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and they praised it.</b> He then taught it <b>in the name of the majority,</b> as an unattributed opinion, <b>and they did not praise it. Apparently, the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> this ruling. Consequently, the Sages did not praise Rabbi Ḥiyya when he taught it as if it were a majority ruling, as that would cause it to be accepted as <i>halakha</i>.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <b>one who throws a bill of divorce to his wife, and she is in her house or in her courtyard</b> at the time, then <b>she is divorced</b> as though he placed the bill of divorce in her hand. If <b>he threw it to her in his house or in his courtyard, even if</b> the bill of divorce <b>is with her in the bed, she is not divorced.</b> If he threw the bill of divorce <b>into her lap, or into her basket</b> [<b><i>kaltah</i></b>], <b>she is divorced,</b> even if she was in her husband’s house at the time.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? What is the basis for the <i>halakha</i> that when the husband throws the bill of divorce into his wife’s house or courtyard, the divorce takes effect? The Gemara answers: It is <b>as the Sages taught:</b> The verse states with regard to a bill of divorce: <b>“And gives it in her hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), from which <b>I have</b> derived that she is divorced <b>only</b> if he actually places it in <b>her hand.</b> But <b>from where</b> do I derive that she is divorced even if he places it on <b>her roof,</b> in <b>her courtyard, or</b> in <b>her enclosure? The verse states: “And gives it,”</b> indicating that she is divorced <b>in any case,</b> regardless of the manner in which he gives her the bill of divorce.
<b>And that is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to a thief.</b> It is written: “If the theft be found <b>in his hand”</b> (Exodus 22:3), from which <b>I have</b> derived that one is liable for theft <b>only</b> when the stolen item was found in <b>his hand.</b> But <b>from where</b> do I derive that one is liable for theft even if it was found on <b>his roof,</b> in <b>his courtyard, or</b> in <b>his enclosure,</b> i.e., if the item reached his domain and he secured it with the intent to steal it? <b>The verse states: “If</b> the theft <b>be found,”</b> indicating that he is liable <b>in any case,</b> whether it was found in his hand or in his domain.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in both cases. <b>As if</b> the Torah <b>had taught us</b> only with regard to <b>a bill of divorce,</b> one could have said: <b>Because</b> a husband <b>divorces</b> his wife <b>against her will,</b> the divorce is effective regardless of how the husband places the document in her possession. <b>But a thief, who is not</b> accountable for theft that he performs <b>against his will, say no,</b> he is liable only when he actually steals the item with his hand, and not when it enters his domain by other means.
<b>And if</b> the Torah <b>had taught us</b> only with regard to <b>a thief,</b> one could have said: <b>Because the Merciful One penalized</b> the thief, obligating him to pay double the value of the item, it is clear that the Torah is strict with a thief. Similarly, the Torah also deemed him responsible for an item that was not actually in his hand. <b>But</b> with regard to a <b>bill of divorce, say no,</b> the divorce is not effective unless the husband places the document in her hand. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in both cases.
§ It was taught in the mishna that if the husband threw the bill of divorce into his wife’s <b>courtyard,</b> she is divorced. The Gemara asks: How can she own a courtyard of her own? There is a principle: <b>That which a woman acquired</b> is <b>acquired</b> by <b>her husband,</b> which indicates that the husband has the rights to all profits generated by his wife’s property. Therefore, for all intents and purposes, the courtyard belongs to him for the duration of their marriage.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>writes to</b> his wife: <b>I have no legal</b> dealings <b>or involvement in your property,</b> thereby relinquishing any ownership rights to her property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And when he writes this to her, what of it? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who says to another</b> with whom he owns a field in a partnership: <b>I have no rights and claims to this field, or: I have no involvement with it, or: My hand is removed from it;</b> it is as though <b>he said nothing,</b> since these expressions are not considered to be a withdrawal of his rights to the field.
The Gemara answers: <b>They say in the school of Rabbi Yannai:</b> The case is one <b>where he writes to her and she is still</b> only <b>betrothed;</b> he has yet to obtain ownership of her property, being that his rights to his wife’s property are only actuated at the time of the marriage. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Kahana, as Rav Kahana says:</b> With regard to <b>an inheritance that comes to a person from another place,</b> i.e., it is not an inheritance from his father, <b>a person can stipulate about it</b> from the outset <b>that he should not inherit it,</b> and this condition is effective in annulling his rights to the inheritance. This teaches that as long as the property has not yet entered his possession, he can withdraw his rights to it.
<b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rava, as Rava says: One who says:</b>

Daf 77b

<b>I do not want</b> to avail myself of <b>the ordinance of the Sages</b> that was instituted on my behalf, <b>such as</b> in <b>this</b> scenario, <b>we listen to him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is referred to by the words: <b>Such as</b> in <b>this</b> scenario? What case did Rava refer to that he indicated that in similar situations the <i>halakha</i> is the same? The Gemara explains that Rava was referring to <b>that which Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says. As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: A woman can say to her husband: I do not</b> wish to <b>be sustained</b> by you, <b>and I will not do</b> work for you. Although the Sages instituted on her behalf that she would be sustained in exchange for her work, she has the choice of waiving that right if she prefers to retain her earnings. Rava adds that in any similar case where the Sages instituted an ordinance for one’s benefit, he can say that he does not wish to accept this rabbinic ordinance if it does not assist him.
<b>Rava said</b> that one can resolve the question about the wife’s ability to acquire a bill of divorce in a courtyard in a more direct way: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>her hand is not acquired by her husband?</b> Yet despite the fact that he owns her hand, she is divorced once she receives a bill of divorce in her hand. <b>Rather,</b> one must say that <b>her bill of divorce and her hand,</b> i.e., her complete ownership over her hand, <b>enter</b> her possession <b>simultaneously.</b> Since the bill of divorce releases her from her obligations to her husband, at that moment she acquires full rights to her hand. <b>Here too,</b> in the case of her courtyard, one can say that <b>her bill of divorce and her courtyard enter</b> her possession <b>simultaneously,</b> as her husband’s rights to her property are terminated at the time of divorce.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Was</b> it <b>difficult for Rava</b> to understand the <i>halakha</i> that one can effect divorce by placing a bill of divorce in <b>the hand of a woman?</b> Why is this difficult? <b>Though</b> the rights <b>to her earnings belong to</b> the husband, <b>does her hand itself belong to him?</b> Therefore, since a woman owns her hand, she is divorced once she receives the bill of divorce in her hand; and it is not necessary to apply the principle that the bill of divorce and her hand enter her possession simultaneously. Therefore, there is no proof that the bill of divorce and her courtyard enter her possession simultaneously.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> It was <b>difficult for Rava</b> to understand the <i>halakha</i> that one can effect emancipation by placing a bill of manumission in <b>the hand of a slave,</b> as follows: <b>According to the one who says</b> that a slave can be emancipated <b>with a bill</b> of manumission <b>by</b> receiving the bill <b>himself,</b> one can ask: How is this effective? Isn’t <b>the hand of a slave like the hand of his master,</b> as the master owns the slave’s body? Therefore, when the master gives the bill of manumission to his slave, it is as though he gave it to himself, and the bill is never considered as having reached the slave’s domain. How can the slave be emancipated in this manner? <b>Rather,</b> one must say that <b>his bill</b> of manumission <b>and his hand enter</b> his possession <b>simultaneously. So too,</b> with regard to a woman’s courtyard, one can explain that <b>her bill of divorce and her courtyard enter</b> her possession <b>simultaneously.</b>
§ The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain person on his deathbed who wrote a bill of divorce for his wife toward the evening of the coming of the Shabbat, but he did not manage to give it to her. The next day his condition intensified</b> and he was unable to give her the bill of divorce. People <b>came before Rava</b> to ask what they should do. <b>He said to them: Go tell him to transfer to her</b> ownership <b>of that place where the bill of divorce is resting, and she should go and close</b> the door <b>and open</b> it <b>and assert ownership over it,</b> thereby acquiring the place together with the bill of divorce that is in it.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 42a): If <b>one locked, fenced</b> in, or <b>breached any amount, this is</b> a valid act of <b>taking possession</b> through which land is acquired.
<b>Rav Ilish said to Rava:</b> How will it help for her to acquire the place, since <b>that which a woman acquired</b> is <b>acquired</b> by <b>her husband?</b> Rava <b>was embarrassed</b> that he issued an incorrect ruling.
<b>Ultimately, it was revealed that she was a betrothed woman. Rava said:</b> I ruled correctly, as even <b>if they said with regard to a married woman</b> that everything she acquires belongs to her husband, would <b>they say</b> the same <b>with regard to a betrothed woman?</b> A betrothed woman’s hand is not considered to be like the hand of her husband. <b>Rava then said:</b> There <b>is no difference</b> if she is <b>a betrothed woman, and there is no difference</b> if she is <b>a married woman,</b> as <b>her bill of divorce and her courtyard enter</b> her possession <b>simultaneously.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> didn’t <b>Rava</b> already <b>say this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that her bill of divorce and her courtyard enter her possession simultaneously, <b>at the outset?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When Rava said this</b> <i>halakha</i>, <b>he said it in connection with this</b> very <b>incident.</b>
§ It was taught in the mishna that if a husband throws his wife a bill of divorce <b>and she is in her house,</b> then she is divorced. <b>Ulla says: This is</b> only if <b>she is standing next to her house and next to her courtyard,</b> as only then will her house and courtyard acquire it for her. <b>Rabbi Oshaya says: Even</b> if <b>she</b> is <b>in Tiberius and her courtyard</b> is <b>in Tzippori,</b> or if <b>she</b> is <b>in Tzippori and her courtyard</b> is <b>in Tiberius, she is divorced.</b>
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But isn’t</b> it <b>taught</b> in the mishna that <b>she is in her house and in her courtyard?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: And she is</b> considered to be <b>like one who is in her house; and she is</b> considered to be <b>like one who is in her courtyard.</b> This means that <b>since it is a courtyard that is secured with her knowledge,</b> it is as though she is there, and <b>she is divorced.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that they disagree about this</b> issue: One <b>Sage,</b> Ulla, <b>holds</b> that a <b>courtyard is included</b> in the areas where she can obtain ownership of a bill of divorce <b>as</b> an extension of <b>her hand.</b> Consequently, it has the same <i>halakhot</i> as her hand, so that just as her hand is close to her, so too, her courtyard must be close to her in order for her to acquire the bill of divorce through it. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Oshaya, <b>holds</b> that a <b>courtyard is included</b> in the areas where she can obtain ownership of a bill of divorce <b>as</b> an extension of <b>agency,</b> and therefore, like an agent, her courtyard can acquire the bill of divorce for her when she is far away.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone</b> agrees that a <b>courtyard is included</b> in the areas where she can obtain ownership of a bill of divorce <b>as</b> an extension of <b>her hand.</b> They disagree about how it is compared to her hand. One <b>Sage,</b> Ulla, <b>holds</b> that it is entirely <b>like her hand. Just as her</b> actual <b>hand is next to</b> her, <b>so too, her courtyard,</b> which is an extension of her hand, acquires the bill of divorce <b>when</b> it is <b>next to</b> her.
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Oshaya, holds that <b>if</b> you derive matters in this way, you should say that <b>just as her</b> actual <b>hand is attached</b> to her, <b>so too, her courtyard</b> can acquire a bill of divorce only <b>when</b> it is <b>attached</b> to her, which cannot be. <b>Rather,</b> the comparison is as follows: Her courtyard is <b>like her</b> actual <b>hand,</b> and <b>just as her hand is secured with her knowledge, so too,</b> only <b>her courtyard that is consciously secured by her</b> can acquire a bill of divorce for her. This serves <b>to exclude her courtyard that is not consciously secured by her,</b> i.e., that she has no control over, which cannot acquire a bill of divorce for her, since it is not similar to her hand.
§ The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain man who threw a bill of divorce to his wife</b> while <b>she was standing in a courtyard. The bill of divorce went</b> and <b>fell onto a board</b> of wood. <b>Rav Yosef said: We see</b> the precise circumstance: <b>If the</b> board encompassed an area of <b>four cubits by four cubits, it</b> thereby is considered to be <b>a separate domain of its own</b> and is not included in the courtyard within which she was standing, and she is consequently not divorced. <b>And if</b> the board was <b>not</b> that large, <b>it is</b> part of the courtyard and it is all <b>one domain,</b> and she is therefore divorced.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>With what are we dealing</b> here? <b>If we say</b> that the incident occurred <b>in her courtyard, if</b> the board <b>had</b> an area of <b>four cubits, what of it?</b> Since the board belongs to her as well, it should still be an effective divorce. <b>Rather,</b> say that the incident occurred <b>in his courtyard;</b> but then, even <b>if</b> the board did <b>not have</b> an area of <b>four cubits, what of it?</b> Since none of it belongs to her, why would it be an effective divorce?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he lent her</b> the <b>place,</b> i.e., the courtyard, as a means to acquire the bill of divorce. And <b>since people lend one place,</b> but <b>people do not lend two places,</b> if the board is considered to be a separate domain then it was not included in the courtyard that was lent to her, and it would therefore not be an effective divorce.
The Gemara notes: <b>And we said</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case where the place onto which the bill of divorce fell <b>was not ten</b> handbreadths <b>higher</b> than the courtyard. <b>But</b> if the place onto which the bill of divorce fell was <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>higher, even though</b> the board did <b>not have</b> an area of <b>four cubits,</b> it is still considered to be a separate domain.
<b>And we said</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case where the place onto which the bill of divorce fell <b>does not have</b>

Daf 78a

<b>a modifier,</b> meaning that this board is not referred to by a unique name. <b>But</b> if <b>it has a modifier, even though it is not ten</b> handbreadths <b>higher</b> than the courtyard, <b>and even though</b> the board did <b>not have</b> an area of <b>four cubits,</b> it is still considered to be a separate domain, and it would therefore not be an effective divorce.
§ It was taught in the mishna that if he throws a bill of divorce to his wife while she is in his house, she is not divorced, <b>even if</b> the bill of divorce <b>is with her in the bed,</b> i.e., he throws it onto the bed in which she is sitting or lying. <b>Rava says: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case where he throws the bill of divorce to her and it is with her <b>in his bed. But</b> if he throws the bill of divorce to her and it is with her <b>in her bed,</b> then <b>she is divorced.</b>
<b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If he throws the bill of divorce to her when she is <b>in his bed, she is not divorced;</b> if he throws it to her when she is <b>in her bed, she is divorced.</b>
The Gemara asks: And if he throws the bill of divorce to her <b>in her bed, is she divorced?</b> But the bed <b>is</b> like <b>vessels of a buyer</b> that are <b>in the domain of the seller,</b> since the bed that belongs to her is in the house of the husband. Can <b>you conclude from</b> here that even if the <b>vessels of a buyer</b> are <b>in the domain of the seller, the buyer acquires</b> anything that is deposited into his vessels? This issue is disputed elsewhere. Some hold that when a vessel of the buyer is in the domain of the seller, the vessel cannot serve to acquire an item on behalf of the buyer.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where</b> the bed is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high,</b> as then the bed is considered to be its own domain. The Gemara challenges this: <b>But there is the place</b> on which the <b>legs</b> of the bed are standing; the legs are standing in the husband’s domain. The Gemara answers: <b>People are not particular</b> about <b>the place of the legs</b> of the bed since it is so small. Therefore, since the bed is considered to be its own domain, it is not considered to be within the domain of the husband.
§ It was taught in the mishna that if the husband threw the bill of divorce <b>into her lap, or into her basket,</b> then <b>she is divorced,</b> even if she is in her husband’s house at that time. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is she divorced? <b>Is this</b> not like a case of <b>the vessels of a buyer</b> that are <b>in the domain of the seller,</b> with regard to which there is a dispute concerning whether the vessels can serve to acquire an item on the buyer’s behalf?
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where her basket was hanging from her</b> body, and therefore it is not considered to be within the domain of the husband. <b>And so Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where her basket was hanging from her</b> body. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> If it was <b>tied</b> to her then that is enough, <b>even though it is not hanging</b> from her body.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where her basket was placed between her thighs</b> and is therefore in the place where she is sitting, and since her husband is not particular about the place in which she is sitting, it is considered her domain. <b>Rav Mesharshiyya bar Rav Dimi says:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where her husband was a basket seller,</b> and therefore is not particular about the place where the basket is since his whole courtyard is full of baskets, and it is therefore considered to be her domain.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> There is no need for these explanations, since <b>the place of her lap belongs to her,</b> and <b>the place of her basket belongs to her. Rava said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s</b> statement? <b>Because a person is not particular, not about the place of</b> his wife’s <b>lap, nor about the place of her basket,</b> it is as though he transferred ownership of the place to her for her use.
<b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he threw</b> the bill of divorce <b>to her into her lap, or into her basket, or into anything that is like her basket, then she is divorced.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the wording of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is included</b> by the expansive term: <b>Anything that is like her basket?</b> It serves <b>to include the basket [<i>taska</i>] from which she eats dates,</b> as he is not particular about its place as well.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>he said to</b> his wife: <b>Take this promissory note,</b> and it was a bill of divorce, <b>or she found it behind him</b> and he did not tell her what it was but <b>she reads</b> what is written in <b>it and</b> discovers that <b>it is her bill of divorce, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce until he says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b>
If <b>he gave it</b> to her <b>in her hand and she</b> was <b>sleeping,</b> and he then <b>woke her, and</b> when <b>she reads</b> what is written in <b>it,</b> she finds that <b>it is her bill of divorce, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce until he says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Apropos the mishna’s statement that if she found the bill of divorce behind him, it is not a valid bill of divorce until he says: This is your bill of divorce, the Gemara asks: And <b>when he says to her: This is your bill of divorce, what of it?</b> Why is it considered to be a valid bill of divorce if it was not given to her in the proper manner, being that <b>it is</b> as though he told her: <b>Take your bill of divorce from</b> where it is placed <b>on the ground?</b>
<b>And Rava says</b> that if one says to his wife: <b>Take your bill of divorce from</b> where it is placed <b>on the ground,</b> it is as though <b>he didn’t say anything</b> and it is not a valid bill of divorce, since a woman is divorced only when the bill of divorce is given to her by her husband. The Gemara answers: <b>Say that</b> the bill of divorce was not placed on the ground behind him, but rather <b>she pulled it out from behind him.</b> In other words, the bill of divorce was tucked into his belt and she pulled it out. Consequently, she received the bill of divorce from him.
The Gemara challenges this: If <b>she pulled it out,</b> it is <b>also</b> not a valid bill of divorce, since it is <b>required</b> that the directive: <b>“And gives it in her hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), be fulfilled, <b>and</b> in this case <b>it is not</b> fulfilled, since he did not give it to her; rather, she took it. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he bent</b> [<b><i>da’arak</i></b>] <b>his waist</b> over toward her <b>and she pulled it out,</b> and by extending his waist to her, it is as though he gave the bill of divorce to her.
<b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 8:1): If <b>he said to</b> his wife: <b>Take this promissory note, or</b> if <b>she pulled it out from behind him, read it, and</b> saw that <b>it is her bill of divorce; it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce until he says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Actually, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce until he takes it from her and gives it to her again, and says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If <b>he gave it</b> to her <b>in her hand, and she</b> was <b>sleeping,</b> and he then <b>woke her, and</b> when <b>she reads</b> what is written in <b>it,</b> she finds that <b>it is her bill of divorce; it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce until he says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> It is not a valid bill of divorce <b>until he takes it from her and gives it to her again, and says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to mention this dispute in both cases. <b>As if</b> this dispute would have <b>been stated</b> only <b>with regard to</b> the cases in <b>the first clause,</b> one could assume that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>is saying</b> his opinion specifically <b>with regard to</b> the cases in <b>this</b> clause, <b>because she is subject to being divorced,</b> since she is awake and able to receive a bill of divorce, even though he did not tell her that this is a bill of divorce. <b>But</b> if <b>he gave it</b> to her <b>in her hand and she</b> was <b>sleeping, she is not subject to being divorced</b> since while she is sleeping she is a person who lacks the halakhic competence required to receive a bill of divorce. Therefore, one could <b>say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>concedes to Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> that giving the bill of divorce while she was sleeping is totally not valid. It was therefore necessary to mention that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi disagrees in this case, as well.
<b>And if</b> this dispute would have <b>been stated</b> only <b>with regard to this</b> case, where she was sleeping, one could assume that specifically <b>with regard to this</b> case <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar is saying</b> that he must give her the bill of divorce a second time. <b>But in the other</b> case, in which she was awake, one could <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to mention this dispute in both cases.
<b>Rava says:</b> If <b>he wrote a bill of divorce for her, and he placed it in the hand of her slave</b> when <b>he is sleeping and she is guarding him, it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> Within the context of the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce, a slave has the same status as land, in the sense that both belong to their owner. Therefore, when the husband places the bill of divorce in the slave’s hand, it is as though he placed it into her courtyard. If her slave <b>was awake, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> because <b>he is</b> like <b>a courtyard that is not consciously secured by her.</b> Since he guards himself, he therefore does not acquire it on her behalf.
Rava continues: If <b>he is sleeping and she is guarding him, it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara asks: But <b>why;</b> isn’t it true that the slave <b>is</b> like <b>a mobile courtyard, and a mobile courtyard does not acquire</b> items on behalf of its owner?
<b>And if you would say</b> that a case in which he is <b>sleeping is different</b> because he is currently not moving, <b>but didn’t Rava say:</b> In <b>any</b> case in which <b>if he would be moving</b> he would <b>not acquire</b> items, then even if he is <b>standing or sitting,</b> he also does <b>not acquire</b> items? The Gemara concludes: <b>And</b> this <b><i>halakha</i></b> that Rava said, indicating that it is a valid bill of divorce, applies only <b>where</b> the slave is <b>bound</b> and sleeping, since in that case placing the bill of divorce in his hand is like placing it in her hand.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the woman <b>was standing in the public domain</b> and her husband took the bill of divorce <b>and threw it to her,</b> if it fell <b>closer to her, she is divorced,</b> and if it fell <b>closer to him, she is not divorced.</b> If it is <b>equally balanced,</b> there is uncertainty as to whether <b>she is divorced or</b> whether <b>she is not divorced. And</b> the <b>same</b> <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>with regard to betrothal.</b>
<b>And</b> the <b>same</b> <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>with regard to a debt.</b> If <b>his creditor said to him: Throw</b> the payment for <b>my debt to me, and he threw it to him</b> and the money fell <b>closer to the creditor,</b> the <b>creditor acquired</b> the payment. The debtor is absolved of his obligation to pay even if the money did not reach the creditor’s hand, e.g., it was stolen or lost after it was thrown and before the creditor was able to take it. If it fell <b>closer to the debtor</b> and the money was lost, <b>the debtor</b> is still <b>obligated</b> to pay. If it was <b>equally balanced</b> and was lost, <b>the two of them divide</b> it, i.e., the debtor owes half of the amount.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies that which was taught in the mishna: <b>What is considered closer to her, and what is considered closer to him? Rav says:</b> If it fell within <b>four cubits of her, this is</b> what was meant by the mishna’s statement: <b>Closer to her;</b> if it fell within <b>four cubits of him, this is</b> what was meant by: <b>Closer to him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is considered midway? Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: Such as</b> when <b>the two of them were standing within</b> the same <b>four cubits.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us see which of them preceded</b> the other into these four cubits, and the four cubits would then be considered as belonging to that person. <b>And if you would say that both of them came simultaneously, but</b> isn’t there a principle that <b>it is impossible to be</b> so <b>precise?</b> It is not possible that both events occurred at exactly the same time, and it is certain that one of them arrived there before the other.
<b>Rather, Rav Kahana said: Here we are dealing with</b> a case of <b>precisely eight cubits,</b> where his four cubits are adjacent to her four cubits,

Daf 78b

<b>and</b> the <b>bill of divorce extends from his four cubits into her four cubits,</b> meaning that part of the bill of divorce is in his four cubits, and part is in hers. Therefore, in this case there is uncertainty whether she is divorced or whether she is not divorced.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the bill of divorce still <b>attached to him,</b> since part of it is within his four cubits, and therefore it cannot be considered as if he gave her the bill of divorce completely? <b>Rather,</b> one should explain as <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both say: Here we are dealing with two groups of witnesses; one says</b> that the bill of divorce fell <b>closer to him, and one says</b> that the bill of divorce fell <b>closer to her.</b> Therefore, the expression in the mishna, equally balanced, is referring not to distance but to opinions.
As opposed to Rav, who explained that in the mishna, the word closer meant within four cubits, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: We learned</b> that <b>closer to her</b> means that the bill of divorce was actually closer to her, <b>even</b> if it was <b>one hundred cubits</b> away from her. <b>And we learned</b> that <b>closer to him</b> means that it was actually closer to him, <b>even</b> if it was <b>one hundred cubits</b> away from him.
The Gemara asks: According to the explanation offered by Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>what are the circumstances</b> of when it was <b>equally balanced? Rav Shemen bar Abba said: This was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> himself: If it is so positioned that <b>he can guard it and she cannot guard it, this is</b> considered <b>closer to him.</b> If it is so positioned that <b>she can guard it and he cannot guard it, this is</b> considered <b>closer to her.</b> If it is so positioned that <b>the two of them can guard it,</b> or <b>the two of them cannot</b> guard it, <b>this is</b> considered <b>equally balanced.</b>
<b>The Rabbis said this</b> explanation <b>before Rabbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rabbi Yonatan,</b> and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said</b> in amazement: Do <b>our Babylonian friends know how to explain in accordance with this explanation?</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan was astonished that they also understood the issue as he did.
<b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 8:1): <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> bill of divorce <b>that is closer to her than</b> it is <b>to him, and a dog came and took it</b> before the bill of divorce reached her hand, <b>she is not divorced.</b> The Gemara asks: Why is it that <b>she is not divorced?</b> Once it was closer to her, before the dog took it, the divorce should have taken effect. <b>Must she continue guarding</b> her bill of divorce <b>indefinitely,</b> even after the bill of divorce took effect?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> bill of divorce <b>that is closer to her than</b> it is <b>to him, and if a dog</b> were to <b>come and</b> attempt to <b>take it, he</b> would be <b>able to guard it and she</b> would <b>not</b> be <b>able to guard it,</b> in that case <b>she is not divorced,</b> as the bill of divorce is considered in his domain.
<b>Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: One with large teeth</b> [<b><i>shinnana</i></b>], i.e., a nickname for Rabbi Yehuda, when they said: Closer to her, it meant <b>so that she could bend down and take it. And you should not perform an action</b> to permit a divorcing woman to remarry <b>until the bill of divorce</b> actually <b>reaches her hand.</b>
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: There was an incident like this,</b> in which the bill of divorce was closer to the woman than to the man and it was then lost; <b>and,</b> after her husband died, <b>they required</b> the woman to engage in <b>the ritual through which the <i>yavam</i> frees the <i>yevama</i> of her levirate bonds [<i>ḥalitza</i>]</b> in order to permit her to marry, due to uncertainty. They did not rely on the bill of divorce that was given to the woman, since it never actually reached her hand.
§ The mishna stated the <i>halakha</i> about a bill of divorce that was closer to him or her, and the mishna added: <b>And</b> the <b>same</b> <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>with regard to betrothal. Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They said</b> these <i>halakhot</i> only <b>with regard to bills of divorce, but not with regard to another matter.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba raised an objection to</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Asi</b> from what was explicitly taught in the mishna: <b>And</b> the <b>same</b> <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>with regard to betrothal.</b> He responded: <b>It is different there</b> with regard to betrothal, <b>as it is written: “And she departs</b> out of his house, and goes <b>and becomes</b> another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2). The Torah thereby compares betrothal, through the use of the word “becomes,” to divorce, through the use of the words “and she departs,” so one can learn the <i>halakhot</i> of betrothal from the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce. One cannot learn <i>halakhot</i> concerning other matters from divorce.
<b>Another objection to</b> his statement was <b>raised</b> based on what is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> the <b>same</b> <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>with regard to a debt.</b> If a creditor said to a debtor: <b>Throw</b> the payment for <b>my debt to me, and he threw it to him</b> and the money fell <b>closer to the creditor,</b> the <b>debtor merits,</b> i.e., his debt is repaid. If it fell <b>closer to the debtor</b> and the money was lost, <b>the debtor</b> is still <b>obligated</b> to pay. If it was <b>equally balanced</b> and was lost, <b>the two of them divide</b> it, i.e., the debtor owes half of the amount. Accordingly, the <i>halakhot</i> of debts are compared to the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the creditor <b>said to</b> the debtor: <b>Throw</b> the payment for <b>my debt to me, and you will be absolved</b> of your obligation to pay through this. The Gemara challenges this: <b>If so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this? Since he made an explicit stipulation, it is obvious that the outcome will be in accordance with his stipulation. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where</b> the creditor <b>said to</b> the debtor: <b>Throw</b> the payment for <b>my debt to me</b> according <b>to the procedure</b> in effect with <b>bills of divorce,</b> meaning that the <i>halakha</i> that applies to divorce should apply here too.
The Gemara asks: <b>And still, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this, since the creditor stipulated explicitly: According to the procedure in effect with bills of divorce? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that the creditor <b>can say to</b> the debtor: <b>I am teasing you,</b> and what I stipulated has no validity. Therefore the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that if he stipulated that it should be treated as a bill of divorce, then his stipulation takes effect.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If <b>the bill of divorce was in her hand and a string</b> tied to the bill of divorce was <b>in his hand,</b> as he gave her the bill of divorce in this way, <b>if</b> the husband <b>can</b> still <b>pull</b> the bill of divorce out of her hand <b>and bring it to him, she is not divorced; and if</b> he is <b>not</b> able to do so, <b>she is divorced.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> that she is not divorced, despite the fact that he gave her a bill of divorce? The reason is that <b>we require severance, and it is lacking,</b> since the husband still has a hold on the bill of divorce.
<b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> If <b>her hand was positioned like a slope and he threw it to her, despite</b> the fact <b>that the bill of divorce reached her hand, she is not divorced,</b> since it cannot remain in her hand and will fall out.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why? But when</b> the bill of divorce <b>falls</b> from her hand, <b>it falls within her four cubits.</b> The Gemara answers: Rav Yehuda is discussing a case <b>where</b> the bill of divorce <b>did not rest</b> within her four cubits. Rather, it fell further away.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>let her be divorced</b> because the bill of divorce was in <b>the airspace of</b> her <b>four cubits?</b> And if you do not say this, then <b>resolve</b> the dilemma <b>that Rabbi Elazar raised</b> with regard to <b>the four cubits that</b> the Sages <b>stated</b> in the <i>halakhot</i> of acquisition: <b>Do they have airspace</b> with the same legal status <b>or do they not have airspace? Resolve</b> that dilemma from here, i.e., <b>that they do not have airspace.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: One cannot resolve the dilemma from here since it is possible to say that <b>here we are dealing with</b> a woman who is <b>standing at the riverbank, as</b> the bill of divorce <b>stands to be destroyed from the outset,</b> since if it does not remain in her hand it will fall into the river. In such a case, everyone agrees that the airspace of the four cubits does not acquire the item.

Daf 79a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a woman <b>was standing on top of the roof</b> and her husband was standing below, <b>and he threw</b> a bill of divorce <b>to her, once</b> the bill of divorce <b>reaches the airspace of the roof, she is divorced.</b> If <b>he</b> was <b>above</b> on the roof <b>and she</b> was <b>below, and he threw it to her, once it leaves the area of the roof,</b> even if the wording <b>was erased or</b> the document <b>was burned</b> before it fell to the ground, <b>she is divorced.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the airspace of the roof <b>unsecured?</b> Since the bill of divorce can be blown away from the roof by the wind, it should be considered an unsecured courtyard, which does not acquire items. If so, why is she divorced once the bill of divorce reaches the airspace of the roof? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: We are dealing with a roof that has a parapet.</b> Therefore, it is like a secured courtyard, since the bill of divorce cannot be blown away.
<b>Ulla bar Menashya said in the name of Avimi</b> that there is another answer: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case in which the bill of divorce is <b>within three</b> handbreadths <b>of the roof, as anything within three</b> handbreadths <b>of the roof is</b> considered to be <b>like the roof</b> itself, based on the principle that views two solid surfaces as connected if the gap between them is less than three handbreadths wide.
§ It was taught in the mishna: If <b>he</b> was <b>above</b> and she was below, and he threw the bill of divorce to her, once it leaves the area of the roof, she is divorced. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the airspace of the courtyard <b>not secured,</b> since the bill of divorce can be blown out of the courtyard by the wind? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> We are discussing a case <b>where the lower partitions</b> in the courtyard <b>extend beyond the upper</b> partitions on the roof, so that the bill of divorce will certainly fall in the courtyard.
<b>And so Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> We are discussing a case <b>where the lower partitions extend beyond the upper</b> partitions. <b>And so Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> We are discussing a case <b>where the lower partitions extend beyond the upper</b> partitions.
<b>Rabbi Abba said to Ulla: In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i> that once the bill of divorce enters the woman’s domain, it is considered as though it was given to her, even though it was destroyed before it landed on the ground? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said</b> that with regard to the prohibition of transferring an item from one domain to another on Shabbat, an object <b>in airspace is considered at rest?</b> This means that any item in the airspace of a domain is considered to be placed within that domain.
Ulla <b>said to him: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, since <b>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>only with regard to Shabbat.</b> They maintain that with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, the item must actually come to rest in the domain to which it was transferred; while it is in the air, it is not considered as though it has landed on the ground. <b>But here,</b> in the case of divorce, <b>it is because</b> the bill of divorce <b>is secured</b> that she is divorced, <b>and</b> in this case <b>it is secured</b> while within the airspace of the partitions.
<b>And so Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> We are discussing a case <b>where the lower partitions</b> in the courtyard <b>extend beyond the upper</b> partitions on the roof. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Asi: In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i>? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who says</b> that an object <b>in airspace is considered at rest?</b>
Rabbi Asi <b>said to him: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> since <b>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>only with regard to Shabbat. But here, it is because</b> the bill of divorce <b>is secured</b> that she is divorced, <b>and</b> in this case <b>it is secured</b> while within the airspace of the partitions.
§ It was taught in the mishna that once the bill of divorce leaves the domain of the roof, even if the writing <b>was erased</b> before it reached her hand, she is divorced with it. <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only when</b> the writing <b>was erased</b> when it had already left the confines of the roof and was on its <b>descent,</b> entering her domain. <b>But</b> if the writing <b>was erased</b> while it was on its <b>ascent,</b> i.e., as it arched upward before falling down, then <b>no,</b> she is not divorced. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Because <b>initially,</b> before it began its descent, the bill of divorce <b>is not destined to land</b> in her domain, since it could be blown elsewhere. Consequently, it cannot be considered as though it is already resting in her courtyard at that time.
It was taught in the mishna that once the bill of divorce leaves the domain of the roof, even if the document <b>was burned</b> before it reached her hand, she is divorced with it. Here, as well, <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only when</b> the throwing of the <b>bill of divorce preceded the fire. But</b> if the <b>fire preceded the</b> throwing of the <b>bill of divorce,</b> then the woman is <b>not</b> divorced. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Because <b>initially,</b> when the bill of divorce was thrown, <b>it was heading toward being burned,</b> and therefore it is considered that he never gave her a bill of divorce.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says: Domains are divided with regard to bills of divorce.</b> If there are several areas within the same domain, e.g., a house and a courtyard, or a courtyard and a roof, they are not all considered a single domain with regard to bills of divorce. Rather, each one is considered to be a separate domain.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said to Rava: From where does the Elder,</b> i.e., Rav Ḥisda, derive <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? Rava <b>said to him: It is</b> derived from <b>the mishna</b> that taught: If the woman <b>was standing on the top of the roof and</b> her husband <b>threw</b> a bill of divorce <b>to her</b> from below, <b>once the bill of divorce reaches the airspace of the roof, she is divorced.</b>
Rava explains: <b>With what are we dealing? If we say</b> that we are dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>her roof and her courtyard, why do I</b> require the bill of divorce to reach <b>the airspace of the roof</b> in order for her to be divorced? Even if the bill of divorce remained in the courtyard, she would be divorced, since it is her courtyard.
<b>Rather,</b> we must be dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>his roof and his courtyard.</b> But <b>when</b> the bill of divorce <b>reaches the airspace of the roof, what of it?</b> Why is she then divorced, if the bill of divorce has not left his domain?
<b>Rather,</b> it <b>is obvious</b> that we are dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>her roof and his courtyard.</b> Rava questions this conclusion: <b>Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which taught: If <b>he</b> was <b>above</b> on the roof <b>and she</b> was <b>below, and he threw it to her, once it leaves the area of the roof,</b> even if the wording <b>was erased or</b> the document <b>was burned</b> before it fell to the ground, <b>she is divorced. And if</b> we are dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>her roof and his courtyard, why is she divorced? Rather,</b> it is necessary to say that we are dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>his roof and her courtyard.</b>
Rava asks: Is it possible that <b>the first clause</b> in the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>her roof and his courtyard, and the latter clause</b> in the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>his roof and her courtyard?</b> How could the same mishna discuss two <i>halakhot</i> where each one is dealing with a different reality, without mentioning this distinction?
Rava explains Rav Ḥisda’s inference: <b>Rather, is it not</b> so <b>that</b> the mishna is dealing with a case <b>where</b> both the roof and the courtyard belong to him, but <b>he lent her</b> a <b>place</b> in his domain wherein she could acquire her bill of divorce, and she is standing in that place? In the first clause he lent her the roof, and in the second clause he lent her the courtyard, Consequently, only once it reaches that domain is she divorced. The reason why she does not acquire the bill of divorce until it reaches the specific domain that he lent her is <b>that people lend</b> only <b>one place; people do not lend two places.</b> Rav Ḥisda understood that one can infer from the mishna that the courtyard and roof remain as separate domains, and concludes that, with regard to bills of divorce, different areas in one domain are considered to be multiple domains.
Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>Are the cases comparable? Perhaps this</b> case is <b>as it is and that</b> case is <b>as it is,</b> i.e., <b>the first clause</b> in the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>her roof and his courtyard,</b> and <b>the latter clause</b> is dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>his roof and her courtyard.</b> In some instances, one mishna deals with two different cases. Therefore, the mishna is not an adequate proof for Rav Ḥisda’s statement.
<b>Rava says:</b> There are <b>three</b> unique <b>qualities with regard to bills of divorce,</b> as compared to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat. The first is <b>that which Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> An object <b>in airspace is</b> considered <b>at rest; and the Rabbis disagree with him. This matter</b> about which they disagree <b>applies</b> only <b>with regard to Shabbat. But here,</b> in the case of divorce, <b>it is because</b> the bill of divorce <b>is secured</b> that she is divorced; <b>and</b> once the bill of divorce is within the airspace of the partitions, <b>it is secured</b> and the Rabbis agree that she is divorced.
<b>And</b> the second matter is <b>that which Rav Ḥisda says</b> concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat: In the case of one who <b>embedded a reed in</b> the ground of <b>a private domain, and on its top was a basket [<i>teraskal</i>], and he threw</b> an object from the public domain and <b>it rested on top of it, even</b> if the reed was <b>a hundred cubits high, he is liable because the private domain extends upward until the sky.</b> Therefore, the object landed in a private domain. <b>This matter applies</b> only <b>with regard to Shabbat,</b> as with regard to Shabbat domains are defined based on their partitions and the way in which they are used, which differs from the way domains are defined in other halakhic areas. <b>But here,</b> in the case of divorce, <b>it is because</b> the bill of divorce <b>is secured</b> that she is divorced, <b>and</b> when it is on the reed <b>it is not secured.</b>

Daf 79b

<b>And</b> the third matter relates to <b>that which Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> On Shabbat <b>a person should not stand on this roof and collect rainwater from the roof of another</b> if there is no joining of courtyards. <b>As just as the residences are separated below, so too, the residences are separated above.</b> Each residence has a separate domain, and it is forbidden by rabbinic law to transfer an item from a private domain to another private domain if they are not joined. Similarly, despite the fact that the roofs are not totally separated from one another and nobody lives there, each roof is considered to be its own domain.
Rava explains: <b>This matter applies</b> only <b>with regard to Shabbat. But with regard to a bill of divorce,</b> if it fell onto another roof that is adjacent to the roof that he lent her for the purpose of acquiring the bill of divorce, she is divorced. The reason that a woman is usually not divorced when a bill of divorce falls into a different place, even though that place also belongs to her husband, is <b>due to</b> the fact that a husband <b>is particular</b> and does not want to lend her more than one place; <b>but people are not particular to that extent,</b> i.e., in this case the husband would not be particular about allowing her to temporarily use an adjacent rooftop that also belongs to him.
§ <b>Abaye says:</b> If there are <b>two courtyards</b> that are configured such that <b>this</b> courtyard is <b>within that</b> courtyard, and the <b>inner</b> courtyard <b>is hers and</b> the <b>outer</b> courtyard <b>is his, and</b> the <b>partitions</b> of <b>the outer</b> courtyard <b>extend higher than</b> the partitions of <b>the inner</b> courtyard, <b>and he threw</b> a bill of divorce <b>to her</b> into her courtyard, <b>once it reaches the airspace of the partitions of the outer</b> courtyard, i.e., it reaches the area above the inner courtyard at a height lower than the height of the partitions of the outer courtyard, <b>she is divorced.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? The <b>inner</b> courtyard <b>itself is secured by</b> the <b>partitions</b> of <b>the outer</b> courtyard. Therefore, the outer partitions service the inner courtyard as well. If the bill of divorce is secured by being encompassed by the outer partitions, it can be viewed as belonging to the inner courtyard once it reaches its airspace.
The Gemara comments: <b>This is not so with regard to baskets.</b> In a case where there were <b>two baskets, this</b> one <b>within that</b> one, resting in a domain that does not belong to either of them, and <b>the inner</b> basket <b>is hers and the outer</b> basket <b>is his, and he threw</b> a bill if divorce <b>to her</b> into her basket, <b>even</b> if the bill of divorce <b>reached the airspace</b> of <b>the inner</b> basket but was burned or taken before it landed therein, <b>she is not divorced.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because</b> the bill of divorce did <b>not</b> yet <b>rest</b> within the basket, and in this case, the walls of the outer basket do not service the inner basket.
The Gemara asks: <b>And when it rests</b> within the basket, <b>what of it?</b> They <b>are</b> like the <b>vessels of a buyer in the domain of the seller,</b> since her basket is within his basket, which is his domain. She cannot acquire the bill of divorce, despite the fact that it is in her basket, since it is within his domain.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here? With a basket that has no bottom,</b> and consequently the inner basket is resting on the ground and not inside the outer basket. Therefore, once the bill of divorce lands inside the inner basket, she is indeed divorced.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Shammai say: A man may send,</b> i.e., divorce, <b>his wife with an outdated bill of divorce, and Beit Hillel prohibit</b> him from doing so. <b>And what is an outdated bill of divorce? Any</b> case <b>where he was secluded with her after he wrote it for her</b> and before he gave it to her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? Beit Shammai hold</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that the bill of divorce is not valid due to a rabbinic <b>decree, lest they say</b> that receipt of <b>her bill of divorce precedes</b> conception of <b>her son.</b> If he gives her the bill of divorce long after it was written, she may give birth to children from him in the interim. There is a concern that people will say that she was actually divorced on the date written on the bill of divorce before the children were born, and the children were conceived through licentious sexual intercourse.
<b>And Beit Hillel hold</b> that <b>we do say</b> that this bill of divorce is not valid due to a rabbinic <b>decree, lest they say</b> that receipt of <b>her bill of divorce precedes</b> conception of <b>her son.</b> Consequently, if a woman was secluded with her husband following the writing of the bill of divorce, the bill of divorce is not valid.
<b>Rabbi Abba says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> Even according to Beit Hillel, <b>if</b> the woman <b>was married</b> on the basis of an outdated bill of divorce given to her by her previous husband, who did not ask advice from the rabbis, <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her second husband. In such a case, this decree is not severe enough to invalidate the bill of divorce.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: If she was divorced</b> with an outdated bill of divorce, this woman can <b>marry</b>even <b><i>ab initio</i></b> on the basis of this bill of divorce. There is no requirement for her to wait for her first husband to write her a new bill of divorce.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>he wrote</b> the date on the bill of divorce using a calendrical system that counts years <b>in the name of a kingdom that is not legitimate,</b> or he wrote the date <b>in the name of the kingdom of Medea,</b> or <b>in the name of the Greek Empire,</b> after it ceased to exist, or he wrote the date counting <b>to the building of the Temple,</b> or counting <b>to the destruction of the Temple,</b> in all these case, the bill of divorce is not valid. In the time of the mishna, the local government was particular that documents be dated with the official government date. Therefore, the Sages instituted that this must be done in bills of divorce as well. If one deviates from this practice, the rabbinic dictates of bills of divorce have been violated, and the bill of divorce is invalid.
If <b>he was in the east and he wrote</b> the location in the bill of divorce as <b>in the west,</b> or if he was <b>in the west and he wrote</b> the location in the bill of divorce as <b>in the east,</b> the bill of divorce is not valid. If he divorced her with this bill of divorce and she remarried, <b>she</b> must <b>leave</b> both <b>this</b> first husband <b>and that</b> second husband, <b>and she needs a bill of divorce from this</b> husband <b>and that</b> husband.
<b>And she does not receive</b> payment of her <b>marriage contract, and not</b> the <b>profits</b> from her properties that her husband consumed, <b>and</b> she does <b>not</b> have a claim to receive <b>sustenance, and</b> she does <b>not</b> have a claim to <b>worn clothes</b> that belonged to her, but which her husband used. She cannot demand these items, <b>not of this</b> husband <b>and not of that</b> husband.
<b>If she took</b> any of these items <b>from this</b> husband <b>or from that</b> husband, <b>she</b> must <b>return</b> what was taken. <b>And the child</b> that was born <b>from this</b> husband <b>or from that</b> husband that was conceived after she married the second husband is a <b>son born from an adulterous relationship [<i>mamzer</i>]. And neither this</b> husband <b>nor that</b> husband, if they are priests, is permitted to <b>become ritually impure by her</b> when she dies, which a husband may ordinarily do for his wife. <b>And neither this</b> husband <b>nor that</b> husband <b>have the rights to objects she finds, or to her earnings, or to the annulment of her vows.</b>
If <b>she was an Israelite woman,</b> then through these two marriages <b>she</b> becomes <b>disqualified from</b> marrying into the <b>priesthood,</b> due to the prohibition against a priest marrying a <i>zona</i>.

Daf 80a

If she was the <b>daughter of a Levite,</b> through these two marriages she becomes prohibited <b>from</b> partaking of <b>the tithe</b> that is given to Levites. If she was the <b>daughter of a priest,</b> she becomes prohibited <b>from</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> even after she returns to the house of her father the priest.
<b>And the heirs of this</b> husband <b>and the heirs of that</b> husband <b>do not inherit</b> the rights to collect payment of <b>her marriage contract</b> if she dies. <b>And if</b> the husbands <b>die, the brother of this</b> first husband <b>and the brother of that</b> second husband <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> since she was betrothed to the second one as well, <b>and they do not consummate the levirate marriage.</b>
The mishna proceeds to teach an additional <i>halakha</i> concerning a bill of divorce written not in accordance with its <i>halakhot</i>: If <b>he changed his name,</b> i.e., he wrote a different name in the bill of divorce, <b>or</b> he changed <b>her name,</b> or if he changed <b>the name of his city or the name of her city,</b> and she remarried on the basis of this bill of divorce, then <b>she</b> must <b>leave</b> both <b>this</b> first husband <b>and that</b> second husband. <b>And all of those</b> above-mentioned <b>ways</b> of penalizing a woman who remarried based on the bills of divorce detailed in the earlier clause of the mishna apply <b>to her</b> in this case as well.
The mishna teaches another <i>halakha</i> associated with the previous <i>halakhot</i>: With regard to <b>all</b> of those cases in <b>which they said</b> that a man who died without children and left behind a widow who is, to the man’s brother, one of <b>those with whom relations are forbidden,</b> e.g., she is his wife’s sister, not only is there no levirate bond for her, but <b>the rival wives</b> of the brother who died <b>are</b> also <b>permitted</b> to marry without either levirate marriage or <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The mishna discusses another case: <b>These rival wives went and married</b> another man without <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>and these</b> widows with whom relationships were forbidden <b>were found</b> to be <b>sexually underdeveloped women</b> incapable of bearing children <b>[<i>ailonit</i>].</b> Therefore, it became clear, retroactively, that the marriage to the dead brother was never valid, and accordingly, the rival wives were never exempt from the obligation of levirate marriage due to their being the rival wives of a forbidden relationship. Consequently, the rival wives were forbidden to marry anyone else without <i>ḥalitza</i>, and the rival wives must <b>leave</b> both <b>this</b> man whom they remarried, <b>and that</b> <i>yavam</i>, i.e., they cannot enter into levirate marriage with him. <b>And all of those</b> above-mentioned <b>ways</b> of penalizing a woman who remarried based on the bills of divorce detailed in the earlier clause of the mishna apply <b>to her</b> in this case as well.
Similarly, with regard to <b>one who marries his <i>yevama</i>, and her rival wife went and got married to another</b> man, <b>and it was found that this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>was a sexually underdeveloped woman,</b> the rival wife must <b>leave this</b> man whom she remarried <b>and that</b> <i>yavam</i>, i.e., she cannot enter into levirate marriage with him. Because the <i>yevama</i> was a sexually underdeveloped woman, the obligation of levirate marriage never applied to her, and her levirate marriage did not exempt her rival wife. <b>And all of those</b> aforementioned <b>ways</b> of penalizing a woman who remarried based on the bills of divorce detailed in the earlier clause of the mishna apply <b>to her</b> in this case as well.
The mishna now discusses another case: <b>A scribe wrote a bill of divorce for a man,</b> so that the man could divorce his wife with it; <b>and</b> he wrote <b>a receipt for the woman,</b> for her to give to her husband upon receiving payment of her marriage contract, verifying that she received the payment. <b>And</b> the scribe <b>erred and gave</b> the <b>bill of divorce to the woman and</b> the <b>receipt to the man, and</b> not knowing what was written in the documents that were in their possession, <b>they gave</b> what they received from the scribe <b>to each other.</b> The woman gave her husband a bill of divorce and the husband gave his wife a receipt, and consequently, there was no divorce at all.
<b>And after</b> some <b>time, the bill of divorce is in the possession of the man, and the receipt is in the possession of the woman,</b> and they discover that the divorce never actually transpired. If the woman had remarried another man, <b>she</b> must <b>leave this,</b> the first husband, <b>and that,</b> the second husband. <b>And all of those</b> above-mentioned <b>ways</b> of penalizing a woman who remarried based on the bills of divorce detailed in the earlier clause of the mishna apply <b>to her</b> in this case as well.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says: If</b> the bill of divorce <b>is immediately [<i>le’altar</i>] in</b> the husband’s possession, <b>this is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> since he clearly never gave it to her. But <b>if it is in</b> his possession <b>after</b> some <b>time,</b> then <b>this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> since <b>it is not in the power of the first</b> husband <b>to eliminate the right of the second</b> husband. The assumption is that the husband did in fact give her the bill of divorce in the correct manner, but at some point, he took it back from her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It was stated in the mishna that if one wrote the date on a bill of divorce according to a kingdom that is not legitimate, it is invalid. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the description: <b>A kingdom that is not legitimate?</b> The Gemara answers: This is referring to <b>the Roman Empire,</b> and he wrote the bill of divorce in a different country, such as Babylonia, where the Romans were not in power. <b>And why is it called: A kingdom that is not legitimate? Because they have neither</b> their own <b>script, nor</b> their own <b>language,</b> but rather, they took them from other nations.
<b>Ulla said: For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>institute</b> that the date should be written according to the years of the local <b>kingdom, in bills of divorce? Due to</b> the need to maintain <b>peaceful</b> relations with <b>the kingdom,</b> as the government is particular that important documents issued in its domain be written with the date of that government.
