The Gemara asks: <b>But due to</b> an ordinance instituted by the Sages solely for the sake of maintaining <b>peaceful</b> relations with <b>the kingdom,</b> would they be so stringent that the woman would be forced to <b>leave</b> her husband, <b>and</b> they would declare the status of <b>the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes. Rabbi Meir</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning. As Rav Hamnuna says in the name of Ulla: Rabbi Meir would say</b> that <b>anyone deviating from the formula coined by the Sages for bills of divorce,</b> even if it is only a minor deviation, the bill of divorce is invalid, and if the woman remarried on the basis of this bill of divorce, then <b>the offspring</b> from that marriage <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
It was stated in the mishna: If he wrote the date on a bill of divorce <b>in the name of the Greek Empire,</b> then the bill of divorce is invalid. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> and the other <i>halakhot</i> as well. <b>As, if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a kingdom that is not legitimate,</b> one could say that the bill of divorce is invalid <b>because</b> this kingdom is currently <b>ruling,</b> and the local government where he is writing the bill of divorce therefore objects to his writing the date of an another kingdom. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>the kingdom of Medea, and the Greek Empire,</b> it is not necessary to invalidate the bill of divorce, since <b>what was, was,</b> and since these kingdoms are no longer in power, the local government is not particular if they are mentioned in a document.
<b>And if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the kingdom of Medea and the Greek Empire,</b> one could understand the concern, <b>because they were kingdoms,</b> and the current government objects to another kingdom being mentioned in a document. <b>But</b> if he wrote the date counting to <b>the building of the Temple,</b> then one could say <b>what was, was,</b> and the local government is not particular if this is mentioned in a document. Consequently, it was necessary for the mishna to teach us this <i>halakha</i> as well.
<b>And if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the building of the Temple,</b> then one could say that the reason why this is problematic is because the governments <b>will say:</b> The Jews <b>mention their</b> own <b>praise,</b> instead of honoring the ruling government. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>the destruction of the Temple, which is a</b> cause of <b>anguish</b> for us, <b>say</b> that <b>no,</b> the government is not particular about this. Therefore it is <b>necessary</b> to mention all of these <i>halakhot</i>.
§ It was stated in the mishna, that if <b>he was in the east and he wrote</b> the location in the bill of divorce as <b>in the west,</b> then the bill of divorce is invalid. The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the mishna discussing? <b>If we say</b> that the place of the <b>husband</b> was changed, then <b>this is</b> the same as what is stated later on in the mishna: <b>He changed his name, or her name; the name of his city or the name of her city.</b>
<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>a scribe</b> who changed the place in which the bill of divorce was written, and did not record the correct location where he was when he wrote the bill of divorce? <b>As Rav said to his scribes, and similarly, Rav Huna said to his scribes: When you are situated in</b> the place called <b>Shili, write</b> the location of the document as: <b>In Shili, even though the matters were presented to you,</b> i.e., the transaction recorded in the document took place, <b>in</b> the place called <b>Hini. And when you are situated in</b> the place called <b>Hini, write: In Hini, even though the matters were presented to you in Shili.</b> One must be careful to write the precise location where the document was written and not somewhere else, as that is considered an illegitimate deviation.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b>

Daf 80b

<b>This</b> is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> who is particular about maintaining peaceful relations with the kingdom, with regard to bills of divorce. <b>But the Rabbis say: Even if he wrote</b> a date on the bill of divorce <b>only in the name of</b> the <b>guardsman [<i>santar</i>] in the city, she is divorced,</b> since it is irrelevant which calendrical system was used for the date.
It is related that there was <b>a certain bill of divorce in which</b> the date <b>was written in the name of the governor [<i>istandera</i>]</b> of the city <b>of Bascar,</b> i.e., the date was marked according to the years of his government. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda sent this</b> dilemma <b>before Rabba: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in <b>a case like this?</b>
<b>He sent him</b> in response: <b>With regard to this, even Rabbi Meir concedes</b> that the bill of divorce is valid. <b>What is the reason?</b> The governor <b>is</b> an official <b>from that kingdom,</b> so the ruler of the kingdom does not mind.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from the guardsman in the city?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There, it is demeaning for them</b> that the date is written in the name of an unimportant official. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the governor, <b>it is complimentary for them</b> that the date is written in the name of a senior official.
<b>Rabbi Abba says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: This</b> mishna is in accordance with <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> who is stringent with regard to this bill of divorce and holds that the child is a <i>mamzer</i>. <b>But the Rabbis say:</b> The lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed. And the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Meir, that if he changed his name or her name, the name of his city or the name of her city, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi says: We, too, learn</b> in the mishna: If <b>he changed his name or her name, the name of his city or the name of her city,</b> and she remarried on the basis of this bill of divorce, then <b>she</b> must <b>leave this</b> husband <b>and that</b> husband, <b>and all of those ways</b> of penalizing a woman who remarried based on the bills of divorce detailed in the earlier clause of the mishna apply <b>to her.</b>
It is necessary to clarify <b>who teaches this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>Rabbi Meir, let him combine</b> the case of one who writes a different kingdom, and the case of one who changes the names, <b>and teach them</b> both as one <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rather, conclude from it</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Conclude from it</b> that until this point the mishna was quoting the statement of Rabbi Meir, but subsequently it is the statement of the Rabbis that is quoted, that in a case of such a fundamental change, even in their opinion such a bill of divorce is invalid.
§ It was taught in the mishna that in <b>all</b> of those cases in <b>which they said</b> that a man who died and left behind a widow who is to the <i>yavam</i> one of <b>those with whom relations are forbidden,</b> and the rival wives were thought to be permitted to remarry, if it later became clear that the forbidden relation was an <i>ailonit</i> and therefore they were in fact forbidden from remarrying, then they must leave the man whom they remarried, and they cannot enter into levirate marriage with the <i>yavam</i>, and many other penalties apply to them as well. The Gemara comments: It is possible to deduce from the language used by the mishna that only if <b>they married</b> other men, then <b>yes,</b> these <i>halakhot</i> apply to them. But if the rival wives <b>engaged in licentious sexual intercourse,</b> then <b>no,</b> these <i>halakhot</i> do not apply to them.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that this is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Hamnuna, as Rav Hamnuna says: A widow awaiting her brother-in-law</b> to perform levirate marriage <b>who engaged in licentious sexual intercourse</b> is likened to a married woman who committed adultery, and <b>she is prohibited from</b> entering into levirate marriage with <b>her <i>yavam</i>.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> this is not a refutation, since it is possible to explain that the mishna gave the example that <b>they married, and the same is true in</b> a case where <b>they engaged in licentious sexual intercourse. And this that</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If <b>they married,</b> is because it <b>employed a euphemistic expression,</b> to refrain from discussing a case of licentiousness.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the exchange went as follows: From the mishna’s statement about the rival wives that remarried, one can understand, that the <i>halakha</i> is so if <b>they married, and the same is true in</b> a case where <b>they engaged in licentious sexual intercourse.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that it <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Hamnuna, as Rav Hamnuna says: A widow awaiting her brother-in-law</b> to perform levirate marriage <b>who engaged in licentious sexual intercourse is prohibited from</b> entering into levirate marriage with <b>her <i>yavam</i>.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is <b>specifically</b> when <b>they married</b> that they are forbidden, <b>because</b> she <b>is confused with a woman whose husband traveled to a country overseas</b> and she went and remarried. In that case she is certainly prohibited from marrying both the first and the second husband. Similarly, they instituted the same decree for a <i>yevama</i> who married someone else. By contrast, in the case of a <i>yevama</i> who engaged in licentious sexual intercourse, which is completely different, they did not institute this decree.
§ It was taught in the mishna that <b>one who marries his <i>yevama</i>,</b> and her rival wife went and married another man, and ultimately the <i>yevama</i> was found to be an <i>ailonit</i>, then the rival wife must leave her husband, and she cannot enter into levirate marriage with the <i>yavam</i>, and many other penalties apply to her as well. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> as well, although it seemingly deals with the same issue as the previous <i>halakha</i>. <b>As, if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to the first</b> case of a rival wife of a woman who is forbidden to the <i>yavam</i>, then one could say that the <i>halakha</i> is so, <b>because the mitzva of levirate marriage was not fulfilled</b> at all, since the rival wife married someone else, and the <i>yavam</i> did not perform levirate marriage.
<b>But here,</b> in this latter case, <b>where the mitzva of levirate marriage was fulfilled</b> in some way when he married the <i>yevama</i>, although ultimately it became clear that it was not a legitimate levirate marriage, <b>say</b> that the rival wives are <b>not</b> penalized, since she is not guilty by not having waited.
<b>And if</b> the mishna <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>here,</b> with regard to a <i>yavam</i> who married a <i>yevama</i> who was ultimately found to be an <i>ailonit</i>, then one could say that specifically here there is reason to penalize her, <b>because</b> this rival wife who remarried <b>was</b> also <b>placed before</b> the <i>yavam</i>, as he could have entered into levirate marriage with any of his brother’s wives. Therefore, she could have waited to see if the levirate marriage was effective before remarrying. <b>But there,</b> in the first case of a <i>yevama</i> who is forbidden to the <i>yavam</i>, <b>that she is not placed before him,</b> as all of them are entirely exempt from levirate marriage, <b>say</b> that the rival wives are <b>not</b> penalized. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state both <i>halakhot</i>.
§ It was taught in the mishna that if <b>the scribe wrote</b> a bill of divorce, <b>and erred and gave</b> the <b>bill of divorce to the woman and the receipt</b> to the man, and consequently the husband gave his wife a receipt and she gave him a bill of divorce, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If</b> the bill of divorce <b>is immediately in</b> the husband’s possession, it is not a valid bill of divorce. But if it is in his possession after some time, the assumption is that she was divorced in a correct manner and the bill of divorce was returned to him later.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in which the bill of divorce is <b>immediately</b> in the husband’s hand <b>and what are the circumstances</b> in which it is in his possession <b>after</b> some <b>time? Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: All</b> the <b>while that they are sitting and are engaged in the issue</b> of the divorce, <b>this is</b> considered <b>immediately.</b> If <b>they</b> already <b>arose</b> and concluded the proceedings, <b>this is</b> considered <b>after</b> some <b>time.</b>
<b>And Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> If <b>she was not married</b> to someone else, <b>this is</b> considered <b>immediately,</b> since they can rectify the situation by requiring him to give the bill of divorce properly. If <b>she was married, this is</b> considered <b>after</b> some <b>time.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna with regard to Rabbi Elazar’s statement: <b>It is not in the power of the first</b> husband <b>to eliminate the right of the second</b> husband. <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava, this</b> explanation <b>is</b> consistent with <b>that which is taught:</b> The <b>second</b> husband, since the mishna is discussing a case in which she remarried and has a second husband. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, what</b> is the reference to a <b>second</b> husband? Shmuel’s opinion is that as soon as they arise and conclude the proceedings, it is considered to be after some time, and in this case there is no second husband. According to Shmuel’s opinion, how does Rabbi Elazar’s statement apply?

Daf 81a

The Gemara answers: It is not referring to the right of a second man that she already married, but rather to <b>the right that is due</b> to a suitor who wishes to become her <b>second</b> husband, meaning that the first husband cannot eliminate the right of a second man who wishes to marry her.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one wrote</b> a bill of divorce <b>to divorce his wife, and reconsidered</b> and did not give it to her, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Although merely writing the bill of divorce does not dissolve the marriage, by doing so <b>he disqualified her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood. And Beit Hillel say: Even if he gave</b> the bill of divorce <b>to her conditionally and the condition was not fulfilled,</b> and therefore the bill of divorce did not take effect, <b>he did not disqualify her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b> A woman is disqualified from marrying into the priesthood only if the divorce takes effect.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yosef, son of Rav Menashe from Devil, sent</b> a query <b>to Shmuel: Our teacher, instruct us.</b> In the case of a priest <b>about whom</b> the following <b>rumor circulated: So-and-so</b> the <b>priest wrote a bill of divorce to his wife, but she is</b> still <b>residing under his</b> roof <b>and attending to him; what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Need one lend credence to this rumor?
Shmuel <b>sent</b> the following response <b>to him: She</b> must <b>leave</b> her husband; <b>but the matter requires investigation</b> before he is forced to divorce her. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the investigation that is required? <b>If we say that</b> the investigation is <b>whether we</b> can <b>abolish the rumor</b> that circulated, <b>or we cannot abolish</b> it; that cannot be the question: <b>But isn’t Neharde’a the place</b> where <b>Shmuel</b> is the halakhic authority and the rulings there are in accordance with his opinion, <b>and in Neharde’a they do not abolish a rumor? Rather,</b> the required investigation is to determine <b>whether</b> people in that place <b>refer to giving</b> a bill of divorce as <b>writing.</b> If that is the case, the rumor would be that he gave her a bill of divorce.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if they refer to giving</b> as <b>writing,</b> it proves nothing, as <b>don’t they refer to writing itself</b> as <b>writing?</b> Therefore, the fact that they refer to giving as writing does not mean that he gave the woman the bill of divorce. The same term would be employed even if he only wrote the bill of divorce.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as if it is discovered that they refer to giving</b> as <b>writing,</b> then there is reason to suspect that <b>perhaps they are saying</b> in the rumor <b>that he gave</b> her the bill of divorce, and there is concern that she is actually divorced.
Apropos Shmuel’s statement that she must leave his home, the Gemara asks: <b>She</b> must <b>leave? But doesn’t Rav Ashi say: We are not concerned for any rumor that</b> circulates <b>after marriage.</b> According to Rav Ashi, if a rumor circulates that a woman was betrothed to a man, there is concern about the rumor, and she is not allowed to marry someone else until she receives a bill of divorce from her rumored betrothed. But if such a rumor circulates after she has married someone else, there is no concern about such a rumor, and she is not obligated to leave her husband. Here too, in the case of this woman who is suspected of being divorced, she is currently living with her husband. Therefore, perhaps we should not be concerned about such a rumor.
The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is the meaning of Shmuel’s directive: <b>She</b> must <b>leave?</b> This <b>also</b> means that <b>she</b> must <b>leave the second</b> husband. If her first husband dies, and she marries another priest, she must leave him due to the rumor that circulated that her first husband gave her a bill of divorce.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, you cast aspersions on the children of the first</b> husband. If the reason that she must leave the second husband is because she is assumed to be a divorcée, this means that she remained with her first husband while she was already divorced, and the children they had after the rumor circulated would be disqualified from the priesthood. The Gemara answers: <b>Since we remove her</b> only <b>from the second</b> husband, <b>and we do not remove her from the first</b> husband, <b>they will come to</b> explain the incident by <b>saying</b> as follows: The first husband <b>divorced her proximate to</b> his <b>death,</b> and the children from him are of unflawed lineage. Since he divorced her, she may not marry another priest. Because the assumption here is that the divorce took place proximate to the first husband’s death, there is no concern of aspersions being cast on the children from the first husband.
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda bar Elai: Come and see that the later generations are unlike the earlier generations,</b> as the earlier generations were more conscientious about maintaining an unflawed lineage.
The Gemara explains: <b>The earlier generations</b> is referring to <b>Beit Shammai.</b> Beit Shammai were so careful about the sanctity of the priesthood that they said, as stated in the mishna, that the writing of a bill of divorce alone renders a priest’s wife forbidden to him. <b>The later generations</b> is referring to <b>Rabbi Dosa, as it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 3:6): A priest’s wife who was taken <b>captive</b> may <b>partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> and there is no concern that perhaps she was raped while in captivity and thereby became forbidden to her husband and disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Dosa.</b>
In explanation of this statement, <b>Rabbi Dosa says: And what did this Arab do to her</b> when he took her captive? <b>Because he fondled her breasts he disqualified her from the priesthood?</b> As long as it is not determined that her captors actually raped her, she is not prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i>. It is apparent from here that the later generations are more lenient than the early generations with regard to the sanctity of the priesthood.
<b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda bar Elai: Come and see that the later generations are unlike the earlier generations. The earlier generations</b> would <b>bring in their produce</b> from the field by <b>way</b> of the <b>main entranceway [<i>teraksemon</i>], in order to obligate</b> the produce <b>in tithes.</b> By contrast, <b>the later generations</b> would <b>bring in their produce</b> by <b>way</b> of <b>roofs and</b> by <b>way</b> of <b>enclosures, in order to exempt</b> the produce <b>from tithes.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>As Rabbi Yannai says: Untithed produce does not become obligated in tithes until it sees the entrance of the house,</b> through which people enter and exit, <b>as it is stated</b> in the declaration of the tithes: <b>“I have put away the hallowed things out of my house”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:13). As long as untithed produce is not taken into the house through the primary entrance of the house, it is permitted to eat it casually without tithing it. Consequently, they would take the produce in through another entrance in order to exempt it from tithes.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> with regard to this issue: <b>Even</b> entry into the <b>courtyard establishes</b> an obligation to tithe, <b>as it is stated: “That they may eat within your gates, and be satisfied”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:12). This indicates that once the produce is brought into the courtyard, it is obligated in tithes.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who divorces his wife, and</b> afterward <b>she spent the night with him at an inn [<i>befundaki</i>], Beit Shammai say: She does not require a second bill of divorce from him, and Beit Hillel say: She requires a second bill of divorce from him,</b> since they may have engaged in sexual intercourse at the inn and thereby betrothed her once again.
<b>When</b> did they say this <i>halakha</i>? <b>When she was divorced following</b> the state of <b>marriage.</b> Beit Hillel <b>concede that when she was divorced following</b> the state of <b>betrothal, she does not require a second bill of divorce from him, due to</b> the fact that <b>he is not accustomed to her.</b> Therefore, there is no concern that they engaged in sexual intercourse, even though they spent the night together at the inn.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel is specifically <b>in</b> a case <b>where they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse,</b>

Daf 81b

<b>as Beit Shammai hold: A person does</b> engage in <b>licentious sexual intercourse.</b> Although they were seen engaging in sexual intercourse, one cannot assume that he intended to betroth her, since they were recently divorced. The assumption is that they were simply engaging in licentious sexual intercourse. Consequently, he is not required to give her a second bill of divorce.
<b>And Beit Hillel hold: A person does not</b> engage in <b>licentious sexual intercourse.</b> Therefore, he had the intention to betroth her, and he must give her another bill of divorce. <b>But</b> if <b>they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse,</b> even though they spent the night together at an inn, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>she does not require a second bill of divorce from him,</b> as there is no concern that perhaps they engaged in sexual intercourse.
The Gemara challenges this understanding of the mishna: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that Beit Hillel <b>concede that when she was divorced following</b> the state of <b>betrothal, she does not require a second bill of divorce from him because he is not accustomed to her. And if</b> the mishna is referring to a case in <b>which they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse, what</b> is the difference <b>to me</b> if it was <b>following</b> the state of <b>betrothal and what</b> is the difference <b>to me</b> if it was <b>following</b> the state of <b>marriage?</b> In either case, they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse.
<b>Rather</b> it can be explained that <b>the mishna</b> is actually speaking about a case in <b>which they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse. Rabbi Yoḥanan stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance</b> with the statement of <b>that <i>tanna</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai did not disagree about</b> a case <b>where they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse.</b> Everyone agrees <b>that</b> in such a scenario, <b>she does not require a second bill of divorce from him.</b>
<b>With regard to what</b> case <b>did they disagree?</b> They disagreed <b>about</b> a case <b>where they saw that she engaged in sexual intercourse. As Beit Shammai say: A person does engage in licentious sexual intercourse. And Beit Hillel say: A person does not</b> engage in <b>licentious sexual intercourse.</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar disagrees with the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the mishna, which we established</b> as discussing a case in <b>which they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse, with regard to what do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: They disagree about a case in <b>which there are witnesses</b> to their <b>seclusion, but there are no witnesses</b> to an act of <b>sexual intercourse.</b>
With regard to such a case, <b>Beit Shammai hold: We do not say</b> that <b>these are the witnesses of seclusion, these are the witnesses of sexual intercourse.</b> According to Beit Shammai, although there are witnesses that they were secluded, this is not considered to be tantamount to testimony that they engaged in sexual intercourse. <b>And Beit Hillel hold: We</b> do <b>say</b> that <b>these are the witnesses of seclusion, these are the witnesses of sexual intercourse.</b> Since it is assumed that they engaged in sexual intercourse, she is required to obtain a second bill of divorce from him.
<b>And</b> Beit Hillel <b>concede that when she was divorced following</b> the state of <b>betrothal, she does not require a second bill of divorce from him,</b> even if they were alone together. <b>For since he is not accustomed to her, we do not say</b> that these are the witnesses of seclusion; <b>these are the witnesses of intercourse.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that Beit Hillel require a second bill of divorce only when witnesses saw that they engaged in sexual intercourse? <b>But didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> in all cases <b>is like an unattributed mishna. And we established the mishna</b> to be discussing a case in which <b>they did not see that she engaged in sexual intercourse.</b> How then does Rabbi Yoḥanan rule contrary to the mishna? The Gemara answers: <b>They are <i>amora’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> Some of them hold that Rabbi Yoḥanan does not always rule in accordance with an unattributed mishna.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a woman <b>was married</b> by her second husband <b>on the basis of</b> receiving <b>a bare bill of divorce,</b> i.e., a folded and tied bill of divorce that is missing signatures, <b>she</b> must <b>leave</b> both <b>this,</b> the first husband, <b>and that,</b> the second husband. <b>And all of those</b> previously mentioned <b>ways</b> of penalizing a woman who remarried based on the bills of divorce detailed in the earlier mishna (79b) apply <b>to her</b> in this case as well.
With regard to <b>a bare bill of divorce; anyone,</b> even those who are disqualified from bearing witness, <b>can complete it,</b> i.e., sign it in addition to the primary witnesses, so that it will not remain bare. This is <b>the statement of ben Nannas. Rabbi Akiva says: Not</b> all who are disqualified from bearing witness can <b>complete it. Rather, only relatives who are fit to testify in another case.</b> Rabbi Akiva permits only the inclusion of witnesses who would ordinarily be valid witnesses, but who are invalid here because they are relatives of either the husband and wife or the other witnesses.
<b>And what is a bare bill of divorce?</b> It is <b>any</b> bill of divorce <b>where</b> the number of <b>its folds</b> is <b>more than</b> the number of <b>its witnesses.</b> In a folded and tied bill of divorce, the bill of divorce is folded and the folds are then tied. Instead of having two witnesses sign at the bottom of the document, witnesses would sign on each tied fold. A bare bill of divorce has more folds than signatures, i.e., some folds lack signatures.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason that a bare bill of divorce</b> is not valid, considering that there are more than two witnesses signed on it? The Gemara answers: It is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that was issued <b>due to</b> one who says: <b>All of you</b> should sign. Since it can be assumed that one who writes a folded and tied bill of divorce wants to have each tied fold signed, there is concern that he may have instructed that all of them sign. If they do not sign, the condition is not fulfilled, and the bill of divorce is not valid.
§ It was stated in the mishna that ben Nannas holds, with regard to <b>a bare bill of divorce,</b> that <b>anyone can complete it.</b> Rabbi Akiva, however, permits disqualified witnesses to sign only if they are invalid because they are relatives of either the husband and wife or the other witnesses.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Akiva, what is the reason</b> that <b>a slave cannot</b> sign? The Gemara answers: The Sages were concerned <b>that</b> people <b>will</b> mistakenly <b>come to say</b> that since the slave served as a witness in this case, the slave is <b>fit to bear witness</b> in all cases. They will use a slave as a witness in situations that demand testimony accepted only from qualified witnesses. The Gemara challenges this: If so, with regard to <b>a relative, too, they will come to say</b> that a relative is <b>fit to bear witness</b> in all cases.
<b>Rather,</b> one could explain that with regard to <b>a slave, this is the reason</b> why he is disqualified: There is concern that <b>perhaps they will come to elevate</b> his status <b>with regard to lineage.</b> If a slave signs the bill of divorce, they might say that if he signed a bill of divorce, he must be an Israelite.
The Gemara asks: If this is the reason why a slave cannot sign, then <b>a robber, who is of</b> unflawed <b>lineage, should be fit</b> to complete the signatures of a folded and tied bill of divorce, according to Rabbi Akiva. <b>Why,</b> then, did <b>we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Not</b> all can <b>complete it. Rather, only relatives who are fit to testify in another case.</b> The Gemara deduces from this: <b>A relative, yes;</b> but <b>a robber, no.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, this is the reason</b> why <b>a slave</b> is disqualified: <b>They will come to say</b> that his master <b>emancipated him</b> and he signed because he is now like any other Israelite. Similarly, with regard to <b>a robber, they will also come to say</b> that <b>he repented</b> and will allow him to testify in other cases, as well. Therefore, Rabbi Akiva declared him to be unfit as well. With regard to <b>a relative, what can be said</b> to disallow him to sign this bill of divorce? With regard to <b>a relative, everyone knows that he is a relative,</b> and there is no concern that they will allow him to testify in other cases involving his relatives.
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rabba bar She’eilta says</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna the Elder says</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between <b>ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva</b> with regard to <b>a bare bill of divorce</b> that has more tied folds than witnesses is <b>only</b> in a case where <b>its ties</b> total <b>seven and its witnesses</b> total <b>six,</b> or its ties total <b>six and its witnesses</b> total <b>five,</b> or its ties total <b>five and its witnesses</b> total <b>four,</b> or its ties total <b>four and its witnesses</b> total <b>three.</b> But if <b>its ties</b> total <b>three and its witnesses</b> total <b>two, everyone,</b> even ben Nannas, <b>agrees</b> that <b>not</b> all disqualified witnesses can <b>complete it. Rather, only a relative</b> can complete it.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabba bar She’eilta: After all, all three</b> witnesses <b>in</b> a folded and <b>tied</b> bill of divorce are <b>like</b> the <b>two</b> witnesses <b>in an ordinary</b> bill of divorce, since the Sages said that a folded and tied bill of divorce requires at least three witnesses. Therefore, <b>just as there,</b> in the case of an ordinary bill of divorce, <b>a relative cannot</b> serve as one of the two witnesses, <b>so too here, a relative</b> should <b>not</b> serve as one of the primary witnesses.
Rabba bar She’eilta <b>said to him: To me as well</b> this was <b>difficult, and I asked that</b> question <b>to Rav Hamnuna, and Rav Hamnuna</b> asked it <b>to Rav Adda bar Ahava,</b> who had transmitted this statement, <b>and he said to him: Leave</b> the case of <b>three</b> witnesses <b>in a</b> folded and <b>tied</b> bill of divorce, <b>as</b> the requirement <b>is not by Torah law.</b> While the requirement to have a minimum of two witnesses in an ordinary bill of divorce is by Torah law, the requirement to have a minimum of three witnesses for a folded and tied bill of divorce is by rabbinic law. Consequently, it is of no concern if the third witness is not fit to bear witness.
The Gemara notes that <b>this is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:9): The <b>dispute</b> between <b>ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva</b> with regard to <b>a bare bill of divorce</b> that has more tied folds than witnesses is <b>only</b> in a case where <b>its ties</b> total <b>seven and its witnesses</b> total <b>six,</b> or its ties total <b>six and its witnesses</b> total <b>five,</b> or its ties total <b>five and its witnesses</b> total <b>four,</b> or its ties total <b>four and its witnesses</b> total <b>three.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If <b>a slave completed it</b> with his signature, and the woman remarried on the basis of this bill of divorce, <b>ben Nannas says: The offspring</b> of a subsequent marriage <b>is unflawed. And Rabbi Akiva says: The offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>. But</b> if <b>its ties</b> total <b>three, and its witnesses</b> total <b>two, everyone agrees</b> that <b>not</b> all disqualified witnesses can <b>complete it. Rather,</b> it can be completed <b>only</b> by <b>a relative</b> of either the husband and wife or the other witnesses.
<b>Rav Yosef taught:</b> Only <b>a valid</b> witness can complete it. The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A relative? Rav Pappa said:</b> Correct the language of the <i>baraita</i>, and <b>teach: Valid.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: In</b> a folded and tied bill of divorce, the Sages <b>validated only</b> the use of <b>one witness</b> who is <b>a relative,</b> to complete the number of signatures as per the number of knotted folds. <b>But two</b> such witnesses, <b>no,</b> they did not validate them. The reason for this is that <b>perhaps they will come to ratify</b> a bill of divorce <b>with two</b> witnesses who are <b>relatives and one</b> witness who is <b>valid.</b> If the bill of divorce will be challenged, it will be necessary to ratify the document. While this bill of divorce has more than three witnesses signed to it, the court needs to authenticate the signature of only three of the witnesses to ratify the bill of divorce, provided that two of them are not relatives. If there are more than two relatives signed on the bill of divorce, a court may unintentionally authenticate the signatures of two relatives and only one valid witness.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of <b>the <i>baraita</i> is also precise,</b> in accordance with this opinion,

Daf 82a

<b>as it teaches</b> by <b>skipping one</b> by <b>one.</b> The examples given relate to one witness missing, e.g., seven ties and six witnesses, and so on. They do not include a case in which two witnesses are missing, e.g., seven ties and five witnesses. This indicates that the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and Ben Azzai is only with regard to the signature of one witness. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from it</b> that this is so.
<b>Abaye said: Learn from it</b> that <b>this relative,</b> who is allowed to sign a folded and tied bill of divorce, can <b>sign if he wants</b> to sign, <b>either at the beginning,</b> as the first signature, <b>in the middle, or at the end.</b>
<b>From where</b> does Abaye infer this? <b>From</b> the fact that <b>it did not designate a place for him</b> to sign. <b>And learn from it,</b> as well, that <b>from any three</b> of the witnesses who signed on a folded and tied bill of divorce, <b>we</b> can <b>ratify</b> the bill of divorce, i.e., it can be ratified based on their signatures. <b>And we do not need</b> to confirm the signatures specifically of three <b>consecutive</b> witnesses.
<b>As if it enters your mind</b> that <b>we need consecutive</b> witnesses, then <b>they should designate a place for this relative</b> to sign, <b>in the beginning, or in the middle, or at the end, and they should</b> then <b>validate</b> the use of <b>many</b> disqualified witnesses. It could have been instituted that every third witness may be disqualified. Since in any group of three witnesses, two of them would be valid, more than one disqualified witness could be allowed. Since it is possible to ratify a bill of divorce by confirming signatures that are not consecutive, and therefore there is concern that the court will rely on two disqualified witnesses, the Sages consequently allowed the use of only one disqualified witness.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> concerning the dispute in the mishna, it is related that <b>when they came before Rabbi Ami</b> with a question pertaining to a bare bill of divorce that needed more witnesses, <b>he said to</b> the person overseeing: <b>Go out and complete it</b> even with <b>a slave from the</b> general <b>public,</b> in accordance with the opinion of ben Nannas.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who divorces his wife and said to her</b> while handing her the bill of divorce: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man except [<i>ella</i>] for so-and-so, Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> her to remarry based on this divorce. <b>And the Rabbis prohibit</b> her from remarrying, as their bond is not entirely severed by this divorce, and she is therefore still considered his wife. <b>What should he do</b> so the divorce may take effect? <b>He should take it from her and hand it to her again, and</b> he should <b>say to her: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man.</b> If <b>he wrote</b> his qualification <b>inside</b> the bill of divorce, <b>even if he then erased it,</b> the bill <b>is invalid</b> since it was not written in a valid manner.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: What is the meaning of <b>this</b> word <b><i>ella</i></b> in the husband’s statement? Does <b>it</b> mean <b>except,</b> i.e., the husband intended to divorce his wife in a manner that would render her permitted to marry only a limited group of men? <b>Or</b> does <b>it</b> mean: <b>On the condition,</b> i.e., the husband intended to grant her full divorce on the condition that she would not marry so-and-so?
The Gemara elaborates on how this dilemma affects the understanding of the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis: Does <i>ella</i> mean <b>except, and</b> therefore <b>it is</b> specifically <b>with regard to</b> the <b>exception</b> of a certain man from the intended divorce <b>that the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer</b> and hold that the divorce is invalid? This would be <b>because</b> in a case where the husband noted an exception, it is as if he <b>left out</b> part <b>of her bill of divorce;</b> since she is not permitted to remarry anyone she wishes it does not entirely sever the bond between them. <b>But with regard to</b> divorce <b>on the condition</b> that she will not marry a certain man the Rabbis <b>agree with</b> Rabbi Eliezer that it is valid, <b>just as is</b> the case <b>with regard to any typical condition</b> which the husband attaches to the divorce of his wife.
<b>Or perhaps</b> this <b>is</b> the meaning of <i>ella</i>: <b>On the condition?</b> Accordingly, <b>it is</b> specifically <b>with regard to</b> divorce <b>on the condition</b> that the wife will not marry a certain man <b>that Rabbi Eliezer disagrees with the Rabbis</b> and allows her to remarry based on this divorce; <b>but with regard to</b> the <b>exception</b> of a certain man from the woman’s right to remarry <b>he concedes</b> that the divorce is invalid <b>as</b> the husband <b>left out</b> part <b>of her bill of divorce.</b>
<b>Ravina said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this dilemma from the following mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 12:1): <b>All houses become ritually impure through leprous sores</b> of the house <b>except [<i>ella</i>] for</b> those <b>belonging to gentiles. Granted, if you say</b> that the meaning of the word <i>ella</i> <b>is except,</b> this mishna is <b>well</b> understood. <b>But if you say</b> that its meaning <b>is on the condition,</b> the resulting interpretation of this mishna is that the <b>houses of Jews become impure only on the condition that</b> the <b>houses of gentiles do not become impure; consequently,</b> if the <b>houses of gentiles become impure,</b> the <b>houses of Jews do not become impure.</b> Does this interpretation make any sense?
<b>Moreover,</b> an objection against this interpretation may be raised as follows: <b>Do</b> the <b>houses of gentiles become ritually impure</b> at all? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that from the verse: <b>“And I put the plague of leprosy in a house of the land of your possession”</b> (Leviticus 14:34), it is derived that only <b>the land of your possession,</b> i.e., the houses of Jews, <b>becomes impure through leprous sores</b> of the house, <b>but</b> the <b>houses of gentiles do not become impure through leprosy? Rather, conclude from</b> the mishna that the meaning of <i>ella</i> <b>is except.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Conclude from it</b> that <i>ella</i> means except.
According to this conclusion, <b>our mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis did not disagree with regard to one who divorces his wife and said to her</b> while handing her the bill of divorce: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man except for so-and-so;</b> rather, they were in agreement <b>that</b> in that case <b>she is not divorced. With regard to what</b> case <b>did they disagree?</b> It was <b>with regard to one who divorces his wife and said to her: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man on the condition that you will not marry so-and-so,</b>

Daf 82b

<b>as</b> in this case <b>Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> her <b>to</b> marry <b>any man except for that man</b> about whom the condition was made, <b>and the Rabbis prohibit</b> her from remarrying, as in their opinion this divorce is not valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning behind Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion as cited in the <i>baraita</i>? The Gemara answers: The ruling here is <b>just as it is with regard to any typical condition.</b> The husband has the right to attach conditions to the divorce. <b>And</b> how would <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this reasoning? They would reason that by attaching <b>any typical condition</b> the husband <b>did not leave out</b> part <b>of the bill of divorce,</b> as it does not diminish the essential act of severance. By contrast, <b>here he left out</b> part <b>of the bill of divorce,</b> as she is not permitted to marry any man she wishes. Therefore, the divorce is invalid.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the mishna, which we established as</b> referring to a case of <b>exception, what is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion that the divorce takes effect, despite its lack of complete severance?
<b>Rabbi Yannai said in the name of one elder</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to divorce: <b>“And she departs out of his house, and goes and becomes another man’s wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:2), indicating that <b>even</b> if he divorced her in a manner that <b>only permitted her to</b> marry one <b>other man, she is divorced,</b> i.e., this partial severance takes effect. <b>And the Rabbis would say</b> in response to <b>Rabbi Eliezer’s explanation</b> that <b>this</b> phrase: Another <b>man,</b> which appears in the verse refers not to a specific man but <b>to any man,</b> i.e., it must be permitted for her to marry any man for the divorce to take effect.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion <b>is from</b> the verse <b>here,</b> where it is stated with regard to priests: <b>“Neither may they take a woman divorced from her husband”</b> (Leviticus 21:7). This verse indicates that <b>even</b> if <b>she was divorced only from her husband,</b> and was not permitted to marry others, <b>she is disqualified from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood</b> as a divorcée, i.e., she may not marry a priest even after her husband’s death. <b>Apparently,</b> all the more so, divorce that excludes certain men from the wife’s right to remarry <b>is</b> considered a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This is certainly the case when the divorce permits her to marry all men with the exception of one.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> would respond that <b>the prohibition</b> against marrying into the <b>priesthood is different,</b> as even a divorce that is otherwise invalid disqualifies a woman from marrying a priest.
§ <b>Rabbi Abba raises a dilemma:</b> If this kind of exception is made <b>in</b> a case of <b>betrothal,</b> i.e., the man says to the woman that she is hereby forbidden to all men except for so-and-so, <b>how</b> is this betrothal treated? The Gemara elaborates: <b>Let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> and <b>let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>Let the dilemma be raised according to Rabbi Eliezer:</b> Is <b>Rabbi Eliezer saying only here</b> that the divorce is valid <b>because verses are written</b> that support this proposition, as delineated by Rabbi Yannai and Rabbi Yoḥanan; <b>but there,</b> in the case of betrothal, <b>a proper acquisition is necessary,</b> which is not the case when a certain man is excluded from the prohibition to engage in sexual intercourse with her? <b>Or</b> should it <b>perhaps</b> be derived from the juxtaposition between the clause: <b>“And she departs</b> out of his house,” and the clause: <b>“And becomes</b> another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2), which serves as a basis for the comparison of the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce and betrothal, teaching that just as divorce takes effect in this manner, so does betrothal?
<b>Let the dilemma be raised according to the Rabbis:</b> Are <b>the Rabbis saying here</b> that the divorce is invalid <b>only because</b> the <b>severance</b> of the bond between the husband and wife <b>is necessary</b> for the divorce to take effect, <b>and there is no</b> such severance as long as the woman may not marry any man she wishes; <b>but there,</b> in the case of betrothal, <b>any</b> form of <b>acquisition</b> is sufficient for it to take effect? <b>Or</b> should it <b>perhaps</b> be derived from the juxtaposition between the clause beginning: <b>“And she departs,”</b> and the clause beginning: <b>“And becomes,”</b> that what renders a divorce invalid renders a betrothal invalid as well?
<b>After</b> Rabbi Abba <b>raised the dilemma he then resolved it</b> in the following manner: <b>Both according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer and according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis it is necessary</b> to compare the <i>halakha</i> in the case of betrothal to the ruling with regard to divorce, based on the juxtaposition between <b>“And she departs”</b> and: <b>“And becomes.”</b> Therefore, the dispute remains in this case as well.
<b>Abaye said: If you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba’s</b> solution <b>is so,</b> i.e., if you say that Rabbi Eliezer holds that making an exception in a betrothal is valid, the issue of levirate marriage in such cases must be addressed.
If <b>Reuven came</b> to a woman <b>and betrothed her</b> saying that she is forbidden to all men <b>except for</b> his brother <b>Shimon, and Shimon</b> then <b>came and betrothed her</b> saying that she is forbidden to all men <b>except for Reuven, and they both died</b> without children, in this case <b>she performs levirate marriage with</b> their brother <b>Levi, and I do not call her the wife of two dead men.</b> It is stated in tractate <i>Yevamot</i> (31b) that if a woman has a levirate bond with a man due to her two late husbands who were his brothers, she may not perform levirate marriage with him, as it is derived from the verse: “The wife of the dead man shall not be married outside of the family” (Deuteronomy 25:5), that the wife of only one dead man performs levirate marriage, not the wife of two. Abaye stated that in the case under discussion the woman may perform levirate marriage with Levi.
<b>What is the reason</b> that she is not considered to be the wife of two dead men? It is that although her <b>betrothal to Reuven was effective,</b> i.e., it took effect, her <b>betrothal to Shimon was not effective,</b> as it did not render her forbidden to any man to whom she was not already forbidden due to her betrothal to Reuven. Therefore, she is considered only Reuven’s wife.
<b>Rather, under what circumstances is</b> the case of <b>a wife of two dead men found</b> in this context? It is found in a case <b>where Reuven came and betrothed her,</b> saying that she is hereby forbidden to all men <b>except for Shimon, and Shimon</b> then <b>came and betrothed her without specifying</b> any qualifications. <b>Since Reuven’s betrothal was effective in rendering her forbidden to everyone</b> except for Shimon, <b>and Shimon’s betrothal was effective in rendering her forbidden to Reuven,</b> the betrothal of both brothers took effect. And if both of them die she may not perform levirate marriage with Levi, as she is the wife of two dead men.
<b>Abaye raises a dilemma:</b> If a man <b>said to</b> his wife while handing her a bill of divorce: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man except for Reuven and Shimon, and he then said to her:</b> You are permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Reuven and Shimon, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Do we say</b> that <b>what he forbade</b> initially <b>he</b> then <b>permitted,</b> enabling her to marry anyone, including Reuven and Shimon, in which case the severance is complete? <b>Or perhaps what he forbade</b> initially <b>he</b> then <b>permitted,</b> permitting her to marry Reuven and Shimon, <b>and what he permitted</b> initially <b>he</b> then <b>forbade,</b> i.e., he permitted her only to Reuven and Shimon, excluding all other men? <b>If you say</b>

Daf 83a

that <b>what he</b> initially <b>forbade he</b> then <b>permitted,</b> enabling her to marry anyone she wishes, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he said the second time that she is permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Reuven?</b> Did he mean that she is permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Reuven and the same is true</b> with regard <b>to Shimon,</b> i.e., she is permitted to marry him as well? Is the fact <b>that he mentioned</b> only that she is permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Reuven because he opened</b> his prior qualification <b>by</b> mentioning <b>him</b> before he mentioned Shimon, but he intended to permit her to marry Shimon as well? <b>Or</b> did he, <b>perhaps, specifically</b> intend to permit her <b>to</b> marry <b>Reuven?</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that he intended to permit her <b>to</b> marry <b>specifically Reuven</b> and not Shimon, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he said that she is permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Shimon?</b> Did he mean that she is permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Shimon and the same is true</b> with regard <b>to Reuven, and</b> the fact <b>that he mentioned</b> only <b>Shimon is because he ended</b> his initial previous statement <b>by</b> mentioning <b>him? Or perhaps</b> he was <b>specifically</b> referring only <b>to Shimon?</b>
<b>Rav Ashi raises</b> another <b>dilemma</b> with regard to the same case: If he said to her the second time: You are <b>also</b> permitted <b>to</b> marry <b>Shimon, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the word <b>also referring to Reuven,</b> i.e., she is permitted to marry Shimon in addition to Reuven, <b>or perhaps</b> it is <b>also referring to everyone,</b> i.e., she is permitted to marry Shimon in addition to all men, but not Reuven? The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 9:1): <b>After the death of Rabbi Eliezer, four Sages entered</b> the discussion <b>to refute his statement. They were: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, Rabbi Tarfon, Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, and Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Tarfon responded</b> to Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, <b>saying:</b> If after the husband stipulated that the wife not marry a certain man <b>she went and married the brother of the one to whom she was prohibited</b> from marrying, <b>and</b> this husband <b>died without children,</b> she cannot perform levirate marriage with her husband’s brother, because he is forbidden to her due to the stipulation of her first husband. <b>Is</b> the first husband <b>not found</b> to be <b>uprooting a matter of Torah law</b> through his stipulation? <b>You have therefore derived that this is not</b> an act of <b>severance.</b> The divorce is not valid, as the Torah would not sanction a manner of divorce that can cause a mitzva to be nullified.
<b>Rabbi Yosei</b> also <b>responded</b> to Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, <b>saying: Where do we find</b> an example of something that is <b>forbidden to this</b> person <b>and permitted to that</b> other person? <b>What is forbidden is forbidden to everyone, and what is permitted is permitted to everyone.</b> This contradicts Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion that a divorcée can be prohibited from marrying a certain man and permitted to marry all other men. <b>You have therefore derived that this is not</b> an act of <b>severance.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya responded, saying:</b> What is the meaning of the expression: “Scroll of <b>severance,”</b> which is used in the Torah for a bill of divorce? It means <b>something that severs</b> the bond <b>between him and her</b> entirely. This woman, by contrast, is still bound to her husband after their divorce, as his stipulation prevents her from marrying a certain man. <b>You have therefore derived that this is not</b> an act of <b>severance.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva responded, saying:</b> If after the husband stipulated that the wife not marry a certain man <b>she went and married a man from the</b> general <b>public, and she had children</b> with him, <b>and she was</b> subsequently <b>widowed or divorced</b> from the second husband, <b>and she</b> then <b>arose and married the one to whom she was forbidden</b> by her first husband’s condition, <b>isn’t the bill of divorce</b> thereby <b>found</b> to be <b>nullified? And</b> would this not render <b>her children</b> from her second marriage as <b>born from an adulterous relationship [<i>mamzerim</i>],</b> as she is retroactively considered her first husband’s wife? <b>You have therefore derived that this is not</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as the Torah would not enable a divorce that could lead to such a situation.
Rabbi Akiva continued to offer <b>an alternative</b> refutation of Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion: If <b>the one to whom she was forbidden was a priest, and</b> her ex-husband <b>who divorced</b> her <b>died, is she not</b> thereby <b>found</b> to be <b>a widow with regard to him,</b> as she was considered a married woman with regard to this priest even after her divorce, <b>and a divorcée with regard to any</b> other <b>man?</b> Nevertheless, she is forbidden to him too, just as she is forbidden to any other priest.
<b>And</b> it is therefore <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that <b>just as</b> the prohibition for <b>a divorcée</b> to marry a priest (see Leviticus 21:14) <b>is</b> a relatively <b>minor</b> prohibition, yet <b>she is forbidden</b> to this priest <b>due to the element of divorce that applies to her,</b> even though with regard to him she is not a divorcée but a widow, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that the prohibition against sexual intercourse with <b>a married woman, which is a major</b> prohibition, should apply to every man during the lifetime of the ex-husband, due to the fact that she is considered a married woman with regard to this one man? <b>You have therefore derived that this is not</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as this divorce does not permit her to marry any man.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to them:</b> Even though your objections are valid, <b>one does not refute</b> the opinion of <b>a lion after</b> his <b>death.</b> After a Sage has passed away one cannot reject his opinion based on a difficulty with it, as he possibly would have provided an answer had it been presented to him while he was still alive.
<b>Rava said: All of</b> the previously mentioned responses <b>have refutations</b> that can be raised against them <b>except for</b> the response <b>of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, which does not have a refutation.</b> The Gemara notes that <b>this is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, as <b>Rabbi Yosei said: I see the statement of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya</b> as preferable <b>to the statements of all</b> the other Sages.
The Gemara commences discussion of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said</b> that <b>Rabbi Tarfon responded, saying:</b> If <b>she went and married the brother of the one to whom she was prohibited</b> from marrying, <b>and he died without children, is</b> the first husband <b>not</b> thereby <b>found</b> to be <b>uprooting a matter of Torah law?</b> The Gemara asks: What is the meaning of the question: Is the first husband not <b>uprooting</b> a matter of Torah law? Is it <b>he</b> who <b>is uprooting</b> the mitzva? <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Tarfon means that the husband <b>is stipulating to uproot a matter of Torah law.</b>
The Gemara questions this assertion as well: Is the husband <b>stipulating</b> to uproot a mitzva? <b>Did he say to her</b> that <b>it is not sufficient if she does not marry the brother of that man,</b> who he rendered forbidden to her? Since he did not stipulate this, he did not uproot the mitzva; it is the woman who uprooted the mitzva by marrying specifically that man’s brother. <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Tarfon means that the husband <b>is causing a matter of Torah law to be uprooted.</b>
The Gemara asks: He <b>is causing</b> of matter of Torah law to be uprooted? <b>But if that is so,</b> one <b>should not marry his brother’s daughter lest he die without children, and he will</b> thereby <b>be found</b> to be <b>causing a matter of Torah law to be uprooted</b> in that his brother will not be able to perform levirate marriage with his own daughter, and the Sages laud one who marries his brother’s daughter. The Gemara responds: <b>This is the refutation</b> against Rabbi Tarfon’s response that Rava was referring to.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to what</b> case did Rabbi Tarfon refute Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>with regard to</b> a case in which the husband said that his wife is permitted to marry any man <b>except</b> for so-and-so, the refutation is irrelevant, as <b>Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> the woman to marry this man after she married another man.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 9:1): <b>With regard to</b> a case where a man <b>divorces his wife and said to her</b> while handing her the bill of divorce: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man except for so-and-so, and she went and married someone from the</b> general <b>public and was</b> subsequently <b>widowed or divorced</b> from him, <b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes that she is</b> now <b>permitted to</b> marry the man <b>whom she was</b> initially <b>prohibited</b> from marrying by the qualification of her first husband.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Tarfon’s refutation was clearly stated <b>with regard to</b> a case where the woman was divorced <b>on the condition</b> that she would not marry so-and-so. A condition still applies after the woman remarries and its violation nullifies the divorce retroactively.
The <i>baraita</i> states that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili responded, saying: Where do we find</b> an example of something that is <b>forbidden to this</b> person <b>and permitted to that</b> other person? <b>What is forbidden is forbidden to everyone and what is permitted is permitted to everyone.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is</b> there <b>not</b> such an example? <b>Aren’t <i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of the produce designated for the priest, <b>and sacrificial</b> meat <b>forbidden to this</b> group, i.e., non-priests (see Leviticus 22:10), <b>and permitted to that</b> group, i.e., priests? The Gemara answers: <b>We are referring to a forbidden woman.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Aren’t those</b> women <b>with whom relations are prohibited</b> due to familial ties forbidden to some men, i.e., their relatives, and permitted to others? The Gemara answers: <b>We are referring to</b> a woman who is forbidden due to <b>marriage.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t a married woman</b> forbidden to all men but permitted to her husband? The Gemara responds: <b>This is the refutation</b> against Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s response that Rava was referring to.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And with regard to what</b> case did Rabbi Yosei HaGelili raise this objection? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>with regard to</b> a case in which the divorce was granted <b>on the condition</b> that she not marry a certain man, she is not entirely forbidden to him, as <b>she is permitted</b> to engage <b>in licentiousness with him;</b> the condition was with regard to marriage, not licentiousness. <b>Rather,</b> he clearly raised the objection <b>with regard to</b> a case where the husband told his wife that she is permitted to marry any man <b>except</b> for so-and-so, rendering her entirely forbidden to that man.
The <i>baraita</i> states that <b>Rabbi Akiva responded, saying:</b> If <b>she went and married a man from the</b> general <b>public, and she had children</b> with him, <b>and she was</b> subsequently <b>widowed or divorced</b> from this second husband, <b>and she</b> then <b>arose and married the one to whom she was forbidden, isn’t the bill of divorce</b> thereby <b>nullified? And</b> would this not render <b>her children <i>mamzerim</i>?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> and there is a concern that she will eventually violate the condition, <b>in</b> a case of <b>any typical condition</b> that the husband attaches to the divorce <b>she should not remarry either, lest she not fulfill his condition and the bill of divorce</b> be <b>found</b> to be <b>nullified and her children</b> be rendered <b><i>mamzerim</i>.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>This is the refutation</b> against Rabbi Akiva’s response that Rava was referring to.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to what</b> case did Rabbi Akiva raise this objection? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>with regard to</b> a case in which the husband said that his wife is permitted to marry any man <b>except</b> for so-and-so, the objection is irrelevant, as <b>Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> the woman to marry so-and-so after she marries another man.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to</b> a case where a man <b>divorces his wife and said to her: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man except for so-and-so, and she went and married someone from the</b> general <b>public, and was</b> subsequently <b>widowed or divorced</b> from him, <b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes that she is</b> now <b>permitted to</b> marry the man <b>whom she was</b> initially <b>prohibited</b> from marrying. <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Akiva’s objection was clearly <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>a condition</b> that she would not marry so-and-so.
The <i>baraita</i> states that Rabbi Akiva added <b>an alternative</b> response: If <b>the one to whom she was forbidden was a priest, and</b> her ex-husband <b>who divorced</b> her <b>died, is she not found</b> to be <b>a widow with regard to him and a divorcée with regard to any</b> other <b>man? And</b> it is therefore <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that <b>just as</b> the prohibition against <b>a divorcée</b> marrying a priest <b>is minor,</b> and yet <b>she is forbidden</b> to this priest <b>due to the element of divorce that applies to her, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that the prohibition against relations with <b>a married woman, which is major,</b> should apply to every man during the lifetime of the ex-husband, due to the fact that she is considered a married woman with regard to this one man? Therefore, the divorce does not take effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to what</b> case was this objection raised? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>a condition,</b>

Daf 83b

<b>isn’t</b> the woman <b>a divorcée with regard to</b> engaging in <b>licentious</b> behavior <b>with him?</b> The husband stipulated that she not marry that man, but he did not prohibit her from engaging in licentious behavior with him. Therefore, she is considered a divorcée with regard to him as well. This removes the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as with regard to all other men she is not considered married at all. <b>Rather,</b> the objection was clearly raised <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>exception.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that Rabbi Eliezer is referring to a case of <b>an exception, he should raise an objection</b> with regard to <b>an exception, and if he holds</b> that Rabbi Eliezer is referring to a case of <b>a stipulation, he should raise an objection</b> with regard to a case of <b>a stipulation.</b> Why does he raise one objection with regard to an exception and then another with regard to a stipulation?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Akiva heard that there is</b> someone <b>who states</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling with regard to <b>an exception, and there is</b> someone else <b>who states</b> it with regard to <b>a stipulation.</b> He therefore raised objections with regard to both exceptions and stipulations; according to <b>the one who says</b> that it is with regard to <b>an exception, this is the refutation, and</b> according to <b>the one who says</b> that it is with regard to <b>a stipulation, that is the refutation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the refutation</b> that Rava found for Rabbi Akiva’s second objection? <b>If we say</b> that it is that <b>the prohibition</b> against marrying into the <b>priesthood is different,</b> and therefore the <i>halakhot</i> of adultery and divorce cannot be inferred from it, <b>doesn’t Rabbi Eliezer also derive</b> his opinion <b>from the prohibition</b> against marrying into <b>the priesthood?</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan stated (82b) that Rabbi Eliezer’s ruling is derived from the verse that states with regard to priests: “Neither may they take a woman divorced from her husband” (Leviticus 21:7), indicating that even if a woman was divorced only from her husband and was not permitted to marry others, she is disqualified from marrying into the priesthood as a divorcée.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rava taught</b> his statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yannai,</b> who said <b>in the name of one elder</b> that Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion is derived not from the prohibition against marrying into the priesthood, but from the verse: “And she departs out of his house, and goes and becomes another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2), which indicates that even if he divorced her in a manner that permitted her to marry only one other man, the divorce takes effect. Therefore, Rava refutes Rabbi Akiva’s latter objection by claiming that the prohibition against marrying into the priesthood is different from other prohibitions and cannot be compared to them.
It is stated in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: One does not refute</b> the opinion of <b>a lion after</b> his <b>death.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that Rabbi Yehoshua holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer? <b>But doesn’t he also raise a refutation</b> against Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion?
The Gemara answers that <b>this is what he was saying to them: I also have a refutation</b> against Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, <b>but both my</b> objection <b>and yours</b> should not be raised, as <b>one does not refute</b> the opinion of <b>a lion after</b> his <b>death.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is Rabbi Yehoshua’s refutation?</b> It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said</b> that the passage: “When a man takes a wife, and marries her, and it comes to pass, if she finds no favor in his eyes, because he has found some unseemly matter in her, and he writes her a scroll of severance, and gives it in her hand, and sends her out of his house; and she departs out of his house, and goes and becomes another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:1–2), <b>juxtaposes</b> the woman’s status <b>before the second marriage to</b> her status <b>before the first marriage.</b> It should be derived from here that <b>just as before the first marriage she is not bound to another man, so too, before the second marriage she is not bound to another man.</b> Therefore, a woman cannot remarry if she is still bound to her ex-husband due to a qualification that prohibits her from marrying a certain man.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> that was mentioned above in passing: <b>With regard to</b> a case where a man <b>divorces his wife and said to her: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man except for so-and-so, and she went and married someone from the</b> general <b>public and was</b> subsequently <b>widowed or divorced</b> from him, <b>Rabbi Eliezer concedes that she is</b> now <b>permitted to</b> marry the man <b>whom she was</b> initially <b>prohibited</b> from marrying.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Shimon bar Elazar raised a refutation to Rabbi Eliezer’s statement: Where do we find</b> a situation <b>where this</b> person <b>prohibits</b> something <b>and that</b> other person <b>permits</b> it? How can the first husband render the woman prohibited from marrying a certain man and her second husband render her permitted to do so after his death or their divorce?
The Gemara questions this refutation: Is there <b>not</b> such a situation? <b>But isn’t</b> there the case of <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> a woman <b>whose husband</b> dies childless, and he <b>deems</b> her <b>forbidden</b> to other men while she waits for his brother, her <i>yavam</i>, to perform levirate marriage with her, <b>and</b> the <b><i>yavam</i>,</b> after performing levirate marriage with her, <b>deems</b> her <b>permitted</b> in the event of divorce or his death?
The Gemara answers: <b>There, it is the <i>yavam</i> who renders her forbidden, since if</b> not for the <i>yavam</i>, i.e., if her deceased husband did not have any brothers, <b>she would have already been released from</b> her bond to her <b>husband</b> and permitted to marry any man. It is only the existence of the <i>yavam</i> that prevents her from marrying other men. Therefore, it is he who renders her permitted.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> there the matter of <b>vows, where</b> the <b>one who takes the vow prohibits</b> something <b>and a halakhic authority renders</b> it <b>permitted</b> by dissolving the vow? The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>a halakhic authority dissolves</b> a vow <b>only through regret</b> of the person who took the vow. Since it is necessary for this person to express regret for taking the vow, it is not actually the halakhic authority who causes the dissolution of the vow.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> there <b>the nullification of</b> a wife’s vows by <b>the husband, where</b> the <b>wife vows,</b> creating a prohibition, <b>and</b> her <b>husband nullifies</b> the vow? The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> it can be explained <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Pineḥas</b> reasoned <b>in the name of Rava, as Rav Pineḥas says in the name of Rava</b> that with regard to <b>any woman who takes a vow,</b> it is from the outset contingent <b>on her husband’s consent</b> that <b>she takes the vow.</b> Therefore, the husband can nullify it.
§ The Gemara resumes discussion of the previous <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya responded, saying:</b> What is the meaning of the expression: “Scroll of <b>severance [<i>keritut</i>],”</b> that is used in the Torah for a bill of divorce? It means <b>something that severs</b> the bond <b>between him and her</b> entirely. <b>You have therefore derived that this</b> divorce, after which the wife is still bound to her husband due to his qualification, <b>is not</b> an act of <b>severance.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what do the</b> other <b>Rabbis,</b> who did not refute Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion in this manner, <b>do with this</b> term <b>“severance”?</b> How do they interpret it? The Gemara answers: <b>They need it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will not</b> ever <b>drink wine,</b> or: <b>On the condition that you will never go to your father’s house, that is not</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as she remains restricted by him indefinitely. If he stipulates that she may not do so for <b>thirty days, that is</b> an act of <b>severance.</b> The Rabbis derive from the term severance that any indefinite condition prevents the divorce from taking effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, derive this principle? The Gemara answers: <b>It is derived from</b> the fact that the verse does not utilize the basic form of the word severance, i.e., <b><i>karet</i>,</b> but rather its conjugate, <b><i>keritut</i>.</b> This indicates an additional principle that is derived from the term. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the other</b> Sages derive from the seemingly superfluous use of this word? The Gemara answers: <b>They do not interpret</b> the distinction between <b><i>karet</i></b> and <b><i>keritut</i>.</b>
§ <b>Rava says</b> that if a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will not drink wine</b> for <b>all the days of my life, that is not</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as she remains bound to his condition for the rest of his life. If he stipulates that she may not drink wine for <b>all the days of the life of so-and-so, that is</b> an act of <b>severance.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about the case where he mentioned <b>the life of so-and-so?</b> Is it <b>because perhaps</b> that person <b>will die and she will</b> thereby <b>fulfill the condition,</b> allowing her to remarry? With regard to <b>his own life</b> it is <b>also</b> true that <b>perhaps he will die and she will</b> thereby <b>fulfill the condition.</b> Why is the divorce invalid in that case?
<b>Rather, say</b> that if the husband tells her: This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will not drink wine for <b>all the days of your life, that is not</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as the wife will never be released from this restriction. If he says: For <b>all the days of my life, or:</b> For all the days of <b>so-and-so’s life, that is</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as the condition can potentially be fulfilled during her lifetime.
§ <b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> If a man hands his wife a bill of divorce and says to her: <b>Today you are not my wife, and tomorrow you are my wife, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara elaborates: <b>Let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> and <b>let the dilemma be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>Let the dilemma be raised according to Rabbi Eliezer: Is Rabbi Eliezer saying</b> that <b>only there,</b> in the case of the mishna, the divorce is valid <b>because concerning the one whom</b> the husband <b>permits</b> the wife to marry, <b>he permits</b> her <b>to marry him forever, but here,</b> the divorce is <b>not</b> valid as it is limited in time? <b>Or perhaps it is no different</b> from the case in the mishna, and in both cases Rabbi Eliezer holds that the divorce takes effect?
<b>Let the dilemma be raised according to the Rabbis:</b> Perhaps <b>the Rabbis are saying only there</b> that the divorce is invalid <b>because</b> the husband <b>did not separate her from himself entirely,</b> as she is prohibited from marrying a certain man due to his qualification. <b>But here,</b> the divorce takes effect, as <b>once he separates her,</b> even for a limited period of time, <b>he has</b> consequently <b>separated her</b> entirely.
<b>After</b> Rava <b>raised the dilemma he then resolved it</b> on his own:

Daf 84a

<b>It stands to reason, both according to Rabbi Eliezer and according to the Rabbis,</b> that <b>once he separates her, he has separated her</b> entirely. By rendering her entirely permitted for one day he dissolves the bond between them and the divorce takes effect.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:7) that if a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you marry so-and-so, she may not marry</b> that man, <b>but if she marries</b> him the marriage is valid and <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> She is forbidden from marrying whom? <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: She may not marry him,</b> i.e., she may not marry the man mentioned by her husband in the condition, <b>lest</b> people <b>say</b> that these people <b>are giving their wives</b> to each other <b>as a gift. But if she marries another</b> man <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> him.
The Gemara asks: <b>Do we not remove her from him,</b> thereby <b>allowing a married woman to</b> marry <b>anyone, due to</b> a rabbinic <b>decree,</b> lest people say that the husband is giving her as a gift?
