As long as the condition that she would marry a specific man is not fulfilled, she is a married woman by Torah law.
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: She may not marry him,</b> i.e., the man who was specified in the condition, <b>lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>they are giving their wives</b> to each other <b>as a gift. But if she marries him she</b> need <b>not leave</b> him, <b>as we do not remove</b> a woman from her husband <b>due to a decree.</b>
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Naḥman: It may be inferred from your statement that <b>it is</b> specifically <b>to him that she may not get married, but she may marry another</b> man <i>ab initio</i>. <b>But isn’t</b> she <b>required</b> to <b>fulfill the condition</b> by marrying the specified man before marrying someone else?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>it is possible for her to get married today</b> to someone else <b>and get divorced</b> from him <b>tomorrow and</b> then <b>fulfill</b> her <b>condition</b> by marrying the specified man, <b>and you</b> can <b>compare it to that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>over which you disagree with Rav Yehuda. As it was stated</b> with regard to one who says: <b>Sleeping is</b> forbidden to me <b>as if</b> it were <b>an offering [<i>konam</i>] for my eyes today if I will sleep tomorrow, Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>he may not sleep today lest he sleep tomorrow,</b> causing the vow to have been violated today, retroactively.
<b>And Rav Naḥman says: He may sleep today,</b> as there is currently no prohibition, <b>and we are not concerned that perhaps he will sleep tomorrow,</b> as he will be careful not to sleep. This dispute pertains to the general issue of a prohibition that will take effect retroactively if a condition is not fulfilled. Rav Yehuda holds that the prohibition must be observed until the condition is fulfilled, whereas Rav Naḥman maintains that it is not necessary to observe the prohibition, as he assumes that the condition will be fulfilled. Here too, perhaps Rav Naḥman allows the woman to marry another man because she can fulfill the condition after she is divorced from him.
<b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the vow, the fulfillment of the condition <b>is in his</b> capability, <b>as, if he wants</b> to prevent himself from falling asleep <b>he can prick himself with thorns [<i>silevata</i>] and he will not fall asleep. Here, is it in</b> the woman’s power <b>to get divorced?</b> Perhaps her husband will not agree to divorce her and the condition will not be fulfilled.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should be interpreted in the following manner: <b>This</b> woman <b>may marry neither</b> the man who was specified in the condition <b>nor another</b> man. <b>She may not marry him lest</b> people <b>say</b> that these men <b>are giving their wives</b> to each other <b>as a gift,</b> and <b>she may not marry another</b> man <b>because she is required to fulfill</b> the <b>condition.</b>
<b>And if she marries</b> the specified man <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> him, <b>as we do not remove</b> a woman from her husband <b>due to a decree.</b> But if she gets married <b>to another</b> man <b>she must leave</b> him, <b>as she is required to fulfill</b> the <b>condition</b> before marrying another man.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava: This</b> woman <b>may marry neither him nor another</b> man, <b>but if she marries him she</b> need <b>not leave</b> him. But if she gets married <b>to another</b> man <b>she must leave</b> him.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 7:8) that if a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you ascend to the sky,</b> or <b>on the condition that you descend to the depths</b> of the sea, or <b>on the condition that you swallow a four-cubit reed,</b> or <b>on the condition that you bring me a hundred-cubit reed,</b> or <b>on the condition that you cross the Great Sea,</b> i.e., the Mediterranean Sea, <b>by foot,</b> or on any other condition that it is impossible to fulfill, <b>it is not a</b> valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima says:</b> A bill of divorce <b>like this</b> is a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> as the condition is void. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima said</b> the following <b>principle:</b> With regard to <b>any condition that cannot be fulfilled in the end, yet</b> even so the husband <b>stipulated it initially, he is only hyperbolizing.</b> It is assumed that he did not really intend to attach a condition to the divorce, but rather, to cause her distress, <b>and</b> therefore the divorce <b>is valid</b> without her fulfilling the condition.
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rav says: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says:</b> The language of <b>the mishna is also precisely</b> formulated in support of this opinion, <b>as it teaches:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> condition <b>that can be fulfilled in the end and</b> the husband <b>stipulated</b> it <b>initially, his condition stands</b> (<i>Bava Metzia</i> 94a). <b>Consequently,</b> if <b>his condition cannot</b> be fulfilled <b>it is void.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from it</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If a husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you eat pig meat, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Abaye said: It is the same.</b> This is also a condition that cannot be fulfilled, as it is forbidden by Torah law. Therefore, the condition is void. <b>Rava said: It is possible for her to eat</b> it <b>and be flogged</b> for it. Consequently, the condition can be fulfilled, although it is forbidden for her to do so.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>According to Abaye,</b> the <b>principle</b> stated by Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima serves <b>to include</b> a condition to eat <b>pig meat.</b> When a <i>tanna</i> states a general principle, it expands the <i>halakha</i> beyond the specific case mentioned previously. In this case, the stating of the principle serves to apply the <i>halakha</i> to a condition subject to a Torah prohibition, in addition to a physical impossibility. <b>According to Rava,</b> when Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima stated: A bill of divorce <b>like this</b> is a valid bill of divorce, the limiting term of: Like this, serves to emphasize that only when there is a condition that cannot be physically fulfilled is the bill of divorce valid, and serves <b>to exclude</b> a condition to eat <b>pig meat,</b> which cannot be fulfilled due to a Torah prohibition. Therefore, if she does not fulfill this condition the divorce is invalid.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rava’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: If a man says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you engage in sexual intercourse with so-and-so,</b> and <b>the condition is fulfilled, this is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. And if</b> the condition is <b>not</b> fulfilled then <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> If he says to her: <b>On the condition that you do not engage in sexual intercourse with my father or your father,</b> she is permitted to remarry, as <b>we are not concerned that perhaps she engaged in sexual intercourse with them.</b>
<b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>does not teach</b> that the condition is binding when the husband says: <b>On the condition that you engage in sexual intercourse with my father or your father,</b> which is forbidden by Torah law. <b>According to Abaye</b> it <b>works out well,</b> as in his opinion a condition that violates Torah law is void. <b>According to Rava</b> it is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: Granted,</b> with regard to <b>pig meat it is possible for her to eat</b> it <b>and be flogged.</b> Similarly, if the condition is that she engage in sexual intercourse with <b>so-and-so, it is also possible for her to bribe him with money</b> to engage in sexual intercourse with her. <b>But</b> with regard to the case of my <b>father or your father, is it in her</b> power to engage in sexual intercourse with them? <b>Though she can</b> potentially <b>perform a forbidden act</b> in order to fulfill her desire to get married, <b>would</b> my <b>father or your father perform a forbidden act?</b> They certainly would not cooperate. There-fore, this is a condition cannot be fulfilled, and it is considered hyperbole.
Based on this analysis, <b>according to Rava,</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima stated his <b>principle</b> in order <b>to include</b> the condition of <b>my father and your father,</b> as this condition is also considered impossible to fulfill. And the expression: A bill of divorce <b>like this</b> is a valid bill of divorce, serves <b>to exclude</b> the condition of eating <b>pig meat,</b> in which case the divorce is not valid unless she fulfills the condition.

Daf 84b

And <b>according to Abaye</b> this <b>principle</b> was stated <b>to include</b> the case of a condition that she should eat <b>pig meat,</b> and the expression: A bill of divorce <b>like this</b> is a valid bill of divorce, serves <b>to exclude</b> a condition that she should engage in sexual intercourse with <b>so-and-so,</b> in which case the divorce takes effect only once the condition is fulfilled, as it is possible to fulfill this condition in a permitted manner.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from another <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:10): If the husband said to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you eat pig meat; or</b> similarly, <b>if she was a non-priestess,</b> i.e., the daughter of an Israelite, and he stipulated: <b>On the condition that you partake of <i>teruma</i>; or if she was a nazirite</b> and he stipulated: <b>On the condition that you drink wine</b> (see Numbers 6:3); in all of these cases, if <b>the condition is fulfilled it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce, and if not, it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> This <b>works out well according to Rava,</b> who holds that a condition that she should perform a forbidden act is binding; <b>according to Abaye</b> it is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Abaye</b> could have <b>said to you: Do you hold</b> that this ruling <b>is agreed</b> upon <b>by everyone?</b> That is not the case. Rather, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda ben Teima, maintaining that even a condition that cannot be fulfilled is a valid condition.
The Gemara challenges: Regardless of the issue of a condition that cannot be fulfilled, <b>derive</b> that this condition is void from the fact <b>that</b> the husband <b>is stipulating counter to that which is written in the Torah, and</b> there is a principle that with regard to <b>anyone who stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void.</b>
<b>Rav Adda son of Rav Ika said</b> in response: <b>When we say</b> that if one <b>stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah his condition is void,</b> the reference is to a case <b>such as</b> a man who betroths a woman on the condition that he will not be obligated to provide her with <b>her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, as</b> there <b>he is uprooting</b> a matter of Torah law by fulfilling the condition. <b>But here,</b> it is <b>she</b> who <b>is uprooting</b> a matter of Torah law by fulfilling the condition and not him.
<b>Ravina strongly objects to this</b> response: <b>Isn’t she uprooting</b> it <b>only</b> in order <b>to fulfill his condition?</b> It is therefore <b>found that he is uprooting</b> a matter of Torah law by attaching this condition to the divorce.
<b>Rather, Ravina said: When we say</b> that if one <b>stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah,</b> that <b>his condition is void,</b> the reference is to a case <b>such as</b> that of a man who stipulates that he will not be obligated to provide his wife with <b>her food, her clothing, and her conjugal rights, as</b> by attaching this condition <b>he is definitely uprooting</b> a matter of Torah law. <b>But here, is he saying to her</b> that it is <b>not possible for her not to eat? She may not eat and not get divorced.</b> The condition does not counter Torah law in and of itself, as the wife has the choice of whether or not to fulfill it.
§ It is stated in the mishna: <b>What should he do</b> after giving her the bill of divorce and stipulating that she is not permitted to so-and-so? <b>He should take it from her,</b> and hand it to her again, and say to her: You are hereby permitted to marry any man. The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that? <b>Ḥizkiyya said</b> that <b>it is Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a husband gives his wife a bill of divorce without her knowledge, <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says</b> that it does not take effect <b>until he takes it from her, and hands it to her again, and says to her: This is your bill of divorce.</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that it is not necessary for him to hand it to her a second time; rather, it is sufficient for him to tell her that he is giving her a bill of divorce. The mishna is therefore in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, who holds that the husband must hand it to her again.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Your</b> Sage, referring to Rav Kahana, who came from Babylonia to study in Eretz Yisrael, <b>said</b> that <b>it is different here, since</b> the wife has already <b>acquired</b> the bill of divorce with regard <b>to</b> her <b>becoming disqualified</b> from marrying <b>into the priesthood due to it,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that he need not take it back and give it to her again. Since the bill of divorce was already partially effective, it is in the wife’s possession and cannot be used by the husband to divorce her in full unless she gives it back to him and he gives it to her again. Therefore, even Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi agrees that he must give it to her a second time.
§ It is stated in the mishna that if the husband <b>wrote</b> his qualification <b>inside</b> the bill of divorce, it is invalid even if he subsequently erased it. <b>Rav Safra said: We learned</b> in the mishna that the bill is invalid only if <b>he wrote</b> the qualification <b>inside</b> the bill of divorce, not if he stated it orally.
The Gemara asks: It <b>is obvious</b> that this is the case, as <b>we learned</b> in the mishna explicitly that <b>he wrote it inside.</b> The Gemara answers: Rav Safra stated this <b>lest you say</b> that <b>this matter applies</b> only when the qualification was written <b>after the essential</b> part of the bill of divorce, which contains the names of the husband and wife and the date, <b>but before the essential</b> part was written; <b>even</b> if the qualification was stated <b>orally,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>invalid,</b> as it was written with the intention that the wife would not be permitted to marry any man. Rav Safra therefore <b>teaches us</b> that only a written qualification in the bill of divorce renders it invalid, and an oral statement does not render it invalid. Consequently, the husband can hand this bill of divorce to his wife without stating the qualification and it will be valid.
<b>And Rava said: They taught</b> that it is specifically writing the qualification that invalidates the bill of divorce <b>only</b> when the qualification is stated <b>after</b> the writing of <b>the essential</b> part. <b>But</b> if the qualification is stated <b>before the essential</b> part of the bill of divorce is written, <b>even</b> if it is stated <b>orally,</b> the bill of divorce <b>is invalid.</b>
<b>And Rava followed his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Rava said to those who write bills of divorce: Silence</b> the <b>husband until you write the essential</b> part <b>of the bill of divorce,</b> lest he state a condition, thereby rendering the bill of divorce invalid.
<b>The Sages taught: All conditions</b> that are written <b>in a bill of divorce invalidate</b> it, this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say: Any</b> qualification <b>that invalidates</b> the divorce when stated <b>orally</b> by the husband while he hands the bill of divorce to his wife <b>invalidates</b> it <b>when written, and any</b> qualification <b>that does not invalidate</b> it when stated <b>orally does not invalidate</b> it <b>when written.</b> Therefore, issuing a qualification that she is permitted to marry any man <b>except</b> for so-and-so, <b>which invalidates</b> the divorce when stated <b>orally, invalidates</b> it as well <b>when written,</b> whereas attaching a standard <b>condition, which does not invalidate</b> it when stated <b>orally, does not invalidate</b> it <b>when written.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> applies to a case where the condition was written in the bill of divorce <b>before the essential</b> part was written, <b>as Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>we issue a decree</b> that <b>a stipulation</b> invalidates the bill of divorce <b>due to</b> a case of <b>an exception, and the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we do not issue a decree</b> that <b>a stipulation</b> invalidates it <b>due to</b> a case of <b>an exception. But</b> if it was written <b>after the essential</b> part,

Daf 85a

<b>everyone agrees</b> that it <b>is valid. And the mishna, which teaches</b> that if <b>he wrote</b> his qualification in the bill of divorce it is invalid, <b>and we established</b> that it is referring only <b>to</b> a case of <b>an exception, but a condition does not render</b> the bill of divorce <b>invalid,</b> does not contradict this <i>baraita</i>. As <b>if you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where the qualification is written <b>before the essential</b> part of the bill of divorce, <b>and</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. And if you wish, say</b> that it is referring to a case where the qualification is written <b>after the essential</b> part, <b>and everyone,</b> even Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>agrees</b> with regard to its ruling.
<b>And Rava said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis <b>is</b> with regard to a case where the condition is written <b>after the essential</b> part, <b>as Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>we issue a decree</b> rendering the bill of divorce invalid <b>due to</b> a case where the condition is written <b>before the essential</b> part, <b>and the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we do not issue a decree due to</b> a case where it is written <b>before the essential</b> part. <b>But</b> if it is written <b>before the essential</b> part, <b>everyone agrees</b> that it <b>is invalid.</b>
<b>And</b> accordingly, <b>the mishna, which teaches</b> that if <b>he wrote</b> his qualification in the bill of divorce it is invalid, <b>and we established</b> that it is referring only <b>to</b> a case of <b>an exception, but a condition does not render</b> the bill of divorce <b>invalid,</b> does not contradict this <i>baraita</i>. It is referring to a case where he wrote the condition <b>after the essential</b> part, <b>and it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that a condition written after the essential part does not render the bill of divorce invalid.
<b>The father of Rabbi Avin taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rabbi Zeira:</b> If one <b>wrote a conditional bill of divorce, everyone agrees</b> that it <b>is invalid.</b> Rabbi Zeira asked him: <b>Everyone agrees</b> that it <b>is invalid? But don’t they disagree</b> about this?
Rabbi Zeira therefore modified the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with his opinion: <b>Rather, say</b> that <b>everyone agrees</b> that it <b>is valid. And what are the circumstances</b> in which both sides agree that it is valid? It is referring to a case where the condition is written <b>after the essential</b> part of the bill of divorce.
The Gemara counters: <b>Let</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>say</b> an alternative modification of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>It is invalid,</b> omitting the words: Everyone agrees, <b>and</b> this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara answers: <b>The <i>tanna</i> taught him</b> that <b>everyone agrees,</b> which is a conspicuous statement. Although <b>he may</b> conceivably <b>confuse</b> the word <b>valid with invalid, he</b> certainly <b>does not confuse</b> the phrase: <b>It is, with</b> the phrase: <b>Everyone agrees.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Zeira modified the <i>baraita</i> the way he did.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a man says to his wife while handing her a bill of divorce: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man, except to</b> marry <b>my father or to</b> marry <b>your father, to</b> marry <b>my brother or to</b> marry <b>your brother, to</b> marry <b>a slave or to</b> marry <b>a gentile, or to</b> marry <b>anyone</b> to whom <b>she cannot</b> legally become <b>betrothed,</b> the divorce <b>is valid.</b> Since these men cannot betroth her anyway, his qualification is meaningless.
If he says to her: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man, except</b> for when doing so violates the following: The prohibition against <b>a widow</b> being married <b>to a High Priest;</b> the prohibition against <b>a divorcée or a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>]</b> being married <b>to a common priest; a <i>mamzeret</i> or a Gibeonite woman</b> being married <b>to an Israelite</b> man; <b>an Israelite woman</b> being married <b>to a <i>mamzer</i> or to a Gibeonite</b> man; <b>or</b> marrying <b>anyone</b> to whom <b>she can</b> legally become <b>betrothed, even</b> if this betrothal would be <b>a transgression,</b> such as in the aforementioned cases; in all of these cases the divorce <b>is invalid.</b> His statement renders it a partial divorce, as the woman is still not permitted to marry any man who is eligible to betroth her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The stating of <b>the generalization in the first clause</b> of the mishna: Anyone to whom she cannot legally become betrothed, serves <b>to include the rest of those liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> for engaging in sexual intercourse with her, who are not listed explicitly in the mishna. The stating of <b>the generalization in the last clause</b> of the mishna: Anyone to whom she can legally become betrothed, serves <b>to include the rest of those liable by a prohibition</b> for engaging in sexual intercourse with her, <b>such as an Ammonite and a Moabite, a Gibeonite, an Egyptian, and an Edomite</b> (Deuteronomy 23:4, 8–9). Although they are all prohibited from engaging in sexual intercourse with her due to a prohibition or a positive mitzva, she can legally become betrothed to them.
§ <b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> If the husband says that she is permitted to marry any man <b>except for a betrothal to</b> so-and-so, who is <b>a minor boy</b> at that time, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that <b>now,</b> since <b>he is in any event not eligible for betrothal,</b> as a minor boy cannot betroth a woman, the husband’s qualification does not prohibit his wife to anyone, and it is a complete act of severance? <b>Or perhaps,</b> since <b>he will reach</b> eligibility for <b>betrothal,</b> is the husband’s qualification considered as prohibiting her to someone to whom betrothal could apply?
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: You learned</b> the solution to this dilemma in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A minor girl can get divorced</b> from her husband even if she was betrothed to him <b>through her father’s betrothal,</b> i.e., her father betrothed her to her husband (see Deuteronomy 22:16).
<b>Why</b> can she? <b>But don’t we need</b> there to be a broad similarity between the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce and betrothal, as derived from the juxtaposition between the clause: <b>“And she departs,”</b> and the clause: <b>“And becomes”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:2), which serves as the basis for the comparison of the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce and betrothal? Accordingly, since she will not be eligible to receive her own betrothal until she reaches majority, she should not be able to receive her bill of divorce. <b>Rather,</b> evidently, since <b>she will</b> eventually <b>reach</b> the age of eligibility to receive her own <b>betrothal</b> she is considered essentially eligible for betrothal now as well. <b>Here also,</b> since the minor boy, whom the husband prohibited the wife from marrying, <b>will reach</b> the age of eligibility for <b>betrothal,</b> the divorce is invalid.
Rava raised another dilemma: If the husband says that she is permitted to marry any man <b>except for those who will be born</b> in the future, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Should it be reasoned that <b>now,</b> since <b>in any event they are not yet born,</b> the qualification is void, as it pertains to people who do not exist? <b>Or perhaps</b> they are considered forbidden to her as <b>they will be born in the future.</b>
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: You learned</b> the solution to your dilemma in the mishna, which states that if the husband says that she is forbidden <b>to</b> marry <b>a slave or to</b> marry <b>a gentile</b> the divorce is valid; <b>if it is so</b> that future situations are taken into account, <b>a slave and a gentile are also likely to convert.</b> Therefore, the husband is prohibiting her from marrying a man whom she might be able to marry in the future, which should render the divorce invalid. Evidently, only the present situation is taken into consideration.
The Gemara rejects this solution: <b>Those</b> people <b>do not stand</b> before the court ready <b>to convert.</b> It is only a possibility that they will convert, as there is no reason to assume that they will do so. By contrast, <b>these</b> people who will be born <b>stand</b> ready <b>to be born.</b> Therefore, this solution cannot be inferred from the mishna.
Rava raised another dilemma: If he permits her to marry any man <b>except for her sister’s husband, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Should it be reasoned that <b>now,</b> since <b>in any event she is not yet fit for him,</b> as sexual intercourse between them is punishable by <i>karet</i>, the divorce is valid? <b>Or perhaps</b> should it be reasoned that <b>sometimes</b> a woman’s <b>sister dies and she is</b> thereby <b>fit to</b> marry her husband?
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: You learned</b> the solution to your dilemma in the mishna, which states that if the husband says that she is forbidden <b>to</b> marry <b>a slave or to</b> marry <b>a gentile</b> the divorce is valid. And <b>a slave and a gentile are also</b> potentially fit to marry her as they are <b>likely to convert.</b> Evidently, only the current situation is taken into account. The Gemara rejects this; whereas <b>conversion is uncommon, death is common.</b>
Rava raised another dilemma: If he says to her: You are hereby permitted to any man <b>except for your licentiousness,</b> meaning she may get married to any man but she may not engage in sexual intercourse outside of a second marriage, as she is still rendered a married woman in that regard, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case? Is the divorce valid? Should it be reasoned that <b>with regard to marriage he did not leave</b> anything <b>out</b> of the divorce, as she is permitted to marry any man, <b>or perhaps he left out</b> part of the divorce <b>with regard to sexual intercourse?</b>
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: You learned</b> the solution in the mishna: If the husband says while handing her the bill of divorce: You are hereby forbidden <b>to my father or to your father,</b> the divorce is valid. <b>And with regard to what</b> action is this stated? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>with regard to marriage, are my father and your father eligible for marriage?</b> Her betrothal to them would not take effect. <b>Rather, is it not with regard to</b> them engaging in <b>licentiousness</b> with her? <b>And</b> it may be inferred from the mishna that only if he renders her forbidden <b>to my father or to your father is it not</b> considered as if <b>he left out</b> part of the divorce, rendering the divorce valid; but if he renders her forbidden <b>to</b> engage in licentiousness with <b>another</b> man, it is considered as if <b>he left out</b> part of the divorce, and it will not take effect.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna is referring <b>to marriage, where</b> the father <b>transgresses</b> the prohibition <b>and marries</b> her anyway. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to licentiousness cannot be inferred from here.
Rava raised another dilemma: If he says to her that she is permitted to any man <b>except for</b> engaging in <b>intercourse in an atypical manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Should it be reasoned that <b>with regard to typical</b> sexual intercourse <b>he did not leave out</b> part of the divorce, rendering the divorce valid? <b>Or perhaps</b> from the fact that the expression: <b>“Cohabitations of a woman”</b> (Leviticus 20:13), <b>is written</b> in the plural, it is derived that typical and atypical sexual intercourse have the same status, and accordingly this is considered a partial divorce, and it will not take effect.
The Gemara raises a similar dilemma: If he says to her that she is permitted to marry any man: <b>Except</b> for the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the nullification of your vows,</b> i.e., no man who marries her can nullify her vows other than her ex-husband, who retains his power to do so, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Should it be reasoned that <b>with regard to</b> her ability to enter into <b>marriage, he did not leave out</b> anything from his act of severance? <b>Or perhaps</b> is it derived from that which <b>is written: “Her husband may sustain it, or her husband may nullify it”</b> (Numbers 30:14), that a husband’s power to nullify his wife’s vows is an intrinsic component of being married, and therefore this divorce is not a complete severance?
The Gemara raises another dilemma: If he says to her: You are hereby permitted to marry any man <b>except for your</b> partaking of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., if she marries a priest she will not be able to partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Should it be reasoned that <b>with regard to</b> her ability to enter into <b>marriage, he did not leave out</b> anything from his act of severance? <b>Or perhaps</b> is it derived from that which <b>is written: “The purchase of his money,</b> he may eat of it” (Leviticus 22:11), indicating that a priest’s wife partakes of <i>teruma</i> because she is his acquisition, and that if she is prohibited from partaking of <i>teruma</i>, then his acquisition of her is not complete?
The Gemara raises another dilemma: If he says to her: You are hereby permitted to marry any man <b>except for your inheritance,</b> i.e., her future husband will not be considered her husband with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of inheritance, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Should it be reasoned that <b>with regard to</b> her ability to enter into <b>marriage, he did not leave out</b> anything from his act of severance? <b>Or perhaps</b> since it is derived that a husband inherits from his wife, who is considered his next of kin, from that which <b>is written: “To his kinsman</b> that is next to him of his family <b>and he shall possess it”</b> (Numbers 27:11), then if a husband does not become his wife’s beneficiary, is their marriage not complete?
The Gemara raises another dilemma: If he says to her: You are hereby permitted to marry any man <b>except for your</b> ability to enter <b>betrothal by</b> receiving <b>a document,</b> i.e., if another man betroths her by giving her a document of betrothal, the betrothal will not take effect, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that since one <b>can</b> still <b>betroth her with money or with sexual intercourse,</b> the act of severance is complete? <b>Or perhaps</b> is it derived from the juxtaposition between the clause: <b>“And she departs”</b> and the clause: <b>“And becomes”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:2), that the different ways of <b>becoming</b> a wife <b>are compared to each other,</b> so that the inability to perform one of them renders the severance incomplete?
The Gemara comments: These dilemmas <b>shall</b> all <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The basic,</b> essential, element <b>of a bill of divorce is: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man.</b>

Daf 85b

<b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that there is also another essential sentence: <b>And this that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce, and a letter of leave, and a bill of dismissal to go to marry any man that you wish.</b> And <b>the basic</b> element <b>of a bill of manumission</b> for a maidservant is: <b>You are hereby a free woman,</b> or: <b>You are hereby your own.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It is obvious</b> that if one <b>stated</b> in a bill of divorce <b>for his wife: You are hereby a free woman, he has stated nothing,</b> as that is not a statement of divorce. Similarly, if one <b>stated</b> in a bill of manumission <b>for his maidservant: You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man, he has stated nothing,</b> as that is not a statement of manumission.
The Gemara asks: If <b>he stated</b> in a bill of divorce <b>for</b> his <b>wife: You are hereby your own, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is he saying to her:</b> You are <b>entirely</b> your own, meaning that she has full control over her status and may marry another man? <b>Or is he saying to her:</b> You are your own with regard <b>to work,</b> meaning that she may keep the revenue from her work? If so, this is not a statement of divorce.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution <b>that we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The basic</b> element <b>of a bill of manumission is: You are hereby a free woman,</b> or: <b>You are hereby your own. And just as</b> with regard to <b>a slave, whose body is acquired</b> by the master, <b>if</b> the master <b>states</b> in a bill of manumission <b>for</b> the slave: <b>You are hereby your own,</b> the slave <b>acquires his body, all the more so</b> with regard to <b>a wife, whose body is not acquired</b> by her husband, is it <b>not</b> clear that by his writing in a bill of divorce: You are hereby your own, she is completely released from their marriage?
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> If <b>he stated</b> in a bill of manumission <b>for his slave: I have no business with you, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is this a valid statement of manumission?
<b>Rav Ḥanin said to Rav Ashi, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Ḥanin from Meḥoza</b> who said this <b>to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution <b>that we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who sells his slave to a gentile,</b> the slave <b>is emancipated but</b> nevertheless <b>requires a bill of manumission from his first master. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>when</b> the master <b>did not write his document for</b> the slave when he sold him; <b>but</b> if <b>he wrote his document for him, that is</b> the slave’s bill of <b>manumission.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the phrase: <b>His document,</b> referring to? <b>Rav Sheshet says that he writes for him</b> as follows: <b>When you will escape from</b> the gentile to whom I sold you, <b>I have no business with you.</b> Consequently, as soon as he escapes his gentile master in any manner, he is entirely emancipated. It may be derived from here that the statement: I have no business with you, is valid with regard to manumission.
§ It is stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that in addition to the statement: You are hereby permitted to marry any man, there is another essential sentence in the bill of divorce: <b>And this [<i>veden</i>] that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce and a letter [<i>ve’iggeret</i>] of leave.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Rabbis hold</b> that <b>ambiguous intimations are valid intimations.</b> An incomplete statement is sufficient as long as the intention is clear from the context. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>even if he does not write for her</b> explicitly: <b>And this</b> that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce and a letter of leave, the bill of divorce is valid as <b>it is evident that he is divorcing her with this bill of divorce.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>ambiguous intimations are not valid intimations, and</b> therefore <b>the reason</b> that the bill of divorce <b>is</b> valid is <b>that he writes for her: And this</b> that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce and a letter of leave, <b>so it is evident that he is divorcing her with this bill of divorce. But</b> if <b>he does not write for her: And this</b> that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce and a letter of leave, people <b>will say</b> that <b>he is divorcing her orally,</b> and will mistakenly assume that the husband’s statement to her when he hands her the bill of divorce is what causes the divorce to take effect, <b>and</b> that <b>the document is merely evidence</b> of the divorce, rather than the divorce itself.
§ The Gemara relates several rulings concerning the precise terminology to be used in writing a bill of divorce. <b>Abaye said: This person who writes a bill of divorce should not write</b> the word meaning: <b>And this,</b> by spelling it <i>vav</i>, <i>dalet</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>nun</i>, <b>as</b> that can be misread as having the vowel of a <i>ḥirik</i> under the letter <i>dalet</i>, not a <i>tzeire</i>. Read with a <i>ḥirik</i>, it <b>indicates: And</b> there is <b>a law</b> that we should get divorced. <b>Rather,</b> he should make sure to write the word meaning: <b>And this,</b> without a <i>yod</i>, so that it is clear that it should be read with a <i>tzeire</i>.
<b>And he should not write</b> the word meaning: <b>A letter,</b> by spelling it <i>alef</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>reish</i>, <i>tav</i>, <b>as</b> that can be confused with another identically spelled word that <b>indicates a roof. Rather,</b> he should write the word meaning: <b>A letter,</b> without a <i>yod</i>. <b>And he should not write: To go,</b> by spelling it <i>lamed</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>khaf</i>, <b>as</b> that could be read as a conjunction which <b>indicates: For me from this. And he should</b> be sure <b>not to write <i>limḥakh</i>,</b> i.e., he must be careful that the letter <i>heh</i> not look like a <i>ḥet</i>, <b>as that indicates</b> that it is <b>like a joke.</b>
Abaye continues: In the clause: That you shall be permitted to go marry any man that you wish, the words <b><i>ditihevyin</i></b> and <b><i>dititzviyin</i></b> must include <b>three</b> instances of the letter <b><i>yod</i></b> in a row in each word, <b>as</b> with only two instances of the letter <i>yod</i> these words <b>indicate:</b> That <b>they shall be [<i>tehevyan</i>], and:</b> That <b>they wish [<i>titzviyan</i>],</b> referring to other women. <b>And he should extend the <i>vav</i> of <i>teirukhin</i> and the <i>vav</i> of <i>shevukin</i>, as</b> otherwise, the <i>vav</i> may be mistaken for a <i>yod</i>, and those words spelled with a <i>yod</i> <b>indicate divorced [<i>terikhin</i>] and left [<i>shevikin</i>]</b> women. In other words, it will change the meaning from describing the document as one that divorces or sends away to describing the women as divorced and sent away.
<b>And</b> in the clause: And now [<i>ukhedu</i>] I have dismissed and ousted and divorced you, <b>he should extend the <i>vav</i> of <i>khedu</i>, as</b> other-wise, the <i>vav</i> may be mistaken for a <i>yod</i>, and spelled with a <i>yod</i> it <b>indicates: And with nothing [<i>ukhedi</i>]. And</b> in the expression: To go marry [<i>lehitnasseva</i>] <b>he should not write <i>le’itnasseva</i></b> with an <i>alef</i> and a <i>yod</i>, <b>as,</b> if he leaves space between the letters it will <b>indicate: Will not get married [<i>la yitnasseva</i>]. Rather,</b> he should write <b><i>lehitnasseva</i>,</b> with a <i>heh</i> and without a <i>yod</i>, so there will be no room for this error.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before them: Do we need</b> to write: <b>And this</b> that you shall have from me is a scroll of divorce, and a letter of leave, and a bill of dismissal to go to marry any man that you wish, <b>or do we not need</b> to write the clause beginning with the words: <b>And this?</b> Is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda or the Rabbis?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution, <b>as Rava instituted</b> the following wording <b>in bills of divorce:</b> We saw <b>how so-and-so, son of so-and-so, dismissed and divorced so-and-so, his wife, who was his wife from beforehand, from this day and forever. But he did not state</b> the clause beginning with the words: <b>And this.</b>
The Gemara challenges this solution: <b>And according to your reasoning, did</b> Rava <b>state all</b> of the other necessary clauses of a bill of divorce? <b>Rather, we need</b> to write them even though they were not mentioned explicitly in Rava’s formulation. <b>Here too, we need</b> to write the clause beginning with the words: And this, even though it was not mentioned specifically by Rava.
§ The Gemara analyzes the wording instituted by Rava: The expression: <b>From this day,</b> is written <b>to the exclusion of</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yosei, who said: The date</b> written <b>in a document proves</b> when <b>it</b> takes effect, and therefore it is not necessary to write the expression: From this day. Rava added this expression to take the opposite opinion into account.
The expression: <b>And forever,</b>

Daf 86a

was instituted <b>to the exclusion of that which Rava asked Rav Naḥman,</b> with regard to a case <b>where</b> the husband <b>said</b> to his wife while handing her the bill of divorce: <b>Today you are not my wife and tomorrow you are my wife.</b> Does this limitation take effect? Although the conclusion of that inquiry was that once the wife is divorced she is divorced forever, Rava instituted the addition of this expression in the text of the bill of divorce to remove any uncertainty with regard to such a case.
§ It is stated in the mishna: <b>The basic</b> element <b>of a bill of manumission</b> for a maidservant is: <b>You are hereby a free woman,</b> or: <b>You are hereby your own. Rav Yehuda instituted</b> the following formulation <b>in a document of sale for slaves: This slave is justified,</b> i.e., fit <b>for slavery, and he is dismissed and removed from manumission and from accusations and from contests of the king and queen,</b> meaning that he was not sentenced to death by the governmental court. <b>And there is not a sign [<i>reshum</i>] of</b> ownership of another <b>person on him. And he is clean of any blemish and of boils that emerge on him for four [<i>tatzhar</i>]</b> years, whether <b>new or old.</b>
The Gemara asks tangentially: <b>What is the cure for</b> boils? <b>Abaye said:</b> One takes <b>ginger [<i>ginebara</i>], and slag from silver, and sulfur [<i>kavrita</i>], and wine vinegar, and olive oil, and white naphtha [<i>natpik</i>], and spreads it with a goose feather.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Three bills of divorce are invalid</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but if</b> the woman <b>marries</b> another man on the basis of one of these bills of divorce the lineage of <b>the offspring</b> from this marriage <b>is unflawed.</b> In other words, she is not considered to be a married woman who engaged in sexual intercourse with another man, which would impair the lineage of their child.
These three bills are: A bill of divorce that the husband <b>wrote in his handwriting but has no</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on</b> the document at all, a case where <b>there are</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on</b> the document <b>but there is no date</b> written <b>on it,</b> and a case where <b>there is a date</b> written <b>on it, but it contains only one witness. These are</b> the <b>three invalid bills of divorce</b> with regard to which the Sages said: <b>And if she marries,</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even though there are no</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on</b> the document, <b>but he handed it to her in the presence of</b> two <b>witnesses,</b> it <b>is a valid</b> bill of divorce. <b>And</b> on the basis of this bill of divorce the woman <b>can collect</b> the amount written for her in her marriage contract even <b>from liened property, as</b> Rabbi Eliezer maintains that <b>the witnesses sign the bill of divorce only for the betterment of the world.</b> If no witnesses sign a bill of divorce the husband can contest its validity at any time by denying that he wrote it. Nevertheless, the witnesses’ signatures are not an essential part of a bill of divorce.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>But are there no other</b> invalid bills of divorce? <b>But isn’t there an outdated bill of divorce,</b> where the husband and wife were secluded after it was written and before it was handed to her? The Gemara answers that there is a difference between the cases: <b>There,</b> in the case of an outdated bill of divorce, if the woman remarries on the basis of that bill of divorce <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her husband; <b>here, she must leave</b> him.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>here she must leave</b> her husband, even though the lineage of their children is unflawed. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>here she</b> need <b>not leave, what is there to say?</b> Why is an outdated bill of divorce not mentioned in the mishna?
The Gemara answers: There is still a difference between the cases, as <b>there,</b> in the case of an outdated bill of divorce, <b>she may remarry <i>ab initio</i>;</b> while <b>here,</b> it is only <b>after the fact,</b> if she remarried, that she need not leave her second husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there a bare bill of divorce,</b> i.e., one that is missing a signature, which is also invalid? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> if the woman remarries based on this bill of divorce <b>the offspring</b> of her second marriage <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>; here,</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that <b>anyone who deviates from the formula coined by the Sages with regard to bills of divorce</b> renders <b>the offspring a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> Therefore, a bare bill of divorce is completely invalid, and if the woman remarries the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>. <b>But according to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i>, <b>what is there to say?</b> Why is a bare bill of divorce not listed in the mishna?
The Gemara answers that there is still a distinction between the cases: <b>There,</b> if the woman remarries <b>she must leave</b> her husband, even according to the Rabbis who hold that the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i>; <b>here, she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>here she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her husband; <b>but according to the one who says</b> that <b>here she must leave</b> her husband, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: Apparently the mishna <b>is not speaking about</b> a folded and <b>tied</b> bill of divorce, which requires a signature on every fold, but rather, an open bill of divorce. There are only three cases in which this type of a bill of divorce is invalid in a manner that obligates the woman, if she remarries, to leave her second husband, although the lineage of their children would be unflawed.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> a bill of divorce that is invalid <b>due to</b> the need to maintain <b>peaceful</b> relations with <b>the kingdom,</b> as it mentions the year of the divorce according to the age of another kingdom? Why is this not mentioned in the mishna? The Gemara answers: <b>There, she must leave</b> her husband; <b>here, she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her husband.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>here she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her husband. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>she must leave</b> her husband, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>; here,</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to Rabbi Meir; but according to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that in the case of a bill of divorce in which the date is written according to the age of another kingdom, the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i>, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: The one who holds that in the cases in the mishna the woman must leave her husband <b>establishes it in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> according to whom <b>there, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>. Here,</b> the lineage of <b>the offspring is unflawed.</b>
The mishna emphasizes twice that there are three bills of divorce that are invalid. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does <b>the quantity in the first clause</b> serve <b>to exclude? And what</b> does <b>the quantity in the latter clause</b> serve <b>to exclude?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The quantity</b> mentioned <b>in the first clause</b> serves <b>to exclude those</b> invalid bills of divorce <b>that we</b> previously <b>mentioned,</b> which are treated either more or less stringently than the cases in the mishna.
<b>The quantity</b> mentioned <b>in the latter clause</b> serves <b>to exclude that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to an agent <b>who brings a bill of divorce</b> for a certain woman <b>from a country overseas,</b> and <b>gives it to her but does not say to her: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence,</b> and she remarries, her second husband <b>must divorce</b> her, <b>and the offspring</b> of their marriage <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: The offspring</b> of the second marriage <b>is not a <i>mamzer</i>;</b> rather, <b>how should</b> the agent <b>act</b> to rectify the situation? <b>He should take</b> the bill of divorce <b>from her, and give it to her again in the presence of two</b> witnesses <b>and say: It was written in my presence and it was signed in my presence.</b> Since this problem can be corrected, it is not listed in the mishna as one of the invalid bills of divorce.
§ It is stated in the mishna: A bill of divorce that the husband <b>wrote in his handwriting, but has no</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on it</b> at all, is invalid; nevertheless, if the woman remarries, the lineage of the child born from her second husband is unflawed. <b>Rav says: We learned</b> that this is referring to <b>his handwriting.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to which</b> clause of the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring <b>to the first clause,</b> what Rav said <b>is obvious,</b> as the case of <b>his handwriting is</b> explicitly <b>taught</b> in that clause.
<b>And</b> if it is <b>rather</b> referring <b>to the middle clause,</b> i.e., an undated bill of divorce, why does it matter whether it was written in the husband’s handwriting? <b>Aren’t there</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on it? Rather,</b> it must be referring <b>to the latter clause</b> in the mishna, i.e., a bill of divorce that <b>has a date</b> written <b>on it but has only</b> the signature of <b>one witness.</b>

Daf 86b

<b>And</b> Rav is saying that <b>specifically</b> when the bill of divorce is written in <b>his handwriting and</b> has the signature of one <b>witness,</b> the woman’s child from her second husband is of unflawed lineage. <b>But</b> if it is written in <b>a scribe’s handwriting,</b> even if it includes the signature of one <b>witness,</b> the child’s lineage is <b>not</b> unflawed, but rather he is a <i>mamzer</i>, as the bill of divorce is completely invalid.
<b>And Shmuel says: Even</b> where it is written in <b>a scribe’s handwriting and</b> it has the signature of <b>a witness,</b> the lineage of the child is unflawed, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (87b): In the case of a bill of divorce in which <b>the scribe’s handwriting</b> is recognizable <b>and</b> there is one <b>witness</b> signed, it is <b>valid.</b>
<b>And Rav</b> would respond: <b>Is</b> that case <b>comparable? There,</b> in that case, the mishna indicates that the woman <b>may marry <i>ab initio</i>.</b> Therefore, it must be a case where the scribe also signed as a second witness. But <b>here,</b> in the case of this mishna, the bill of divorce is invalid and the woman may not remarry; it is only if she remarried and had a child that his lineage is rendered unflawed <b>after the fact.</b> Therefore, it must be referring to a case where the husband wrote it.
<b>And Shmuel,</b> who holds that both cases are referring to a bill of divorce that was written by a scribe but not signed by the scribe as one of the witnesses, would respond that the contradiction is <b>not difficult. That</b> mishna, where the bill of divorce is rendered valid <i>ab initio</i>, is referring <b>to</b> the handwriting of <b>an expert scribe,</b> who can presumably be relied upon to have written the bill of divorce properly and only according to the husband’s instructions, <b>and this</b> mishna is referring <b>to</b> the handwriting of <b>a scribe who is not expert.</b> Since the bill of divorce was not signed by two witnesses, there is concern that the scribe did not write it properly.
<b>And similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rav: <b>We learned</b> that the mishna is referring to <b>his handwriting. Rabbi Elazar,</b> assuming that Rabbi Yoḥanan was explaining the middle clause, <b>said to him: Aren’t there</b> signatures of <b>witnesses in</b> the bill of divorce? Why is the husband’s handwriting necessary? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> I was referring <b>to the latter clause,</b> in which there is only one witness.
§ With regard to the three invalid bills of divorce mentioned in the mishna, <b>sometimes Rav said</b> that if the woman remarries based on one of these bills of divorce <b>she must leave</b> her second husband, and <b>sometimes Rav said</b> that <b>she</b> need <b>not leave.</b>
<b>How so?</b> How can the contradiction between Rav’s statements be explained? If <b>she</b> already <b>has children</b> from her second husband then <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> him, as, if she is required to leave him there will be slander that their children are <i>mamzerim</i>. But if <b>she does not have children</b> from him, <b>she must leave</b> him.
<b>Mar Zutra bar Toviya raises an objection</b> to Rav’s opinion from a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 30b). With regard to a woman whose husband died childless [<i>yevama</i>] but who is prohibited from marrying her late husband’s brother [<i>yavam</i>] because he is a forbidden relative to her, not only is she herself exempt from levirate marriage, but she causes any rival wives of hers to be exempt as well, even if they are not forbidden relatives to the brother. The mishna lists fifteen examples of such forbidden relatives (<i>Yevamot</i> 2a). <b>And</b> if <b>any of these</b> fifteen women <b>had undergone a betrothal or divorce</b> whose status is <b>uncertain</b> with the deceased brother, <b>those</b> rival wives <b>must perform the ritual through which the <i>yavam</i> frees the <i>yevama</i> of her levirate bonds [<i>ḥalitza</i>] and</b> may <b>not enter into levirate marriage,</b> since they are possibly the rival wives of a forbidden relative.
<b>How</b> could there be <b>a betrothal</b> whose status is <b>uncertain?</b> If <b>he threw her</b> money or a document as <b>betrothal</b> in the public domain, and the item was <b>possibly closer to her,</b> whereby she could acquire the object and become betrothed, and <b>possibly closer to him,</b> preventing her from acquiring it, <b>this is</b> a case of <b>a betrothal</b> whose status is <b>uncertain.</b>
How can there be <b>a divorce</b> whose status is <b>uncertain?</b> It is in the cases of invalid bills of divorce mentioned in the mishna here: A bill of divorce that the husband <b>wrote in his handwriting but has no</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on</b> the document at all, a case where <b>there are</b> signatures of <b>witnesses on</b> the document <b>but there is no date</b> written <b>on it,</b> and a case where <b>there is a date</b> written <b>on it but it contains only one witness.</b> In each of the three cases, <b>this is</b> considered <b>a divorce</b> whose status is <b>uncertain.</b>
<b>And if you say</b> that despite this woman’s problematic divorce <b>she</b> need <b>not leave</b> her second husband, <b>her rival wife</b> from her first marriage might <b>come to enter into levirate marriage</b> after the first husband’s death, assuming that she was already divorced. This would violate the ruling of the mishna in tractate <i>Yevamot</i> that she may not do so, as the status of the divorce is uncertain and therefore it is uncertain whether she is the rival wife of a forbidden relative.
The Gemara answers: <b>She may enter into levirate marriage, and</b> there is <b>no</b> problem <b>with that,</b> as the difficulty with the bill of divorce <b>is</b> merely <b>a concern by rabbinic law.</b> By Torah law it is a complete bill of divorce, and the rival wife is fit for levirate marriage.
Contrary to Rav’s opinion that a woman who remarries based on one of these bills of divorce must leave her second husband unless they have children, <b>Levi says</b> that <b>she</b> is <b>never</b> required to <b>leave</b> him, whether or not they have children. <b>And similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>she</b> is <b>never</b> required to <b>leave</b> him.
<b>And similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan said to the sons of Rabbi Ḥalafta of Huna: Your father said the following</b> two statements that I heard from him: That <b>she</b> is <b>never</b> required to <b>leave</b> him, <b>and</b> that <b>a <i>kartzit</i> in the sheaf does not disqualify water of purification</b> (see Numbers 19:17–19). Even if a <i>kartzit</i> drinks from this water, it may still be sprinkled on a person in order to purify him from ritual impurity imparted by a corpse.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is a <i>kartzit</i>? Abaye said</b> that it is a species of <b>fly [<i>didveta</i>] that is</b> found <b>between the sheaves.</b>
<b>Rav Daniel bar Rav Ketina raises an objection</b> to this ruling from the Mishna (<i>Para</i> 9:3): <b>All birds disqualify water of purification</b> by drinking from it, because some of the water spills from the bird’s beak back into the basin after being disqualified by having been in the bird’s mouth. This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all birds <b>except for the pigeon, because it sucks</b> the water, which prevents it from spilling back. <b>And if it is so</b> that a <i>kartzit</i> does not disqualify water of purification, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that all birds disqualify <b>except for</b> the <b>pigeon and</b> the <b><i>kartzit</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: The matter <b>is not clear-cut, as,</b> while <b>a large</b> <i>kartzit</i> <b>does not disqualify</b> the water, <b>a small one does disqualify</b> it. This ruling is not mentioned in the mishna, as it is not common to all species of <i>kartzit</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>And how</b> small must a <i>kartzit</i> be to disqualify water of purification? <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Ami</b> who said: The size is <b>up to an olive-bulk.</b>
§ It is stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Even if</b> there are no signatures of witnesses on the document, but rather he handed it to her in the presence of two witnesses, it is a valid bill of divorce. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce.</b> But <b>when I said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Shmuel, he said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Elazar <b>with regard to</b> monetary <b>documents as well.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rav hold</b> that <b>with regard to</b> monetary <b>documents</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>not</b> in accordance with Rabbi Elazar? <b>Doesn’t</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>teach</b> in the mishna that on the basis of this bill of divorce a woman <b>can collect</b> the amount written in her marriage contract even <b>from liened property?</b> Apparently, Rabbi Elazar’s ruling has monetary ramifications as well.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Elazar made two statements,</b> i.e., his ruling was both with regard to divorce and with regard to monetary documents. <b>And Rav holds in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>with regard to one</b> issue, i.e., divorce, <b>and disagrees with his</b> opinion <b>with regard to one</b> issue, monetary documents.
<b>And similarly, Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce. And Rabbi Yannai says:</b> This <b>does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Yannai not hold</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar</b> at all, as opposed to the other <i>amora’im</i>? The Gemara answers: Rather, <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Yannai <b>is saying: According to the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Elazar, this bill of divorce <b>does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce.</b>
<b>And similarly, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This <b>does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan does not hold</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar</b> at all. The Gemara answers: Rather, <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>is saying: According to the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Elazar, this <b>does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda sent</b> the following request <b>to Marei bar Mar: Ask Rav Huna</b> whether the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce or</b> whether the <b><i>halakha</i> is not</b> in accordance with his opinion.
<b>Meanwhile,</b> before this request reached him, <b>Rav Huna died. Rabba, son of</b> Rav Huna, <b>said to</b> Marei bar Mar: <b>My father said in the name of Rava like this:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce. And our teachers who are well-versed in matters of <i>halakha</i></b> also <b>said in the name of our teacher</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce, as Rav Ḥama bar Gurya,</b> referred to as our teachers, <b>says</b> that our teacher <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of this statement: <b>And our colleagues who are well versed in matters of <i>halakha</i> and the disciples of our teacher said in the name of our teacher</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce, as Rav Ḥisda,</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna’s colleague, <b>said that Rav Ḥama bar Gurya,</b> his teacher, <b>said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce.</b>
<b>And similarly, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael he said that <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> the <i>amora</i>, <b>says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar with regard to bills of divorce.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a case of <b>two</b> men <b>who sent</b> their wives <b>two identical bills of divorce</b> with an agent, as both their names and their wives’ names are identical, <b>and</b> the two bills of divorce <b>were mixed up,</b> the agent <b>should hand both</b> bills of divorce <b>to this</b> wife <b>and both</b> of them <b>to that</b> wife, so that each wife definitely receives her bill of divorce, although it is unclear which one is hers. <b>Therefore,</b> if <b>one of</b> the bills of divorce <b>was lost</b> before it was given to both women, <b>the other is void,</b> because it is unknown which bill of divorce was meant for which woman.
With regard to <b>five</b> husbands <b>who wrote a general wording in the bill of divorce,</b> i.e., who wrote one common bill of divorce for their wives with a single formula, writing that <b>so-and-so divorces</b> his wife <b>so-and-so, and so-and-so</b> divorces <b>so-and-so, and the witnesses</b> signed <b>below,</b> in this case <b>all</b> of these bills of divorce that were combined into one bill <b>are valid; and</b> the bill <b>must be handed to each and every</b> wife individually, so they will all be divorced by it.
If the scribe <b>was writing</b> a separate <b>formula</b> in the bill of divorce <b>for each and every</b> couple, <b>and the witnesses</b> signed <b>below,</b> the formula <b>with which the witnesses’</b> signatures <b>are read is valid.</b> In other words, the formula directly underneath which they signed is valid, and the others are not valid.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that the two bills of divorce that were mixed up should be handed to both wives? <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> It <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, as had</b> it <b>been</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, since he says</b> that <b>witnesses of the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, handing both bills of divorce to both wives would not enable the divorce of each woman to take effect. This is because the witnesses <b>do not know</b> at the time of the transmission <b>with which one of</b> the bills of divorce <b>she is being divorced.</b>
<b>Abaye said: You</b> can <b>even say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar. Say that</b> although <b>Rabbi Elazar requires the writing</b> of the bill of divorce to be <b>for her sake,</b> i.e., with the specific woman and man for whom it is designated in mind, <b>does he require giving</b> it to her <b>for her sake?</b> Although the transmission of the bill of divorce is what causes it to take effect, it need not be done with the designated woman in mind. Therefore, the divorce here is valid, as the bill of divorce was definitely given to the wife for whom it was intended.
§ It is stated in the mishna: With regard to <b>five</b> husbands <b>who wrote a general wording</b> in a bill of divorce, all of them can divorce their wives with it. But if a separate formula was written for each, only the last one is valid. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances of</b> the case of the <b>general wording,</b> and <b>what are the circumstances of</b> the case of the separate <b>formula</b> that was written for each couple?
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If there is <b>one date</b> and one formula written <b>for all of them,</b> such as: On such-and-such a date so-and-so divorced so-and-so, and so-and-so divorced so-and-so, <b>that is a general wording.</b> If a separate <b>date</b> and formula was written <b>for each and every one</b> of them, <b>that is</b> considered a separate <b>formula.</b>
<b>And Reish Lakish says:</b>

Daf 87a

<b>Even</b> if <b>one date</b> was written <b>for all of them it is still</b> considered a separate <b>formula</b> if the divorce of each couple is mentioned separately. <b>Rather, what are the circumstances of</b> the case of <b>a general wording?</b> It is a case <b>where one wrote: We, so-and-so and so-and-so, have</b> hereby <b>divorced our wives so-and-so and so-and-so.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba objects to this: According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says</b> that when there is <b>one date</b> written <b>for all of them that is a general wording, we should be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps when the witnesses signed</b> the bill of divorce <b>they</b> intended to <b>sign for</b> only <b>the last</b> couple. <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 9:9) that if <b>witnesses are signed on a greeting</b> that was written <b>in a bill of divorce,</b> i.e., after the formulation of the bill of divorce the scribe extended greetings to someone and the witnesses signed underneath, it is <b>invalid,</b> as <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps they signed</b> the <b>greeting</b> and not the bill of divorce?
The Gemara answers: <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to</b> this <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> It <b>was explained to me by Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that if the wording of the greeting is: <b>Ask</b> about the well-being of so-and-so, it is <b>invalid,</b> as perhaps the witnesses intended to witness only the greeting. But if the wording is: <b>And ask</b> about the well-being of so-and-so, with the conjunctive prefix <i>vav</i>, thereby making it appear as a continuation of the previous matter, it is <b>valid,</b> as the witnesses presumably signed the bill of divorce as well. <b>Here too,</b> it should be explained that this is a bill of divorce <b>in which it is written: So-and-so</b> has divorced his wife so-and-so, <b>and so-and-so</b> has divorced so-and-so, <b>and so-and-so</b> has divorced so-and-so, as the conjunctive prefix indicates continuation.
The Gemara raises another challenge: <b>And furthermore, according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says</b> that when there is a separate <b>date</b> written <b>for each</b> couple, <b>that is</b> considered a separate <b>formula, why</b> is it rendered invalid <b>specifically due to</b> it being considered a separate <b>formula? Derive</b> that it is invalid <b>because it is</b> like a bill of divorce that <b>was written during the day and signed at night,</b> which is invalid because it was signed on a different calendar date than it was written. Here too, since a different date was written for each couple, and the witnesses signed only after the last formula, they clearly signed only on that date, and with regard to the previous couples it is therefore an invalid bill of divorce.
<b>Mar Kashisha, son of Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: We say the following</b> explanation of the case <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> It is a case <b>where it is written in</b> the respective formulations: <b>On Sunday, on Sunday.</b> In other words, the date written in each bill of divorce is the same, as they were all written on the same date.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> According <b>to Reish Lakish, who says</b> that if the divorce of each couple is mentioned separately, then even if <b>one date</b> was written <b>for all of them it is still</b> considered a separate <b>formula, and</b> he explains that <b>what are the circumstances of</b> the case of <b>a general wording;</b> a case <b>where the following</b> wording <b>is written in</b> the bill of divorce: <b>We, so-and-so and so-and-so, have</b> hereby <b>divorced our wives so-and-so and so-and-so.</b> Accordingly, <b>two women are found being divorced with one bill of divorce.</b> All of these women are divorced with the same bill of divorce that contains a list of several couples. <b>And the Torah said: “And he writes her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and</b> it is derived from this phrase that he <b>cannot</b> write it both <b>for her and for another</b> woman. Rather, each woman requires a separate bill of divorce.
The Gemara answers: It is valid <b>because he then wrote</b> after the general formulation: <b>So-and-so has divorced so-and-so, and so-and-so has divorced so-and-so.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who writes</b> a document granting <b>all of his property to his two slaves, they</b> both <b>acquire</b> the property <b>and</b> must <b>emancipate each other?</b> Since the slaves are included in the property, by acquiring the property together they each have ownership over half of the other slave. Consequently, they must emancipate each other. Since the <i>halakhot</i> of emancipation of slaves are compared to the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce, it can be proven from here that one bill of divorce can be written for two wives.
The Gemara answers: <b>But didn’t we establish</b> that that <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case where the master wrote <b>two documents,</b> one for each slave, stating that he is giving him all of his property, and he gave them to them simultaneously? Certainly each slave needs his own bill of emancipation.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> and similarly it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish.</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> as follows: With regard to <b>five</b> men <b>who wrote in the bill of divorce: So-and-so</b> hereby <b>divorces so-and-so, and so-and-so</b> divorces <b>so-and-so, and so-and-so</b> divorces <b>so-and-so, and</b> wrote <b>one date for all of them, and the witnesses</b> signed <b>below,</b> in this case <b>all of them are valid; and</b> this document <b>must be handed to each and every one</b> of the women mentioned in it.
Nevertheless, if a separate <b>date</b> is written <b>for each and every one and the witnesses</b> signed <b>below,</b> the bill of divorce <b>with which the witnesses’</b> signatures <b>are read is valid. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: If there is space between them</b> it is <b>invalid,</b> as the witnesses’ signatures appear to be referring only to the last couple. <b>But if</b> there is <b>not</b> a space it is <b>valid, as</b> the <b>date</b> written for each couple <b>does not separate</b> between <b>them.</b> Rather, they are still considered the same bill of divorce with regard to the witnesses’ signatures.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish:</b> With regard to <b>five</b> men <b>who wrote a general wording in the bill of divorce: We, so-and-so and so-and-so, have</b> hereby <b>divorced our wives so-and-so and so-and-so; so-and-so has divorced so-and-so, and so-and-so has divorced so-and-so, and</b> they wrote <b>one date for all of them, and the witnesses</b> signed <b>below,</b> in this case <b>all of them are valid; and it must be handed to each and every</b> woman.
If a separate <b>date</b> was written <b>for each and every one, and</b> there is <b>a space for each and every one, and the witnesses</b> signed <b>below,</b> only <b>the one with which the witnesses’</b> signatures <b>are read is valid;</b> the others are not. <b>Rabbi Meir says: Even if there is no space between them,</b> the upper ones are <b>invalid, as the date separates them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Reish Lakish, why</b> is the <i>baraita</i> referring <b>specifically</b> to a case in which a separate <b>date</b> was written <b>for each and every one? Didn’t he say</b> that if <b>one date</b> was written <b>for all of them it is still</b> considered a separate <b>formula?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This matter</b> applies <b>where he did not merge them at the outset</b> but instead wrote the divorce of each couple separately. <b>But here, he merged them at the outset,</b> writing: So-and-so and so-and-so have hereby divorced their wives so-and-so and so-and-so. Therefore, <b>if</b> the <b>date separates them</b> they <b>are</b> considered to be separate bills of divorce, and <b>if not,</b> then they are <b>not</b> considered separate bills of divorce.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>two bills of divorce that</b> a scribe <b>wrote</b> on the same paper <b>one next to the other, and</b> the signatures of <b>two Hebrew witnesses,</b> i.e., witnesses who signed in Hebrew from right to left, <b>extend from underneath this</b> bill of divorce on the right <b>to underneath that</b> bill of divorce on the left, <b>and</b> the signatures of <b>two Greek witnesses,</b> i.e., who signed in Greek from left to right, <b>extend from underneath that</b> bill of divorce on the left <b>to underneath this</b> bill of divorce on the right, the bill of divorce <b>with which the</b> names of the <b>first</b> two <b>witnesses are read [<i>nikra’in</i>] is valid.</b> The other bill of divorce is invalid, as it is not considered signed by these witnesses.
If <b>one witness</b> signed in <b>Hebrew</b> from right to left, <b>and one witness</b> signed beneath him in <b>Greek</b> from left to right, <b>and</b> underneath that signature <b>one witness</b> signed in <b>Hebrew, and</b> beneath him <b>one witness</b> signed in <b>Greek,</b> with the signatures <b>extending from underneath this</b> bill of divorce <b>to underneath that</b> bill of divorce, <b>both</b> bills of divorce <b>are invalid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It is stated in the first case of the mishna that the bill of divorce under which the names of the first two witnesses appear is valid and the other is not, even though the signatures extend to that bill of divorce as well. The Gemara says: <b>But let this</b> bill of divorce <b>be validated by</b> the name <b>Reuven</b> alone, <b>and</b> let <b>that</b> bill of divorce be validated <b>by</b> the continuation: <b>Son of Ya’akov, witness,</b> which can be considered a separate signature. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a subsequent mishna (87b) that a signature that reads: <b>Son of so-and-so, witness, is valid?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is a case <b>where</b> the words: <b>Reuven, son of, are written on the</b> side of the <b>first</b> bill of divorce, <b>and</b> the words: <b>Ya’akov, witness,</b> are written <b>on the</b> side of the <b>latter</b> bill of divorce, indicating that it is one signature.
