The Gemara says: <b>But let this</b> bill of divorce, on the first, left-hand, side, <b>be validated by</b> the words: <b>Reuven, son of, and let that</b> bill of divorce on the other, right-hand, side <b>be validated by</b> the words: <b>Ya’akov, witness. Didn’t we learn</b> in the same mishna that a signature that reads: <b>So-and-so, witness,</b> without the father’s name, <b>is valid?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is a case <b>where</b> the word <b>witness is not written.</b> The latter side includes only a name, which is not sufficient. <b>And if you wish, say: Actually,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the expression: Ya’akov, <b>witness, is written</b> underneath the second bill of divorce; <b>but</b> it is a case <b>where we know that this signature is not Ya’akov’s.</b> Evidently it is part of the signature of Reuven, son of Ya’akov, and cannot serve as a separate signature for the second bill of divorce.

Daf 87b

The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> Reuven signed both bills of divorce, and <b>he signed</b> the second one <b>with his father’s name?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>One does not leave</b> out <b>his</b> own <b>name and</b> instead <b>sign in the name of his father.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps he made</b> his father’s name <b>a symbol</b> for his own signature? <b>As Rav would draw a fish</b> instead of signing his name, <b>Rabbi Ḥanina</b> would draw <b>a date palm, Rav Ḥisda</b> would write <b>a <i>samekh</i>, Rav Hoshaya</b> would write <b>an <i>ayin</i>,</b> and <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna would draw a sail.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>A person would not be so brazen as to make his father’s name a symbol.</b> Therefore, it is assumed that the word Ya’akov is a continuation of Reuven’s signature on the first bill of divorce, not a separate signature on the second bill of divorce.
The Gemara raises a different question: <b>But let this</b> bill of divorce <b>be validated by</b> the <b>two Hebrew witnesses, and let that</b> bill of divorce <b>be validated by</b> the <b>two Greek witnesses, as we learned</b> in the subsequent mishna that <b>a bill of divorce that was written in Hebrew and its witnesses</b> signed <b>in Greek,</b> or that was written <b>in Greek and its witnesses</b> signed <b>in Hebrew, is valid.</b>
<b>And if you would say that since</b> the signatures of the witnesses of the second bill of divorce <b>are two lines away</b> from the bill of divorce itself, it is <b>not</b> valid, as that is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a document that has a gap between the text and the signatures, <b>but didn’t Ḥizkiyya say</b> that if the gap was <b>filled,</b> even <b>with</b> the signatures of <b>relatives</b> who are disqualified from serving as witnesses, it is <b>valid?</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Ze’eiri</b> in fact <b>teaches</b> that <b>both of</b> the two bills of divorce <b>are valid,</b> not only the one beneath which the names of the first two witnesses appear. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the reasoning of <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna, who does not agree with this ruling? The Gemara answers: He is concerned that <b>perhaps</b> the bottom two witnesses <b>signed in reverse [<i>gundalit</i>].</b> For example, if the top two signatures are in Hebrew, perhaps the witnesses who signed in Greek reversed the word order of their signatures, imitating the Hebrew style, <b>and</b> in actuality <b>all of the</b> witnesses <b>signed one</b> bill of divorce.
§ It is stated in the mishna that if <b>one witness</b> signed in <b>Hebrew and</b> then <b>one witness</b> signed in <b>Greek,</b> and then one more witness signed in Hebrew and one in Greek, both bills of divorce are invalid. The Gemara asks: <b>But let this</b> bill of divorce <b>be validated by one Hebrew witness and one Greek witness, and that</b> bill of divorce be validated <b>by</b> the other pair composed of <b>one Hebrew witness and one Greek witness. Didn’t we learn</b> in the subsequent mishna that a bill of divorce that was signed by <b>one witness</b> in <b>Hebrew and one witness</b> in <b>Greek is valid?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Ze’eiri</b> in fact <b>teaches</b> that <b>both of them are valid.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the reasoning of <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna? The Gemara answers: He is concerned that <b>perhaps they signed in reverse,</b> i.e., perhaps one of the witnesses who signed in Greek reversed the word order of his signature, <b>and</b> in actuality he signed the other bill of divorce. Consequently, <b>three</b> witnesses signed <b>one</b> bill of divorce <b>and</b> only <b>one</b> witness signed the other <b>one.</b> Therefore, they are both rendered invalid.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a scribe <b>left out part of the bill of divorce and wrote it in the second column,</b> i.e., the bill of divorce is written in two columns on one paper, <b>and the</b> signatures of the <b>witnesses are beneath</b> the second column, it is a <b>valid</b> bill of divorce. If the <b>witnesses signed at the top of the column, on the side, or on the back of an ordinary,</b> non-folded <b>bill of divorce,</b> it is <b>invalid.</b>
If the scribe <b>placed the top of this</b> bill of divorce <b>next to the top of that</b> bill of divorce so that both are written in the same column but with the text in opposite directions, <b>and the witnesses</b> signed <b>in the middle,</b> between the bills of divorce, <b>both</b> bills of divorce <b>are invalid.</b> If he placed <b>the end of this</b> bill of divorce <b>next to the end of that</b> bill of divorce, <b>and the witnesses</b> signed <b>in the middle</b> between them, the bill of divorce <b>with which the witnesses’</b> signatures <b>are read,</b> i.e., the bill that is written in the same direction as the signatures, <b>is valid.</b> If he placed <b>the top of this</b> bill of divorce <b>next to the end of that</b> bill of divorce, <b>and the witnesses</b> signed <b>in the middle,</b> the bill of divorce <b>at the end of which the witnesses are read,</b> i.e., the upper bill of divorce, <b>is valid.</b>
With regard to <b>a bill of divorce that was written in Hebrew and its witnesses</b> signed <b>in Greek,</b> or that was written <b>in Greek and its witnesses</b> signed <b>in Hebrew,</b> or in which <b>one witness</b> signed <b>in Hebrew and one witness</b> signed <b>in Greek,</b> or if a bill of divorce has <b>the writing of a scribe,</b> and the scribe identifies his handwriting, <b>and</b> one <b>witness</b> verifies his signature, it is <b>valid</b> as though two witnesses testified to ratify their signatures.
As for the wording of the signature, if a witness signed: <b>So-and-so, witness,</b> without mentioning his father’s name, it is <b>valid.</b> Similarly, if he did not write his name and instead wrote: <b>Son of so-and-so, witness,</b> it is <b>valid.</b> If he wrote: <b>So-and-so, son of so-and-so, but did not write</b> the word <b>witness,</b> it is <b>valid. And this is what the scrupulous people of Jerusalem would do,</b> i.e., they would sign without the word witness. As for the names of the husband and wife, if the scribe <b>wrote his surname [<i>ḥanikhato</i>]</b> or nickname <b>and her surname</b> or nickname, it is <b>valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to a bill of divorce that is written in two columns, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps these were two</b> adjacent <b>bills of divorce,</b> the second one higher up on the page than the first, <b>and the date</b> written at the top <b>of the first</b> bill of divorce <b>and the</b> signatures of the <b>witnesses</b> written at the bottom <b>of the latter</b> bill of divorce <b>happened</b> to be written next to each other, <b>and</b> someone <b>cut out the date of the latter</b> bill of divorce <b>and</b> the signatures of <b>the witnesses of the first</b> so that it appears to be a single bill of divorce written in two columns.
<b>Rav Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> It is a case <b>where there is space</b> on the paper <b>below</b> the first bill of divorce, so it is clear that nothing was cut out. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps he cut out the date of the latter</b> bill of divorce, making it look like a continuation of the first one, which was actually never finished? The Gemara answers: <b>Just as Rabbi Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says</b> that it is a case <b>where there is space below</b> the first bill of divorce,

Daf 88a

<b>so too,</b> it is a case <b>where there is space above</b> the latter one, so it is clearly not a separate bill of divorce that was cut.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> although it is clearly one bill of divorce, <b>perhaps</b> the scribe wrote the first part of the bill of divorce and then the husband <b>changed his mind</b> about divorcing his wife, thereby canceling the bill of divorce, and afterward he changed his mind again <b>and</b> the scribe then <b>wrote</b> the rest of the bill of divorce in the second column, after the first part was already canceled.
The Gemara answers: It is a case <b>where he wrote: You are hereby, on the bottom</b> of the first column, <b>and</b> continued: <b>Permitted</b> to marry any man, <b>at the top</b> of the second column. In this case there is obvious continuity between the columns, and he certainly did not change his mind in the meantime. The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps it happened</b> that he stopped in the middle of the sentence? The Gemara answers: <b>We are not concerned to such a degree;</b> it is highly unlikely that he changed his mind in the middle of a sentence.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where the stretch of the scroll is clear,</b> so it is obvious that it is a complete piece of parchment and that nothing was cut out of it.
§ It is stated in the mishna: If <b>the witnesses signed at the top of the column</b> or on the side, the bill of divorce is invalid. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Is that so? Wouldn’t Rav sign on the side?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of Rav, he would sign <b>with the roof,</b> i.e., the top, <b>of</b> his signature <b>facing the text</b> of the document, so it was clear that he was signing the document.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> this contradicts <b>that which is taught</b> in the mishna: If the scribe <b>placed the top of this</b> bill of divorce <b>next to the top of that</b> bill of divorce, writing both bills of divorce in the same column in opposite directions, <b>and the witnesses</b> signed <b>in the middle</b> between them, <b>both</b> bills of divorce <b>are invalid.</b> According to the above answer, <b>let us see</b> with regard to <b>which</b> one <b>of them</b> the top of the witnesses’ signatures <b>faces the text, and let it be rendered valid.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the mishna, it is a case <b>where</b> the signatures are not parallel to the text. Rather, <b>they are placed like</b> a door <b>bolt,</b> perpendicular to the text, so they are not written in the same direction as either of the bills of divorce.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> consider <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches</b> that if the scribe placed <b>the top of this</b> bill of divorce <b>next to the end of that</b> bill of divorce, <b>and the witnesses</b> signed <b>in the middle,</b> the bill of divorce <b>at the end of which the witnesses are read is valid. And if</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the signatures <b>are placed like a bolt,</b> perpendicular to the text, <b>they are neither read with this</b> bill of divorce, <b>nor are they read with that</b> one.
<b>Rather,</b> a different answer must be offered: <b>Rav would sign</b> only <b>letters</b> and rulings on the side, where the location of his signature is inconsequential. By contrast, bills of divorce and monetary documents must be signed beneath the text.
§ It is stated in the mishna: With regard to <b>a bill of divorce that was written in Hebrew</b> and its witnesses signed in Greek, or that was written in Greek and its witnesses signed in Hebrew, or in which one witness signed in Hebrew and one witness signed in Greek, or if a bill of divorce has <b>the writing of a scribe,</b> and the scribe identifies his handwriting, <b>and</b> one <b>witness</b> verifies his signature, it is <b>valid</b> as though two witnesses testified to ratify their signatures. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says: We learned</b> that the mishna means that <b>the scribe signed</b> the bill of divorce as a witness; his handwriting in the text is not sufficient.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that there is no concern that the scribe signed unlawfully.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain marriage contract that was brought before Rabbi Abbahu, which</b> people <b>recognized</b> and verified <b>its formula,</b> i.e., the scribe’s handwriting, <b>and the signature of one witness.</b> Rabbi Abbahu <b>thought to deem it valid</b> based on the scribe’s handwriting and the witness. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: We learned</b> that the mishna means that <b>the scribe signed</b> the bill of divorce; his handwriting alone is not sufficient.
§ It is stated in the mishna: With regard to the names of the husband and wife, if the scribe <b>wrote his surname</b> or nickname <b>and her surname</b> or nickname, it is <b>valid. The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 8:6): <b>A surname</b> from one’s <b>forefathers</b> is valid <b>with regard to bills of divorce until ten generations</b> after the forefather. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> It is <b>valid</b> for only <b>three generations; from this</b> point <b>forward</b> it is <b>invalid.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rabbi Ḥanina said,</b> that <b>the writing of a surname</b> from one’s <b>forefathers</b> is valid <b>with regard to bills of divorce until three generations</b> after the forefather? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.</b>
<b>Rav Huna said: What is the verse</b> from which this opinion is derived? It is the verse: <b>“When you will beget children, and children’s children, and you will have been long [<i>venoshantem</i>]</b> in the land” (Deuteronomy 4:25). Since the word <i>venoshantem</i> stems from the word <i>yashan</i>, meaning old, it is derived that after one’s grandchildren, or three generations, a matter is considered old and forgotten.
§ The Gemara cites another derivation from this verse. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The first <b>destruction</b> of <b>Eretz Yisrael did not</b> occur <b>until seven</b> dynasties and their <b>courts committed idol worship in it, and they are these: Jeroboam, son of Nevat; and Baasa, son of Ahijah; and Ahab, son of Omri; and Jehu, son of Nimshi; and Pekah, son of Remaliah; and Menahem, son of Gadi; and Hoshea, son of Elah, as it is stated: “She who has given birth to seven languishes; her spirit droops; her sun is gone down while it was yet day, she is ashamed and confounded”</b> (Jeremiah 15:9).
<b>Rabbi Ammi said: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived that it was seven dynasties? <b>“When you will beget children, and children’s children,</b> and you will have been long in the land, and will deal corruptly, and make a graven image, even the form of anything…you will soon utterly perish from off the land” (Deuteronomy 4:25–26). The phrase “when you will beget children and children’s children” is interpreted homiletically as indicating seven generations. This is because the term “you will beget [<i>tolid</i>],” written in the singular form, indicates one generation, and the word “children,” written in the plural form, indicates two generations. Since the word “children” is mentioned three times, seven generations are indicated in total.
<b>Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: It is written with regard to Hoshea ben Elah: “And he did that which was evil in the eyes of the Lord, yet not as the kings of Israel</b> that were before him” (II Kings 17:2). <b>But it is written</b> subsequently: <b>“Against him came up Shalmaneser,</b> king of Assyria” (II Kings 17:3) and exiled the people of Israel. If Hoshea performed less evil than the previous kings of Israel, why was his generation the one that was punished?
Rav <b>said to them: Hoshea came and canceled those guards [<i>pardesei’ot</i>] that Jeroboam placed on the roads in order to prevent</b> the subjects of the kingdom of <b>Israel from ascending to</b> Jerusalem <b>on the pilgrimage Festival, and even so</b> the subjects of the kingdom of <b>Israel did not ascend to</b> Jerusalem <b>on the pilgrimage Festival. The Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> therefore <b>said</b> that for <b>those years that</b> the subjects of the kingdom of <b>Israel did not ascend to</b> Jerusalem <b>on the pilgrimage Festival they will go into captivity.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Mar Ukva said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said,</b> that <b>Mareimar interpreted</b> a verse <b>homiletically</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And so the Lord has watched over the evil, and brought it upon us; for the Lord our God is righteous [<i>tzaddik</i>]”</b> (Daniel 9:14)? How can it be that <b>because the Lord, our God, is righteous, the Lord watched over the evil and brought it upon us?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it must be interpreted as follows: <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, performed charity [<i>tzedaka</i>] with</b> the people of <b>Israel by exiling</b> them in <b>the exile of Zedekiah while the exile of Jeconiah still existed</b> in Babylonia, <b>as it is written with regard to the exile of Jeconiah: “And the craftsmen [<i>ḥarash</i>] and the smiths [<i>masger</i>] a thousand”</b> (II Kings 24:16). The great scholars, referred to in this verse as craftsmen and smiths, of the generation were exiled with Jeconiah, and they were therefore able to give guidance to those who were exiled in the time of Zedekiah when they came to Babylonia.
Why are the great scholars referred to as craftsmen [<i>ḥarash</i>] and smiths [<i>masger</i>]? <b><i>Ḥarash</i>,</b> containing the same letters as <i>ḥeresh</i>, meaning deaf, is an allusion to the fact <b>that when they would introduce</b> a statement of Torah <b>everyone would become like deaf persons,</b> as they would not understand. <b><i>Masger</i>,</b> which stems from the root <i>samekh</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>reish</i>, meaning to close, alludes to the fact that <b>once they would close</b> a certain matter that they did not comprehend, <b>no</b> one <b>would introduce</b> it <b>again,</b> as no one was capable of solving such a problem. <b>And how many</b> scholars were there? There were <b>one thousand.</b>
<b>Ulla says</b> that God performed charity with the people of Israel <b>by advancing</b> their exile <b>by two years</b> relative to the numerical value of the word <b><i>venoshantem</i></b> that appears in the verse. Although the numerical value of the word is 852, God exiled the Jewish people from the land after only 850 years, so that the punishment mentioned subsequently, i.e., utter annihilation, would not be fulfilled either.

Daf 88b

<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: Learn from</b> this numerical value that <b>soon [<i>mehera</i>] for the Master of the World is eight hundred and fifty-two</b> years, as it is stated in the verse in Deuteronomy: “You will soon [<i>maher</i>] utterly perish.” Since the Jewish people dwelled in Eretz Yisrael for almost this amount of time, it is apparently considered soon.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a bill of divorce</b> that the husband <b>was compelled</b> by the court to write and give his wife, if he was compelled <b>by a Jewish</b> court it is <b>valid, but</b> if he was compelled <b>by gentiles</b> it is <b>invalid. But with regard to gentiles they may beat him</b> at the request of the Jewish court <b>and say to him: Do what the Jews are telling you, and it is a valid</b> divorce.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>a bill of divorce</b> that the husband <b>was compelled by a Jewish</b> court to give his wife, if they did so <b>lawfully,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> obligated the husband to divorce his wife, it is <b>valid.</b> This is referring to cases where sexual intercourse is forbidden or specific cases where the Sages instituted that the husband is obligated to divorce his wife. If they did so <b>unlawfully,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>invalid, but</b> it is not considered entirely invalid, as it <b>disqualifies</b> the wife from marrying a priest after her husband’s death.
<b>And</b> in a case where the husband was compelled <b>by gentiles,</b> if he was compelled <b>lawfully,</b> the bill of divorce is <b>invalid, but</b> it also <b>disqualifies</b> the wife from marrying a priest. But if he was compelled <b>unlawfully it does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce,</b> and the wife is not even disqualified from marrying a priest.
The Gemara raises an objection: With regard to the statement that if the husband was compelled by gentiles the divorce is invalid but it also disqualifies the wife from marrying a priest, <b>whichever way you look at it,</b> the statement is difficult. <b>If gentiles are</b> legally <b>capable of compulsion, it should be rendered valid</b> with regard to the woman’s permission to remarry <b>as well. If they are not</b> legally <b>capable of compulsion, it should not disqualify</b> her either.
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya says: By Torah law a bill of divorce</b> that the husband <b>was compelled by gentiles</b> to write and give his wife <b>is valid, and what is the reason</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that it is <b>invalid?</b> It is <b>so that each and every woman will not go and depend on a gentile</b> to compel her husband to divorce her through temptation or bribery, <b>and</b> thereby she will <b>release herself from her husband</b> unlawfully.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that where the husband was compelled by gentiles the bill of divorce is valid by Torah law, why did Shmuel rule that if he was compelled <b>unlawfully it does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce? Let</b> a bill of divorce that the husband was compelled <b>unlawfully</b> by gentiles to give his wife <b>be compared to</b> a case where he was compelled unlawfully by <b>Jews, and disqualify</b> the wife from marrying a priest <b>as well.</b>
<b>Rather, that</b> statement <b>of Rav Mesharshiyya,</b> that by Torah law a bill of divorce is valid even if the husband was compelled by gentiles to write it and give it to his wife, <b>is a mistake.</b> In principle it does not have even the trace of a bill of divorce, even if the husband is required by law to divorce his wife.
<b>And what is the reason</b> that the wife is disqualified from marrying a priest in this case? It is because the case where the husband was compelled <b>lawfully</b> by gentiles <b>can be confused with</b> a case where he was compelled <b>lawfully by Jews.</b> If a bill of divorce that gentiles compelled the husband to write and give to his wife carries no weight, people might think that this is likewise the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case where Jews compelled the husband to do so. Therefore, the Sages issued a decree that even if the husband was compelled by gentiles the wife is disqualified from marrying a priest. By contrast, the case where the husband was compelled <b>unlawfully</b> by gentiles <b>cannot be confused with</b> a case where he was compelled <b>lawfully by Jews,</b> as they are too dissimilar. Therefore, a bill of divorce that gentiles unlawfully compelled the husband to write and give his wife is entirely invalid.
§ <b>Abaye found Rav Yosef sitting</b> in court as the judge <b>and compelling</b> husbands to give their wives <b>bills of divorce. He said to him: But aren’t we ordinary people,</b> not ordained judges? <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Tarfon would say:</b> With regard to <b>any place where you find gentile courts [<i>agoriot</i>], even if their laws are like Jewish laws, you may not attend them, as it is stated: “Now these are the ordinances which you shall set before them”</b> (Exodus 21:1). It is derived from here that one may go to court only <b>before them,</b> i.e., Jewish judges, <b>and not before gentiles. Alternatively,</b> it is derived that one may go to court <b>before them,</b> i.e., ordained judges, <b>and not before ordinary people.</b> Since we are not ordained judges, how can you perform a distinctly judicial act?
Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> We see ourselves as agents of the ordained judges in Eretz Yisrael, and <b>we are performing</b> our task as judges on the basis of <b>their agency, just as is</b> the case <b>with regard to</b> cases of <b>admissions and loans,</b> which we attend to on the same basis.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> why is the <i>halakha</i> that judges living outside Eretz Yisrael do not judge in cases of <b>robbery and</b> personal <b>injury?</b> They should judge in these cases <b>as well.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When we perform</b> our tasks as judges on the basis of <b>their agency,</b> it is <b>with regard to common matters,</b> e.g., cases that pertain to the <i>halakhot</i> of admissions and loans, which arise frequently between people. But <b>with regard to uncommon matters,</b> e.g., cases of robbery or personal injury, <b>we do not perform</b> our tasks as judges on the basis of <b>their agency.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a rumor circulated in the city</b> that an unmarried woman is <b>betrothed, she is</b> considered to be <b>betrothed.</b> Similarly, if a rumor circulated that a married woman is <b>divorced, she is divorced, provided there is no</b> valid alternative <b>explanation [<i>amatla</i>]</b> for the rumor.
<b>What is</b> considered a valid <b>explanation?</b> For example, it is a case where there is a rumor that <b>so-and-so divorced his wife</b> but that the bill of divorce was given to her <b>conditionally.</b> It is therefore possible that the condition was not fulfilled and she is not actually divorced. Similarly, if there is a rumor that a woman was betrothed but that the man <b>threw her betrothal,</b> i.e., the money or document of betrothal, <b>to her,</b> and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it was <b>closer to her</b> and <b>uncertain</b> whether it was <b>closer to him,</b> and therefore the status of their betrothal is likewise uncertain, <b>this is</b> considered a valid <b>explanation.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement that a woman who is rumored to be divorced is divorced, <b>do we render her forbidden to</b> her <b>husband</b> if she is married to a priest? <b>But didn’t Rav Ashi say</b> that <b>we are not concerned about any rumor that</b> circulates <b>after marriage?</b> Accordingly, a woman should not be compelled to leave her husband merely on the basis of a rumor.
The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying:</b> If <b>a rumor circulated in the city</b> that a woman is <b>betrothed, she is betrothed,</b> and she may not marry another man until she receives a bill of divorce from the man to whom she is rumored to be betrothed. If she is rumored to have been <b>betrothed</b> to a certain man <b>and</b> subsequently <b>divorced</b> from him,

Daf 89a

<b>she is</b> considered to be <b>divorced</b> and may remarry. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The <b>rumor</b> came <b>with its receipt.</b> The rumor that she is betrothed is canceled by the rumor that she is divorced.
§ <b>Rava said:</b> If <b>a rumor circulated in the city</b> that a woman <b>engaged in licentious sexual intercourse, we are not concerned</b> that the rumor is true with regard to her eligibility to marry a priest. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is assumed that people <b>saw her</b> engage in <b>merely licentious behavior,</b> in a manner that does not disqualify her from marrying a priest.
This statement is <b>parallel to</b> one side of a dispute among the <b><i>tanna’im</i>:</b> If a woman <b>ate in the marketplace, walked with her neck stretched forward</b> in an arrogant manner <b>in the marketplace,</b> or <b>nursed in the marketplace, with regard to all of</b> these cases <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that <b>she must leave</b> her husband, since all of these behaviors are considered licentious behavior. <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that she must leave him only <b>once the women who spin [<i>mozerot</i>] by the moonlight converse about her</b> having engaged in promiscuous sexual intercourse, as this indicates that the matter is well known and accepted as fact.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri said to him: If so, you have not allowed</b> any <b>daughter of Abraham our forefather to remain with her husband,</b> i.e., all wives will be forced to leave their husbands, as it is common for women to slander their peers. <b>And the Torah said: “Because he has found some unseemly matter in her,</b> and he writes her a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and it says over there: “At the mouth of two witnesses, or at the mouth of three witnesses, a matter shall be established”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:15). <b>Just as there,</b> the word “matter” is referring to <b>a clear matter,</b> as it is established through witnesses, <b>so too here,</b> the unseemly matter that is considered a cause for divorce is also referring to <b>a clear matter</b> that was not established merely through a rumor. Rava’s statement is in accordance with this opinion.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If a rumor circulated that a certain unmarried woman is <b>a non-virgin, one is not concerned about it,</b> and she may marry a High Priest. If a rumor circulated that she is <b>a married woman, one is not concerned about it.</b> If a rumor circulated that she is <b>a betrothed woman, one is not concerned about it.</b> If a rumor circulated that she is betrothed, but <b>not to so-and-so,</b> i.e., the man who betrothed her is not specified, <b>one is not concerned about it.</b> If a rumor circulated that she was betrothed <b>in another city, one is not concerned about it.</b>
If a rumor circulated that she is <b>a daughter born from an incestuous or adulterous relationship [<i>mamzeret</i>], one is not concerned about it.</b> If a rumor circulated that she is <b>a maidservant, one is not concerned about it.</b>
Similarly, if a rumor circulated that <b>so-and-so consecrated his property,</b> or that <b>so-and-so renounced ownership of his property, we are not concerned about these</b> rumors, and his property cannot be taken away by the Temple treasury or another person.
§ <b>Ulla says:</b> The rumor mentioned in the mishna with regard to betrothal is <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> people only <b>heard an echo. Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> there is circumstantial evidence, as <b>there are candles lit and beds made</b> in the woman’s house, as was the custom for brides, <b>and people entering and leaving and saying</b> that <b>so-and-so is becoming betrothed today.</b>
The Gemara asks: If people merely are saying that she is <b>becoming betrothed,</b> what is the reason for concern? <b>Perhaps she was not betrothed</b> in the end. Rather, <b>say</b> that people are saying that <b>so-and-so was betrothed today.</b>
<b>And similarly, Levi taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: The mishna is <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> people only <b>hear an echo. Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where candles are lit and beds are made, and women are spinning by candlelight and rejoicing for her and saying</b> that <b>so-and-so is becoming betrothed today.</b> The Gemara asks: If they are merely saying that she is <b>becoming betrothed,</b> what is the reason for concern? <b>Perhaps she was not betrothed</b> in the end. <b>Rav Pappa said: Say</b> that they are saying that <b>so-and-so was betrothed today.</b>
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The mishna is <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> people only <b>heard an echo. Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where there are candles lit and beds made and people entering and leaving.</b> If <b>they made</b> an explicit <b>statement</b> that the woman was betrothed, <b>this is a rumor</b> that renders her betrothed. If <b>they did not make</b> such <b>a statement, this is</b> the <b>explanation</b> mentioned in the mishna.
The Gemara asks: If <b>they did not make</b> such <b>a statement,</b> why is it considered an explanation? <b>But they did not say anything</b> that requires an explanation. The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yoḥanan did not mean that the people did not say anything, but rather that they did not state unequivocally that the woman is betrothed, <b>to the exclusion of that which Rabba bar Rav Huna said: The explanation mentioned</b> in the mishna negates the rumor <b>even</b> if it circulates at some point <b>from now until ten days</b> after the rumor begins to circulate. Rabbi Yoḥanan therefore <b>teaches us</b> that only if the people <b>did not say</b> unequivocally that she is betrothed <b>is it considered an explanation</b> that negates the rumor. But if <b>they said</b> so unequivocally, any later explanation <b>is not considered an explanation</b> that negates the rumor.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The mishna is <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> people only <b>heard an echo. Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> people <b>say: From where did so-and-so hear</b> that this woman is betrothed? <b>From so-and-so, and so-and-so</b> heard it <b>from so-and-so. And</b> as a result, the judges <b>investigate</b> the rumor <b>continuously,</b> tracing the hearsay <b>until they reach a clear matter,</b> i.e., eyewitnesses.
The Gemara raises an objection: If the court reaches <b>a clear matter it is proper testimony,</b> not a rumor. <b>Rather, when Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda came</b> from Eretz Yisrael he taught that <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The mishna is <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> people only <b>heard an echo. Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> people <b>say: From where did so-and-so hear</b> this? <b>From so-and-so, and so-and-so</b> heard it <b>from so-and-so, and they went overseas,</b> so that the court cannot investigate further.
§ <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Do we suppress a rumor</b> that was not substantiated by the court, <b>or do we not suppress</b> it? <b>He said to him: Since Rav Ḥisda says</b> that a rumor is not treated stringently <b>until</b> the court <b>hears</b> it <b>from valid</b> witnesses, which indicates that rumors are generally treated leniently, <b>learn from it</b> that <b>we suppress a rumor.</b>
Abaye <b>said to him: On the contrary, since Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>even</b> if the court hears it <b>from women it is</b> considered a serious <b>rumor,</b> indicating that rumors are treated stringently, <b>learn from it</b> that <b>we do not suppress a rumor.</b>
Rav Yosef <b>said to him: These</b> opinions correspond to the local custom in two different <b>places. In Sura they suppress a rumor,</b> whereas <b>in Neharde’a they do not suppress a rumor.</b>
The Gemara relates several incidents: <b>A rumor circulated that a certain</b> woman <b>was betrothed to a student</b> of Torah. <b>Rav Ḥama summoned her father</b> and <b>said to him: Tell me</b> exactly <b>how the incident</b> transpired. The father <b>said to him:</b> The student <b>betrothed</b> her <b>conditionally, with the intention that he would not go to</b> the city of <b>Bei Ḥozai, and he</b> subsequently <b>went</b> there, thereby nullifying the betrothal. Rav Ḥama <b>said to him: Since at the time that the rumor existed</b> this <b>explanation did not exist, it is not in your power to create the presumption of an explanation.</b> Therefore, the rumor must be treated stringently.
<b>A rumor circulated that a certain</b> woman <b>was betrothed with a mat of dates [<i>atzifa detoḥela</i>] from the spring of Bei Shifei. Rav Idi bar Avin sent</b> the case to be presented <b>before Abaye,</b> asking him: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in <b>a case like this?</b> Should this rumor be suppressed? Abaye <b>said to him: Even according to the one who said</b> that <b>we do not suppress a rumor, in this</b> case <b>we suppress the rumor.</b> This is because if she marries someone else people will not slander her. Rather, <b>they will say</b> that <b>the Sages investigated her betrothal,</b> i.e., the value of the mat of dates with which she was betrothed, <b>and</b> concluded that <b>it was not worth one <i>peruta</i></b> and therefore the betrothal was invalid.
<b>A rumor circulated that a certain</b> woman <b>was betrothed</b>

Daf 89b

<b>to one of the sons of so-and-so,</b> who had both adult and minor sons. The son to whom she was betrothed was not specified. <b>Rava said: Even according to the one who says</b> that <b>we do not suppress a rumor, in this</b> case <b>we suppress the rumor.</b> People will not slander her. Rather, <b>they will say</b> that <b>the Sages investigated the betrothal and</b> concluded that <b>it was the betrothal of a minor.</b>
<b>A rumor circulated that a certain woman was betrothed to a minor boy who looked like an adult,</b> as his body was developed like an adult. <b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: There was a precedent in which</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that there is no concern that people will think that the woman is betrothed, since the boy <b>did not yet reach the divisions of Reuben,</b> i.e., the competence of adulthood, <b>as it is stated: “Among the divisions of Reuben there were major resolves of heart”</b> (Judges 5:16). Therefore, the betrothal is rendered entirely invalid, and there is no concern of slander.
§ It is stated in the mishna that a rumor is treated seriously only <b>provided there is no explanation. Rabba bar Rav Huna said: The explanation mentioned</b> in the mishna negates the rumor <b>even</b> if it circulates at some point <b>from now,</b> i.e., from the time the rumor circulated, <b>until ten days</b> afterward. <b>Rav Zevid says: Where</b> there is the reasonable possibility of <b>an explanation, we are concerned about</b> the possibility of <b>an explanation</b> even if it is not mentioned explicitly, and the rumor is therefore disregarded.
<b>Rav Pappa raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Zevid</b> from the expression in the mishna: <b>Provided there is no explanation,</b> which indicates that the explanation must be mentioned for it to be regarded. Rav Zevid <b>said to him:</b> The mishna <b>is saying</b> that <b>where</b> there is the reasonable possibility of <b>an explanation</b> the rumor is disregarded, even if it was not mentioned.
<b>Rav Kahana said to Rav Pappa: And you, do you not hold</b> Rav Zevid’s statement to be true? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that if a woman <b>was betrothed</b> after her husband was taken for dead, <b>and then her husband came</b> back, <b>she is permitted to return</b> to him (<i>Yevamot</i> 92a), which would not have been the case if she had been married and not merely betrothed? <b>Isn’t</b> this <b>because we say</b> that the second man <b>betrothed her conditionally,</b> stipulating that if her husband is found to be alive the betrothal is null, even though this explanation did not circulate explicitly?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there because the husband comes and contests</b> the betrothal, which shows clearly that he never divorced her and that her betrothal was mistaken. Therefore, there is no need for an additional explanation.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> in a case where <b>she married</b> the second man, it should <b>also</b> be permitted for her to return to her first husband. Why do the Sages render it prohibited for her to do so? The Gemara answers: In a case where <b>she married</b> him, <b>since she performed a prohibited</b> action, albeit unintentionally, by engaging in sexual intercourse with a man who is not her husband while she was married, <b>the Sages penalized her.</b> By contrast, in a case where <b>she was</b> merely <b>betrothed, since she did not perform a prohibited</b> action, <b>the Sages did not penalize her.</b>
§ <b>Rav Ashi said: Any rumor that was not confirmed in court is not</b> regarded as a significant <b>rumor. And Rav Ashi said:</b> With regard to <b>any rumor that</b> was spread about a woman <b>after</b> her <b>marriage, we are not concerned about it.</b> She need not leave her husband, and he need not divorce her. The Gemara infers that if the rumor circulated <b>after</b> her <b>betrothal we are concerned about it,</b> and she must be divorced from her betrothed. <b>Rav Ḥaviva said: Even</b> if it circulated <b>after</b> her <b>betrothal, we are still not concerned about it.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that <b>we are not concerned about it.</b>
<b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said</b> that a group of students <b>from the study hall of Rav sent</b> the following question <b>to Shmuel</b> after Rav’s death: <b>Teach us, our master:</b> If <b>a rumor circulated about</b> a woman that she is betrothed <b>to a first</b> man, <b>and another</b> man <b>came and betrothed her</b> in a manner of <b>betrothal</b> that is recognized <b>by Torah law,</b> as there is clear testimony of it, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He sent them</b> an answer: <b>She must leave</b> the second man, <b>and you clarify the matter</b> to figure out exactly what happened <b>and inform me.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: <b>And you clarify the matter? If we say that</b> he said this so that <b>if it is discovered that the betrothal of the first</b> man <b>was not a proper betrothal we</b> should <b>suppress the rumor,</b> thereby permitting her to marry the second man, <b>isn’t Neharde’a Shmuel’s locale? And</b> as mentioned above, in Neharde’a <b>they would not suppress a rumor. Rather,</b> he must have instructed them in this manner <b>because if it is discovered that the betrothal of the first</b> man <b>was a proper betrothal, she does not need a bill of divorce from the second</b> man.
<b>And</b> in ruling that she does not need a bill of divorce from the second man, Shmuel <b>is in disagreement with Rav Huna, as Rav Huna says:</b> In the case of <b>a married woman who extended her hand and received</b> money or a document of <b>betrothal from another</b> man, it is considered uncertain whether or not the woman is <b>betrothed</b> to him, and she needs a bill of divorce from him.
Rav Huna’s opinion is based on a principle stated <b>by Rav Hamnuna, as Rav Hamnuna says</b> that <b>a woman who said to her husband: You divorced me, is deemed credible,</b> due to the <b>presumption</b> that <b>a wife is not</b> so <b>brazen</b> to lie in this manner <b>before her husband.</b> Therefore, in the case brought before Shmuel, the fact that the woman received money or a document of betrothal from the second man should be considered sufficient basis for the rumor to be suppressed, since if she were already betrothed she certainly would not have accepted the betrothal from him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> Sage, Shmuel, who disagrees with Rav Huna, relate to this principle? The Gemara answers: He holds that <b>Rav Hamnuna’s</b> principle <b>was stated</b> in reference to a case <b>when</b> the wife says <b>in</b> her husband’s <b>presence</b> that he divorced her, but when she is <b>not in his presence she is certainly brazen</b> enough to lie in this manner. Therefore, in the case brought before Shmuel, the woman may have accepted the betrothal of the other man because it was not in her husband’s presence.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>they did not find a clear matter,</b> i.e., they could not establish with certainty whether she was betrothed to the first man?
<b>Rav Huna says:</b> The <b>first</b> man <b>divorces</b> her <b>and</b> the <b>second</b> man <b>marries</b> her. <b>But</b> for the <b>second</b> man to <b>divorce her and</b> the <b>first</b> man to <b>marry</b> her is <b>not</b> permitted. The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that it is not permitted? It is prohibited lest people <b>come to say</b> that the first man is <b>remarrying his divorcée after</b> her <b>betrothal</b> to another man, as they will mistakenly assume that the first man betrothed her and then divorced her, thereby enabling her to be betrothed to the second man. Therefore, if he marries her after she is divorced from the second man, people will conclude that he is in violation of the Torah prohibition of remarrying one’s divorcée after she was married to another man.
<b>Rav Shinnana, son of Rav Idi, says:</b> For the <b>second</b> man to <b>divorce</b> her <b>and</b> the <b>first</b> man to <b>marry</b> her <b>is also</b> permitted. There is no concern that people will assume that the first man is remarrying his divorcée, as <b>they will say</b> that <b>the Sages investigated the</b> second man’s <b>betrothal and</b> found that <b>it was a mistaken betrothal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>a rumor circulated about her</b> having been betrothed <b>to this</b> man <b>and</b> then another rumor was spread that she became betrothed <b>to that</b> man? <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> In <b>this</b> case <b>too,</b> the <b>first</b> man <b>divorces</b> her <b>and</b> the <b>second</b> man <b>marries</b> her, due to the previously mentioned concern that people will think that he is remarrying his divorcée after she was betrothed to another man. <b>Ameimar says: She is permitted to both</b> the first and the second man. One of them must divorce her while the other may marry her.

Daf 90a

<b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>she is permitted to both of them.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Shammai say: A man may not divorce his wife unless he finds</b> out <b>about her</b> having engaged in <b>a matter of forbidden sexual intercourse [<i>devar erva</i>],</b> i.e., she committed adultery or is suspected of doing so, <b>as it is stated: “Because he has found some unseemly matter [<i>ervat davar</i>] in her,</b> and he writes her a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1).
<b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> He may divorce her <b>even</b> due to a minor issue, e.g., because <b>she burned</b> or over-salted <b>his dish, as it is stated: “Because he has found some unseemly matter in her,”</b> meaning that he found any type of shortcoming in her.
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He may divorce her <b>even</b> if <b>he found another woman</b> who is <b>better looking than her</b> and wishes to marry her, <b>as it is stated</b> in that verse: <b>“And it comes to pass, if she finds no favor in his eyes”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Beit Hillel said to Beit Shammai: But isn’t</b> the word <b>“matter” already stated</b> in the verse, indicating that any disadvantageous matter is a legitimate reason for divorce? <b>Beit Shammai said to them: But isn’t</b> the word <b>“unseemly [<i>ervat</i>]” already stated?</b>
<b>Beit Hillel said to them: If</b> the word <b>“unseemly” had been stated and</b> the word <b>“matter” had not been stated, I would have said</b> that a wife <b>should leave</b> her husband <b>due to forbidden sexual intercourse,</b> but <b>she should not</b> have to <b>leave</b> him <b>due to</b> any other <b>matter. Therefore,</b> the word <b>“matter” is stated. And if</b> the word <b>“matter” had been stated and</b> the word <b>“unseemly” had not been stated, I would have said</b> that if he divorced her merely <b>due to</b> a disadvantageous <b>matter she may marry another</b> man, as the Torah continues: “And she departs out of his house, and goes and becomes another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2). <b>But</b> if she was divorced <b>due to</b> her engaging in <b>forbidden sexual intercourse, she may not marry another</b> man, as she is prohibited from remarrying. <b>Therefore,</b> the word <b>“unseemly” is stated,</b> indicating that even a wife who is divorced due to adultery is permitted to remarry.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what do Beit Shammai do with this</b> word <b>“matter”?</b> How do they interpret it? It seems superfluous, as in their opinion the verse refers specifically to a wife who engaged in forbidden sexual intercourse. The Gemara answers: The word <b>“matter” is stated here,</b> with regard to divorce, <b>and</b> the word <b>“matter” is stated there,</b> with regard to testimony: <b>“At the mouth of two witnesses, or at the mouth of three witnesses, a matter shall be established”</b> (Deuteronomy 19:15). <b>Just as there,</b> it is stated that a matter is established only <b>through two witnesses, so too here,</b> a matter of forbidden sexual intercourse justifies divorce only if it is established <b>through two witnesses.</b>
<b>And Beit Hillel</b> would respond to this analogy in the following manner: <b>Is it written:</b> Because he has found something <b>unseemly in a matter [<i>erva bedavar</i>],</b> indicating that it was established through the testimony of two witnesses that she engaged in adultery? <b>And Beit Shammai</b> would respond to Beit Hillel’s interpretation as follows: <b>Is it written:</b> Because he has found <b>either</b> something <b>unseemly or</b> another <b>matter <i>[o erva o davar</i>],</b> in accordance with Beit Hillel’s understanding?
<b>And Beit Hillel</b> would respond that <b>for this</b> reason the expression <b>“some unseemly matter [<i>ervat davar</i>]” is written, as it indicates that</b> interpretation, i.e., that a husband is not obligated to divorce his wife unless there are two witnesses to her having engaged in forbidden sexual intercourse, <b>and it</b> also <b>indicates this</b> interpretation, i.e., that he may divorce her due to any deficiency, be it adultery or any other shortcoming.
§ It is stated in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He may divorce her <b>even</b> if <b>he found another woman</b> who is better looking than her. <b>With regard to what do they disagree?</b> They disagree <b>with regard to</b> the application of <b>Reish Lakish’s</b> statement, <b>as Reish Lakish said</b> that the term <b><i>ki</i></b> actually <b>has</b> at least <b>four</b> distinct <b>meanings: If, perhaps, rather,</b> and <b>because.</b>
<b>Beit Shammai hold</b> that the verse <b>“And it comes to pass, if she finds no favor in his eyes, because [<i>ki</i>] he has found some unseemly matter in her”</b> means that she did not find favor in his eyes <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>he has found some unseemly matter in her. And Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that the phrase <b>“because [<i>ki</i>] he has found some unseemly matter in her”</b> means: <b>Or if he has found some unseemly matter in her.</b>
§ <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava:</b> According to Beit Hillel, if the husband <b>found about her neither forbidden sexual intercourse nor</b> any other <b>matter,</b> but divorced her anyway, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the divorce valid?
Rava <b>said to him</b> that the answer can be derived <b>from what the Merciful One reveals</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to a rapist: “He may not send her away all his days”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29), indicating that even if he divorces the woman whom he raped and was subsequently commanded to marry, <b>all his days he stands</b> commanded <b>to arise and remarry</b> her as his wife. Evidently, <b>specifically there</b> the husband is obligated to remarry his divorcée, <b>as the Merciful One reveals</b> as much. <b>But here, what he did, he did.</b>
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya said to Rava: If he intends to divorce her and she is living with him and serving him, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rava <b>read</b> the following verse <b>about</b> such a person: <b>“Devise not evil against your neighbor, seeing he dwells securely by you”</b> (Proverbs 3:29).
§ It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Sota</i> 5:9) that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: Just as there are</b> different <b>attitudes with regard to food, so too, there are</b> different <b>attitudes with regard to women.</b> With regard to food, <b>you have a person who,</b> when <b>a fly falls into his cup, he throws out</b> the wine with the fly <b>and does not drink it. And this is</b> comparable to <b>the demeanor of Pappos ben Yehuda</b> with regard to his wife, <b>as he would lock</b> the door <b>before his wife and leave</b> so that she would not see any other man.
<b>And you have a person who,</b> when <b>a fly falls into his cup, he throws out</b> the fly <b>and drinks</b> the wine. <b>And this is</b> comparable to <b>the demeanor of any</b> common <b>man, whose</b> wife <b>speaks with her siblings and relatives, and he lets her</b> do so.
<b>And you have a man who,</b> when <b>a fly falls into</b> his <b>serving bowl, he sucks</b> the fly <b>and eats</b> the food. <b>This is the demeanor of a bad man, who sees his wife going out</b> into the street <b>with her head uncovered, and spinning in the marketplace</b> immodestly,

Daf 90b

<b>and with her garment open from both sides, and bathing with men,</b> and ignores it.
The Gemara asks: <b>Can it enter your mind</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a wife who bathes <b>with men?</b> Even a man of the lowest moral character would not allow his wife to act in this manner. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that she bathes <b>in a place where men</b> often <b>bathe.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: With regard to <b>this</b> kind of wife, <b>it is a mitzva by Torah law to divorce her, as it is stated: “Because he has found some unseemly</b> matter in her, and he writes her a scroll of severance, and gives it in her hand, <b>and he sends her out of his house…And she goes and becomes another [<i>aḥer</i>] man’s wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1–2). <b>The verse called</b> the second husband <i>aḥer</i>, other, <b>to state that this</b> man <b>is not a peer of the first</b> husband. They are morally distinct, as <b>that</b> first husband <b>evicted a wicked woman from his house and this</b> second man <b>introduced a wicked woman into his house.</b>
If <b>the second</b> man <b>merits, he will send her out, as it is stated</b> in the following verse: <b>“And the latter husband hates</b> her…and he sends her out of his house” (Deuteronomy 24:3). <b>And if not, she will bury him, as it is stated</b> in the same verse: <b>“Or if the latter husband dies.”</b> It is <b>appropriate for him to</b> receive the punishment of <b>death, as that</b> first man <b>evicted a wicked woman from his house and this</b> second husband <b>introduced a wicked woman into his house.</b>
§ The prophet Malachi states in rebuke of those who divorce their wives: <b>“For I hate sending away,</b> says the Lord, the God of Israel” (Malachi 2:16). <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The verse means that <b>if you hate</b> your wife, <b>send</b> her away. Do not continue living with a woman whom you hate. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The verse means that <b>one who sends</b> his wife away <b>is hated</b> by God.
<b>And</b> the Gemara explains that <b>they do not disagree. This</b> statement <b>is with regard to a first marriage,</b> i.e., one should tolerate his first wife and not divorce her, and <b>that</b> statement <b>is with regard to a second marriage,</b> in which case the husband should divorce his wife if he hates her.
<b>As Rabbi Elazar says:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who divorces his first wife, even the altar sheds tears over him, as it is stated: “And this further you do: You cover the altar of the Lord with tears, with weeping, and with sighing, insomuch that He does not regard the offering anymore, nor does He receive it with goodwill from your hand. Yet you say: What for? Because the Lord has been witness between you and the wife of your youth, against whom you have dealt treacherously, though she is your companion, and the wife of your covenant”</b> (Malachi 2:13–14). Clearly one should not divorce the wife of his youth, i.e., his first wife, as one who does so is hated by God for divorcing the woman to whom he was bound in companionship and covenant.
